Then again, if I have a lot of time, I won't choose a \"fast food\" spot and instead go to a sit down restaurant. I hope they fix their service and turnaround time.

For such an upscale hotel, I expected better fare, a better menu and better service.
More like a bar menu.
The ambiance was nice,,,but burgers and wrap? Come on!
I had a mediocre caesar salad...nothing special (except the price$$$).
The Aria mall is pristine and upscale---as it should be.

I must confess to feeling utterly unimpressed with our culinary encounter at Strip Steak, Mandalay Bay. Firstly, the duration between placing our order and receiving our cuisine was considerable, despite the eatery not appearing to be particularly crowded. Furthermore, when our meals did arrive, they failed to meet our expectations in terms of temperature, as nothing was served piping hot. 

I opted for the chop, which, unfortunately, proved to be the most lackluster piece of meat I have had the misfortune of consuming. It was utterly devoid of any discernible flavor, leaving much to be desired. My fellow diners, who selected the Filet Mignon, found their dishes to be merely adequate, but neither could finish their steaks in their entirety, as they simply did not possess the quality one would anticipate from a high-end steakhouse. 

The duck fat fries were undoubtedly the highlight of our meal, boasting an unparalleled richness and flavor. However, the truffle mac and cheese was only passable, while the asparagus was enjoyable, albeit slightly chilled. The selection of sweet treats was limited, but the cheesecake, with its ethereal lightness, managed to impress. 

In conclusion, our dining experience at Strip Steak was a utter disappointment, and I would strongly advise potential patrons to exercise caution and explore alternative establishments to satisfy their culinary inclinations.

I must admit to being totally underwhelmed with our dining experience at Strip Steak, Mandalay Bay.

Firstly the time between ordering and receiving our food was lengthy  although the restaurant didn't appear to be very full. When  we did receive our dinner,  nothing was piping hot. 

I had the chop and I think it was probably the blandest piece of meat I have ever eaten.  Totally devoid of any flavor what so ever.  My companions who both ordered the Filet Mignon, found they were  satisfactory but neither completely finished their steaks as they just weren't that good. 
 
The duck fat fries were delicious, truffle mac and cheese was okay.  The asparagus was nice, but the mushrooms were cold.  The selection of desserts was poor although the cheese cake was very light and delicious. 

 As I said a totally underwhelming dining experience.   Frankly I would have been disappointed if I we had eaten this meal at a steakhouse with a mid range price point but this meal cost over $400.00. 
I would recommend skipping Strip Steak if you wish to avoid being disappointed.

I love Flame Broiler. But this one is a bit harder to enjoy. Food was not as good as I usually get. But my biggest beef was the music - it was so loud that it was hard to hear the woman behind the counter as I was ordering. I said the music was really loud. She just smiled at me. Maybe she couldn't hear me? \n\nI may return but won't eat in again.

Our collective decided to convene at this establishment for Sunday brunch, and upon perusing the menu, we discovered that the prices ranged from 7.95 to 10.95 for breakfast or lunch options. A few members of our party opted for the eggs benedict, which surprisingly, was quite palatable. However, the turkey lunch left much to be desired, as the mashed potatoes had an unpleasant, processed taste and the stuffing was excessively salty. Another member of our group ordered eggs, fruit, and a croissant, which was adequate. Unfortunately, the service we received was subpar, and thus, warranted a rating of two stars. Upon entering the premises, the host failed to acknowledge our presence, offering no greeting whatsoever, not even a cursory "bon jour." The waiter, who appeared to be having a miserable day, did not introduce himself and displayed a perpetual scowl throughout our visit. His demeanor was unfriendly and taciturn, leading us to surmise that either he detested his occupation or was attempting to replicate the stereotypical French attitude, albeit unsuccessfully. We strongly suggest that this establishment reevaluate its approach to customer service by implementing a thorough training program for its staff, lest they wish to be perceived as inferior to establishments such as Denny's or Village Inn.

"Underwhelming experience with too many mistakes!" I exclaimed in utter disappointment, as I reflected on my recent birthday dinner at this establishment. "How could they get almost everything wrong?" I pondered. My friend's gluten-free salad arrived with an unsolicited garnish of croutons, my sister's burger was charred beyond recognition, and my grandmother's sandwich, which was explicitly ordered sans jalapenos, was inexplicably adorned with an excessive amount of the pungent peppers. While the beer selection proved satisfactory, the overall dining experience was marred by an unpleasant smoking section on the patio, the pungent odor of which permeated the entire restaurant, leaving an unfortunate lingering impression. In light of these numerous shortcomings, I would recommend venturing elsewhere for a more satisfying culinary adventure; perhaps Four Peaks might provide a superior experience.

So overrated! I had my birthday dinner here and they messed up almost everything. My friend had croutons on her salad despite ordering it gluten-free, my sister's burger was burned to a crisp, they gave my grandma jalapenos on her sandwich which was ordered without them. The beer is good but other than that it's a no. They allow smoking on the patio and the smell gets into the restaurant and it is so gross. Go to Four Peaks instead

The gastronomical experience at this establishment was utterly disappointing, with the pasta dish, specifically the Lasagna, being severely overcooked, resulting in an unpleasant texture and a lack of flavor, further exacerbated by the excessive amount of cheese used, which effectively drowned out any remaining taste, while the pizza, although having an acceptable dough and sauce, suffered from an overabundance of cheese, rendering it unremarkable and lackluster, and the service provided by the elderly server was apathetic and inattentive, adding to the overall unsatisfactory ambiance of the restaurant, which was further marred by the utilization of vinyl tablecloths and gaudy decorations that would not have been out of place in a less affluent neighborhood in New York City, ultimately leading to the conclusion that there is no compelling reason to return to this eatery.

Pasta: over-cooked Lasagna, drenched in Cheese, no Bechamel.
Pizza: dough and sauce okay, way too much cheese, boring

Service: unattentive old man. 
Atmosphere: Vinyl tablecloth, tacky deco, could be in the Bronx

No reason to ever go back.

So my bf and I decided to eat here last week, I ordered the ahi sliders as and app plus I ordered the I love bacon burger, both weren't as good as I wanted it to be. The slider buns they use didn't match the flavor of the fish and ponzu sauce. The burger had no sauce on it so I didn't even want to finish my burgers. My bf ordered the jalapeno burger and he also didn't eat it all.. I'll probably try it again they might of just had a bad day

Spent 5 days in Vegas and this was the highest priced meal bill that I had.  That includes buffets at the Wynn and Studio B at the M Resort. 
We were looking for something without a long wait.  Seated quickly, nice service, 
But my goodness!  Way too expensive for a burger and fries!
Food is all "a la carte".
No, there are better choices out there.

Things I liked: The homemade chips (mmm), the red salsa, the tender chicken pieces in my enchiladas and the service.\n\nThings that just didn't work for me- The green sauce was so blah I couldn't eat it without dousing it in the red to get a little flavor. The beans and rice were disappointing as well. Perhaps it is my lack of familiarity with New Mexican cuisine, but I was not impressed.

"The gado gado sauce exhibited exceptional quality, however, the chicken suffered from an excessive frying process, resulting in a deleterious texture. Furthermore, the sauce accompanying the mixed vegetables presented an unfortunate dearth of subtlety in its viscosity, rendering it excessively thick, inordinately salty, and suspectible to an abundance of monosodium glutamate."

The service here was terrible, probably the worst for me this visit.  The food is overpriced and the seasoning on the cheese curds was not fitting for the food item, over powering.  The one thing going for this place is the amount of TVs with sports on it, just a shame it's right next to the sports book with all the same TVs on.

"Uncertainty permeates my thoughts regarding the culinary offerings at other establishments within the valley, yet the evening repast we partook at the North Scottsdale venue that superseded Mark Gerding's Thai Pan left much to be desired. In essence, the proprietors must abandon their strategy to incorporate a sushi bar (at a Thai eatery? Recall that Malees' attempt proved futile as well) and instead concentrate on enhancing the flavors and textures within their Thai creations. It requires more than a liberal sprinkling of red chili pepper flakes to generate heat in a dish; furthermore, discerning palates can distinguish between the contrasting textures of canned and fresh pineapple. Although the peanut sauce was delectable, and my spouse managed to salvage the red curry by augmenting it with an array of piquant condiments presented upon request, the remaining three dishes we sampled fell short of expectations. I am still endeavoring to comprehend the rationale behind the reviewer's assertion that 'This establishment refrains from catering to "dumbed-down" American palates. This is genuine Thai cuisine, characterized by that inimitable fusion of spices and flavorings.' Such a statement warrants a thorough examination of the critic's taste buds by a medical professional! For the time being, my family and I shall continue to satisfy our Thai cravings with Swaddee and Sala Thai."

Not sure about the other valley locations but tonight's meal at the N. Scottsdale location that replaced Mark Gerding's Thai Pan was a disappointment. 

In a nutshell, the owners need to scrap the plan to add a sushi bar (at a Thai restaurant?  Remember, it didn't work for Malees either) and focus on building the flavors and textures in their Thai dishes.  Creating heat in a dish takes more than adding red chili pepper flakes, and yes most can tell the difference in the texture of canned vs. fresh pinneapple. The peanut sauce was very tasty and the red curry was OK after my husband doctored it up with a tray of hot sauces that were brought out when he asked for them but other than that the 3 other dishes we ordered were mediocre at best.

I'm still trying to DIGEST the reviewer who actually wrote that "This place doesn't cater to "dumbed down" American palettes. This is authentic Thai food with that indescribable combination of spices and flavorings."  Dude needs to go to the doctor and get his tongue examined! 

For now, when my family's need a Thai fix we'll stick with Swaddee and Sala Thai.

"What in the world? Why do individuals assert that the beverages are potent? We consumed shots, indeed SHOTS of vodka, and they were diluted, and overpriced, I must add. I have undoubtedly experienced superior quality. 

Furthermore, the promoter who extended an invitation for us to visit the club proclaimed that there would be an open bar. Fabrications! I do not appreciate individuals who deceive or their establishments that operate during the evening hours. 

Oh, and refrain from anticipating that the lounge area will play music by The Beatles. The demographic present within this location is diverse, encompassing individuals ranging from their twenties to their thirties, as well as those aged fifty and beyond, as evidenced by their appearance and choice of clothing. It appears that the majority of patrons arrive at this venue subsequent to attending a performance by Cirque du Soleil, as individuals stationed outside the show distribute complimentary entrance passes. 

Lastly, the restrooms in this establishment share a communal sink that is activated by foot pedals. Are we situated within a sports arena?"

What the hell? Why do people say the drinks are strong? We got shots, yes SHOTS of vodka and they were watered-down (plus overpriced). I've definitely had better.

Plus, the promoter who wanted us to come to the club said there was an open bar. Lies! I don't like people who lie! Or their nightclubs

Oh, and don't expect the lounge to play Beatles music. The demographic here is all over the place - 20-30yo's plus 50+ (based upon defining characteristics such as hair color and attire). I think most people come here after the Cirque show, as there are people standing outside the show passing out free entrance passes.

Bathrooms also use a shared sink that's activated with your foot. Are we at a baseball stadium?

Poorly stocked and ghetto. There isn't really much to say other than watch your back. They are always poorly stocked and the store is a mess, then you need an employee for assistance just forget it. Drive the extra 10 minutes for a better Walmart. The only reason I shop here is because I get lazy and don't want to drive further.

I brought my wife here for a special meal.  I mean, after all, the reviews were very kind and so I figured it would be a nice place to come. They sat us right away and I was expecting a nice Italian dinner.  The waitress was very nice, however, the food lacked completely.  My wife and I both ordered fettuccine alfredo, and I'm sorry to report that there was absolutely no taste in the food.  There was no garlic, no flavors that you would expect in a (expensive) Italian meal.  When the waitress asked how everything was, we were very honest.  I explained that there was no flavor in the food, to which she apologized.  She brought terimisu (sp?) out complementary at the end, but again, even that lacked flavor.  I hate to say it, but Olive Garden has more flavor, and we despise going there!  This is my suggestion - go to the grocery store, buy your own ingredients, buy a bottle of wine, and have a stay at home date with your partner.  Not only will it be cheaper, but the flavors you can create yourself will beat this restaurant any day.

"An exceptional dining experience, characterized by an impressive array of delectable culinary offerings and a welcoming ambiance, is unfortunately marred by exorbitant pricing for both edibles and potables; however, for individuals who prefer their Mexican cuisine to be relatively unassertive in terms of spiciness, this establishment may still prove to be a suitable choice."

"Enormous frustration! 

A deliberation ensued between the Weekend Champagne Brunch at Bellagio and The Wynn, culminating in our settling upon The Wynn, owing to disparaging remarks from other patrons alluding to the Bellagio's dining area resembling a cafeteria, while The Wynn boasted an atmosphere of superior quality. 

Alas, the cuisine proved to be subpar, with cold appetizers, inadequately prepared seafood, and an overcooked prime rib, save for the shrimp (16-20 count), which merited some acclaim. Lamentably, the sole redeeming feature of this buffet was its exorbitant cost: $50 per person, inclusive of tax and gratuity. A regrettable expenditure, indeed!"

Huge disappointment!

We were debating between the Weekend Champagne Brunch at Bellagio and The Wynn. We eventually decided on The Wynn due to other reviews saying the Bellagio looked like a cafeteria and the atmosphere was much better at The Wynn.

The food was mediocre at best. Cold entrees, dry fish, overcooked prime rib, watery crab legs. The only highlight was the shrimp (16-20 count). Other than that the only memorable thing about this buffet was the price: $50pp with tax and tip. NOT WORTH IT!

We made it back here to give them another try. While the food wasn't terrible it wasn't amazing either. I stand by my original review. I had to add salt and pepper to my steak because it lacked flavor. Also this piece of prime rib was mostly fat. I cook steaks at home and know all about marbeling and how it gives flavor but there needs to be an even balance between the fat and meat otherwise you just feel ripped off. I still feel going to Outback Steakhouse will give you better tasting steaks with lower prices. The location on Chandler Blvd had never disappointed. Sorry Firebirds you're just not for us.

Drove from union county for fried chicken and onion rings.  They have removed onion rings from the menu!!  Why?  They were amazing.  Fried chicken was cooked in old oil, and I do mean OLD.  They should utilize a filter agent or change oil more often.  Have been a patron for years, this will not encourage my continued patronage.

We here for their lunch buffet, very disappointing. It got a scummy dirty feeling and the service sucked. I was hoping that the food would be its saving grace but no. Dry, to greasy, and just horrible. Too many better choices to ever go here.

"It was an utterly unimpressive production, devoid of any semblance of artistic merit, with a lead performer who lacked any discernible aptitude in either thespian or choreographic disciplines, her sole attribute being a physical appearance that could be described as aesthetically pleasing, yet this was hardly sufficient to compensate for her deficiency in verbal communication skills, which rendered her role somewhat superfluous; meanwhile, the backing vocalists and dancers demonstrated considerable proficiency in their respective crafts, but their efforts were largely overshadowed by the vacuity of the leading lady's performance, resulting in a mere four minutes of mild amusement for me, followed by an arduous struggle to remain conscious throughout the remainder of the lackluster presentation, leading me to conclude that there are undoubtedly superior spectacles available in Las Vegas that would be more worthy of one's financial investment."

What a lame show! Holly has no talent (no acting, no dancing) other than a beautiful body and she doesn't have to say much so that's almost a bonus. The supporting singers and dancers did a great job and would have been better off without her. I got about 4 minutes of laughs out of the show but had to fight falling asleep for the rest of it.\n\nThere must be better shows in Las Vegas to spend your money on!
How could a seafood restaurant this mediocre can event survive?  The Sancerre 2010  would have been the saving grace if they actually made it (not).

"Negative, Samba at The Mirage was an utter letdown.  Moreover, I should have been cognizant of the fact based on the plethora of unfavorable reviews posted herein.  It would be advisable to patronize an alternative Brazilian Steakhouse within the vicinity, despite the possibility of higher prices.  At this establishment, the servers made a concerted effort to satiate us with copious portions of poultry, arid sausages, and even garlic bread, all of which were proffered on skewers prior to the presentation of the sirloin and lamb.  Subsequently, the server excised two minuscule pieces of beef from the roast.  My thoughts were, 'Aha! I shall receive additional beef subsequently.'  Unfortunately, that was not the case, as upon completion of their numerous rounds, they ceased their visits altogether.  Although, upon my request for further sirloin, the staff accommodated my desire with a modicum of extra meat.  The plantains, rice, and beans were of superior quality.  The confection (creme brÃ»lÃ©e) was unfortunate - its taste was reminiscent of having been stored in a refrigerated state for an extended period of time."

My significant other and I opted to procure takeout from this establishment this evening, having previously visited the restaurant on one occasion and recalling that the culinary offerings were satisfactory.
Upon entering the eatery, we decided to sample the bruschetta, which, while adequate, did not particularly impress. For our primary course, my companion selected the blackened chicken pasta, a dish that I also partook of and found to bear a striking resemblance in flavor to a certain chef boyardie product that I consumed during my childhood years. As for my own selection, I chose the four cheese pizza, which, while not the most unpalatable pie I have ever had the misfortune of consuming, was certainly not the most delectable either. The sauce was applied sparingly and the cheese possessed an unmistakable synthetic quality.
In conclusion, our dining experience at this venue was not particularly remarkable and did not warrant excessive praise or commendation.

My boyfriend and I got take out from here tonight. We've been to the restaurant once and I remembered thinking it was good. 

Tonight we got the bruschetta which was fine. It wasn't amazing. For our entree he got the blackened chicken pasta, which I tried. It tasted like this chef boyardie thing I used to eat when I was a kid. I got the four cheese pizza. Not the worst pizza I've ever had, however definitely not the best. There was barely any sauce and the cheese tasted plasticy. 

Nothing to brag about.

My friends and I strolled into this restaurant because the patio seemed to be the only happening spot in the entire village.  There was a man playing live music inside which could be heard outside, it was the perfect setting for a relaxing evening. 

I ordered a carne asada burrito.  My carne asada was a generous portion served with a side of beans and rice.  The carne seemed more like ground beef and the taste was a little bland.  My boyfriend ordered the chimichanga and was also "just so" with his choice.  The general consensus from everyone around the table was that the food was not horrible but definitely not something to write home about.  From the 6 dishes we ordered, it seems as if the chicken fajitas were the best choice.

The margaritas were watered down and the other alcoholic drinks weren't very strong, especially for the price that was paid.  Definitely don't go in expecting to get your buzz on, unless of course you order straight shots, then maybe you can be on a good one.  

Our waiter Omar was really nice, he gets 5 stars if I could just rate on staff alone.  But this is for overall experience.

Next time I am in town, I will probably skip this place and will try something else out, or maybe I would stop in for a shot of tequila, but otherwise, I'd skip the food!

The pizza here is way undercooked. It seems to be a theme in Pittsburgh in general to not cook the pie long enough for it to crisp up and the cheese to get golden. The sauce was pretty generic and tasted like cheap stuff from a jar. The price was fair at about $2 a slice. The workers at the counter were friendly. However, the pizza itself is just doughy/rubbery and pretty bland.

Decent place, friendly staff, but poor wine list.  I asked the staff about the list and was told the owners only want to carry wines that nobody else does.  My guess is that they want to carry wines that you are not familiar with so you don't know how badly you are getting ripped off.  I had a $10 glass of a $11 bottle of wine (retail).  It was ok, and I expect high prices at a bar but I at least want a decent glass.

The only thing I enjoyed was sitting outside and people watching. 

My husband and I came for dessert and drinks and it definitely wasn't worth what we paid (like many places on the strip). 

The martinis were tasty, but not $16 tasty...worth about $10 in my book. I had high expectations for the desserts (it's called the Sugar Factory after all...) and they fell short. I feel like I could have made my fruit tart at home with a flakier, less "hope this fork doesn't bend when I cut this" crust. My husband's chocolate cake thing had beautiful presentation but was way too rich. I get that that was the point, but it was more ganache-like than I would have liked. 

Probably wont go here again, nor would I recommend to friends.

"Well, I must admit that I had been fixated on this establishment for quite some time in the past. However, after a hiatus of approximately a month, I returned to find that numerous alterations had taken place. The menu had undergone significant changes, with several of my preferred dishes conspicuously absent. Furthermore, the array of options appeared to have diminished substantially. The most disheartening aspect of my visit, however, was the absence of the all-you-can-drink draft beer option, which had previously been available as an add-on for the all-you-can-eat menu. It is rather evident that the primary motivation for our frequent visits was the opportunity to indulge in unlimited draft beer at a relatively reasonable price, as opposed to paying an exorbitant fee for a single beer. Unfortunately, this feature is no longer available, and I fear that it may deter me from visiting this location as frequently in the future. There are numerous alternative sushi restaurants in the vicinity that offer comparable or superior quality food and beverages at more affordable prices. While they may be somewhat further away from my residence, the appeal of this particular establishment has undoubtedly diminished."

Well, I USED to be obsessed with this place. I didn't come in for about a month and on my recent visit, everything was different. The menu changed and they took off a lot of my favorite rolls. Didn't seem like there were as many options as before. 

The saddest part of my visit was that they no longer have the all you can drink draft beer as an add on for all you can eat.  To be honest that's one of the main reasons we would all come here, because who wants to pay $7 for ONE beer when you can pay $4.99 for all you can drink draft Sapporo?! Nobody, that's who! 

Needless to say, I probably won't be frequenting this location anymore. There's plenty of other good sushi restaurants with cheaper AYCE and alcohol specials. Yes they're farther from my house but this place has lost its luster. If it was still the awesome Sushi Bomb I knew and loved, we would still all be going there!

I am a big fish taco fan, and to my disappointment this place did not live up to the hype. Food was just average. Margaritas are just alright. The ingredients seemed cheap. Perhaps their fame comes from being the only Mexican restaurant in NoDa, I wouldn't dare to say it is because of their food. I had the blackened mahi mahi signature tacos and  \"meh\" is all I have to say. Best fish tacos? Seriously?? Only if you have low fish tacos standards.

Be careful, all sales are final and the owner won't allow even a store credit for return of brand new merchandise.  Unfortunate, otherwise a lovely store with nice salespeople and a really good selection of merchandise.

"This establishment represents one of my initial experiences consuming Indian cuisine, and, to be precise, it may have been the premier encounter. However, I ponder whether my lack of familiarity with the culinary genre at that time precludes me from rendering a semi-competent assessment. Notwithstanding, I have had the privilege of indulging in copious amounts of Indian fare subsequent to this particular visit, and, unfortunately, this restaurant failed to meet expectations. The flavors were insipid, the presentation appeared haphazard, and the overall quality seemed uninspired. Although Indian cuisine is frequently misconstrued as a hodgepodge of flavors, I maintain that this eatery capitalizes on serving subpar Indian dishes. Consequently, I do not endorse it."

One of the first Indian restaurants I have ever eaten at. Actually I think it might of been the first. I don't know if that disqualifies me from being a half decent critic. But I have eaten tonnes of Indian food since, and this place just didn't cut it. The food was bland, uninspired, and presented in a sloppy fashion. Granted it is Indian food, but I believe that Indian unfairly gets a bad rap for being mishmash food. I think this place gets away with serving sub par Indian food, I do not recommend it.

"The culinary offerings were satisfactory, however, our grill operator appeared somewhat novice, despite his amiable demeanor. Our server was pleasant, yet her performance was subpar, particularly regarding the replenishment of our beverages, the retrieval of our bill, and the forgetfulness regarding my spouse's card, which necessitated a subsequent visit to recover it. Moreover, during the preparation of our meals, she accidentally dropped a utensil in the condiment, causing a splashing effect that stained my husband's attire. 

Accompanying us were our two progeny, who relished the fare, but subsequently succumbed to severe gastrointestinal discomfort, with my daughter requiring a day of absence from her academic institution. This resulted in the squandering of our $20 per plate investment, which constituted a considerable waste. 

Furthermore, the sanitary facilities were utterly deplorable. Both the masculine and feminine restrooms were reprehensible, to the extent that I would have preferred utilizing a portable toilet facility instead. I am loath to elaborate further on their shortcomings. 

Our recent dining experience was our second at this establishment, with the initial visit being relatively uneventful. Unfortunately, the unpleasant events of our most recent excursion have left my family and me feeling apprehensive about future visits to this particular venue."

"It is my conviction that this particular recreational aquatic facility, when juxtaposed with other prominent venues such as Encore Beach, Wet Republic, and Marquee, falls short in certain aspects. Specifically, I found the venue to be overcrowded, which necessitates a larger pool to accommodate the volume of patrons. Additionally, I noted a dearth of shaded areas, umbrellas, and alternative spaces for attendees seeking respite from the primary gathering area. Furthermore, there was only a single bar available, which led to an excessive wait time for beverages. It is worth mentioning that during my visit on Memorial Day weekend, the cost of cabanas and daybeds was exorbitant, and the prices of lockers, water, and alcoholic beverages were also considerable. Notwithstanding my reservations regarding the venue, I must acknowledge that the clientele was engaging, and the establishment has demonstrated a commitment to hosting accomplished disc jockeys. To ensure entry, I recommend arriving promptly."

Meh...compared to Encore Beach, Wet Republic, or Marquee, this venue is lacking.  It was too packed and needs a bigger pool if they are going to admit that many people.  Not enough shady spots/umbrellas/trees or different little areas to get away from the main area if you need to.  Only one bar, and it took forever.  Went Memorial Day opening weekend and cabanas or daybeds were absolutely ridiculous in terms of cost (and not full).  And as with most things Vegas, everything was pretty ridiculous in terms of cost.  Lockers were $40 bucks for the day, waters were $10, big sports bottles of booze were $40.\n\nEven though I didn't like the venue itself, the crowd was fun and they bring in some pretty good DJs.  Make sure you get there on the early side so you can get in.

I love Jimmy Buffett but cant say I love the Margaritaville Cafe.  The food is ok but honestly not worth the price or the stupid long wait.   

Positives:
It serves food.
Fun decorations downstairs and upstairs.
Connects to the store that sells all sorts of Margaritaville stuff.

Negatives:
Stupid crazy lines.
Food is freakin expensive and isnt that good - very dumbed down for the masses.
The margaritas kinda suck - just seem really processed.

Honestly I wouldn't go again but friends always want to give it a try.

Hmmmm.... Went here on a Wednesday afternoon. The bakery seemed very friendly. I wanted to try some macarons because I've never tried them before. Please don't laugh, but I initially thought macarons was a cake sandwich with a consistency of a small little cake with icing in the middle. So I got the peach, vanilla almond, vanilla, raspberry, and the blue one( I forgot the name). I didn't like any of them. So as I bit down, they were kind of crunchy and soft but just too darn sweet. This kind of reminded me of a cookie. Some people may like them, but they just didn't agree with my taste buds. I will go here again but try something else!!!

Ate there with the wife last night. Everything tasted to us like it was straight out of a can and came to the table cold. Server was nice, but the everything home made speech is a crock. Just because it was put in a pot, then from a pot to a plate does not mean it should be called homemade or hand made.

I infrequently enter a Walmart establishment, with an average frequency of once every three months. Upon entering the premises, I am consistently met with an unorganized and chaotic environment; it is truly perplexing how customers are able to navigate the store and locate their desired items amidst the disarray. On a recent visit, I embarked on a quest to procure a specific product, specifically a vacuum cleaner, and was taken aback by the utter disarray in which the merchandise was displayed. The various sections within the store were in complete disarray, resembling a haphazard bargain basement sale. It appears that the staff has adopted an apathetic attitude towards maintaining a well-organized and welcoming shopping environment, which is particularly concerning given the broad range of products available, ranging from modestly priced items at $38 to more extravagant offerings exceeding $400.  

Upon proceeding to the checkout area, I was taken aback by the absence of a cashier, despite the presence of a illuminated indicator signaling that the register was operational. My companion and I hesitated, contemplating whether to remain and wait for the cashier's return or to abandon our purchases altogether. Fortunately, a managerial figure noticed our predicament and summoned the cashier back to her post, thereby allowing us to complete our transaction. It is worth noting that this particular Walmart location boasts an inadequate number of parking spaces designated for handicapped individuals, resulting in a frequent shortage of accessible parking options. Despite the prevalence of vehicles displaying permits, the management has elected not to expand these spaces, a decision that is both disappointing and reprehensible.

I rarely walk into a Walmart, maybe once per quarter. This store is a mess! In fact it's so much of a mess that I wonder how people shop. A quiet Monday evening and there are carts full of merchandise around the store just sitting there. Went in looking for one particular product (a vacuum) and the sections were completely in shambles. A shame when you are looking at products that range from $38 to over $400. This reminds me of a bad bargain basement sale. It's like no one really cares and forget trying to find products on the shelves. Really... the competition has come to town and instead of competing you decide making your store look like trash is the way to go.... really!

Walked to the cash to pay, light is on, but the cashier isn't even there. We stand there for a while deciding if we are going to pay for what we have in hand. Manager notices us and calls girl back to her cash. Four cashiers for the whole store and one goes walking away leaving people waiting? 

Important Note: This Walmart has very limited handicapped parking and it is often impossible to find a spot. They just don't care enough to increase the spots, in spite of the fact that they are often full with cars that all have permits. Shameful.

"Although the exterior faÃ§ade of Garcia's pizza appears quaint and welcoming, upon entering the establishment, one's expectations are quickly dissipated by the unremarkable nature of the pizza offered, thereby rendering it unworthy of consideration for a satisfying dining experience."

I do not like Garcia's pizza very much! From the outside the place looks cute and very inviting but once you go inside you will think differently! The pizza is nothing to talk about and I would suggest going somewhere else!

Okay, so I was craving a good burger.  So Got on Yelp as I so often do.  I found this place.  After reading the reviews I was sold. I mapquested and was on my way.  I agree with the comments about the inside of it but I know that sometimes the best foods comes from hole in the walls.  I ordered a double with chili and cheese combo.  Driving home I was excited.  Upon taking my first bite, I must say that my expectations far  exceeded the taste.  The chili was so bland...it just kind of coated my tongue.  I tried another bite and couldnt really distinguish that it was indeed chili that I was eating.  The burger itself was good...it reminded me of in and out burger.  I scraped the chili off added some salt.  And was still not impressed.  All in all it was a decent taste of beef and although I didn't like the chili at all...I would go back and just order a cheeseburger.  The fries were okay...they looked a bit like that had been sitting and then refried.  In and out are definitely better and you can tell that they are fresh,,,these not so sure!  Maybe this batch of chili wasn't up to par but it's a NO for me!  Now back to trying to eat the rest of this burger.......

I am NOT a fan of Sweet Tomatoes. This location is always packed with soccer moms and their kids and I don't get why. The salad bar is fine but it's overpriced and has cheap ingredients. My biggest pet peeve is that even though the restaurant's name is Sweet Tomatoes, they don't even have sweet cherry tomatoes on their salad bar! What the heck? I know cherry tomatoes are pricey but c'mon, that's your namesake for crying out loud!

This place tries to lure you in by claiming to be "healthy" but it's really carb central in disguise. While it's true you can eat reasonably well at the salad bar, the food bars are a different story. Bread, pizza, macaroni and cheese, pasta, sugar and starch laden soups, baked potatoes....not a lot of options for the healthy eater. How about adding some steamed vegetables or something? Although it's an all you can eat restaurant, I often leave here hungry because there's hardly any protein!

This place is overpriced and low quality. You can do better. And I don't know if it's some sort of additive they put on the salad bar but every single time I eat here, I get tummy troubles. No kidding.

Style over substance. Ruben was an unmanageable mess, poutine had more fries than curds or gravy, no good beer on the menu. \n\nVegetarian options are pasta, pizza, or you can ask for a salad with no meat.

the two stars are solely dedicated to the counter rental agent as he was kind and professional.  he explained everything with a smile and efficiency.  however, when we said no to all insurance and gas filling...note...car rental agents make commissions by selling these things. he told us there is a $20 surcharge on top of the original amount quoted.  this surcharge is a mandatory road side assistance surcharge... something no other car rental companies do.  as a result, we paid the same amount to payless for a very beat up compact when we could've rented from dollar or alamo for something better.  heading back to vegas in june for world serious but won't be renting from them ever again...\n\nTry e-z car rental 10 steps again.  They re soooo much better!!!

the bouganvilla restaurant was not so good. after ordering, our drinks appeared quickly. then things went down hill. our food took almost 45 minutes to arrive, and was disappointing. runny scrambled eggs were the main culprit. i enjoyed the sourdough toast and hashbrowns. the bacon was weird. he had a burger and fries ... the fries were awesome, but his burger was quite pink, despite being ordered \"medium\". on our way out, we tried our luck at the wheel of fortune machine, where i dropped in $5 and walked out with $65, a miller lite (for him) and a vodka tonic. our winnings more than covered the cost of our middle-of-the-night meal.\n\na couple hours after my 2 am breakfast, i found myself worshipping a waste receptacle. i suspect the runny eggs were the cause. the only reason this place is getting 2 stars is the service. our server was, experienced, prompt and did all the right things at the right times. i liked her. i just wish she had the opportunity to serve a better product.

The sentiment regarding my experience at this establishment was utterly unfavorable, as I was thoroughly unimpressed with the entirety of my visit. My culinary preferences are quite discerning, and I have always been an ardent admirer of Fate and the exceptional gastronomical prowess of Chef Johnny. However, my expectations were not merely surpassed, but utterly decimated by the deplorable quality of service that we received. Our server's comportment was brusque and taciturn, radiating an palpable aura of disdain that permeated the atmosphere and left an indelible impression of discomfort upon our party of four. Furthermore, the concept of "tapas" is one that I comprehend, yet the exorbitant cost of our meal, which totaled a hundred dollars without even including beverages, struck me as an unjustifiable amount to pay for a dining experience that left us all feeling unsatisfied and still hungry. In light of these factors, I must regretfully assert that I would not consider returning to this restaurant in the future, although I might potentially indulge in their drinks selection.

I was NOT impressed with this place at all!  I LOVED fate and think Johnny is a great chef.....  I eat out everyday either lunch or dinner, the service was horrible, our server had an attitude.  The whole table (4) could feel her akwardness.  I understand the whole \"tapas\" thing, but $100 dollar food check not including drinks is a bit much for us to leave hungry.  I dont think I would eat there again, drink? yes.

I was put off by the attitude I got at this place.  I didn't like how the guy taking my order belittled me for not ordering any appetizers or drinks.  I also don't like the handwritten signs that made excuses for why their service is slow and why they don't let non-patrons use their bathroom (a simple "customers only" would work, but no, they have to go into great lengths to explain that toilet paper is expensive and therefore only their "friends" -- the customers -- can use the toilets blah blah).

That aside, decor (minus the handwritten signs) is great.  I felt like I was at a noodle stand in southeast Asia.  I enjoyed my Cambod-Ican noodle soup (their take on pho).  I normally don't like pho because it tastes too much like MSG but it wasn't so bad here.  I tasted my friend's crispy noodles and thought it tasted like really sweet, low quality Chinese take out lo-mein (but at least the noodles were sufficiently crispy).  My other friend found her vegetable curry with chicken to be too spicy for her liking.

The whole payment system is awkward.  Why not just take payment when I order at the window?  Why do I have to awkwardly and deliberately put on my coat in full view of the window to signal them to come out and give me the check?  It's beyond me.
The food was decent, and they have some crazy soda machine with like 1000 flavors (ok not really that many, but a frikn lot.)

After an initial triad of visits within a two-month period of this specific visit, this review would have constituted a perfect five-star rating; however, the final visit proved to be a profound disappointment. Four individuals, including myself, placed orders for 9 oz. medium rare filets, which were served with an unfortunate predominance of brown coloration, devoid of any residual redness. I promptly brought this to the attention of the wait staff, who demonstrated an expeditious responsiveness in addressing my concern by transporting the dish back to the kitchen. Through the transparent partition separating the dining area from the culinary domain, I observed the cook's initial inquiry, which focused on the possibility of the patrons desiring further cooking. This query seemed to belie an inherent incredulity, as the steaks, in point of fact, had been overcooked. Despite the potential influence of luminosity, the culinary faux pas remained unrectified. The waiter failed to manifest any subsequent dialogue or remunerative offer, allowing the impression of dissatisfaction to linger unaddressed. As a former denizen of Wisconsin, and cognizant of the proprietors' Badger State provenance, I must aver that this manner of supper club operation does not comport with the local customs of that region. Consequently, I can no longer, in good conscience, recommend your establishment. My apologies.

After first three visits within two months of this same visit, this would have been 5 stars but the last visit was very disappointing. Four of us all ordered 9 oz. medium rare filets that came out mostly brown without any red. I immediately told the waiter who was quick to agree to take it back to the kitchen. I saw the communication through the window and the cook's first question was, \"do they want it cooked more?\"  Really???  Waiter came back and told us 'it was the light' that made the steaks look more brown. Although it may have been a factor, the steaks were over cooked.  Waiter never said a thing again even though we twice mentioned the steaks were not cooked correctly. No offer to take anything off our bill and no apology if anything did not meet our expectations. As a former Wisconsin resident, and knowing the owners are also from there, this is not how Wisconsinites run a supper club!!  I can no longer recommend your business. Sorry.
It's a Macaroni Grill... not much to say about this... if you have gone to one, you have seen them all. Nothing is really memorable. Including the service. Prices are reasonable.

My first time here tonight. Service was good, the guy let me try some sauces and was helpful. The wings were ok, nothing to go out of the way for. They give you a lot of fries  but the food was cheap and they don't put much sauce on. It's on a college campus and it's surprisingly clean.

There is nothing wrong with this place, but nothing particularly redeeming either.  The food was mediocre, and the interior didn't seem to fit the theme.  The servers seemed aloof.   We were there for the lunch buffet which had an ok selection of the Indian standards.  The best part was a never-ending basket of your choice of fresh baked Naan.

On our maiden visit to this establishment today, my spouse and I were less than enthralled by the culinary offerings, specifically those of Taiwanese provenance, and furthermore, we found the tariffs to be somewhat elevated in relation to the gastronomic experience provided.
First time here today me and my husband, i don't like their Taiwanese traditional dishes and actually the price little higher compared with food quality.

Tried this place for the first time.  The prices are reasonable however the food is sub par!  I ordered over easy eggs and got over medium to over hard eggs.  Not happy!!!  Pancakes take like dirty dish cloth!!  Yuck!!!  The bacon and hashbrowns were actually very good.  Customer service was average, nothing memorable.

Won't be back!!!  Sorry, there are way too many breakfast places in the valley to choose from.  If you want to stand out, you have to do better than this.

Recommend Peoria Cafe or Brothers instead!!!

"Arrived for a midday repast on the seventh day of the week, specifically at an hour thirty minutes past noon, and was met with an extensive queue. Patronized the establishment to the tune of $37, plus an additional $4 per person, culminating in a total expenditure of $41. Comprised a group of nine individuals, thereby necessitating a communal seating arrangement, specifically a circular table configured to accommodate numerous persons. Observed that the culinary offerings, while visually appealing, did not necessarily translate into commensurate gastronomical satisfaction, as the emphasis seemed to be placed upon aesthetic presentation rather than actual taste. Sampled various exotic fare, including duck ravioli and tea eggs, albeit in minuscule portions and served in diminutive cooking vessels. Concluded that the most satisfactory edible was, in fact, the beef brisket accompanied by mashed potatoes. Likewise, the most enjoyable sweet treat was indubitably the black forest cheesecake. However, it is worth noting that the premises were abruptly cleared and illuminations extinguished at precisely three o'clock post meridian, without prior notification from the cashier, thus precipitating a sense of inconvenience and truncating the duration of our repast."

Came for lunch on Saturday around 1:30 pm and the line was really long. Paid $37 plus tax per person, which came out to $41. There were nine of us so they sat us at a banquet like round table. Dishes were not as good as they looked, it is more about presentation here. Exotics dishes such as duck raviloi and tea eggs. Some of the dishes are served in little pans and are small portions. Best dish IMO was the beef brisquette with mashed potatoes. Best dessert IMO was the black forest cheesecake. The worst part was that they started turning off the lights and putting food away at 3:00 pm on the dot, even though the cashier did not indicate to us that this would happen.

Had a gel polish change for my hands & feet, and I must say I was very disappointed. $40 for a gel polish change, NO pedicure. She cut my nails entirely TOOOO short & now my feet look like ugly french tipped nubs! I was going to get acrylics but since I didn't expect to pay so much for my feet I just got a gel manicure. It was OK, nothing special & it also $40 for that. Since I mentioned the discount from yelp they took $12 off my $80. I didn't feel she deserved any sort of tip but tipped her anyway... but I'll never come back.

"Having been desirous of visiting this establishment for an extended period of time, we finally had the opportunity to partake in its offerings. Upon entering, we were struck by the lively atmosphere, which was further enhanced by the presence of a musical ensemble preparing to perform in the lounge area. Opting for a table in close proximity to the stage, we perused the menu and selected several tacos for our culinary indulgence. While the carne asada and pork varieties were merely satisfactory, the shrimp iteration proved to be somewhat more palatable. However, our enjoyment of the edibles was somewhat diminished by the exorbitant cost of the beverages, with pitchers of beer priced at an astronomical $17. Nevertheless, we were willing to overlook this incongruity in light of the overall ambiance. Unfortunately, the temperature within the venue was unbearably high, rendering our experience less than optimal. Furthermore, our request for a bottle of Bud Light was met with a canned version of the beverage, which only served to further mar our satisfaction. In light of these factors, we have decided to patronize America's Taco Shop in the future, where the carne asada is reportedly exceptional."

"We attended Surrender Nightclub to witness Calvin Harris's performance, having procured prepaid tickets that facilitated our expedited entry, albeit arriving at the venue relatively late, at 11:30 pm. Subsequent to gaining access to the club without any issues, our initial enthusiasm rapidly waned. While the notion of an 80% outdoor setting within the club was intriguing, its execution proved subpar. Calvin Harris was indeed performing within the indoor section of the club, but the absence of access to the dance floor for those without a $3000 table reservation rendered the experience futile. One must ponder the logic behind allowing patrons entry while restricting their ability to participate in the primary activity. The cover charge, though not nominal, seemed unnecessary given the circumstances. Therefore, we would recommend exploring alternative establishments for an enjoyable nightlife experience."

Was at Surrender for MDW to see Calvin Harris, bought prepaid tickets which got us in fast, despite arriving at the scene at 11:30pm. After entering the club hassle-free, the excitement quickly dwindled. \nThe concept of having 80% of the club outdoor is nice, however the implementation was poor. Calvin Harris was playing at the indoor portion of the club, except no one was allowed on the dance floor except if you purchased a $3000 table. Why even let people in if you don't allow anyone on the dance floor? Waste of money on cover, and it wasn't like the cover was cheap either; $100 for guys and $40 for ladies. Go somewhere else to have a  good time.

This is my second time here. I thought I'd give em another try. This visit really isn't different than my last one. I ordered a Green Chile cheeseburger. The waiter had to advise me it'll be hot. Lol ok whatever. So I finally get it. The presentation of the food looked half assed. Very sloppy. I take the top portion of bread off... There's hardly any green chile on it. I ask for a side of chile. It shows up. The green chile was hot. Which is good. It tasted straight out of the can tho. Gross. I'm sure they get Hatch food service cans or something. My girlfriends meal wasn't much better. She got The Green Chile Chicken Especial or something to that extent. The presentation of the food was horrid. It was a conglomeration of rice, beans, and cheese. With a little boat of chicken soupy something or other. She said that it was too salty. \n\nThe food isn't New Mexican. It's Tex Mex style food using Hatch Chile.

2 Stars because the restaurant decor was Awsome but unfortunatly we never got to eat here.  We ordered our food and 60 minutes later we still did not have our food.  We had to get up and leave.  I'd like to think that the food would have been good but now I'll never know.

After doing some shopping nearby, I was lured into ATS by their slogan: \"Best Carne Asada in Phoenix\".  When ordering at the counter, the staff seemed very disinterested in helping customers.  When I finally did order my carne asada burrito, I was given a number and asked to take a seat.  While I waited, I noticed a few other customers wondering what was going on with the bad service at the counter.  When my carne asada arrived at the table, I was starving.  However, the burrito that sat in front of me was tiny.  I'm not really one to complain about small portion sizes, as I feel that most portions are too big, but this portion was just comical.  The burrito was served with a lime wedge that was dry and looked like it had been sliced the day before.  The flavor of the carne asada was bland, as was the texture.\n\nOverall, this was a pretty disappointing meal.   \"Best Carne Asada in Phoenix\" is a really misleading phrase to have on their sign.  This place is not even close.

I thought that Lucille's BBQ in Las Vegas is much better.  Pot Liquor has big portions and big prices.  I had the Spare Ribs, which were good, but nothing amazing.  I thought that the portion was way too big for lunch and wish that they had some lunch options\n\nThe service was \"OK.\"  It was a typical \"What do you recommend?\" \"Oh, everything is good\" service. If you come to Pot Liquor, just don't come with high expectations.

Two stars for being the worst of the three that I've been to.

The usual SS staples are there, and the food isn't bad, but they ditched the Calimari that is on the Chicago menu!  Unbelieveable.  That was the most delicious thing I had ever had!

Mostly, my beef with this place is the location, in a mall, and the ambience of the place.  The ironic part is that when you are dining at the Chicago or Miami locations, it feels like you are in Vegas: swanky, cool, fun.  But dining in the Vegas one feels like you are at a Legal Seafoods in suburbia.

Just misses something.  If you're in Vegas, go someplace else.

Yuck! It's vegas and I wanted an eiffel tower drink but never again! I'll stick with Fat Tuesday. But if you want to get drunk within minutes, this drink definitely does the trick.

The drink itself is disgusting. I got the strawberry daquiri b/c I didn't want any tequila. But I mean the drink got me drunk within minutes but I felt like shit. Plus, it costs $16.99 for it. I almost would have rather paid for the eiffel tower and had Fat Tuesday filled it up instead. At least their alcohol doesn't get me feeling extremely shitty for the next two hours. Also, the alcohol wasn't even proportionally mixed in. The dude basically pour alcohol at the bottom of the cup and then filled the rest of the tower up with strawberry daiquiri. I ended up pouring the last 1/4 of my drink. I couldn't drink anymore of it.

Pass.

Come here if you want the cup. For the alcohol? go to fat tuesdays.

"An opulent lodging establishment, characterized by spacious, immaculate accommodations, but unfortunately, the quality of the guest experience was not augmented by the hospitality proffered by the personnel. Specifically, the front desk attendant, during our departure, did not trouble herself to inquire about our satisfaction with our stay nor express gratitude for our patronage, her greeting was perfunctory and immediately followed by the presentation of our bill, which seemed discourteous given the premium nature of the hotel and my personal inclination towards being easily pleased; thus, it is regrettable that the service we received did not align with our expectations."

Very nice hotel. Beautiful, large and clean rooms. However, customer service was not so great. Overall, the place just felt stuffy and staff was not very friendly. Upon checkout the girl at the desk didn't even bother to ask us how are stay was or thank us for staying there. She just said hello and then handed us our bill. I am fairly easy to please, but when I'm paying for a hotel like this I expect you to at least pretend you appreciate my patronage.

Me and my boyfriend were visiting Fremont street and got hungry.  We had been spending ridiculous amount of money on strip food so this place seemed like a real bargain.  I kinda liked the decor.  It was an 80's jungle theme.  Our server was very nice and attentive. Most of the food was not very good.  I got quite a few items that I only took 1 or 2 bites of. I think it's funny that they advertised it was a steak dinner buffet and what they served was thin strips of  carne asada.  It was still yummy though.  Just not what I picture when I think of steak.  To get full I had to make 10 trips to the carving station, they are very stingy with the meat. Bottom line- I didn't get sick, I got full and it was really cheap. Would I go back? No.

My sandwich took 30 minutes for me to get. Really?? A sandwich?? Its worth a shot to try this spot. Alot of my friends like this place but not me. Too loud too have a conversation with someone sitting right next to you. The waitress took our order..brought out the food..gave us the check. . And not once asked if we needed anything. No refills. No more alcohol.  Napkins. Nothing.   Rude..I hate bad service.  If you dont want to wait on people then why are you here.  The only reason I gave 2 stars is because they have soooo many tvs.  And every sport on.

The word \"Premium\" shouldn't be used here.  This place is outdated and I really think the selection of stores are boring.  The good news, especially in the summer time is that you have an indoor mall, unlike the North Outlets which has a much better selection of stores, but all outside.  Unless they put some more interesting stores in here, I think I will continue to bypass it.

Below average, overpriced, unwelcoming.

I have been meaning to try this place since it opened. My boyfriend is from North Carolina and loves BBQ so I've been trying to find him a place in Pittsburgh he might enjoy. We got takeout - brisket sandwich, 1/4 fried chicken, meaty Mac, and coleslaw. We found everything to be underwhelming. The brisket was average- it was tender but I've had better.  The fried chicken was salty.  The meaty Mac would have been better without the blue cheese.  I ate it by picking out meat chunks and the crispy cheese on top. The coleslaw was good, and by far our favorite part of the meal. That should say enough. 

Price was $35 for all of the above. 

As far as service, the waitress seemed uninterested in us. There were only three other guests in the downstairs of the restaurant.

"An immense WHA WHA! ensued, precipitated by my attendance within a coterie of six females; however, upon discovering the entrance fee was twenty dollars, we opted to forgo the experience due to the lateness of the hour. As we were exiting, we were presented with complimentary passes, which prompted our about-face and return to the interior of the establishment. The ambiance was indeed captivating, but the fundamental purpose of a nightclub is to facilitate dancing. This objective becomes unattainable when one finds oneself immured within a throng of six hundred other individuals, whose inebriated state renders them uncoordinated and unpleasant. Although, I conjecture that if one is extremely inebriated, it may be a judicious strategy to force one's way into the center of the crowd, given that it is nearly impossible to fall due to the multitude of people supporting one. Furthermore, the young women positioned in the pool areas evoke melancholy sentiments. When amiable females extend greetings and inquire about one's welfare, and one responds by gazing blankly ahead and affecting a pose from a distance of a foot, it suggests that one has been coerced into such employment. Alternatively, it may be necessary to become intoxicated in order to endure one's shift."

Luckily, I don't mind Coke, albeit, I have been here several times and it's been rather lackluster, to say the least; however, the last time I came through the drive-thru and ordered a simple medium number one combo with onion rings, I thought it was quite peculiar that the order taker failed to inquire about my beverage preference, but instead, simply drove around, presumably assuming that he would inquire about my desired drink when I arrived at the pickup point; nonetheless, much to my chagrin, he handed me a Coca-Cola without so much as a query regarding my inclination.  While I strive to maintain a flexible and accommodating demeanor in most situations, this particular occurrence proved to be somewhat vexing for me.  Upon opening the bag, much to my dismay, I discovered fries, which, needless to say, were not part of my original order; furthermore, the employee's response was utterly dismissive and lacking any semblance of remorse or regret, as he merely retrieved the onion rings and handed me the bag back without so much as an explanation or apology.  It appears that the adage, "you get what you pay for" holds true in this instance, and while I may opt to patronize this establishment again in the future, given its proximity to my domicile and my occasional craving for a Burger King meal, I must confess that this experience left much to be desired, to put it mildly.

Luckily I don't mind Coke....  I have been here several times and it's been... \"meh\"... but the last time I came through the drive thru and ordered a simple Medium #1 with onion rings.  I thought it was strange that the order taker did not ask what I wanted to drink, but just drove around (figured he would ask me when I got there).... NOPE just handed me a coke.  I try to roll with the punches more-often-than-not, but this was not the end of the world for me.  When I opened the bag, I had fries... and mentioned it to him.  There was no apology and he just went and got the onion rings and handed me the bag back.\n\nI guess  the phrase, \"you get what you pay for\" applies here.  I will probably give this place another shot since it's right near my house when I need a BK fix, but this is very disappointing in my book.

It seems like everyone had a better experience here than me. Maybe I just went on a bad day.  My biggest gripe about this place is that the veggies didn't look good. I had to pick through the carrots and tomatoes to find ones that looked relatively fresh. The sweet and sour sauce was kind of bland. Service was good though. Our server was friendly and checked on us regularly. Maybe I'll have better luck next time.

I went here with my fianc\u00e9 and we both ordered the steak omelet. His came out filled with steak and all the goodness it comes with, mine came out with literally 3 pieces of steak. When I questioned them about it they has 2 managers come tell me that the steak is all pre-weighed and that is what it comes with. I pointed out my finances plate vs mine and stated that if I'm paying the price for the steak then I want steak! They ended up bringing me a side of stake bits after about 20 min and were very rude. I will not go back there!

I seriously don't understand the five star reviews. My food was about as bland as it gets. Its Vietnamese...the spices and herbs they normally use add terrific flavor. My meal here had none. Now, Jeff's on the other hand tasted like they dumped an entire shaker of salt on it. Ummmm, salt on Vietnamese?? Anyway, I'm here for the weekend and its the closest vegan joint, so I'll likely be back. I'll order the spring rolls...those, I liked. Sorry, but Vegas and vegans are not a good mix!

"In close proximity to a grocery store, boasting a 24-hour operation, yet unpredictable in inventory management, resulting in frequent stockouts or discontinuation of specific items, rendering it unreliable for essential grocery shopping. Instead, consider alternative options such as Harris Teeter or Trader Joes for reliable grocery procurement. Notwithstanding, this establishment may suffice for incidental purchases like dairy products or eggs, albeit with caution regarding overcharges and inadequate coupon credits, necessitating vigilant monitoring of transactions."

Close by grocery store ... Open 24 hrs - but count on it ... If you have a need for something specific - there's a good chance they will be out of it or have discontinued carrying it ... This place is not dependable for the real groceries... Go to Harris Teeter or Trader Joes for that ... This is good for creamer or milk or eggs ... Maybe ...  Also watch the cashiers - famous for over charges and not giving credit for coupons even after they're mentioned to them ... Most definitely pay attention to your charges !

I've been here a countless amount of times. I had been wanting Pei Wei for about two weeks. Finally decided\nTo go and get lettuce wraps and one spring roll. Quick as always but wraps just didn't taste right. They had an \"aftertaste\" not a good one either. Spring roll was okay. Could taste the go ginger and the seaweed was too chewy. Very disappointed and am in no hurry to run back.

"This culinary establishment fell short of exceptional quality, with a price point of $17 plus for pasta that failed to align with my expectations of gastronomical excellence. Opting for the Gorgonzola chicken pasta, I anticipated an indulgent and velvety pasta dish, regrettably, it did not live up to my expectations, instead, it closely resembled the quality of institutionalized cuisine. Disappointment ensued. However, they did possess a welcoming ambiance for families, accompanied by delectable bread and an adequate clam appetizer. Additionally, my spouse relished the flavorful prime rib. The restaurant demonstrated attentive service in addressing my dissatisfaction with the pasta, yet ultimately, the cost was not commensurate with the quality of the culinary offerings."

This restaurant was far from great. With a price of $17+ for pasta I expected great. I had the Gorgonzola chicken pasta and I expected a deliciously rich and creamy pasta. Instead I could only describe this as tasting like pasta from a cafeteria. So disappointing. 

They were kid friendly, which was helpful. They had good bread and we had a pretty decent clam appetizer. My hubby had some tasty prime rib as well.

They took care of the pasta which I appreciated. Overall, they were friendly and accommodating but the food just wasn't  worth the price.

Good French food, average service

Stopped into Mon Ami Gabi on a vacation to Vegas.  My wife and I thought it was superb 11 years ago and were happy to see they are still in business.  We both recalled how much we loved their French Onion Soup.

With some relatives coming down the street, I was disappointed by the young lady managing the hostess desk.  She wouldn't even say if or how long our wait was, "Unless your full party is here."  I could understand not being seated, but the rude tone and nonsensical retort that they can't even give you an estimate on wait time got things off to a poor start.  Then, we were seated immediately when our family members arrived.

The menu is simple enough and the food was good, but not great.  Salads were unremarkable.  The Fillet Mignon was very good.  And the final bill was about $205 for four adults, a toddler, and a baby.  Note: They put 18% gratuity on for themselves.

There were much better years ago.  And if there were better service, I would readily give them three stars.
everytime i come here for a haircut they mess it up. a good haircut is suppose to last 15 to 25 minutes this place has you in and out in 5 minutes. never coming back
Got the Shrimp wonton w/ramen noodle. The portion was very good but, the soup has absolutely no flavor.  Disappointed as all the reviews said it was great.

Great selection for a wide range of fabric/upholstery needs. Some items are well priced and others, outrageous. Two star rating is for the service there.....EVERY time I go there I am treated as if I am a ghost!!! They have a \"take a number\" system that even THEY don't really use. LOTS of people working there but ALL seem to have another agenda that doesn't include the CUSTOMERS! \nReally should give one star for service but product selection gets them Two!

Went in for breakfast. We were sat pretty quickly but no one came to our table for about 10 minutes. Apparently no one was sure who's section we were in. The food was ok, definitely nothing to get excited about. I had to ask for a glass of water 4 times before they brought it. \nWe have had a decent dinner there before and may go back for that sometime but for breakfast there are much better places in town.

"I had what I thought was a great facial and after two days, I experienced an adverse reaction to their products.  I purchased a few of the items during my visit so I called to let them know of what happened.  The young woman in the spa said she would have to check to see if I could return the skin care products that I purchased for $85.00. After asking me again why I was returning them, she said, âThey would allow meâ?to return them but they would have to issue a check instead of crediting my credit card that they so easily accepted when I purchased the items.  I returned to the spa the following day with the items and they gave me a credit voucher and said they would check with the manager to make sure he would approve the return.  I received a call 4 days later letting me know he did indeed âapprove itâ?and they would put a check in the mail...which I still have not received.  No one was concerned that I just spent $160 on a facial spa treatment and my face was all chapped, peeling and red from the reaction.  All they were concerned with was whether they would allow me to return items that I clearly couldn't use.  I was a returning guest but after this incident, I will no longer be a patron of the Arizona Grand Spa.  Apparently they've changed management and the customer no longer comes first."

I ultimately arrived at this destination after being transported by individuals who were ardent devotees of the establishment and frequented it regularly. The edifice itself was quite captivating, and I would highly recommend paying it a visit if you ever find yourself in the vicinity. The throng was pleasant, albeit not excessively boisterous. The bill of fare was intriguing, and the culinary offerings were satisfactory, although they did not particularly impress. The aspect that truly stood out during my dining experience was the utter lack of fervor or concern exhibited by our server. Considering the eatery's proximity to an institution of higher learning, I had anticipated that the individual attending to our needs might have displayed a modicum of vivacity and joviality. However, such was not the case. When I requested a container for taking leftovers, the server merely placed it adjacent to my plate and retreated without even deigning to acknowledge my presence. Perhaps, had I indulged in a greater quantity of alcoholic beverages, I might have derived a greater degree of enjoyment from this establishment. Nonetheless, I am compelled to question the logic behind revisiting Four Peaks, as the experience evoked a sense of familiarity with the aged adage, "Purchase another drink for me, for you remain unsightly." The server's demeanor served as a poignant reminder of this phrase, as their unfriendliness was palpable.

"Although my experience at Lola Lo was merely average, I must admit that the ambiance was somewhat satisfying, primarily due to the friendly and accommodating bar staff, an array of delectable cocktails, and an aesthetically pleasing decor that effectively captured the essence of a beach theme without appearing excessively kitsch. However, several aspects of the venue left much to be desired, including exorbitant prices, a cover charge that seemed disproportionate to the quality of entertainment offered, and a disappointingly diminutive dance floor that failed to accommodate the number of patrons adequately, resulting in a atmosphere that felt more akin to a glorified bar than a legitimate nightclub. Furthermore, the music selection was uninspired and lacked the vitality that one would expect from a establishment purporting to offer a truly dynamic nightlife experience. In conclusion, while I cannot unequivocally recommend Lola Lo, I would not necessarily decline an invitation to return, provided that my companions expressed a strong desire to visit and I had no better alternatives."

Meh, lola lo is just ok. Had a few fun nights here. This is a simple list of what they get right & what they get wrong:
Good - bar staff are very friendly & helpful, yummy cocktails, bouncers are surprisingly nice, decoration is beautiful (I know beach theme can look tacky but they pull it off quite well), people there are pretty down to earth for G.street.
Bad - very expensive,... £4.50 vod/mixer rising to about £7 for any cocktail, cover charge is too expensive like other poster said, music is far too quiet & last time I went music was a bit crap, dance floor is too small for this to really be a club its more like a bar with dance area, doesn't usually fill up till quite late on in the evening.
Basically I wouldn't really choose to go here, but if everyone else had already made up their mind I would tag along.

First clue was no one in restaurant. Dinner rolls were burnt and Chicken Parmesan was overcooked. Out of 4 of us at the table ... No one liked their dinner. One friend who is vegan asked for plain noodles with veggies. They accommodated, but then topped it with cheese (not vegan). #fail

"The ambiance on the outdoor terrace was pleasant, owing to the soothing sound of the adjacent water features, however, the pungent aroma of chlorine permeated the air, rendering the dining experience somewhat unpleasant. Notwithstanding, the culinary offerings were satisfactory, and our server was accommodating in providing the complementary chips and salsa, as per the Yelp promotion. We opted for the green chili chicken burritos, which were copiously adorned with cheese, making them unsuitable for individuals cognizant of their cholesterol intake. The overpowering richness of the cheese and spices somewhat masked the underlying flavors, although, upon closer inspection, we discerned traces of chicken within the dish. In the absence of the patio and its accompanying water feature, it is unlikely that this establishment would enjoy prolonged success."

This Westin establishment has experienced a notable decline in quality. My associates and I have consistently chosen to patronize this location during Furniture Market due to its complimentary and ample parking facilities, as well as the luxurious Heavenly beds and convenient in-lobby Starbucks. However, our most recent visit revealed a discernible deterioration in the standard of service provided. Despite our status as esteemed Starwood preferred members, it remains uncertain whether we shall continue to frequent this hotel.  

During my stay, the temperature in my quarters proved challenging to regulate, which was particularly problematic given the extreme heat outside, with temperatures soaring to 107 degrees. Following an unsuccessful attempt to rectify the issue via a phone call, a maintenance worker arrived, declared the problem resolved, and departed, leaving the temperature unchanged. Eventually, after enduring an oppressively hot and humid night's sleep, I was relocated to another floor, much to my dismay, as it necessitated transferring my entire collection of unpacked belongings.  

Upon further inspection, a staff member discovered that the air conditioning unit lacked a crucial component, resulting in inadequate air circulation. Once the part was installed, the system functioned efficiently. Additional concerns included neglected floor maintenance and an accumulation of trash in the guest rooms, including items not open to interpretation, such as crumpled paper and miniature creamer containers from the underwhelming in-room coffee service.  

While no catastrophic events occurred, it is evident that a significant change has transpired since our previous experiences at this hotel have been thoroughly enjoyable. Nevertheless, life's brevity precludes excessive concern; instead, we must acknowledge and learn from these alterations.

"We had the privilege of partaking in a culinary experience at an unconventional hour, specifically 8 pm on a Saturday evening, whereupon we discovered that our presence was the sole occupation of the establishment's capacity at that particular time. The gastronomical offerings, while adequate, did not quite live up to our expectations, with the exception of a select few dishes that demonstrated a modicum of culinary prowess. Notably, the presence of saba and other similarly prepared dishes served as a testament to the kitchen's proficiency. However, we couldn't help but feel that the quality of the food was somewhat compromised by the fact that the rolls, in particular, lacked the freshness that one has come to expect from a kaiten sushi restaurant. Furthermore, the location's relative obscurity, situated behind several rows of buildings, coupled with the dearth of conspicuous signage until one reaches the vicinity of the establishment, may contribute to its seemingly low patronage.
