Nonetheless, the interior ambiance was pleasing to the eye, thanks to tasteful decor and well-maintained facilities, and the staff exhibited a commendable level of friendliness and attentiveness towards us during our visit."

Ate late last night - We were the only ones there at about 8pm on a saturday night. The food was okay, but nothing out of this world. I was impressed that they had saba and a few others ready to go, but I think that I would only return when it is busy because I can't see how the rolls could have been fresh. It's not bad if you order and have them prepare it on the fly, but at a Kaiten sushi joint you don't expect that you have to. It is slightly hard to find (behind a few rows of buildings actually!) and signage is minimal until you reach the area (3 parking lot areas deep!)  Maybe that is why it was empty.  It is really clean, and nicely decorated inside and the staff is friendly and attentive.

While I'm not from Chicago, I did live there 6 months. Long enough to know good pizza! I ordered a small pizza and a corn dog from them. Points for having corn dogs, it was a yummy defrosted corn dog.. no complaints there. My fiance was very happy to have a corn dog with his pizza (yes I'm marrying someone that likes to have a corn dog and pizza for dinner, but that's another issue). 

The pizza .. now that was the problem. It sucked! So to explain Chicago pizza.. it should be thin-ish on the bottom, but thick on the sides and top.. sort of like a pie. Yes, a pie. The pizza should when sliced, look like a thick piece of pie. My pizza was about half an inch tall. Maybe just the 9 inch comes out tiny, but seriously I had 10 inch pies in chicago frequently that came out awesome. This one was very similar to those nasty frozen pizzas from pizza hut you buy at the airport. A complete disappointment. We had one slice and threw it away.. 

If you like Giordannos, or Lou Malnati's, or REAL delicious chicago pizza you will be sorely disappointed by this crap.

"On my third attempt at patronizing this establishment, I must admit that my expectations were once again not fully met, despite its proximity to my domicile. Previously, I had been somewhat forgiving of minor errors in my order, but on this particular visit, the extent of the oversight was such that I was compelled to reassess my willingness to continue supporting this business. Specifically, not only did they erroneously prepare my meal, but they also neglected to include certain items that I had specifically requested. In light of these recurring mishaps, I have decided that it would be unwise to expend further effort in attempting to obtain a satisfactory dining experience at this location."

Third time trying this place. Each time I was a bit disappointed, but I kept trying because it's so close to my home. Last time they got my order wrong and I didn't really care too much,  but today they got my order wrong and forgot some of my food. I am not driving back to get my food, I'm giving up on this place.

Our first visit was not the best experience..it was just \"ok\" at best.....nothing special.    The person at the register who took our order didn't know much about the menu...and we didn't get what we ordered (had asked for deep fried and got a sauteed conglomeration instead).  The flavor was good ... but didn't like sauteed eggplant with very tough skin.   I can't say the service was terribly bad or rude...but we didn't feel welcomed or appreciated.   Never got a greeting or smile when we walked in and  never heard the words \"thank you.\"   It was almost as if everyone working there lacked reasonable enthusiasm.   We'll probably give it one more try.  Maybe I am 'old school' but I think no business should treat their customers in such a nonchalant way.  That typeof attitude can make the difference between a one-time customer or a repeat customer.  BTW, the guy with glasses (maybe the owner or manager??)  seemed to annoyed when we asked about menu items... somewhat of a jerk.

This was my first time here. I called our order in and I was told 20 mins!  Perfect, that would be my lunch break from work.  I headed over there and the guy said it would be just a couple more minutes.  About 10 minutes later he said he just needed to make the shakes.  10 MORE minutes later he finally did! Overall it took about 45 minutes to get our food and at this point I was already over on my break!   The \"frozen custard\" shake was the reason I ordered it... no frozen custard  used, it was the discount tub of ice cream!  I could have skipped it for something 'normal'   Over all the food was ok... a bit greasy for my taste.  I don't think I would bother going back there for the time and cost of the meal.
$10 for a medium drink, chicken sandwich, and a small salad = MEH! Overpriced and nothing special of this BBQ chicken sandwich.\n\nI'll go back for a second try, someday...

"Having had the privilege of partaking in the culinary offerings of Hit Mac's on three separate occasions subsequent to my relocation to Charlotte three years ago, I have arrived at the conclusion that the establishment's reputation for serving superior quality brisket is, in my opinion, somewhat exaggerated. My previous experiences with the aforementioned dish left me feeling underwhelmed, as the meat was not only tough and chewy but also lacking in quantity. It is worth mentioning, however, that my expectations were not entirely dismal, as the ambiance of the restaurant was quite pleasant, boasting an impressive selection of beverages and a commendable level of service. Despite these positive aspects, I cannot help but feel that my dining experience was merely mediocre, particularly in regards to the pulled pork, which failed to meet my expectations. In light of these observations, I must say that while I may return to Hit Mac's in the future if circumstances dictate, I do not intend to make a special effort to visit the establishment."

Hit Mac's for the 3rd time since moving to CLT 3 years ago.  I finally had to write.

In my opinion OVERATED.

I had the brisket the first two times and was very disappointed both times.  Tough, chewy, and not much of it.  Yet this is the place that supposedly has the best brisket in town.  Sides: Meh.

This trip I went with the pulled pork thinking it would be a safe bet.  Just so-so.  I have had better in town many times.

So why even give them 2 stars?

This is a FUN place!  Cool atmosphere, great beer list, good service, music just right, etc.  Will I go back?  Probably if I'm going to be in the area.  But definitely not a spot I will go out of my way for.

"Perplexed by my decision to venture forth to this establishment, I must admit that my initial impression was favorable upon entry. However, my enthusiasm was short-lived, as the mashed potatoes lacked the warmth I had anticipated, and the meat failed to impress. Although the sweet tea and cornbread proved to be satisfactory, they were unable to compensate for the overall mediocrity of the meal. I would not recommend revisiting this restaurant, despite its boastful claim of serving the finest barbecue westward."

Not sure why I went outta my way for this place. Seemed good when we first walked in. Then the mashed potatoes were cold and the meat wasn't that great. The sweet tea and the Corn bread were great but that was about it. I wouldn't go back. Best bbq in the west my ass.

Dining-in: it's crowded, loud, and the service is awful. I get that the pizzas take a while, but that doesn't mean that everything else should, too. I've never had a polite interaction with the staff here (nothing outrageous, but for a Champaign "staple", one might think that the staff would be a little more gung-ho about being such an attraction to visitors... yes, you, I saw your roll your eyes at me when I changed my order mid sentence. Rude!).

Ordering-in: A good experience because I can avoid the cramped seating and the impolite staff. Deep dish holds well as a reheat option the next day. Their sausage pizza is really delicious.

One plus: I have friends in Chicagoland who love this pizza and if we're in Champaign for a visit, we bring back Papa Dels. It travels well.

Overall: If you're in Champaign, yes, it's the best deep dish there is. If you're from anywhere else, you can do better.

ugggh , i can't even bare to read aLL the good feedback this restaurant got . 2 stars is being EXTREMELY generous . when i Lived in Vegas years ago , my famiLy & i used to ALWAYS go here & it was thee Biz . i recentLy went here the first week of january when i was visiting & it was pathetic . food was bLand , service was whomp whomp , they have NO chicken katsu , & they ONLY accept cash . Like seriousLy , it's 2011 ... get with the program . as much as i LOVED this pLace when i was younger , i don't think i couLd ever bring myseLf to go here again . if you guys want good hawaiian/isLand food in the mainLand , come to the REAL state of CaLifornia & i'LL be gLad to recommend a handfuL of great pLaces . i was Looking forward to going to this pLace when we got to vegas , & it was such a bummer that it was faiL .

I give the star to the employees only but SAMs sucks when it comes to clothing for larger people same with walmart sorry but we are a larger nation and big people need cloths too I believe the also discriminate against larger people when they charge more and don't carry sizes that fit most large people. Get on the band wagon and treat us big people equal!!!!

The service was great but the food was not. All the pasta for our party was undercooked; there were 14 of us. Other customers also were returning meals. The manager told us they were using a new pasta and had to \"learn to cook it\". She did make an adjustment on our bill to make up for the bad meals.

Large room, ok bed, worn out sofa.  Lousy shower.I booked the room because it was a good price and Expedia rated it as ****. Not four star hotel. The food at the hotel was lousy, won't return to the Rio

Is this place one of the few inexpensive buffet spots on the strip? Yes. Is the food comparable to other buffets on the strip? No. Why? Well, everything my wife and I had during the breakfast buffet was bland, dry and cold. 

The selection here is very limited compared to other breakfast buffets we've attended. So if you're looking for a place that has an overwhelming number of options ready for you to dive into, let me save you the time and tell you look elsewhere. Yes, other buffets can be pricey, but at least at those buffets the food quality is far better and you have a bigger selection of items to choose from.

The only real benefits of coming to this buffet is saving a few extra bucks.

The building and view are beautidul....and that's the only reason why I gave it two stars. The waitress had limited knowledge on fine dining cuisine, the calimari was over cooked so we told the waitress, she returned it to the kitchen and came back out asking if we wanted something else and declines to remake the dish stating \"that's just how they make it. they won't make the dish again because that's how they cook it and it will come out the same way.\" My father asked for fresh lime in his beverage and the waitress said she'll have to check and see if they have any limes, that they didn't have many in stock. The young man filling our water and butter on the table was smacking gum so loud you could hear it across Pittsburgh. He also refilled our table water by reaching over us, so instead of pulling the water glass off the table and pouring it properly he poured the water with the glass directly ont to the table resulting in spilling ice cubes.  I had chucks of solid cheese in my pasta that wasn't melted, missing tomatoes, my dad's escargot was over cooked, my boyfriends steak was flavorful but a poor cut of meat & they ran out of half of their dessert options. Overall they are just stuck in the 1970's with their black tie outfits and old school menu. Save your money, enjoy the view from the overlook and find another restaurant with better quality.

If my mother ever cooked like this I would have fired her. \"My Mother's\" is bland as I am white. I had bland Lasagna with hard spice-less garlic bread and a limp side salad. The only item that saved My Mother's was the pie. The Chocolate Cream Pie (pictured) was heaven. The contrast between dinner and desert made me wonder if My Mother had someone else bake the pie.

"Nicholas' culinary establishment has served as a preferred meeting location for a coterie of my acquaintances. I have partaken of their pizza, calzone, and chicken parmesan offerings on multiple occasions, and my experiences with these items have been largely satisfactory. However, in an effort to diversify my gastronomical choices, I opted to sample their baked ziti with meatballs during my most recent visit. Unfortunately, the dish did not meet my expectations due to its overcooking, which resulted in a rubbery texture and an unpleasant dryness. Additionally, the extremities of the ziti were unpalatably hard and crunchy, which further detracted from my enjoyment of the meal. Notwithstanding the disappointing quality of the dish, the attentiveness and proficiency of the waitstaff were truly commendable."
The meat dishes like lamb kebab & chicken 65 we're not that great. \nPaneer tikka masala. Plenty of gravy but only 8 cubes paneer. Chana masala was ok. Naan was fresh & soft.

"The quality of the culinary offerings at this establishment was satisfactory, with the crepes and beverages such as coffee and orange juice being particularly noteworthy. However, the service we received was subpar, characterized by a lack of efficiency and attention to detail, even when the restaurant was not particularly busy, with only a few tables occupied. Additionally, the prices charged for the meal were somewhat elevated, which may have been a deterrent for some patrons."

"The provision of services and seating arrangements at this performance was utterly deplorable and chaotic. Upon arriving at our designated section on the main floor, we discovered that our tickets were invalid due to a malfunction in the ticketing system, resulting in duplicate tickets being issued. Consequently, we were forced to seek assistance from an usher, who relocated us to an alternative location across the auditorium, sandwiched between numerous family groups. 

The show itself was equally underwhelming, with its haphazard and predictable nature evoking laughter from the audience, including ourselves, for the majority of the performance. Throughout the show, a group of pandas danced aimlessly across the stage, accompanied by martial arts and acrobatic displays. 

It was challenging to discern any semblance of a narrative or coherent structure within the performance, leaving me perplexed from the onset. However, the highlight of the show was undoubtedly the scene where a performer vigorously assaulted one of the pandas, causing them to flee in terror. 

In conclusion, this show is unquestionably unworthy of any monetary investment. Its randomness and lack of artistic merit render it an unremarkable experience. The only circumstances under which I would recommend attending this performance would be if one were to receive complimentary tickets or a significantly discounted offer."

Applebee's entire concept perturbs me profoundly. Homogenous, ubiquitous restaurants that proliferate a standardized dining experience across the nation strike me as unsettling. It seems vastly more rewarding to indulge in novel, distinctive culinary ventures, accepting the possibility of an unsatisfactory experience, rather than resorting to a familiar, formulaic establishment that has popularized an annoying tune about baby back ribs... or, for that matter, Chili's. My sentiments toward the latter eatery align with my disdain for Applebee's.

My exposure to this franchise has been restricted to infrequent visits during their happy hour, which, while offering an extensive selection of discounted drinks from 3 p.m. to 7 p.m. and 10 p.m. to midnight daily, proves insufficient to compensate for the disagreeable ambiance. Aside from these designated hours, my opinion of this establishment remains steadfastly unfavorable; specifically, I find it repulsive, unpleasant, and generally distasteful.

The gastronomical experience associated with the consumption of sushi at this establishment was merely adequate, as the service provided by the staff was utterly deficient in terms of promptness and efficiency, resulting in an excruciating delay of approximately twenty-five minutes from the time our order was taken to the point where we were able to procure our dessert, and even then, no apology was tendered or any effort made to rectify the situation, leading us to question the wisdom of ever returning to this restaurant again.

Z Pizza you are nothing special.

Rubbery salty crust.  Your whole pizza is merely so so and your slices border on abysmal.  Staff didn't seem to care if I was there or not.  The owner was there and that was more important than my late lunch order.

Ok you're organic.  Guess what?  I don't care.  When I want pizza I don't want to feel like I am making a healthy compromise.  I only want something tasty and unhealthy.  That's why I'm eating pizza instead of a salad.  

Ok you have gluten free options.  The only thing sadder than that is a fat kid with no money staring at a bakery counter.  

I don't buy your hype.  Your food is so so at best.  I will continue to order elsewhere.

One thing is for sure, you know what you're getting when you order Domino's Pizza.  I wouldn't say it's the best pizza by any stretch, but you know all that going into it.  I mean when you're a stranger in a very strange land, sometimes you just call the number on your hotel room swipe card!!\n\nDominos is kinda the fast-food of pizza... a bit salty, but then you knew that...

Chompies, I wanted to love you, but you missed the mark. I grew up surrounded by Jewish delis, and had been sincerely missing that being in Arizona. They have classic Jewish favorites and the matzo ball soup, and bagels were hits for our group. However, the quality of food and the service were not consistent throughout the meal. We had to ask multiple times for the complimentary pickles to be delivered to the table, and they arrived as we were finishing out meal. The dish I ordered, someone in the kitchen decided to add bacon to, which very much upset this vegetarian. I was offered another meal, but when I didn't particularly trust anything coming from the kitchen at that point. The meal was comped, which was appreciated, but it didn't change the fact that I was extremely let down by a meal that I was looking forward to. At this point, I have no desire to visit Chompies in the future.

My mom and I came here the day before my wedding to have a more upscale experience than my tried and true vietnamese shop.  The salon itself is lovely.  But for $75 a person, it was a complete waste of money and time.  My french manicure looked as though I could have done it myself.  Same for my mom.  After seeing the poor skills of my manicurist, I opted for a solid color on my toes...and even this was done poorly.  Everyone may speak English and the salon may look upscale, but the quality of the mani and pedi was POOR and I will not be going back.  I was embarrased after leaving but did not have time to go to a real manicurist for a polish change.  Hopefully the shoddy job doesnt show in my wedding photos.

A Korean Taco Stand!?  Sounds so cool, I HAD to try it!  I love little places like this and I was so excited to give it a try.

But I hate to say it... I was pretty disappointed.  The tacos themselves were pretty good, but they put so much 'filler' with them to make it look like you're getting lots of food... that really annoyed me.

They brag about the "3 different kids of lettuce,"  but really people... do you get excited about eating lettuce??  I don't!!  The meat hidden under the mounds of lettuce was pretty yummy but I don't feel like I should have to search to get to it.

I felt the same about their 'sweet potato fries."  It's very clever how the cut them suuuuuuper thin so when they put a giant handfull of them on your plate, it looks like a massive mound of food.  But in reality there's nothing substantial there at all.

There was some kind of yummy dark brown sauce that came with the tacos that was super delicious.  If they had given me tortillas actually FILLED with their meat, with some of that sauce and a LITTLE bit of lettuce... I would have been a happy girl.  But instead, I left feeling pretty jipped.  So disappointing.

When I initially relocated to this vicinity, I was thoroughly relishing the hospitable ambiance of this establishment, primarily due to the congenial demeanor of the personnel. Nonetheless, if the cordial staff could initiate accurately fulfilling my beverage requests (twice erroneously prepared within a brief two-day period), it would significantly enhance my propensity to patronize this business, rather than opting for the Starbucks kiosk situated at Target, merely across the adjacent parking area. Such subpar customer service does not align with my expectations from The Bux, I regret to express.

When I first moved here, I was really enjoying this place because of the very friendly staff. However, if the very friendly staff could start getting my drink order correct (wrong twice in the span of two days), it would make me more likely to go there, rather than to the Starbucks counter at Target, just across the parking lot. Not the level of customer service I expect from The Bux, sorry.   :(
Food good, service not so good. For 4 people on duty and 7 patrons I would say waiting over 20 mintues to get our bill is ridiculous but try them for yourself.

I didn't love my food at Super Burrito, but to be fair, I must tell you that 3 trailer-park, hillbilly, in-bred, DOUCHEBAGS, interrupted my famous "Taco Inspection!" 

We arrived at Super Burrito at about 2AM on a Friday night (first mistake) and immediately upon entering the restaurant and identifying myself as "The Taco Inspector," these three ass-clowns got in our face and would NOT stop talking crap--even after we got our food and sat down. 

The date ended with the Scottsdale Police showing up, and well, at least we got a couple minutes of these cock-noses on video with my flip camera! 

You can see the video at www.thetacoreview.com 

From what I remember, my tacos were kind of bland, but we will return for a repeat-inspection.

Peace from The Taco Inspector!

"Hey, Sandy, so the other day I was at --" 
"Stop talking! There's not enough time! The meat is cooking faster than we can pull it off the grill! HUSTLE!" 
Whenever people are trying out KBBQ for the first time, they always make the same observation: "So you're telling me I am paying money to cook for myself AND serve myself?" You are, indeed! 
The thing about Honey Pig is that the servers will actually place the meat on the grill for you, but the actual cooking is up to you. So if you are two people like we were in the conversation above, it doesn't leave too much time for conversation because you are too busy cooking, chewing, timing, grabbing, flipping, drinking, etc. Notice how "waiting" is not one of the above? AIN'T NOBODY GOT TIME FOR THAT. Since the servers are putting the meat (+ kimchi, bean sprouts, and onions) on the grill for you, there's not a lot of freedom to pace the cooking process. 
My friend and I opted for AYCE, so each round just seemed rushed. The only time anything was NOT was in the beginning, when we asked for water - they said OK, and then forgot - and at the end, when we asked for the check - they said OK, and then forgot. Hmm. So perhaps not the best first and last impression.

Bf and I stopped here prior to the KA show.  Emeril's New Orleans Fish House is located inside the MGM where KA was playing, which made it convenient.

Our server was hospitable.  I drink a lot of water with my meals.  My water glass was never empty.  

We had the tuna tacos, which were $17 for three small servings.  I didn't like the sweet flavor and the price point was too high.  We also had a side of mushrooms, which was $9.  It was equally overpriced.  The mozzarella salad was perfectly balanced.  It was light and flavorful.

One of the closer Wendy's. My wife and I do not go here very often anymore. We had food missing from our order, cold or burnt sandwiches, and salads that were very wilted. 

The lights for the restaurant and drive through are turned off some nights at 9 or 10 pm. It doesn't seem like they are open. We went through the drive through and were the only ones there. A lot of service errors for just us being served. 

Would gladly go back if the service and quality went back up.

"This evening marked my second venture to Sakana, a culinary establishment renowned for its proficiency in creating delectable Japanese-inspired dishes. My initial visit transpired during the luncheon hour, whereupon I opted for the lunch sushi special, an offering that, much to my delight, proved to be a veritable cornucopia of sushi, far surpassing my expectations in both quantity and quality, with the Cali rolls in particular, demonstrating an exceptional level of craftsmanship and flavor. However, upon conducting a comparative analysis of the remaining pieces comprising the meal, it became apparent that their quality was somewhat variable, oscillating between mediocrity and middling excellence. Undeterred by this minor drawback, I decided to pay another visit to Sakana this evening, with the intention of sampling their Cali rolls, unagi, and edamame. Much to my satisfaction, the Cali rolls exhibited the same exceptional quality as during my previous visit, with each piece appearing as though it had been meticulously crafted mere moments prior to my arrival. The unagi, a dish consisting of grilled eel, was truly remarkable, boasting generous portions of succulent eel, served at an optimal temperature, thereby heightening its inherent flavors and textures. Unfortunately, the service encountered during this visit left much to be desired, as I experienced an extended delay in receiving a replenishment of my beverage. Notwithstanding this minor inconvenience, my overall assessment of Sakana remains neutral, neither exceptionally laudatory nor disparagingly critical, but rather, a testament to the establishment's ability to deliver a satisfying dining experience, albeit with minor fluctuations in consistency."

Tonight was my second visit to Sakana. My first visit was for the lunch sushi special. More sushi than I could eat, for 10 bucks. Although the Cali roles were outstanding, the other pieces were average. Tonight I stopped in for Cali rolls, unagi, and edamame. The Cali rolls looked and tasted like they had been made 30 minutes before I arrived. The Unagi was outstanding! Huge pieces of eel, served warmed, tasty and filling. Service kinda sucked, waited a long time for a drink refil. Overall, average. Will return for sushi lunch special.

Stopped in for lunch a few weeks ago, the verdict: overpriced mediocre and slow. The Reuben was unremarkable and I nearly died of thirst. Latenight is better with plenty of half and half stouts (ie black and blue) and generally likeable live music on weekends.

Our cat recently came down with some health issues that we could not afford to address. He was in pain and we decided the humane thing was to put him to sleep. We went to the ARL and asked the receptionist there if we had any other options available to us. \"Well basically the only thing you can do is sign him over for euthanasia\" she said in the most uncaring, apathetic voice possible. We were heartbroken of course. \"Go wait by that door and someone will meet you.\" After a few minutes another woman came out and took the carrier. \"I'll bring your carrier back out in a minute.\" We said no, that's okay, keep the carrier. She said okay and took our cat to the back. And that was it. No kind words, no sympathetic gestures, no \"Would you like a moment before I take him?\" No \"I'm sorry.\" Nothing. For us this was one of the worst days of our lives but nobody at the ARL seemed to care, or at least have been trained to pretend to care, one bit. \n\nThey get a couple stars for offering a necessary service. But other than that, this place will only be associated with making a terrible day that much worse with their lack of caring or empathy.

We have had good experiences at Orange Sky, but the one on Nov. 1 was not so.  Service was good, though no one could figure out who was to serve our water for the first 15 minutes we were there.  The food (lobster bisque, king crab, and steak) also tasted good, but within about 4 hours, my wife and I both became violently ill.  I reported this the next day to the hostess, who seemed completely unconcerned.  So, we also reported it directly to management, mostly so they could investigate and possibly prevent others from having the same experience.  Management, however, was also not interested in how food poisoning occurred in its restaurant.  For the price tag you pay to eat here, I'd recommend someplace else.  Most restaurants of this caliber put food safety very high on their priorities list.  Not so at Orange Sky.  (We also were there to celebrate a special occasion.  The restaurant was not half full.  Where did they put us???  Next to the restroom.)

"Bah. I am utterly perplexed and unimpressed by the exorbitant prices and mediocre quality of food at Lemeac, especially when compared to the diverse array of delectable and reasonably-priced dining options available in Vancouver. It appears that the standard practice in Montreal is to charge excessive amounts for individual entrees, without the accompaniment of a salad or dessert, which I find to be an unacceptable and incomprehensible practice. Despite my desire for an extraordinary and memorable dining experience, I have yet to encounter anything that would lead me to believe that Montreal's culinary offerings surpass those of Vancouver. It seems that my taste buds and expectations have been irreparably shaped by my residency in Vancouver, and I fear that I may never truly appreciate the unique qualities of Montreal's gastronomic scene."

Bah. I dunno. Expensive, 'OK' food, but SO overpriced.

I've probably just been in Vancouver too long where the options for dinner at a reasonable price (i.e., $50/person including wine) are numerous and delicious. Or maybe i'm just taking resto suggestions from the wrong people (read: people who make way more money than me). But i wasn't impressed with Lemeac. 

I guess if i'm giong to order an entree for $36 I expect a salad and dessert with it too! It just doesn't compute for me unless i'm ordering lobster or something. But it seems like this is the norm all over Montreal (or again, at the places people suggest to me). I know there are tons of great dives but I was hoping for a really awe inspiring "OMG food in Montreal is so much better than Vancouver" experience and on my last day, I have yet to experience. 

I guess I really am a Vancouverite...

I visited Benny's in the company of my daughter, with the intention of partaking in a traditional morning meal, and we placed an order for a selection of dishes that are commonly associated with a typical breakfast, specifically scrambled eggs, bacon, toast, and home fries. However, upon consuming the items, I was disappointed to discover that the texture of the scrambled eggs was unpleasant, and the appearance of the bacon was somewhat unappealing, possessing a scrawny and irregular shape. Furthermore, while my daughter expressed satisfaction with the home fries, I would have preferred the option of potato style over the deep-fried French fry style. Additionally, the coffee served was of poor quality, which, although not unexpected for a diner-style establishment, was still a disappointment. Considering the fact that I paid the full price of $10 for each breakfast, I felt that the quality of the food was subpar and did not meet my expectations, leading me to suspect that synthetic ingredients, such as eggs cooked in a microwave and pre-cooked microwave bacon, were employed in its preparation. Moreover, the service we received was inadequate, as after our food was delivered, we failed to see the waitress again, leaving us feeling neglected. In conclusion, owing to my underwhelming experience, I do not plan on returning to Benny's for breakfast in the future, and I regret spending the money.

I went to Benny's with my daughter for breakfast and we ordered a pretty standard breakfast: scrambled eggs, bacon, toast,home fries.

-scrambles eggs had a bad texture and the bacon was kinda scraggly looking 
-my daughter liked the home fries but I prefer the option for potato style versus deep fried French fry style.
-coffee was terrible, not unusual for a diner style breakfast place

Had I paid the $2.99 early bird special price I would shrug it off as you get what you pay for but this was full price $10 each breakfast so I expected real food. Felt like the food was made using synthetic ingredients like eggs in the microwave (I've seen it done this way with my own eyes) and pre-cooked microwave bacon. Actually I feel like my breakfast was made in the microwave.

Service wasn't great. We were seated and the order was taken pretty quickly but after the food was delivered we never saw the waitress again. 

I don't personally think I'll go back to Benny's for breakfast and was disappointed I spent the money.

I joined Kansas City Barbecue Society for $35 just to be able to get free day passes to RD. I was really interested in trying some of their private label wines.  Unfortunately at the cash register I found out you can't buy any alcohol from them unless you have a liquor license.  Then I had to wait for about a half an hour to get a refund after they overcharged me $6 for an 11 lb. bar of Callebaut dark chocolate that had been entered in their computer wrong.  Not a happy camper.

"We experienced immense dissatisfaction with the service we received. Arriving a few minutes prior to a group of three individuals, we registered our presence well in advance of their arrival. Unfortunately, our presence was utterly disregarded. As a party of two, we were unable to secure seating at the bar area. Instead, the party of three was accommodated at an unoccupied table, while we were informed that the table was excessively large for our modest party. Following a ten-minute delay, we were eventually seated at a comparable table. However, we were not provided with menus, unlike the adjacent table, which received prompt attention. The hostess exhibited considerable discourtesy towards us. We placed orders for various items not featured on the conveyor belt, but only half of them were delivered. Consequently, we were compelled to reorder the remaining items, as they were allegedly misplaced by the restaurant staff. This encounter was undoubtedly adverse. It appears that this establishment caters exclusively to large parties, as we have previously visited with sizable groups and enjoyed satisfactory experiences."

I just got back from London last week and have been craving Indian food ever since i got back after eating it every other day while there. I came across Taza on Eastern and saw they had a  lunch buffet and gave it a shot. The service is great and the decor is nice as well. Do like the very BIG flat screen they have too. There are a lot of choices for the lunch buffet and it is a good deal for your $ but the food was very dry and not very tasty. The best thing i had there was the naan and soup. Looks like i will have to wait until i go back to London to get some quality Indian

this place is only getting 2 stars bc:

-i was already drunk
-met some really cool asians from texas
-the dj was alright
-my boo got me a double shot of patron.

other than that... it was pretty DEAD.

since i was drunk getting there.. which hotel was this club at any way?

Ramen's excessive sodium content proved detrimental to my gustatory sensibilities, rendering it challenging to assess the inherent flavors of the constituent elements, as the pervasive salinity effaced or overpowered their distinctive characteristics, thereby eliciting regret; notwithstanding, the establishment boasted an aesthetically pleasing ambiance and commendable hospitality.
The ramen was too salty for my taste. I can't tell if the ingredients were tasty.  The saltiness masked or overwhelmed everything.  Too bad.  Nice place and good service.

Made a reservation a month in advance for 7, noting that it was an anniversary dinner (and hoping for one of the curtained off couples tables.) Called the night of and asked if we could change the reservation to 7:30 since we were running late.  We were informed that we could not and that we needed to make it within 15 min of our original reservation in order to be seated.  We rushed and made it right at the \"cutoff\" mark, and were seated at a huge table, I assumed because all the couples tables were full.  After getting settled in, we looked around only to find the restaurant dead empty.  We were one of maybe 5 parties there.  Why the rush?  Would have given only one star if not for the great food, and having plenty of leftovers for lunch the next day.  The server was quite attentive, so I think it's just the hostess desk that's not up to par.\n\nNote; this will be a long meal so plan accordingly.  You can't do this place quick, its an experience.

Wow. What a let down! My husband and I stayed at the Planet Hollywood hotel and they gave us coupons for the buffet. We stopped in one morning for breakfast because we'd read lots of good reviews about it...and let's just say we were seriously disappointed. And glad we used those coupons so we didn't pay full price for it!

Everything - and I mean EVERYTHING - was cold!! Our first go around we loaded up with eggs, hash browns, bacon, sausage, biscuits and gravy, etc. and not one single thing was hot. Not even warm. Cold. That is not the experience you expect when going to a buffet. We left most of that food on our plates and made a second trip to see if maybe we just needed to stir things around or pick from the bottom of the trays, try getting things from a different area - but arrived back at our table to find the second round cold as well. Boo!

Highly disappointing experience, since everything tasted good - those biscuits and gravy would have been a delight - but who wants to eat cold eggs and meat for breakfast? Which left us wondering too how safe the food was if it isn't kept at a proper temperature! 

They had a decent selection and variety, and for the price I'm sure it would be a good value if the food was actually edible. I've had much better buffets in Vegas. Won't be going back!

"The personnel at Lonnie's exhibit a consistent lack of proficiency in their customer service, manifesting in a discourteous and sluggish demeanor during each visit, culminating in an accelerated departure at the conclusion of operating hours; despite this, my return visits are motivated by the superior quality and variety of cane glass beads available, which serves as the sole purpose of my patronage."

"Underwhelming culinary encounter marred by subpar victuals, lackluster hospitality, and an unjustified tariff.\n\nHaving partaken in delectable repasts at esteemed establishments such as Delmonico's and Emeril's Fish House, my expectations were unfortunately not met at Table 10, warranting a deduction of one star for the gastronomical experience, another for the quality of service, and a third for the price point, as the cost did not align with the quality of the meal. Generally, when one indulges in a lavish dining experience, they anticipate savoring flavorful cuisine and receiving attentive service; regrettably, this venue failed to meet those expectations. While it may be considered a slight improvement over the Fish House, whose ambiance and fare are equally uninviting, I would not recommend revisiting Table 10. "

Very disappointing food, service, and experience.\n\nI've eaten at Delmonicos and Emeril's Fish House, so I should have been prepared for the overall poor experience of going to Table 10.  I deducted a star for the taste of the food, a star for the service, and a star for the price point.  Usually when hyou pay for an expensive meal, you way quality tasting food and service.  However, this place was just a disappointment.  I will never go back again.  The only bright spot I can say is that this place is better than the Fish House.  That place is disgusting.

This is for the curbside check in people at the east economy lot. First of all, I don't appreciate being there 95 minutes before my flight, having to wait 6 or 7 minutes for the people in front of me to get done, then get turned away because I'm 88 minutes from my flight. The guy running the show, who isn't very nice, says his computer won't let him do it. I think it's an excuse to be lazy. If it really is the computer thing, they should really build in a grace period. 5 minutes is fine. 

The curbside check in thing is a great service, but they are really turning into luggage nazis. 

Bottom line: make sure you are there 100 minutes or more before your flight or else you'll be pissed off and stressed out like I was.

Walked in for a small bite to eat and saw all kinds of fried stuff. Wings fish (multiple species), shrimp gizzards etc.  I was about to get some of the gizzards but the lady working there said it was wing day.\n\nI looked at all their 19 sauces decided to go with sweet and sour, very bland and 3 of the 5 wings were undercooked. Normally I'd eat them but they were far from being done.  So I won't go back!

Uggghhh. I have been here a few times, and it is simply not all that great.  The servers continually come around with carts full of greasy, fried Chinese food that may or may not be hot.

The service is terrible and only about one in three dishes is particularly good.  The fried shrimp balls and the egg tarts are among the better options.

However, and this is a big "however", if you like the idea of a Chinese buffet that is brought to your table by people who speak no English or French, you may like it.  There are also lots of Chinese people who eat here, so i am open to the possibility of being way off base on this one. Some of the fried items my friends who insist on coming here rave about taste eerily similar to lukewarm Chicken McNuggets to me.

If you have a group of friends and a couple of pre-dinner drinks before coming here, you might love this. It may also be good for those who want to eat in preparation for something like the World Chinese Food Eating Competition (or poor, hungry college students).

"It is with profound disappointment that I must recount the unsatisfactory dining experience my companion and I endured at a certain eatery in Montreal. Specifically, the server assigned to our table exhibited an utter lack of enthusiasm and interest in attending to our needs, responding to our queries with a perceptible air of defensiveness and reluctance. Furthermore, the culinary offerings, which were limited to pre-prepared pastries and cakes, required an unacceptable duration of thirty minutes to arrive, thereby threatening our ability to arrive at the airport in a timely fashion. When we politely inquired as to the cause of such an extensive delay, our server's response was tinged with discourtesy and annoyance. Additionally, we were informed that certain menu items, specifically frappes, were unavailable for ordering despite their presence on the menu, with the server offering an unconvincing explanation regarding the absence of a blender. This series of unfortunate events left us feeling bewildered and dissatisfied, and we were compelled to seek alternative dining arrangements in order to avoid any further inconvenience."

The only negative dining experience I had in Montreal. The lady behind the counter was super friendly but our server was disinterested and defensive. The food, which was already made (just pasteries, cake) took 30 minutes, and we wound up being late for our flight. No, we probably shouldn't have gone here right before our flight, but who would have thought it would take so long to bring me a piece of cake I literally pointed at?

More over, when we politely asked to have it to go because of the flight, she was really rude.

Oh, and they also have frappe's on the menu but not available for order...what's that about. She just said they didn't have a blender. I guess that may be, but then why have them on the menu? Or perhaps she just didn't want to make them? The world may never know...

I was here last year. Not impressed. Food was not memorable. Atmosphere was too casual if that's possible. Too many flies in this way-open, patio-style restaurant. Service was - well I don't remember. But what I do remember was that there is nothing about this place that says, \"Come back!\" ...Nada. My experience wasn't awful but I have no incentive to return when there are so many other places to eat at Tempe Marketplace.

My husband and I sat at the bar for dinner before we had to catch a flight. The food was overall good, but didn't justify the prices. I could eat at Kabuto for what we paid to eat there and still left hungry. We paid close to $300 for 2 people and I didn't even order a drink.\n\nThe rock shrimp was really good, so we ordered another one which then came out soggy and also took awhile because the kitchen was backed up. Everything else was pretty standard with regards to the sushi we ordered. Overall, the food was ok but I don't think I'll return when there are so many other options in the city off the strip.

They bring great DJ's but the club itself just feels awkward.  I feel embarrassed for my town when global DJ's come (i.e. Adam Freeland) and the crowd is lame (which ALWAYS happens).  It's just not the right crowd or place for these DJ's.  I wish they would take the DJ thing and move it over to Bar Smith. I feel like they'd do it right there...

"My expectations for an exceptional experience at this establishment were profoundly disillusioned upon my departure, as the subpar facilities failed to live up to the prestige associated with the renowned Canyon Ranch name and the substantial admission fee of $35. In light of this, I would unequivocally advise potential patrons to seek alternative destinations for their financial investment."

I came in with great expecations for this place, but walked out pretty dissapointed.  The facilities were unimpressive for both the Canyon Ranch name and the $35 admission fee.  I would strongly suggest taking your money and visiting elsewhere.

"While the culinary offerings boasted delectable ingredients such as chili and lime shrimp, grilled scallops accompanied by mango salsa, et cetera, sadly, the gastronomical experience fell short of expectations. Not only did the flavors fail to impress, but the prices were also exorbitant, with a meager four pieces of shrimp commanding a steep price tag of around $14. Furthermore, the scallops were inadequately cooked. However, the service staff exhibited exceptional friendliness, politeness, and attentiveness. The establishment's aesthetic, with its striking and beautiful decor, may appeal to those seeking a fashionable drinking establishment. Unfortunately, the subpar cuisine precludes any future visits motivated by gastronomical desires."

It was really just barely okay. The descriptions of the food sound heavenly...chili and lime shrimp, grilled scallops with mango salsa, etc. The presentation is nice. But the flavors were really lacking. The food was definitely overpriced; we got 4 pieces of shrimp for something like $14. Our scallops were undercooked. \n\nThe servers were very friendly, polite, and attentive. The decor is definitely striking and beautiful. I think I would come back if I were looking for a trendy place to drink. But the food won't get me back in the door, unfortunately.

I was very surprised by my visit tonight. This was not my first visit to BJ's. At our table of seven chairs, 4 of them were broken. This is a huge accident waiting to happen.   We started out our meal with the calamari appetizer. This was very good. No issues there.  Then with the meal, I ordered the margarita flat bread. I have ordered this before and loved it. Tonight was not the same. I think it had been sitting under the heat lamp for awhile before it was brought to the table. The last time I remember that it had more fresh basil on it, too. This time the basil didn't even cover the entire pizza and it was not very fresh. I couldn't even taste it. My daughter ordered the shrimp scampi. She asked for some grated Parmesan on it and they brought her some packets of Parmesan and told her they couldn't find the grater.  Really?  I am giving them 2 stars only because I know how good it can be ... how good it has been.  I don't know what is going on here but they need some serious attention from upper management to get it back to where it used to be starting with the broken chairs.

I don't even know where to begin....which is ironic because it was hard to find this typical east valley type bar-in-a-strip-mall. I really wasn't sure what to make of the place with the crabby face on the door. \nThere are couple different areas to the place and when packed I could see it having a college house party charm. But empty, you just get the smell of fried food and punching while watching younger folks who think they got dressed up to go to Scottsdale but instead ended up in a Gilbert strip mall.\nI was here to listen to some accoustic sets - not the best  venue for that. Distracted by the TVs, Golden Tee video screen, and a real punching bag game machine (as macho as it gets boys)...So I had one drink, one drink only ($6.50 for Jameson's...really Toby?!?!) and am still perplexed at what this place is trying to be and why they would let people punch a bag during an accoustic music set. Big patio outside, big room inside with a stage and punching machine, and a smaller room for darts and pool. It was kind of like the place I worked back in Iowa that had a buffet, bowling alley, roller rink and minigolf. you can't be all things to all people...but maybe in Gilbert that's a possibility.

We attended this venue for a friend's pre-wedding celebration this weekend, having previously arranged a booking for six individuals at a specified hour and furnished our contact information. Upon arriving, we were informed that no such reservation existed. Although the female staff member was polite, she claimed she had received a call regarding a group of males but was oblivious to its significance and lacked a phone number. Fortunately, a single seat became available, albeit with a prolonged wait for additional openings. However, the representative did not attempt to rectify the situation or offer a discount. The gentleman whose festivities it was had a well-groomed appearance, but that was the extent of it. The rest of us received nothing. It was indeed a disappointment. Therefore, it is advisable to refrain from relying on confirmed appointments.

We went to this place for a my buddy's bachelor party this weekend. We called and set up a reservation for 6 at a specific time and left our number. We got there and there they told us there was no reservation. The woman working was nice enough, but said she got a call about some guys but didn't know what it meant and had no phone number. They happen to have one seat available, but it would be hours until any other openings so...that was it She didn't try to fix the issue, she didn't give us a discount. The guy who's party it was had a nice shave, but that was it. The rest of got nothing. It was a real bummer. So, don't believe your reservation I guess.

I habitually consume my meals at rapid and economical Mexican establishments, as I am not particularly fond of upscale eateries such as Garcias, Macayos, and Arriba, et cetera. However, I have been diligently seeking a superior, genuine Mexican restaurant that offers a tranquil dining experience for a considerable duration. Following my observation of this venue's four-star rating and its nomenclature in Spanish, I chose to sample its culinary offerings. Upon the arrival of the tortilla chips and salsa, my initial enthusiasm subsided somewhat, but I endeavor not to form judgments based solely on such ancillary items. We requested a simple cheese crisp as an hors d'oeuvre, which, to my surprise, proved to be relatively satisfying; its texture was crunchy and not excessively oleaginous. Unfortunately, the primary dishes failed to meet my expectations. The tacos were uninspired and lacking in flavor, while the beans and rice were unremarkable. In general, this establishment serves the standard Americanized Mexican cuisine that is customarily fried, insipid, and covered in oil, similar to the majority of Mexican restaurants. There is nothing extraordinary or genuine about this place. Consequently, I shall not be revisiting it. My pursuit of an excellent, authentic Mexican dining experience continues.

I usually eat at fast/cheap Mexican places because I am not a fan of places like Garcias, macayos, Arriba etc but I have been looking for a good/authentic sit down Mexican food restaurant for a while. After I saw that this place had a 4 star rating and a name in Spanish I decided to give it a try. I was pretty excited to see actual Mexicans eating there! When the chips and salsa arrived my excitement died a bit but I try not to judge on chips and salsa alone. We ordered a plain cheese crisp as an appetizer and it was actually pretty good; it was crispy and not too oily. The main dishes arrived and they were a major disappointment! The tacos were oily and bland. The beans and rice were not much better. Overall this is typical Americanized Mexican food; overly fried, bland, and greasy like most Mexican places. Nothing special or authentic here. I shan't be returning. My search continues...

The first time i walked into One Love Vapors was back in early October and i knew they were just newly opened. Saw them on yelp and decided to see whats up. I walked in and everything was nice, some music playing, i was greeted, and the guy helping me was very energetic and very friendly. 

Now, I haven't been able to drive by again and visit until just about a week ago. I wanted to see what was new, their juices, see if the same guys work there, and just to hang out. I walked in, it was extremely quiet, the guy who i remember came out and asked what i needed. I just wanted to try some juice and he gave me the menu(s). i chose a few and he let me try them. out of maybe 5 flavors, 3 tasted burnt. unfortunately.  This guy changed in a few months i think. Either he was just tired that day, or he just doesnt like the business. This visit was nothing like my first. Customer Service completely fell and i'm uninterested in ever wanting to visit.

2 stars for a couple juices that i sampled and liked.

The drinks were pretty good; I had the dirty chai. The service, was the worst I've ever received. 

I felt extremely unwelcome and it took 10 minutes to make a couple drinks. During that time, the two people working behind the counter never looked at us and took their sweet time making the drinks. 

We considered leaving several times. 

I will not be going back.

I decided to check this place out because I come to this center to run errands.The inside is clean and the cashier was friendly.\n\n   I ordered a torta de lengua which is cow tongue.Frankly, I found the torta to be lackluster in flavor and it just didn't meet my expectations . I doubt that I will be returning anytime soon.

Tonight marked my maiden visit to Pisces, and I must confess that my culinary experience was largely satisfactory, with the exception of a few minor hiccups in the service department. The sushi options presented were innovative and diverse, and the rolls my companion and I opted for (Crunchy Spicy Tuna, Leo, Eel Special, Spicy Tuna) were indeed delectable. Nonetheless, the attention accorded to us by our server left much to be desired.

I observed as our sushi languished at the bar, awaiting collection, for an approximate duration of ten minutes. During this time, our server appeared to be engaged in aimless loitering within the restaurant, displaying an evident lack of urgency in attending to our needs. Upon the eventual delivery of our fare, it transpired that our server had erroneously requested that tobiko be added to the incorrect roll. While this mishap was rectified upon my request for additional tobiko on the side, our server vanished without a trace, only to resurface at the conclusion of our repast. At this juncture, she proffered the side of tobiko with a smug remark, "well, I suppose it's a bit tardy," which struck me as somewhat condescending.

In light of this experience, I shall refrain from patronizing this establishment again, particularly in the server's section whose name I managed to procure from the receipt. It is unfortunate that an otherwise commendable dining experience can be marred by subpar service, and I sincerely hope that the management will take cognizance of this issue and implement measures to address it.

Tonight was my first time at Pisces, and I have nothing to bad to say about the food. The sushi options were very creative and the rolls my boyfriend and I ordered (Crunchy Spicy Tuna, Leo, Eel Special, Spicy Tuna) were delicious. However, the service was not as satisfying.

I watched as our sushi sat at the bar, waiting for pick up, for about ten minutes. Meanwhile, our server milled about the restaurant doing nothing in particular. When our food was finally delivered, she had requested that tobiko be put on the wrong roll. Not a problem, I just requested some extra on the side for the naked roll. Our server agreed to the request then disappeared. She didn't come near our table again until the meal was over, and then offered me the side of tobiko with a smug, "well I guess it's a little late".

I got her name off the receipt, and if I return, I will not be sitting in her section. The food at a restaurant can be incredible, but bad service can make or break a meal. I hope that this is something the management recognizes and works on.

The quality of the coffee at this establishment is contingent upon the accuracy of the order fulfillment, which unfortunately occurs with a mere fifty percent frequency. Thus, patrons should exercise caution when placing their orders, lest they receive an inferior beverage. The breakfast menu items are delectable, provided one has sufficient time to await their preparation, however, it is advisable to avoid the luncheon options, as there are superior alternatives in the vicinity for a comparable price point. Notwithstanding the aforementioned deficiencies, the staff maintains a congenial demeanor, albeit their proficiency in managing the queue could benefit from additional instruction or increased personnel.

This establishment professes to embody the essence of a "traditional British pub," and the new proprietors have unquestionably taken great strides to create an ambiance reminiscent of such an institution, albeit with a few notable exceptions. Specifically, the prices charged for beverages are, in my opinion, somewhat exorbitant. Eight dollars and fifty cents for a single pint of generic imported beer (be it Newcastle, Sapporo, or Carlsberg) strikes me as a tad excessive. Furthermore, the taste of the Murphy's Irish stout, while certainly uncommon in these parts, was slightly disappointing. Upon paying twenty-seven dollars (including gratuity, mind you) for three pints, my fleeting impression of being in a genuine British pub quickly dissipated. Personally, I would prefer to consume pints of locally brewed, fresher, and more affordable beer a mere few blocks away at Dieu Du Ciel. As for the culinary offerings, my dining companion reported that the homemade egg noodles and roasted eggplant ragout were quite flavorful. The menu itself featured several enticing options, although the Ploughman's Lunch priced at thirteen dollars deviated slightly from the customary fare found in traditional pubs. However, given the location in Montreal, it is not entirely surprising that the menu leaned towards more refined and ostentatious selections. In conclusion, while not entirely successful in its attempt to recreate a classic British pub experience, this establishment may still appeal to the tastes of the after-work Ubisoft crowd.

This place boasts of being a "traditional British pub," and in the short time it took the new owners to convert this former Italian café, they have undoubtedly gone to lengths to make it look the part! 

I will say this though: I found the price of drinks to be more than a little bit cheeky. $8.50 for a pint of generic import beer (Newcastle, Sapporo, Carlsberg) is a bit rich! Are you having a laugh?! 

They did have Murphy's Irish stout, which you don't see elsewhere too often, but even then it tasted a bit off. After paying $27 (tip included - we're not REALLY in England) for 3 pints, any illusion I had of being in a traditional British pub fell by the wayside. 

No thanks, I'd much rather drink pints of cheaper and fresher tasting local beer a few blocks away at Dieu Du Ciel. 

I can't speak to the quality of the food because I did not eat, but my companion said the homemade egg noodles and roasted eggplant ragout was tasty. It definitely looked and smelled very appetizing! The menu had some good looking choices. Apart from the Ploughman's Lunch for $13, it's not close to your typical traditional pub fare - but then again we are in Montreal so it's predictable that menus and ingredients skew towards high end and somewhat showy. 

All in all, just a bit off the mark, but the after-work Ubisoft crowd will love it!

Pancakes are just flour, egg, milk, and fluff... so why are they ten dollars here?  I think this place is overrated.  If you have a friend that is a good cook, convince him or her to make you breakfast.  It will be better and you will be able to drink water whenever you want.  You can get it yourself and, no doubt, in a timely fashion.  The only disadvantage to the stay at home plan is that you may not be able to watch a great dane down plate of eggs that his owners purchased for him.  That was amazing.  That great dane eats well.

Someone shoot me next time I try to come here.  I don't know why I come back here.  The only saving grace is the service.  Food sucks. The steaks have been flattened by a bus so it's pretty much impossible to have it cooked any way but well done.  The noise level is ridiculous.  I was literally shivering eating dinner, it's so cold.  I guess they have to keep it so cold so they can cool down the outside seating area (and the rest of Las Vegas.)\nIn a word -- sucks.

Ill start with the good. The bartenders are very friendly and make you feel welcome as most wing/bar joints will. Now on to the bad. This is a wing joint. Their wings are on the low end of the totem pole when it comes to size, flavor, and freshness. Ive been in 3 times and the first time my wings were literally cold. Some were luke warm. Not crispy, not freshly cooked, and 8 of the 12 wings were tiny. The other 2 visits were a little better but when it boils down to it Beef o Bradys and Bdubs both kill this place.  Its a nice layout, is clean, and has mostly friendly staff but unfortunately its not a hospital so the food has to be good as well to get more than 2 stars.

I have been a regular patron of this establishment in the past, as they offer extended hours of operation, which has enabled me to visit them with great frequency. However, I must say that the quality of their coffee has been subpar in the past, with the beverages often being served at an unpleasantly low temperature, even when they were freshly brewed. Therefore, I decided to sample their tea selection on my most recent visit, hoping for a more satisfying and piping hot drinking experience. Unfortunately, my expectations were not met, as the water utilized for the preparation of the tea was not adequately heated, resulting in a disappointingly tepid beverage. It is my sincere hope that management will address these issues and prioritize the quality of their offerings, as the ambiance and staff friendliness are certainly appealing aspects of this venue.

"My sentiments regarding the culinary excursion we embarked upon yesterday evening were, in a nutshell, rather tepid. Although the ambiance of the establishment exuded an aura of conviviality, the gastronomical offerings themselves left much to be desired. Specifically, the French fries, which I had anticipated would serve as a delectable complement to my meal, were unfortunately overcooked to an unfortunate degree, rendering them somewhat lacking in texture and flavor. Furthermore, the hamburger that I had ordered, while certainly palatable, did not exactly bowl me over with its inherent quality or uniqueness. In point of fact, it was rather unremarkable and failed to elicit even a modicum of enthusiasm on my part. All things considered, I would venture to say that our dining experience was, at best, unmemorable."
Meh! it's just OK. The fries were over cooked and the burger was just another burger. Nothing to write home about.

Portions were very small. The food I got (butter chicken) wasn't bad, but a little too salty. But $7 for the tiniest portion ever. A restaurant can make up for price by adding value (friendly service, great ambience), but Wok Box fails on those fronts as well. Next time I'm at that mall and hungry, I'll walk next door to Chipotle and get a better value for my $7.

I usually love Jamba Juice, but this location is lacking. I've been here a few times now and every time there has been a wait. The last visit, there were 4 people ahead of me already waiting for their orders with only one girl making the smoothies. So it was a 10+ minute wait for my order. I ordered a strawberry bowl which comes with granola and topped with bananas ad fresh strawberries. As the cashier was assembling the bowl, he stopped to take someone else's order, handled cash and then proceeded to assemble my bowl again. He did put on gloves but did not wash his hands before putting on the gloves. So pretty much he put on dirty gloves. I used to work in the food industry and that was totally unacceptable. Too bad...looks like I have to go to a farther location to get my smoothie fix.

The Wynn's Sugar & Ice, nestled within the opulent esplanade, presents an unfortunate paradox; its proximity to an array of high-end boutiques notwithstanding, this eatery falls short of its potential as an ideal refuge for those seeking a delectable respite prior to embarking upon the vibrant Las Vegas Strip. Lamentably, a multitude of drawbacks sullies the experience, beginning with an interminable wait for one's culinary selections to arrive at their table. Furthermore, the menu, though replete with gelato and cookie offerings, proves woefully inadequate for those craving a more substantial repast, such as a salad or sandwich; the selection, in this regard, borders on the anemic. Our order of the grilled chicken panini, much to our dismay, materialized as nothing more than sliced deli chicken, rather than the promised grilled chicken breast, served on a bed of greasy bread and accompanied by an overpowering saltiness courtesy of the cheese and aioli. While Sugar & Ice may cater to those with a pronounced sweet tooth, individuals seeking a satisfying meal or snack would do well to explore alternative options, as this establishment fails to deliver an experience commensurate with its luxurious surroundings.

One of the only disappointments at the Wynn

Sugar & Ice is located in the esplanade at the Wynn.  Near the many boutiques, Sugar & Ice should be the perfect place to grab lunch, a snack, or something sweet before venturing out onto the Las Vegas Strip.  Unfortunately, it's far from perfect.  

First of all, you can expect to wait quite some time for your food to be brought to your table.  The menu is quite limited unless you are looking for gelato or cookies.  If you're looking for a salad or sandwich, you will have to make due with very few options.  We ordered the grilled chicken panini.  To our surprise, it was just sliced deli chicken and not a real grilled chicken breast.  The bread was incredibly greasy and the cheese and aioli was way too salty.

If you are looking to satisfy your sweet tooth, this may be a good place to stop by.  But if you are looking for lunch or a more substantial snack, this is not a good option.  Not at all.

I have been to several Planet Fitness since joining a month ago and this location is the worst by far. The bathroom area is always dirty A light has been out in the showers for over a week. Hydro beds don't work right and staff acts like they don't want to be there\n Not a good representation of the chain.

"During my collegiate tenure, I thoroughly enjoyed perusing the assorted collections housed within this establishment alongside my companions on inclement days. It bore an uncanny resemblance to a cinematic sequence of dress-up, albeit one that was privy to our exclusive indulgence. While the experience of browsing held its charm, we encountered some rather haughty sales associates, whose demeanor bordered on fastidiousness. Purchasing garments proved to be an altogether different narrative, as the quality of the attire had experienced a discernible decline over time, rendering it increasingly arduous to chance upon premium labels. Furthermore, the prices associated with these lower-tier offerings could be more effectively procured from alternative sources such as Macy's seasonal clearance sections or even Goodwill outlets. In point of fact, a comparison of costs revealed that this store's prices were uniformly elevated across the board, thereby making it more judicious to seek out comparable items at vintage boutiques in New York City or online marketplaces such as eBay or Etsy."

In college, I loved looking through the racks here with friends on a rainy day.  It was like our own movie montage dress-up moment.  It's fun to browse, but beware that the clerks a bit snotty.\n\nBuying is another story.  The quality of the clothing has gone done over the years and it's more difficult to find high-end brands.  For the lower-end stuff, you can do better with the Macy's sale racks or at Goodwill.  The prices here are high all around in fact--you can do way better on the 70s/80s items at any nearly vintage shop in New York or on eBay or Etsy.

The food was subpar and the service below that.  We initially planned on a complete dining experience here, but after having the Seviche sampler, which only 1 of the 3 choices we selected was even above average we decided to take our taste buds elsewhere.  The decor is very nice, but the food and service don't match that quality.

This ostensible Crowne Plaza has left me utterly perplexed; my incredulity knows no bounds! How can a fourth-floor King Suite possibly compare to Section 8 housing, rather than aligning with the standards of a renowned hotel chain? It appears that I have been transported back in time, to a bygone era reminiscent of my baby-boomer parents' 1980s bungalow (think small, dimly lit, malodorous, and unquestionably 80s). 
  The towels are positively revolting, while the wallpaper peels off the walls in copious amounts. The windowsill harbors an assortment of insects on the interior, and the curtains bear an unmistakable burn from cigarettes. As for the furniture, it exudes a sagging, dubious quality that inspires little confidence. These observations merely scratch the surface of the overall shabbiness that permeates this establishment. 
  We arrived at our accommodations well past midnight, following a grueling drive from Chicago through a relentless snowstorm. My patience had already worn thin, and the clueless night auditor only served to further exacerbate my irritation. Their ineptitude proved maddening, as they quibbled over every detail and failed to produce even a single luggage cart or additional pillow. It was nothing short of a fiasco. 
  In my opinion, everything within these walls appears unkempt, tawdry, and desperately in need of a facelift. As I am compelled to remain here for two more nights, I shall grit my teeth and endure the discomfort. However, I implore those of you who have yet to arrive, to steer clear of this place and seek refuge elsewhere.

"Despite the subpar service we experienced during our previous visit, we have decided to afford Echo & Rig another opportunity to demonstrate their culinary proficiency, as our steaks were indeed impressive, boasting precise cooking techniques and a harmonious balance of flavors. However, it is unfortunate that the service we received did not meet our expectations, particularly when dining downstairs during an early dinner seating. Specifically, we observed a couple departing due to the absence of a server, and upon the arrival of a server, our attempts to garner her attention appeared to be an inconvenience. Notwithstanding, our order was taken with little subsequent interaction, culminating in an abrupt presentation of the check."

Will give Echo & Rig another try because our steaks were amazing, perfectly cooked and flavored. Unfortunately, the service was not up to par. We dined downstairs, early dinner. We watched as one couple left because there was no server in sight. When  one popped up, we seemed to haven disturb her. Took our order, no follow up, just the check.
Very average buffet and a bit expensive for the quality of food. Its about $30 per person on the weekend. The food variety is average for a Vegas buffet althiugh nothing to write home about.

Just ok. Somewhat disappointed as we are looking for a great sports bar we can walk to from the Islands.  Went during happy hour, but couldn't get the happy hour \"special\" (which is a measly $1 off appetizer) because we wanted to sit in the dining room.  Got the fajitas which didn't come with anything (had to pay extra for beans and rice).  Nice size portion of meat, but got charged extra for more tortillas (only came w/ 3) and the waitress didn't tell us we'd get charged - I hate that!  Hubby said his steak was good.  Lots of big screen tvs to watch sports. Service was fair.

Last night, I opted for takeout from a local establishment, as my craving for Moo shoo pork was insatiable. Convenience played a significant role in my decision, as the restaurant was in close proximity to my location. Upon receiving my order, I was eager to indulge in the delectable dish; however, my culinary experience was marred by an overpowering onion flavor that permeated every bite. Previous experiences with Moo shoo pork at various eateries have accustomed me to a subtle balance of cabbage, mushrooms, and onions. Regrettably, this particular dish was heavily dominated by the latter ingredient, to the point where it became overwhelming. Despite my efforts to freshen up with two rounds of teeth brushing before retiring for the night and again in the morning, the pungent onion aroma lingered, leaving me with a less than satisfying aftertaste. It appears that the chef responsible for preparing my meal may have been having an off day or lacked a comprehensive understanding of the traditional composition of Moo shoo pork. As this restaurant enjoys a positive reputation, I believe it is essential for the proprietor to be made aware of the subpar quality of the dish served by the chef on duty.

Ordered take out last night as I was in the mood for Moo shoo pork.  This place is close by so laziness prevailed.  I got the moo-shoo home and I was so hungry I just keep on eating.  I then realized that my whole mouth smelled of onion.  Very much so.  I have had moo-shoo pork in MANY, MANY restaurants.  It consists of a lot of cabbage, mushrooms and some onion.  BUT THIS WAS ONION, ONION, ONION.  I brushed my teeth twice before going to bed and in the morning I could still smell the onion on my breath.  I don't know what happened with this order, but I don't think the chef was on his game or understands what moo-shoo-pork is supposed to be.  This is a well known restaurant that is supposed to be good.  That's why the owner needs to know that chef on duty did not do a good job on this dish.

It was approximately 1:00 AM on a Saturday evening in Las Vegas, and my stomach began to growl with an insatiable hunger, prompting me to seek out a suitable dining establishment. However, upon inquiring with my companion, I discovered that the options available within our immediate vicinity were limited due to the late hour. Specifically, Wolfgang Puck's restaurant located within the MGM Grand was the sole viable choice, given its extended operating hours. 

Upon entering the establishment, I was immediately struck by the imposing appearance of the large circular structures positioned at the entrance. Notwithstanding my initial apprehensions, the staff greeted us warmly and efficiently, despite the bustling atmosphere that permeated the venue. Indeed, one of the unique aspects of Las Vegas is its ability to create the illusion of daytime during the wee hours of the morning. 

From the menu, I selected the Mushroom, Talleggio & Leeks pizza, which promised to satiate my late-night cravings. Unfortunately, the execution of the dish fell short of my expectations, as the raw leeks overpowered the other flavors, rendering the overall experience somewhat unpleasant. Furthermore, the server required an inordinate amount of time to deliver my beverage, leaving me contemplating cancellation. However, my desire for a whiskey-based cocktail prevailed, and I opted for the Makers Mark + Peach drink. To my delight, the combination of peaches and whiskey proved to be an inspired choice, earning my enthusiastic approval. 

Despite the culinary highlights of Las Vegas, I would not consider returning to Wolfgang Puck's restaurant, primarily due to the exorbitant pricing of their menu items and the sluggishness of the service I experienced.

So it was around 1am on a Saturday night in Vegas and I became REALLY hungry as soon as my friend told me there was pretty much no decent restaurants open. Wolfgang was the only option in the MGM past 11pm. The looks of this place kind of puts you off. There are these huge ring things around the front of it. Despite the daunting looks of this place the staff was pretty nice and they were BUSY. One of the many thing I love about Vegas.... that it can feel like its noon at 1am in the morning.

I got the Mushroom, Talleggio & Leeks pizza. Which was just what the doctor ordered for my post midnight hunger pains. But they put raw leeks on the pizza. I think the heat from the pizza is supposed to cook the leeks. But they put so many on that the sheer heat of the pizza couldn't cook all of them. Raw leeks not my favorite thing to eat. 

Server took a really long time bringing me my drink. I almost canceled but I needed a little whiskey (I'm a whiskey girl through and through). I got the Makers Mark + Peach drink. Which quite frankly was the best idea EVER! Peaches and whiskey what more can you ask for? Giving 2 stars  because the menu is overpriced and service was slow + raw leeks. With all the culinary delights in Vegas I don't think I would come back here.
