In conclusion, despite this isolated drawback, I wholeheartedly endorse this library and eagerly anticipate future story time events, provided that all participants are accorded equal treatment during the concluding ritual."

Who knew!? 

I didn't really understand the concept of "Twin Peaks" until I came back from Vegas.  Hey we have one here too in Scottsdale.  My first thought when I walked in here -- "Wow the girls here are pretty hot"!  Compared to the usual UFC fight nights at Hooters this place definitely "out-hots" Hooters by miles.  

Food wise I think its okay at best.  I huge portions and Men/Girl size options.  Guess they're trying to be cute just like one of their dessert option (Scenic View - NC) is actually the waitresses NO COST.  Fair enough since they are smokin.  Needless to say, the food is bar food.  The burger I ordered had way more bun then beef.  I did enjoy the fingerling potato fries and the Nacho is a massive mound! --- Get it!? Anyways, carry on.....

The place itself is like walking into an REI store except you can't buy anything and hot chicks.  Overall, a cover charge of $5 for a UFC is cool.  I probably wouldn't come here for the food.  The "Scenic View" is a plus, but I'm not one for cheap thrills. - Enjoy!

I have been eager to indulge in the culinary delights offered by New York Flavor ever since my relocation to Surprise. However, much to my dismay, my initial experience fell short of my expectations.

The service, though, was quite satisfactory. As a novice customer, I sought guidance from the woman behind the counter regarding the most popular items on the menu. She was extremely helpful in elaborating on the various options, providing me with a comprehensive understanding of the dishes available.

My order consisted of the Spanish Harlem, accompanied by a side of potato salad. Let us begin by examining the potato salad. To my utter surprise, it was served in a minuscule container, barely sufficient to accommodate two paltry bites. The portion size was laughable, leaving me feeling deceived and questioning whether it was part of a prank. Moreover, the quality of the potato salad was unremarkable, resembling something one could easily purchase at a grocery store. It failed to impress me, to say the least.

Moving on to the sandwich, it was somewhat satisfying. The spread boasted an appreciable flavor, and the steak was cooked to perfection. Unfortunately, the bread left much to be desired. At a price point of $8.99, the sandwich seemed a tad overpriced considering its modest proportions.

In conclusion, while the service at New York Flavor was commendable, the cuisine did not live up to my expectations, especially given the positive reviews and the restaurant's self-proclaimed association with New York City.

I have been wanting to try New York Flavor ever since I moved to Surprise. Unfortunately, I was not as impressed as I thought I would be. 

The service is pretty good. Since it was my first time, I asked the woman at the counter if there were any "favorites". She was very helpful in explaining the menu items. 

I ended up ordering the Spanish Harlem with a side of potato salad. First, let's talk about the potato salad. It came in a TINY little cup. I am talking, like two bites of potato salad. I wish I had saved the little cup to take a picture. I almost felt like I was being pranked. I paid $1.99 for this potato salad. I expected to be able to eat more than two bites of it. And, to be honest, the two bites of potato salad I had weren't the greatest. It tasted like potato salad you could buy at the grocery store; nothing to write home about.

The sandwich itself was pretty good. The spread was flavorful and the steak was cooked perfectly. The bread was just okay. The sandwich was $8.99, which felt a little pricey to me based on the size of the sandwich.

All in all, the service is there, but the food here just isn't something I would expect to receive if I were actually in New York, which is the impression I got from the reviews and the restaurant itself.

Nice new place in Goodyear.  Attractive interior (unsurprising, as it's brand new).  Very, very good thin crust - not NY or Chicago-style.  I'm a native NYer, and I've been searching for a great NY-style slice for about a year now.  This isn't it, but it's still very good pizza.  From what I can tell, they use a higher quality cheese than any of their competition in the West Valley that I've tried thus far.  It's certainly not 5-star pizza, but it's better than many of the other options on this side of Phoenix.

This second location for Lukes of Chicago keeps the tradition alive and well on the northeast side of the valley.

Lunch at this location can vary; I have been here at 12:30 and walked right up to put in my order, I have been here at 2pm in a line of 8 people. 

I usually order the chili cheese dog and it's always wonderful and sloppy. Word of caution though, it comes very hot so let that dog cool down a bit before diving in. I also enjoy the fact that many menu items come with fries as they serve a great crinkle cut version.

On the downside, I have had my order "lost" once at this location. To their credit it was a very busy lunch rush and it's a small place. Using the old style written tickets means these things can happen if one falls on the floor or gets bundled with someone else's ticket.

If you're in Scottsdale and don't want to fuss with the fancy places or typical fast food fodder, give Luke's of Chicago a shot. It's nestled in the strip mall area directly next to Sam's Club/Walmart.

"A quintessential indigenous New Yorker's preferred eatery, boasting an ambiance that exudes a sense of familiarity and warmth, reminiscent of a bygone era when local establishments served as community gathering spaces, offering delectable cuisine that showcases the rich cultural heritage of the city's culinary traditions, with a plethora of mouth-watering wing flavors that cater to diverse palates, creating a welcoming atmosphere that invites patrons to linger and savor the nuances of each dish, making it a veritable gem in the midst of the bustling metropolis."
Your typical native new yorker, a nicer location than most because it used to be a local restaurant.  Typical sports grill fare, good amount of wing flavors.

So are you guys going to to have water or do you want anything else... The food was great but the service from our server was lackluster. We got a salad, two pizzas, three appetizers, two glasses of wine and a pitcher yet our server seemed to think we were going to be a table of water and pizza. Food was great but our server couldn't get it right. Missed drinks and wrong orders; for my first time at Federal Pizza, I don't know if I'd necessarily come back as a result of the service.

Big, sweaty, beefy dudes from all over eastern Europe. Athletic, sexy, flexible and half naked women crawling on top of everything. Acrobatics. Water Stunts. A blur of bodies grinding and groping each other. A two hour thrill ride of sexual intensity I won't soon forget.

When it was over... i toweled off and took a shower. Then I left my condo to check out "Le Reve" at the Wynn. 

Not really a big deal.

This particular location has a bit of a bipolar staff. Some days you get the nicest baristas, who take time and make suggestions, which make me want to come back! Other times, you are just left with the hope you have caught someone on a really bad day. I just hope my visits start to lean toward the better days!

While I was awaiting my takeout order, there was a group of four senior citizens (non-Asian) departing with broad grins on their visages. One of the women subsequently articulated, "This is our preferred eatery in town! Everything is consistently superb!" She then gathered all the business cards positioned by the cashier and exited the establishment declaring, "We must acquire more commerce for you!"

I fixated on the takeout menu for an extensive period of approximately 15 minutes. It's Chinese cuisine; I'm familiar with my preferences! I was perplexed by my prolonged deliberation, but ultimately, I opted for the ma po tofu and house special lo mein. Subsequently, I pondered how infrequently I had ordered ma po tofu for takeout, and this thought crossed my mind as I drove home.

NOW I RECOLLECT why I avoid doing so. The contents of the takeout bag were a complete chaos of sauce. I won't commit that error again. The tofu dish was delectable. They utilized ground chicken instead of pork, which gave it a slightly lighter flavor than usual, and the remaining sauce in the container was quite palatable.

The noodles, on the other hand, were mediocre. If only I had perused Clint B's review prior to placing the order, I would have shared his viewpoint on the lo mein and refrained from ordering it. Excessive oil. The chef has gone wild!

I intend to revisit this establishment for the Peking duck, which will likely alter my overall impression of this venue.

They are currently undergoing an extensive renovation project, and I had the pleasure of occupying one of the recently refurbished guest rooms during my stay. The accommodations were exceptional, boasting a supremely comfortable bed, a spacious and meticulously clean environment, and a picturesque view of the bustling strip below (although, I must admit that I found it challenging to determine whether our vantage point was situated up or down the strip, given the unique layout of the city). Unfortunately, the clientele at the establishment tended towards the seedier side of the social spectrum, which proved to be a slight drawback. However, if management can maintain their high standards of service and facilities until the completion of the remodeling efforts, this venue has the potential to regain its former status as an excellent destination for travelers. The staff members I encountered were generally quite hospitable, with the notable exception of the cabana girl, whose haughty demeanor unfortunately deducted a star from my overall rating and resulted in a minor financial loss for the establishment.

The Girlfriend and I came here for breakfast after a night stay there in the Hooters Hotel and Casino. Dan Marino's is located in the Hooters Hotel and  serves breakfast till 12pm. We chose the breakfast buffet because we received a coupon book with a coupon for a 2 for 1 buffet meal when we signed up for the free players club card. Regular price of buffet, $10. Buffet consist of all the basic breakfast goods. Scrambled eggs, bacon, sausage links and patties, diced potatoes and dry cereal. They also had waffles with strawberries as choice for topping. The waffles weren't too bad, tasted more like a thick pancake though.  There was even a bread pudding sort of kinda thing. Oh and fruit, can't forget the fruit. Watermelon, cantelope, pineapple, orange and pink grapefruit slices. Buffett meals include coffee,milk, oj or soda. All in all it was a good bargin and good food.

Now don't get me wrong, The Southern is a nice little bar in the Newington area of town. The decor is nice, it's well laid out and there is plenty of room. 

However, the question I have to ask myself is... Do I need another identical burger menu? Because as a reasonably regular visitor of Holyrood 9A and Red Squirrel, I'm seeing this menu pretty frequently, as menus go. 

Clearly the burger formula is working well for the owners of all three establishments, but to be honest I would have liked something a little bit different. They are all the same. There's also not much else on offer except burgers, so if you're not feeling a filling between two hunks of roll then you're probably not going to like it much here. 

Oh, and the food is served on a wooden slab. Why do restaurant owners hate crockery so much all of a sudden?

Still, my burger was tasty. I enjoyed it. But I fail to see how this place cuts itself in a different way from its sisters.

We indulged in culinary delights at this establishment on two separate occasions during our sojourn at the gaming facility, and while the fare was not haute cuisine, it surpassed our expectations considering the venue. Specifically, the onion straws were delectable and merited unadulterated praise.

"I recently had the pleasure of visiting this establishment for the first time with a group of acquaintances. Upon entering, I was immediately struck by the well-designed layout, complete with pool tables situated in the rear and a couple of dartboards positioned at the front. Additionally, there was a buck hunting game that unfortunately did not appear to be functioning properly, although I suppose it's understandable given the potential risks associated with intoxicated individuals engaging in such activities prior to operating a vehicle. Nevertheless, the outdoor seating area provided a pleasant setting for those who wished to indulge in nicotine products.  

The bartenders demonstrated exceptional friendliness and hospitality, while the prices they charged were remarkably reasonable in comparison to neighboring establishments in the Westgate area. Specifically, the cost of a tall beer was a mere two dollars, making it an excellent value.  

While the ambiance was generally enjoyable, there were a few instances of questionable behavior from certain patrons, including a few individuals sporting crooked hats and adopting what could be described as a "tough guy" mentality. Nonetheless, the overall experience remained positive.  

One minor drawback was the presence of a man stationed in the men's restroom, who appeared to be expecting tips in exchange for utilizing the facilities. This individual offered various candies and breath mints, but I chose to ignore his presence and proceed directly to the sink. Personally, I find it somewhat perplexing to offer gratuities to someone simply for providing free toiletries and confectionery.  

Despite these isolated incidents, I would still highly recommend paying a visit to this venue. The strobe-lit restrooms and complimentary basket of Starburst candy near the dance floor are certainly unique features that set it apart from other establishments. Moreover, if you're seeking a response to the age-old question posed by your significant other regarding how you spent your leisure time, you can now confidently reply, "My dear, I visited 'The Gym' today."

Just went here for my first time with some friends.  

Nice layout, pool tables in the back, couple dart boards up front, and a buck hunting game that didn't work (that's okay, don't need drunk people in THIS town shooting stuff up before they drive home) and a nice outdoor seating area to smoke, if nicotine is your thing!

The bartenders were friendly and the prices were great compared to the local Westgate neighbors (tall beer was only $2 bucks).  

Of course, for the location, there was a fair share of crooked hats "tough guy" mentalities, but it was fun.  The only weird thing was the dude holding down the bathroom.  The boombox in the Men's room was about as louder as the DJ booth.  It was one of those bathroom host-gigs where a guy expects you to tip him for using the sink or whatever.  He had little candies in baskets and blow pops but I just walked on by.  I guess, to Diego here, it's kind of weird to tip a guy a buck for handing you a free towel and a mint.  

But hey, check this place out!  Can't go wrong with a strobe lit bathroom and a basket of Starburst on your way out to the dance floor!  If for nothing else, you can tell your wife when she asks what your lazy self did all day you can say "Honey, relax.  I went to 'The Gym'".

When I undertook a personal culinary excursion to this esteemed eatery approximately one year prior, I had the profound pleasure of partaking in an exceptional seafood platter, which boasted an abundance of succulent shrimp, crab claws, and remarkably delectable baked oysters, thus establishing elevated expectations for my subsequent dining experience; however, much to my dismay, the restaurant had opted to remove said seafood platter from their menu, thereby prompting me to select an alternative dish, specifically a stuffed lobster entree, which, although palatable, failed to satiate my gastronomical desires and did not live up to my preconceived notions cultivated during the aforementioned initial visit; furthermore, I encountered an additional inconvenience pertaining to the presence of cork in each bottle of wine, despite the establishment's assiduous efforts to rectify the issue by offering a complimentary replacement. If I were to evaluate this dining establishment based solely on my maiden visit, I would unhesitatingly confer a perfect five-star rating; regrettably, my overall satisfaction was compromised by the aforementioned drawbacks, leading me to assign a respectable yet somewhat diminished three-star appraisal.

This marks our second visit to this esteemed culinary establishment, and while my previous experience with a fussy infant rendered my recollection of the initial encounter somewhat vague, I can confidently state that the ambiance of the restaurant has undergone a significant transformation since our last visit. Specifically, the interior design has adopted a more modern and sleek aesthetic, which, when coupled with the spotless cleanliness of the facility, creates an atmosphere that exudes both elegance and comfort. However, upon closer inspection, certain aspects of the seating arrangements became apparent, specifically, the disproportionately low height of the chairs in relation to the tables, which resulted in an unfortunate hindrance to the enjoyment of our dining experience. Namely, the elevation of the tables rendered it challenging for our youthful companions to fully appreciate the culinary presentation, prompting them to assume an upright position on our laps, thereby necessitating my manual assistance in elevating their plates to a suitable height for consumption.  
Notwithstanding the aforementioned drawbacks, the quality of the service we received during our visit was truly commendable. The entire staff, including the chef and various servers, displayed a remarkable level of cordiality and accommodation, tailoring their approach to cater to the unique needs of our group, which included a young child who required a slight modification to the customary theatrics of the dining performance. The chef's considerate adjustments notwithstanding, the sushi and complementary appetizers proved to be the undeniable highlights of our repast, boasting an exceptional quality that left us thoroughly impressed. Regrettably, the remaining components of the meal fell short of our expectations, as the chef's liberal application of a distinctive pink sauce resulted in a sense of uniformity that bordered on monotony, rendering each dish indistinguishable from the others. In essence, a simple serving of fried pink paste would have sufficed. Despite this disappointment, the excellence of the sushi and appetizers persuades me to consider a future visit.

This is the second time we ate here. I don't remember much of the first, I think my daughter was still baby and was fussy that night so we didn't stay long. Anyways, this time the restaurant was ok.

The restaurant looks very nice, and it's clean. The chairs are too low for the tables, though. I wasn't the only one who felt like I needed a highchair. The actual high chairs they brought for our toddlers were almost the same height as our chairs, leaving the kids with no chance to see the top of the table, let alone the show. They had to stand on our laps to see anything and I ended up holding a plate at my daughter's level for her to eat.

The service was very good. All the waiters and the chef were friendly and accomodating. We had a young child with us, who was a little scared of some of the flashy parts of the dining show, so the chef toned it down a little for her, but still put on a great show.

The sushi and accompanying appetizers were excellent! Oh, it was sooo good. The rest of the dinner, however, left me a smidgen dissappointed. The chef added a pink paste to everything he cooked. On the one hand, it had an interesting flavor. On the other hand, it made everything taste the same. He may as well have just fried up some pink paste and served us just that. :\

I would go back for the sushi.

"The eatery boasted an aesthetically pleasing ambiance, replete with well-appointed decor and a diverse array of culinary offerings that catered to the discerning palate.  Furthermore, the waitstaff exhibited exceptional proficiency in their duties, ensuring a seamless dining experience for all patrons.  Our visit during the luncheon hour afforded us the opportunity to sample a selection of delectable dishes, including the tempura-battered asparagus accompanied by a tangy chili ranch dipping sauce.  While the portion size left somewhat to be desired, the flavors were undoubtedly tantalizing.  The hoagie sandwiches proved to be a highlight of our meal, with each variation showcasing a unique blend of ingredients that elevated them beyond the standard fare typically associated with this type of sandwich.  Specifically, the prime rib variant, replete with sautÃ©ed onions, mushrooms, and a generous helping of melted cheese, was particularly noteworthy.  Moreover, the bread rolls accompanying the sandwiches were remarkably fresh and soft, allowing for an effortless consumption experience.  It is worth noting, however, that the sandwiches were so succulent that one would be wise to take precautions to avoid staining one's attire while indulging.  Lastly, the French fries were cooked to a golden crisp perfection, rounding out a thoroughly enjoyable repast.  Suffice it to say, we look forward to returning in the future, albeit with the understanding that popularity may render the venue capacity-filled."

"A pleasant establishment, the preliminary offerings were satisfactory. The primary dish, however, was somewhat lacking in quality, owing to the fact that I was present for a celebratory gathering of a bachelor and we were provided with a predetermined selection of culinary options. Notwithstanding, I shall consider returning to sample a superior grade of steak, given that the initial courses and supplementary dishes were palatable. The atmosphere and hospitality were also commendable."

We wanted to eat light so we chose this place. It is located inside the Paris Hotel Casino and our hostess sat us on the outside edge of the restaurant where we could people watch.

I ordered a fish dumping noodle bowl and my wife ordered won ton style soup bowl. We also chose a plate of  mini pork buns when the lady with the dim sum cart rolled by.

Overall it was an okay dining experience. Both our soup bowls were very tasty but they were on the small side for pho. Our pork buns were a little dry also. I paid $46 bucks including tip for this mini meal which is on the expensive side for pho, but were in Vegas so....

Their half sammiches are gigantic.  The ciabatta bread was very good, and word on the street is that the nine-grain is to die for.  \n\nSomething in my roast beef provolone sammich didn't sit right with my stomach though.  I may be reverting back to the Jimmy John's 2 doors down for my 'wich fix now.

"Although I have had the pleasure of indulging in superior Hawaiian cuisine at other establishments, I still hold this particular venue in high regard due to its exceptional value. It appears that regardless of what menu item one selects, they receive an abundance of it, which is particularly advantageous for those who are budget-conscious. Each time I visit this restaurant, I invariably opt for the macaroni salad and spam musubi, as they are staples that never fail to satisfy my cravings. Additionally, their chicken katsu is skillfully prepared, boasting a golden-brown, crunchy exterior complemented by a juicy, tender interior. Whenever my appetite is particularly hearty and I am in pursuit of a meal that will satiate my hunger for an extended period, I find myself drawn to this eatery, where I can indulge in a veritable feast that will leave me feeling pleasantly full for a considerable duration."

I have had better Hawaiian cuisine elsewhere, but I like this place because of it's value. It seems like that whatever you order you get a whole lot of it which is great when you are on a budget. Every time I go to this place I always have to order the mac salad and the spam musubi. Their chicken katsu is also nicely done, crispy on the outside and tender on the inside. I like to come to this place when I'm feeling really hungry and I'm in need of \"stick to your ribs\" kind of food. This place will definitely leave you full for a very long time.

"My significant other and I were eager to sample the culinary offerings at this novel establishment, specifically their barbecue, and assess its quality. Upon perusing their menu, we decided to order a whiskey from their extensive selection and a tap beer. The beverage was presented chilled to an optimal temperature, allowing us to savor its refreshing taste for an extended period. Their daily specials, featuring both beverages and edibles, were prominently displayed on a chalkboard, facilitating our decision-making process. Our server exhibited exceptional proficiency in attending to our needs, ensuring that our dining experience was seamless and enjoyable. However, we did encounter a brief delay in consuming our meals, as they arrived at our table scorching hot, necessitating a brief waiting period before we could indulge in their delectable flavors. We initiated our gastronomical journey by sampling their fried pickles, whose flavor profile was satisfactory, albeit perhaps slightly lacking in thickness. I opted for the fried chicken, comprising three pieces, accompanied by mac and cheese and baked beans. My companion, on the other hand, selected the pulled pork sandwich, complemented by fried okra. The smoky essence of the pork was particularly appealing to my taste buds."

My boyfriend and I wanted to check out this new place and see how their barbecue was. It was pretty good. He ordered a whiskey, which they have a nice selection of, and I got a tap beer. It was served so ice cold and stayed cold for quite some time. They have daily specials on beer and food up on their chalkboard. Our service was great and the food was served so hot we had to wait a minute to eat it. We started with fried pickles, which had a nice flavor but maybe could be thicker? I ordered the fried chicken (it came with three pieces) and mac and cheese with baked beans. My boyfriend ordered the pulled pork sandwich and fried okra. I really liked the smoke flavor of the pork.

First and foremost, we are utterly delighted that you did not opt to cease operations altogether, albeit had it not been for our possession of a computer and an inquisitive inclination to peruse your whereabouts, we would have remained oblivious to your relocation.

In addition, we must commend you on maintaining the identical exceptional culinary offerings and warm hospitality, which has remained consistent with our previous experiences. However, we cannot help but express some reservations regarding the pricing of your menu items. Specifically, we had a half-portion turkey sandwich accompanied by macaroni salad, while my spouse opted for pastrami, paired with potato salad. Notwithstanding the quality of the fare, the cost of our meal, prior to gratuity, amounted to $20, which we deemed somewhat steep for a midday repast in this particular locality.

Were your prices to be more affordable, we would undoubtedly frequent your establishment with greater regularity and perhaps even indulge in a sweet treat or two. As it stands, we shall continue to patronize your restaurant, albeit with a tad less frequency than we would have liked, owing to the aforementioned fiscal constraints.

"Upon venturing to sample Poutine for the first time, my culinary excursion yielded an experience that, while satisfactory, did not quite measure up to the superior quality I would subsequently encounter at other eateries during my travels. Notwithstanding, our server's hospitable demeanor and the captivating ambiance of the outdoor seating area, replete with intriguing adornments, contributed to an overall pleasant dining episode. It is worth mentioning that, owing to its location along the well-trodden tourist route, this establishment might not rank among the cream of Montreal's culinary crop, according to the lofty standards one might reasonably expect from such an illustrious city. A word of advice: eschew the coffee, as the instant variety likely surpasses its brewed counterpart in terms of flavor and quality. Instead, opt for a refreshing beer to accompany your meal, as it will complement the savory fare more effectively. In light of the fact that we did not have the opportunity to sample the full range of offerings on the menu, I would still consider returning to this eatery if circumstances led me to be in close proximity once again, and a craving for a quick bite struck."

"I recently had the pleasure of dining at Ruby Tuesday, courtesy of my esteemed great aunt, who treated me to a delightful luncheon experience, utilizing a coupon, no less. It's quite amusing, really, how my paternal relatives are often jocularly associated with fiscal prudence. My great aunt, however, proved to be an exception to this rule, producing a veritable cache of coupons. I find that when I frequent chain restaurants, I tend to adhere to a tried-and-true formula, opting for either a burger or chicken sandwich, both of which are reliably palatable options. The fact that the chicken may arrive via truck, bearing grill marks, matters not; the essence of the meal lies not in its appearance, but in its gustatory satisfaction. Ruby Tuesday, in particular, offers a tantalizing deal, featuring two diminutive burgers accompanied by a salad bar, all for the reasonable sum of $8. Furthermore, they have recently introduced a pimento cheese alternative, much to my delight. Alas, there are two items that I sorely miss from the halcyon days of yore, both of which graced the salad bar: bread and butter pickles, as well as pineapple. Why, oh why, have these delectable ingredients been exiled from the menu? The absence of these culinary treasures elicits a dramatic lamentation, replete with flair and flourish."

We possess a quartet of offspring, and we effortlessly expended two hundred dollars and two hours within this establishment. It is utterly captivating; however, it does tend to attract an abundance of tourists, thereby creating a congested atmosphere. We do not bring our progeny to Las Vegas, but we bestow upon them numerous presents during each excursion. This emporium encompasses multiple levels, and if your progeny harbor an affection for M&Ms, you will undoubtedly discover an item within these premises that they will be absolutely delighted to acquire. As a matter of fact, my daughter has already petitioned me to procure something for her during our impending journey in January, thus we shall indeed revisit this location. The staff exhibited amicability and helpfulness, although the queues were somewhat protracted. Everything was slightly pricier than we had desired, yet it is essential to consider that the experience and site are integral components of the cost. It is quite advantageous for a leisurely stroll along the strip to culminate in stores of this nature. That is precisely why such establishments are situated in these locations. To be candid, without my offspring, this venue would not hold nearly as much appeal, and I would not have had the tolerance to navigate through the dense crowds of diminutive children who were darting about in all directions. Furthermore, negotiating one's way through the store was somewhat arduous; although not particularly intuitive, we did not find it overly vexing.

I have been eagerly anticipating the opportunity to visit this Farmers Market for an extended period of time. Whenever I attend the Downtown Market, the vegetables have already been thoroughly examined and picked over, leaving limited options for selection. Therefore, with my day off, I decided to embark upon a journey to explore this market, which boasts an opening time of 10 A.M., according to the sign. However, upon our arrival at 9:45 A.M., we observed that the parking lot was already teeming with individuals who appeared to be deeply engrossed in their search for fresh produce. My concern was that I might have missed out on some exceptional specimens.

Upon entering the market, it became apparent that McClendons was responsible for providing the vast majority of the produce on offer. Their display presented a visually stunning array of vibrant colors, including deep purple red beets, lush green leeks, fingerling potatoes, shallots, farm-fresh broccoli, and an assortment of other delectable delights. Many of these items were certified organic and clearly labeled with their origins, which added an extra layer of appeal. Several of the products were sourced from Willcox, thereby ensuring their exceptional freshness.

Despite the presence of five operational registers, a considerable queue had formed, comprising primarily housewives who were zealously gathering and selecting vegetables with remarkable speed and determination. It was imperative to remain vigilant and agile to avoid being overwhelmed or trampled by the enthusiastic shoppers. Nonetheless, the quality of the produce made the experience well worth the effort.

Beyond the fresh produce, the market offered a limited selection of artisanal goods, such as handmade soap, blankets, jewelry, yarn crafts, and a solitary bread stand. While this variety was somewhat underwhelming, the prospect of acquiring fresh, high-quality produce remained the primary draw for me.

In conclusion, while I would certainly consider revisiting this market if I found myself in the vicinity, I would not go out of my way to do so, given my typically busy schedule and the fact that I am usually at work on Wednesday mornings. Nevertheless, for those who reside nearby and have the luxury of free time on Wednesdays, I would heartily recommend paying a visit to this market and capitalizing on the opportunity to procure some truly exceptional produce.

"Chipotle holds a special place in my heart as my preferred culinary establishment due to their consistent delivery of delectable dishes. However, my rating is not solely based on the gastronomical offerings, but rather takes into account the quality of service and efficiency of the staff. On this particular occasion, I must commend the employees for their amiable nature, despite the apparent stress and anxiety that permeated their demeanor. A mere three patrons stood in line, yet the personnel seemed overwhelmed, struggling to maintain a pace that would accommodate the demand. Notably, the gentleman preceding me in the queue had his meal prepared, only to have it abandoned by the attendant, leaving it to languish until her return. Upon her arrival, she discarded the previously prepared dish and began anew, contributing to an already prolonged waiting period that exceeded 15 minutes. Despite these setbacks, the edibles themselves maintained their customary excellence. It is my sincere hope that with time, the team will acclimate to their responsibilities, thereby enhancing the overall experience."

Chipotle is my favorite restaurant because Chipotle IS LIFE! My rating is not based off the food because Chipotle food is always great and always deserves a 5 star. My rating is specifically based off of the service and speed. 
Let me say that the workers there were very nice. They were nice, but you could tell they were flustered and nervous. 
There was like 3 people in line and they seemed overwhelmed (this is compared to others who do fine with lines out the doors). 
The gentleman in front of me started his order and the lady behind the counter left his food sitting there. When she came back, she threw away what she started (since it was cold) and made him a new one. 
Total time took about 15 min to order and everything, so it was a lot slower than most chipotle. 
Food was great like always. 
Hopefully once they get used to working it will speed up!

After perusing various evaluations regarding this establishment, I was cognizant of the fact that it would not conform to my preconceived notion of a military surplus store; nevertheless, I was still disheartened by the dearth of authentic survival equipment. Granted, it constituted an exceptionally captivating zombie-themed curio shop that boasted a diminutive arsenal in its rear section, yet the array of items deemed 'practical' proved limited. 
  If you harbor an affinity for zombies, this location would undoubtedly prove a diverting destination. I envision that juveniles would find it particularly enthralling, as it features numerous interactive games, an abundance of T-shirts, a selection of literature, and various bumper stickers. 
  The MREs are somewhat pricey, as are the alternative camping and survival items available (such as rain ponchos, hand-crank radios, and flashlights). The sole item I purchased was a Twinkie. 
 Ultimately, this themed shop offers a unique and engaging experience, thanks to its friendly staff members.

After reading other reviews about this place, I knew not to expect it to be a military surplus store, but I was still disappointed. Mind you, it was a really cool zombie-themed souvenir shop that had a small armory in the back, but there really wasn't much truly practical "survival" gear.

If you like zombies, this is a really fun place to go. I imagine that kids would love it! There are several interactive game thingies there, lots of T shirts, some books and bumper stickers. 

The MREs are a little pricy, as are the other camping/survival items (think rain ponchos and hand crank radios and flash lights). The only thing that I left with was a Twinkie. 

All in all, this is a fun themed shop with very friendly staff.

The service was outstanding. Everyone on staff was pleasant and helpful. Not the most kid-friendly (no cups with lids). The stuffed mushrooms were tasty, but only slightly warm to cool. The eggplant  and veal parm were tasty, but I think overpriced for what you get. It feels like a restaurant that can't decide whether to be casual or fine. Linen napkins (with paper napkin centerpieces) and oil lamps, but tissue paper plate liners. Might go again without the kids. The patio looked nice for alfresco dining.

We indulged in a culinary excursion with the intent of consuming a delectable pastry delight, specifically, a slice of apple pie.  Upon partaking of this gastronomical treat, we discovered that the filling, infused with a piquant flavor, was quite satisfactory.  However, the outer layer of dough, unfortunately, lacked the requisite degree of doneness, rendering it inedible for our taste buds.  Furthermore, the serving size, intended for a trio of individuals, proved excessive for our appetites, although certain patrons may find it suitable.  In contrast, the key lime variety, characterized by an abundant helping, demonstrated a superior quality compared to others of its kind.  Ultimately, our pursuit of exceptional pie remained unfulfilled, prompting us to continue our search.  Additionally, our experience was marred by sluggish service, though the server's amiability somewhat mitigated this deficiency.

After all our friends had told us to try out Texaz, we finally did. We both ordered, and it wasn't bad! What they forgot to mention to us was that they all had the chicken fried steaks and LOVED them. Guess we'll have to get that next time. Very friendly staff.

Food and service great!  Price was a hidden charge, but at least they tell you when you pay before you sit down to eat.  It's a $5.99 all you can eat breakfast, but if you don't have their \"player's card\" program, they add $3/person.

nice place. one thing i really didn't like is smoke. i couldn't be there more then hour. too much smoke almost everybody smoke. dj was the lady she is so cool i like her a lot. this place is different then lot of place. people say woman free but they charged 10$ each woman. if next time i would go XS

The service was good but I got the 'pollo poblano' entree and it was so not appetizing. The rice and bean stuff was fine but ugh I am never getting that again. They gave us some chips and salsa. The salsa was too liquidy. It sort of seems like as thought they added much more water into it. The dessert thing that they just gave us was interesting. So technically got an appetizer an dessert for free and they give you more so that's nice

This store is fine if you only need to pick up a few items.  This is not a Super-ShurSave. They don't have aisles that endlessly go on and on.

The only complaint that I have is their produce section.

I am very very picky about produces freshness.  I am a bargain shopper, but will go to Giant Eagle Market District a
for my fruits and vegetables and that is where I will pay extra.

"An interior ambiance that exudes an assorted array of styles and influences, complemented by the hospitable demeanor of the staff, serves as the backdrop for an epicurean adventure characterized by diminutive portions of culinary delights, augmented by potent potables artfully infused with house-made syrups. A suitable venue for socializing with acquaintances during the initial hours of the evening, albeit, it is essential to exercise fiscal vigilance, lest one's financial resources be depleted prior to the witching hour; ultimately, this establishment has the potential to ascend to a rating of four or five stars as time progresses."

Very eclectic interior.  Friendly staff.  Food is small plates.  Drinks are strong with house - made syrups.  Good place to meet friends early in the night, but keep an eye on your tab or you might be broke before 10p;)  They will likely be a 4-5 star establishment with time

"A relatively satisfactory lodging establishment, albeit with a somewhat formidable control panel governing various amenities such as illumination and window treatments, which may pose a challenge for less technologically adept individuals. Additionally, the management appears to have adopted a policy of deliberate inconvenience regarding the absence of an in-room coffee maker, seemingly encouraging guests to venture to the casino to acquire a cup of coffee, thereby necessitating an excursion that may prove bothersome for some patrons, particularly those who value convenience and efficiency. However, during our extended stay of four days, we opted to procure a coffee machine and graciously leave it behind for the benefit of the housekeeping staff."

Have had the pleasure of partaking in the indulgences offered by Tao on multiple occasions, and while my initial experience was enjoyable, subsequent visits have led me to reassess my opinion of the establishment.  
Upon arrival, it became apparent that entry would be contingent upon adhering to a strict gender ratio, with a minimum requirement of a 50-50 split between males and females. As our group consisted of four men, we were met with resistance from the doorman, who refused to allow us to queue, effectively barring our entry. Fortunately, through a stroke of serendipity, we had established a connection with an alternative doorman earlier in the evening, who graciously facilitated our admittance without hesitation.  
Once inside, the venue's ambiance initially captivated my attention, boasting an intriguing aesthetic that permeated the space for the first fifteen minutes, prior to the influx of the bulk of the clientele. However, as the club reached capacity, mobility became severely restricted, with limited space for movement, standing, or dancing. It is mystifying how such an overcrowded environment does not pose a safety hazard. The dÃ©cor is undeniably impressive, augmented by the presence of bathing girls, which serves as a unique and alluring feature. The bartenders consistently provide exceptional service, yet the conduct of the doormen and bouncers leaves much to be desired, and navigating the premises proves challenging. Despite these drawbacks, a visit to Tao remains a requisite experience for anyone seeking to partake in the city's nightlife.

"Well, it serves as an appropriate location for families with children to spend time together, as it offers a variety of species that are sure to captivate young minds. However, for adults who are not particularly fond of penguins or other avian species, the experience may prove to be somewhat underwhelming, as the zoo's collection of animals is not particularly extensive or diverse. That being said, the zoo does boast some unique features, such as the meticulous recreations of the natural habitats of various species, which may appeal to those with a keen interest in environmental design and conservation efforts."

"The culinary offerings at this establishment are merely adequate, with generous helping sizes that are commensurate with the cost. However, the gustatory experience they provide is somewhat unremarkable. Despite their proximity to my place of residence, I would not consider it worthwhile to make a special effort to partake of their fare, unless they happen to be the most convenient option in the immediate vicinity."

"The culinary offerings at this establishment are of considerable quality, provided that the items are available, for it appears that the depletion of inventory is a recurring issue, specifically with regard to the goat cheese curds. Furthermore, it is advisable to avoid visiting during trivia night, as the staff may exhibit a lack of enthusiasm towards accommodating patrons who wish to dine prior to the commencement of the trivia competition, thereby potentially hindering the overall dining experience."

"The experience of flying into Orlando was thoroughly enjoyable, as we touched down an hour ahead of schedule, conveniently utilized the airport tram to transport us to the baggage claim area, and then proceeded expeditiously to the taxi stand, thereby facilitating a prompt departure from the airport premises. In contrast, the process of leaving Las Vegas proved to be somewhat more arduous and complicated. Despite the fact that Southwest Airlines provided efficient curbside check-in and skycaps, a member of our group had purchased two minuscule snow globes as mementos of our time in Vegas. Unfortunately, these items were deemed unsuitable for carry-on luggage by TSA regulations, resulting in the individual being escorted back outside the security perimeter to postal services located at the opposite end of the airport, thereby necessitating that they be sent via mail rather than being hand-carried onto the aircraft. Furthermore, our designated gate, C1, was situated at the furthest extremity of the terminal, requiring an exhaustive trek of approximately 100 yards merely to reach the initial gates numbering in the 25 range. This tedious journey involved circumventing the same tram that had transported us so effortlessly upon our arrival, followed by an interminable hike through crowded passageways ultimately leading to an overcrowded, makeshift holding area reminiscent of a 1980's prison cafeteria in both appearance and atmosphere. It became glaringly apparent that while the airport authorities were more than happy to accommodate incoming travelers, their reluctance to facilitate efficient departure procedures seemed to suggest a tacit policy of deliberately impeding the exit of outgoing passengers."

Flying in from Orlando was great. We landed an hour early, took the airport tram over to the baggage area, then out to the taxis and away we went. 

Leaving Vegas wasn't as easy. Southwest's curbside skycaps and check-in  were great. However, one person in our party had bought two very small Vegas souvenir snow globes. TSA wouldn't let him through with them. They escorted him back out so he could go to the post office on the other end of the airport to mail them home instead.

Our flight was at Gate C1, so we thought that it would be nearby. Wrong. You have to walk (no people movers; no tram like you had when you arrived) at least 100 yards before you get to the first gates that start at number 25 or so. Gate C1 is the LAST gate rather than the first one. Eventually, you have to walk around that nice tram that carried you in upon arrival, then keep walking and keep walking and keep walking until you reach the crammed up gate where it's standing room only and decorated like a 1980's prison cafeteria.

Obviously, they love to get you in, but never want you to leave.
Breakfast is very good especially the Skillets and since they put misters outside on the patio breakfast outside is superb.

Been coming here for years, figured that it was time for a review of the buffet.

Let's cut to the chase: The food is average. Nothing too exceedingly fancy, but better than mystery meat swimming in gravy. Breakfast offerings usually include waffles, french toast, made-to-order omelettes, and various styles of breakfast meats and potatoes. Lunch and dinner are pretty much the same, with basic fried seafood, pizza, chinese food (which is pretty tasty), with some nights offering crab legs and steaks for a slightly higher price.

The wait staff is generally nice and attentive.

The price really can't be beat. As long as you have a player's card, breakfast lunch and dinner are 6-9-12 dollars, respectively. Compared to other buffet offerings, I'm not sure where else you can get a decent breakfast or lunch for under $10.

In review: It's inexpensive, it's basic.

"Upon recent visitation for extrication of consumables, my visual sensory organs experienced sudden and profound discomfort due to the vibrant floral patterned seat covers, which seemed to be an amalgamation of various hues and designs, thus creating a sense of optical disparity. However, upon further exploration of the interior, it became apparent that the establishment had been fastidiously arranged, boasting circular tables and crimson Chinese lanterns suspended from the ceiling, thereby creating an atmosphere of conviviality and festivity, augmented by the melodies of traditional Christmas songs emanating from the sound system. My culinary selections consisted of soup dumplings and fried string beans, for which I had hoped would be generously proportioned, given the tariff of $20 for two dishes. Upon consumption, the dumplings proved to be merely satisfactory, possessing a tendency to solidify rapidly upon cooling, while the green beans, although seasoned with considerable skill, were somewhat compromised by their excessive oiliness. Despite these drawbacks, I remain willing to accord this eatery an additional opportunity to demonstrate its gastronomical prowess."

"The culinary server, Monica, exhibited an exceptionally hospitable demeanor throughout the dining experience, manifesting an acute attentiveness to our needs and preferences. The savory patty, though unremarkable in its gastronomic composition, satisfied my hunger and provided adequate sustenance for the duration of the meal. Upon presenting my midday repast voucher, Monica efficiently applied the discount, forestalling any potential pecuniary confusion. Notwithstanding a brief delay in the preparation of the burger, Monica's genial deportment engendered a sense of contentment that rendered the brief wait inconsequential. Furthermore, the eatery's state of tidiness and cleanliness garnered approbation, while the melodic ambiance, characterized by a mellow country twang, contributed to the overall convivial atmosphere, although a slight diminution in volume might have enhanced the dining experience for this patron."

"We have had the privilege of dining at this establishment on multiple occasions, and our experiences have been somewhat inconsistent, as the ambiance and culinary offerings have alternated between impressive and unremarkable. Following a renovation several years ago, the atmosphere still retains a cafeteria-like quality, despite efforts to enhance its aesthetic appeal. The variety of dishes available is adequate but not exceptional, and the quality can fluctuate depending on the day and time of visit. Our previous visit a couple of months prior was forgettable, but we opted to give the buffet another chance after learning that George Michael would be performing at the MGM, and our second experience was relatively successful. The grilled steak station was operational this time, and the aroma of cooked meat greeted us upon entry, complemented by the satisfying taste of the steak. Additionally, the crab legs were flavorful and enjoyable. However, a special event surcharge of $10 per person was applied that evening, bringing the total cost to around $30 per person, which we felt could have been better spent at the Wynn."

After relocating from the metropolitan area of Chicago, it became imperative to locate an exceptional sushi eatery within the vicinity of Madison. Initially, I harbored reservations regarding the prospect of finding a suitable establishment, given its location within a modest strip mall adjacent to a discount store. However, upon conducting a thorough assessment, I was pleasantly surprised by the culinary excellence that this particular venue had to offer. Over the ensuing year and a half, I have remained a loyal patron of Takara, albeit with a brief period of diminished satisfaction. Notwithstanding, I would unhesitatingly endorse this dining establishment, particularly in light of their exceptional lunchtime offering, which comprises two sushi rolls accompanied by a bowl of savory miso soup, all at a remarkably reasonable price point.

"The establishment boasts an extensive array of sugary treats, albeit at exorbitant prices. Despite the prohibitive cost, the customer service was subpar, with the employees exhibiting a lack of warmth and hospitality towards patrons. Nevertheless, the gelato proved to be a delectable exception to the overall experience, with its rich flavors and velvety texture leaving a lasting impression on those who partook in its indulgence."

I was tempted to confer a rating of two stars upon Goodtimes; however, due to my status as an out-of-town visitor and the fact that I have only had the opportunity to visit the establishment on a single occasion, I cannot, with any degree of credibility, attest to its consistent quality.

On a Thursday evening, we decided to pay a visit to Goodtimes, as they were hosting a Goth-themed event titled "Carpe Noctem." Upon our arrival, I could discern that we had indeed arrived at the correct location, as there were several youths clad in spooky attire loitering about the parking lot, and a hearse was parked nearby.

The dance floor was pleasantly crowded, while all tables and seating areas surrounding it were occupied, thus prompting us to proceed towards the bar area, which was devoid of patrons. The bartender demonstrated remarkable efficiency, courtesy, and precision in the pouring of drinks.

Following the consumption of a sufficient quantity of alcoholic beverages, I ventured forth to engage in dancing activities; however, I quickly realized that the dance floor was lacking in sufficient space, as it was composed of peculiar, slick metal plates, rendering me unable to fully unleash my latent dancing abilities.

It is inherently challenging to formulate a definitive judgment regarding a Goth club based solely on a solitary visit. This particular way of life constitutes a scene, and not something that one can casually immerse oneself in. Reflecting on my experiences at my regular club back home, where it took me a considerable duration to establish a sense of belonging, I chose not to rush to judgment.

In light of the gradual decline of the Goth scene (a phenomenon that I shall refer to as a "dying breed"), it is reasonable to assume that the availability of such clubs in Las Vegas is limited, thereby making it essential to derive satisfaction from whatever establishments are available.

"My offspring and I endeavored to sample the culinary offerings of Elmer's establishment for the first time last night. I surmised that it would be beneficial for him to familiarize himself with the ambiance and gastronomical options of the venue, thereby enabling him to make an informed decision regarding his future dining preferences. 

Upon perusing the menu, my progeny opted for the Asada burrito, which he later professed to have relished. In contrast, I selected the green beef hot burrito, which, despite its delectable flavor, proved to be somewhat challenging to consume due to its generous size and juiciness, thus necessitating the utilization of utensils to complete the meal. 

It is worth noting that Elmer's menu boasts an extensive array of options, with prices that are remarkably reasonable. Furthermore, the eatery accepts debit cards and offers complimentary chips and salsa, features that set it apart from its competitor, Guedo's. In addition, the quality of the food, the affordability, and the courteous demeanor of the counter staff all contribute to a superior dining experience at Elmer's. 

However, it must be noted that the establishment's maintenance and upkeep could benefit from some attention, as evidenced by the presence of remnants of food on the floor adjacent to our table, which slightly marred the overall enjoyment of our repast."

The son and I tried Elmer's last night for the first time.  Figured he could see what the place is about so he knows where he can dash to for lunch from CHS.

He got the Asada burrito which he said tasted good.   I got the green beef hot burrito.  It was tasty, but very messy.  I had to grab a fork and knife to finish.

They have a pretty decent sized menu.  Prices are dirt cheap.   Hands down they beat Guedo's because they offer chips and salsa and take debit cards.  Food, prices and counter help is better at Elmer's too.

Not the cleanest of places.  Definite hole in the wall.  The smooshed food on the floor by our table kinda got to me.

"The prevailing sentiment among patrons was that the oxtail chili cheese fries were a culinary masterpiece, however, upon personal inspection, it became apparent that they merely constituted a conventional chili cheese fries dish, albeit with the additional component of an egg. In essence, there was nothing particularly extraordinary or lavish about it. Nonetheless, the fries themselves were somewhat impressive. 

Initially, I had opted for the Kiki's burger, while my spouse had chosen the Miyagi Wagyu burger, yet, subsequent to a shift in my preferences, we decided to interchange our orders. Ultimately, I found the Miyagi burger to be more appealing, as it brought to mind the Manly burger offered at Umami burger. Correspondingly, my husband expressed a preference for the Kiki's burger, thereby rendering the exchange beneficial for both parties. 

Based on the premise that the cuisine is undoubtedly delectable, yet simultaneously expensive, and notwithstanding the fact that the portion sizes are relatively diminutive, I have elected to assign a rating of three stars. Furthermore, it is worth mentioning that this establishment is the first in Las Vegas to serve boba beverages that are reminiscent of those I previously enjoyed in California, thus making it a notable destination for aficionados of such beverages."

"Upon conducting a thorough assessment of my recent dining experience at this establishment, I am compelled to offer my unequivocal endorsement of its culinary offerings, despite their somewhat prohibitive cost. In essence, I have elected to revise my initial stance regarding this venue, and now wholeheartedly advocate for its merits, particularly with regard to the delectable nature of its fare."

"Inexpensive culinary options, variable quality, and inconsistent service are hallmarks of this establishment. Ideally suited for large gatherings of friends and family, comparable to Paradise Buffet or other Freemont buffets. An interesting aspect is the bathroom's connection to the Berlin Wall. 
  Sunday brunch costs $12 with the club card, offering an excellent value. My experiences have shown the food to be relatively consistent with the price, albeit the prime rib is satisfactory, and the brisket could benefit from slower cooking and proper cutting. Notably, the nearby bar serves beer at a reasonable price of $1 per cup. 
  Unfortunately, the service is unpredictable, sometimes meeting expectations and other times neglecting to provide essential drink refills throughout the meal, resulting in only two sightings of our waiter. The ambiance, cleanliness, and location are generic, reminiscent of Bioshock Infinity, within the Main Street Station casino at the end of the Freemont Street Experience. 
  My rating system involves three categories, each starting at 3 points. Impressive aspects earn one point, while disappointing elements deduct a point. Calculating an overall rating by rounding the average of the ratings yields a score of 3."

Cheap food, cheap quality, hit and miss service.

Who I'd Take Here: Large groups of friends and family.
Comparable to: Paradise Buffet, any other buffet in Freemont.
Notes: A wall of the bathroom (the casino bathroom nearest to this location) is ostensibly a part of the Berlin wall.

Food Quality: 4
Sunday brunch at this location is only $12 with the club card. This is an excellent price. I've been here twice, and the food is pretty much on par with what you paid for (OK). The prime rib is OK, but avoid the brisket because they cut it at the wrong angle (chewy) and it needed a few more hours in the slow cooker. Note that the bar near the restaurant will serve you beer in the $1 range for a cup.
+1 price.

Service Quality: 2 
The service here is pretty hit and miss. When it hit, it was pretty good. When it missed, we went our entire meal without drink refills. That time, we saw our waiter twice. 
-1 bad service.

Location, Cleanliness and Ambiance: 3
The decorations on the ceiling remind me of Bioshock Infinity. Otherwise, its pretty generic. Like the service, the cleanliness is hit or miss. This is located in the Main Street Station casino, which itself is located at the end of the Freemont Street Experience.

How I rate: I have 3 categories, and each category starts at 3 points. For each item where I am impressed, they get 1 point; disappointed, lose one point.

Overall rating: round(average(ratings)) = 3

It is challenging to refrain from adoring anything situated on picturesque William Street, yet, for some unexplained reason, I failed to experience an elevated level of enthusiasm upon visiting The Melville during my recent excursion. Perhaps it was the trio of gentlemen of a particular age indulging in tobacco products near the entrance, or the perceptible odor that filled the atmosphere upon my arrival, leading me to momentarily speculate that the smoking prohibition had yet to be enforced within the premises.

The cost of beverages was somewhat steep in comparison to various other establishments in the proximate city center region, lacking the identical carefree and fashionable ambiance that Teuchters, located just across the street, seemingly possesses. Notwithstanding, the menu showcasing edibles appeared enticing and reasonably priced, thereby impelling me to consider patronizing this establishment again in the future, albeit without an exceptionally high ranking on my list of priorities.

I had arrived at Lake Las Vegas when I first encountered my future spouse, yet I had neglected to dine at any establishments within the quaint township. I selected this particular eatery for our one-year commemoration due to its prime location adjacent to the marina, boasting an unobstructed panorama of the picturesque lake. Alas, the outdoor seating area was in disarray, with feathered creatures' excrement adorning the chairs, detracting from the ambiance. Notwithstanding, the culinary offerings proved to be remarkably delectable. I had opted for the steak entrÃ©e, which was skillfully prepared to achieve a satisfying medium rare consistency without sacrificing tenderness. Our server exhibited attentive and responsive service, albeit her absence was conspicuous for extended periods. Regrettably, the mixed drinks failed to impress, serving as a stark contrast to the gastronomical excellence. Notwithstanding, the edible aspects constituted a significant advantage. Additionally, we were compelled to seek out the server to settle our financial obligations for the meal.

I am originating from Southern California, where an abundance of sushi options are readily available. Upon relocating to Arizona, I have been ardently seeking a local sushi establishment that can provide comparable quality to that of Los Angeles, all while maintaining reasonable price points. Considering the fact that the seafood in LA is often fresher and not previously frozen due to the city's proximity to harbors, I entered Hiro's with tempered expectations to avoid potential disappointment. Generally speaking, the atmosphere and sushi quality are quite satisfactory for a venue situated in Arizona. Nonetheless, the prices are somewhat elevated, which is only natural given the restaurant's location in Scottsdale and the associated increased costs of procuring premium seafood in an inland area. Furthermore, I find it perplexing that the bento boxes, such as the Teriyaki Chicken and Mixed Tempura, carry such a hefty price tag. In light of this, I am unlikely to return to Hiro's, particularly if I am seeking non-seafood options. Such items should not be priced so exorbitantly, especially when they are sourced locally. I would comprehend if they were offering Kobe beef or something of similar caliber, but for chicken, it seems unjustified. To compound matters, the chicken I received during my visit was slightly dry. Although it may have been an isolated incident, for such a steep price, I rightfully anticipate superior quality or, at the very least, naturally raised organic chicken. Thus, I feel misled in this regard. My apologies, Hiro; I shall continue my search elsewhere.

I'm from S. Cali where the Sushi options are plentiful. Moving to AZ I've been in desperate need of finding a local sushi spot that would be at least semi-comparable to the quality we get back in LA and at reasonable price-points. Taking in to consideration that the fish might be fresher and not previously frozen because LA has its harbors, I went to Hiro's with lower expectations so I wouldn't be disappointed. Overall, the ambiance and the sushi quality is pretty good for being in AZ. However, the prices are a bit high as to be expected being that it is located in Scottsdale and that the rent and getting quality fish so far inland from the coast would raise cost. The portions could be larger to justify the higher prices. Moreover, I don't understand WHY the bento boxes (i.e. Teriyaki Chicken & Mixed Tempura) is priced so high! For that reason, I probably won't be returning here, especially if I want non-fish options. That kind of stuff shouldn't be priced so high because it's produced locally. I would understand if it were Kobe beef or something.. but chicken? And to add insult to injury, the chicken that I received that night was a bit on the dry side. Not sure if it was an isolated incident but for the high price I expect quality or even naturally raised organic style chicken...now we're talking! Anyway, now I feel cheated in that respect. Sorry Hiro, on to the next spot!

"Although the culinary offerings at this establishment were satisfactory, they fell short of excellence due to a few key deficiencies. Specifically, the poultry dish we sampled was somewhat lacking in moisture, while the BBQ sandwich was comparably unremarkable. However, the ribs truly stole the show, boasting an impressive richness of flavor that nearly compensated for the previous disappointments. Furthermore, the abundance of side dishes available was truly astounding, and each of the four we selected proved to be delectable. Unfortunately, our experience was marred by a notable delay in the fulfillment of our order, during which time numerous patrons who placed their orders subsequent to ours received their takeout meals before we did. This inexcusable lapse in service was partially redeemed by the apologetic demeanor and generosity of the gentleman manning the cash register, who offered us a complimentary dish as restitution. Despite these setbacks, I remain willing to give this restaurant another chance, optimistic that our encounter was merely an anomaly."

My spouse and I opted for an early evening repast, selecting an alfresco dining experience on the outdoor patio, which, while pleasant, was somewhat marred by the audible sounds emanating from the adjacent thoroughfare. The interior atmosphere was stifling and cacophonous, rendering the exterior seating option a more appealing alternative. The flatbread and garlic-infused spherical bread basket was satisfactory, arriving at our table warm and fresh. However, upon the arrival of the primary course, my spouse expressed disappointment with the meager proportions of his linguine and clam dish, quipping that a visit to a fast food establishment may have been more satiating. The portion consisted of a scant seven minuscule clams and a mere half cup of pasta, raising questions about the sufficiency of the serving size. In contrast, my chicken marsala was generously proportioned, boasting rich flavors and an artistic presentation. Kindly sharing my culinary delight with my partner, we collectively decided to forgo a subsequent dining excursion to McDonald's. Unfortunately, the service we received was sluggish, further contributing to our ambivalence regarding a future visit.

"Subpar sushi experience with too much repetition."

Ra was the inaugural edifice where I had the privilege of partaking in sushi, and my initial impression was one of enjoyment; however, subsequent to expanding my culinary boundaries and sampling the offerings of various other sushi establishments (Hiro et al.), I came to the realization that there exist superior alternatives throughout the valley.

In the event that you opt to visit this establishment, I would recommend indulging in the Las Vegas roll, whose ingredients remain unclear to me, and the calamari roll, which boasts a combination of fried calamari, cream cheese, white rice, and is topped with both eel sauce and tempura flakes. These two options are relatively palatable and outshine their other offerings by a considerable margin.

It is worth mentioning that Ra offers satisfactory happy hour deals. Nonetheless, it is imperative to acknowledge that the sushi rolls served here are noticeably diminutive in size compared to those offered at other establishments I have visited.

Urban Outfitters' presence within Mandalay Place's second floor premises appears to mirror its various other establishments, boasting an extensive array of laid-back attire and a plethora of playful novelty items and literature positioned at the store's entrance, while Mandalay Place and Mandalay Bay share a complimentary parking facility, accessible via self-parking.

***This Urban Outfitters (located on the second floor of Mandalay Place) seems very similar to all the other Urban Outfitters locations out there--good selection of casual clothes and quite a few funny gag gifts/books located at the front of the store***\n\nMandalay Place shares a free parking structure with Mandalay Bay (self-parking).

"It has been an extended period of time since my last visitation to a retail establishment specializing in offering goods at a fixed price point of $.99. My recent absence from such a store has resulted in a significant loss of awareness regarding the abundance of advantageous transactions available to consumers. In light of the current economic climate, characterized by widespread financial constraints, it is essential to optimize one's search for superior value. Thus, I recommend periodic perusal of this particular store, as it houses a diverse array of items, ranging from tableware and cookware to an assortment of canned comestibles. It is highly likely that a cursory examination of the merchandise will uncover at least one item that meets your needs or piques your interest, making a visit to this establishment a worthwhile endeavor."

"I believe their culinary offerings possess a certain degree of quality, however, it appears that an order fulfillment deficiency persists, as evidenced by the consistent omission of crucial components from my salad, specifically the absence of the advertised pear, which is particularly vexing given my explicit articulation of said expectation to the server. Furthermore, I have encountered instances where my request for blue cheese dressing has been disregarded, only to be replaced by ranch, an unacceptable substitute. These recurring inconsistencies, coupled with the premium pricing, engender a sense of annoyance and dissatisfaction. Notwithstanding, the staff has consistently demonstrated a willingness to rectify their mistakes and provide compensation, yet the frequency of these errors remains a concern."

I think their food is pretty good BUT it never fails Every time I order the pear salad it's always missing something! It's like the waitress isn't listening. Or I order wings and I ask for blue cheese and always get ranch! It's little things like this that makes the experience and the prices I pay irritating. I want to get what I pay for. I don't want to get home with my take out and dip a wing and discover its in a dressing I hate or that my salad is all together wrong! BUT they are always very accommodating and fix their error and compensate me for it, but it happens all too often.

"The establishment's interior surpasses its exterior appearance, boasting a pristine atmosphere that belies its age and size. Upon ordering my meal to be consumed off-premises, I received a chicken noodle soup served within a bread bowl. Unfortunately, the bread receptacle was quite frigid upon removal from the carrying case, necessitating a brief exposure to microwave radiation to enhance its temperature. While the soup exhibited exceptional flavor, the bread accompanying it proved somewhat lacking in taste and became unpleasantly sodden at an alarming rate. Essentially, the bread bowl consisted of a standard dinner roll with a central aperture, which seemed slightly underwhelming. Furthermore, I concurred with a previous patron's assessment regarding the unsavory nature of the staff member's behavior involving his posterior and subsequent return to sandwich preparation. Nonetheless, I must applaud their beverage options, specifically the Coca-Cola machine offering an impressive array of over one hundred flavors. Despite this positive aspect, I am inclined to explore alternative dining venues for future meals, albeit without entirely dismissing the possibility of a subsequent visit based on my tolerable experience."

The store is very clean, and looks a lot newer and bigger on the inside than it does on the outside. I got my order to go, which was chicken noodle in a bread bowl. The bread bowl was cold when I took it out of the bag, and I had to microwave it for a few seconds. The soup tasted amazing but the bread was pretty bland and got soggy VERY fast. Basically the bread bowl was just a dinner roll with a hole punched in the middle of it. I read someone else's review about the man scratching his behind and then returning to making the sandwiches and also thought that was pretty gross. I have to commend them for having the coke soda machine with over 100 flavors, though. I will probably just eat somewhere else next time, but it wasn't too bad of an experience.

"Reliable and venerable establishment, Beanscene, has consistently served as my preferred venue for a substantial cup of Americano, coupled with a complimentary perusal of the day's news and a tranquil atmosphere conducive to focused studying, all within the confines of its spacious leather booths, for numerous academic years. The harmonious confluence of welcoming staff, mellifluous background tunes, and an individualized approach, distinct from the impersonal nature of larger commercial enterprises, has fostered a gratifying and dependable experience that perpetually lures me back. Although, I must admit, my visits have been primarily motivated by the desire to partake in their diverse assortment of expertly crafted coffee beverages, rather than indulging in their menu offerings, which include nachos and paninis; nonetheless, Beanscene's inviting ambiance and commitment to quality remain unwavering."

Of all the establishments catering to a predominantly homosexual clientele within the city limits, 941 perhaps ranks in the middle of them all in terms of overall quality and appeal. There is nothing particularly remarkable or deplorable about this venue, and it blends in seamlessly with its surroundings, making it easily overlooked by passersby who are not familiar with its reputation as a gay bar. Having stated this, the ambiance and enjoyment of one's visit can vary greatly depending on the time of day and the specific crowd present during that period. On a recent Saturday afternoon, I had the pleasure of partaking in their happy hour special, which featured a generously-sized Mai Tai cocktail served in a large glass for the reasonable price of $4.75. The bartender was quite affable and engaging, contributing to an overall positive experience. However, my previous visit to this establishment several months prior, in the company of my romantic partner, proved to be a somewhat mixed bag. The assortment of patrons present that evening was diverse and eclectic, to say the least, with some individuals exhibiting behavior and attire that could be described as eccentric or unconventional. Furthermore, the prices charged for alcoholic beverages seemed slightly exorbitant, especially when compared to other similar establishments in the area. Additionally, my order of a cranberry vodka was served in a minuscule glass containing only a fraction of the liquid present in my drink during my most recent visit. Thus, it is essential to approach this venue with a sense of flexibility and open-mindedness, as the quality of one's experience can fluctuate greatly depending on various factors.

I've wanted to try this place for a long time now, every time I go to Vegas I see it and the building draws me towards it. Finally got to try it during my last trip out there. 
The wait was ridiculous for inside seating (2 hours +) so we decided to grab some food inside of the Ceasar's food court then later go back to their outside window to order some frozen hot chocolates. 
The line was pretty long still for the outside and we figured out why when we got up to the window FINALLY.. the guy who was working was all by himself struggling to juggle everything all at once, poor guy.
We had 7 girls so we shared two large frozen hot chocolates which are made for two people but it was just enough, just get extra straws if you're going to do so. It was really good but truthfully tasted like a typical chocolate milkshake but more chocolate flavorings which was good, I also actually liked the grittiness from the mixture.
It was good to try but not worth the $8.00
