Tasty tacos in a slightly too-cute interior.  While the tacos were tasty (I tried three of the meat variety), I thought the rice and beans were a little bland.\r\n\r\nI'll head back but if I'm craving Mexican, there are better options.

I opt to visit Outback due to the predictability of the culinary experience they offer, which is characterized by consistently palatable fare, a spotless ambiance, and passable, albeit unremarkable, customer service. This particular establishment fulfills all of the aforementioned criteria. Two individuals, including myself, partook in an evening repast at 5 pm, thereby avoiding the throngs that often congregate during peak dining hours.

I go to Outback because you know what you are going to get. The food is good, place is clean, service is average or better. This location meets all of the above.\n2 of us went at 5pm for dinner beating the crowds.

There has been an improvement from when this was Terrible Herbst. The food is better and the service is slightly faster than before. The $10 specials are still a good value. I have always liked the Cafe over the Buffet even when the buffet was comped. The one remaining problem is that this is where old waitresses go to die. Slow and often need ing to ask two or three times for condiments or set ups for additional people.
Pretty standard theatre, never had a bad experience here, except sometimes it can be crowded, and of course its expensive. Except matinee = $5!
I just hate the lines at Walmart and it takes for ever to get in and out of this place. Need to open up more registers.

I had held such elevated expectations for this establishment, given that my colleagues had extolled its virtues to such an extent. The carne asada tacos were indeed impressive, possessing a certain je ne sais quoi that rendered them tantamount to culinary perfection. Conversely, the shrimp tacos were somewhat lackluster, prompting me to express a desire for additional carne asada tacos in lieu of the crustacean variety. Alas, the service proved to be sluggish, with a prolonged delay of approximately 15 minutes elapsing before the procurement of my beverage, specifically a beer, which, according to my associates, was frequently unavailable, particularly in the case of Dos Equis. Our party consisted of eight individuals, thereby necessitating a sizable table. Unfortunately, the majority of orders were botched, with only a pair of checks being executed correctly. The rectification of these errors required a considerable amount of time, approximating 20 minutes, during which period the server appeared visibly exasperated. The male staff member responsible for transporting the comestibles manifested signs of annoyance, understandably so, given the multitude of mistakes that had been committed. However, as paying patrons, it is reasonable to assume that our orders should be fulfilled accurately. Thus, I shall endeavor to visit this establishment once again prior to relinquishing hope entirely, with the expectation of potentially modifying my assessment in the future. Additionally, I must advise against the frozen margaritas, priced at $7 for a diminutive quantity of questionable potency, suitable only for those who are less than robust in their constitution.

"Satisfactory culinary experiences. Beverages of an alcoholic nature. Regrettably, a prolonged waiting period is customarily associated with the consumption of piscine entities on the fifth day of the week. Notwithstanding this inconvenience, the aforementioned edible aquatic organisms, whether submerged in oil or subjected to heat via direct flame, are of superior quality. A strong fondness exists towards the aforementioned establishment's deep-fried fungi."

"Diminuative Mexican eatery discovered serendipitously while seeking an alternative culinary establishment. Menu offerings are succinct, comprising merely ten options. Observed during my visitation, a solitary, hirsute gentleman, devoid of any discernible Mexican ancestry, attended to both the culinary preparations and customer service. Each table boasts its unique assortment of fiery condiments and diminutive vessels brimming with seasonings. My curiosity regarding this minuscule edifice is piqued, prompting further exploration. The interior design integrates elements of tiki huts, Mexican flags, Frida Kahlo's artwork, paper lanterns, miscellaneous cinematic posters, and laminated menus. Additionally, they provide a variety of traditional Mexican confectionaries and potables. Enchiladas smothered in mole sauce constituted my meal of choice, which, while not exemplifying proficiency in mole sauce preparation, proved satisfactory, albeit my limited exposure to this quintessential Mexican delicacy. The kitchen's diminutive size suggests that the majority of their offerings undergo reheating in a microwave oven, a practice that, while unremarkable, remains understandable given the constraints imposed by the compact cooking area. An endearing and memorable dining experience, which, owing to its novelty, warrants repetition."

Tiny Mexican hole in the wall I found while looking for a different restaurant. The menu is brief - ten items.  When I was there, it was one bearded not very Mexican guy taking the orders and making the food. Every table has its own selection of hot sauces and little pots of seasonings.  I'm incredibly curious about this little restaurant. The decor is a mix of tiki hut, Mexican flags, Frida Kahlo art, paper lanterns, random movie posters and laminated pictures from the menu. They also have a selection of Mexican candies and beverages.

I had the enchiladas with mole sauce and they were good - I'm no mole expert but in my limited experience I felt that the sauce was a good example of Mole.  The kitchen is very tiny and I'm thinking that most everything they serve is reheated in a microwave but I also realize that this is probably the case in many situations where the kitchen is not visible.  

All in all a neat little experience and I would go again.

Service was great but drinks and prices were horrible.  Mojito and margarita were served in plastic cups with more ice than drink, paid eleven each for lunch time.  Nachos were great but wasn't exactly how we ordered.  Probably wouldn't come to this one again..I'll stick with the locations I know and trust.

"Having observed an extensive array of performances, it is evident that this particular production fell short of expectations. Numerous errors in coordination among the cast members detracted significantly from the overall enjoyment, further exacerbated by the discourteous behavior of certain staff members. Prior to the commencement of the show, one performer announced that flash photography was prohibited; however, following this declaration, audience members opted to disable their camera flashes, only to be confronted by a rude elderly woman who not only admonished them for taking photographs but also attempted to physically confiscate their cameras, citing a blanket ban on photography during the performance. It would be advisable for the show's organizers to provide clearer instructions regarding photography restrictions to avoid such unpleasant encounters. Moreover, the quality of the show itself was subpar, rendering it a less-than-desirable experience for viewers. In conclusion, while the performance may have had some redeeming aspects, the prevalence of mistakes and poor staff conduct made it an underwhelming experience, thereby warranting a below-average rating."

"My affection for the atmospheric charm of this establishment and its visually appealing bar design has been consistent, yet my culinary experience during my most recent visit was somewhat mixed; while the fried bologna sandwich proved to be an exceptional item on the menu, the absence of any white wine varieties from their selection during a peak holiday period raised concerns regarding their inventory management practices, leading me to deduce that a more attentive approach to stocking their beverages would greatly enhance the overall quality of their service."

I normally love the ambience of this place and the beautiful layout of the bar.  Food is OK, but the fried bologna sandwich is excellent.  Didn't give it 5 stars because I went in there last Saturday over Memorial Day weekend, sat at the bar, and ordered a glass of white wine to go with my lunch.  The bar didn't have ANY white wine - no chardonnay, no sauvignon blanc, no pinot grigio - nothing.  What kind of bar doesn't have white wine on a holiday weekend?  They need to do some inventory control.  No wonder the place was deserted.

Had the fried chicken salad. Wish they would add a grilled chicken salad. Trying to make good choices with my dining, and fried chicken strips on a salad is counter productive. Waitress/bartender was on the spot.\n\nIf you go between 4 - 6 don't sit facing the window, the Sun blinds you like a Gamma Ray. I asked the bartender if she could shut the blind as the sun was reflecting off a wind shield and boring a hole in my face, I pointed at the window.  She proceeded to shut all blinds but the one that had the super nova coming through.

Regular sports bar with a couple of unique amenities.  Large patio on the Scottsdale greenbelt.  Menu where every sandwhich has a corresponding salad version (essentially replace the bread with lettuce).  Lots of specials, and a fun birthday offer.  It's quite large with multiple sections, and televisions all around.

Good food but service could have been a bit better. Try the dumplings on the appetizer menu... They are the best! Also the blended margaritas are stiff so watch yourself because before you know it you will be riding a nice buzz!

A cursory examination of the gaming facility revealed a substantial quantity of individuals meandering throughout the premises, which seemed to suggest a high level of popularity among patrons. The employees were quite hospitable, offering assistance and answering queries with great alacrity. However, the prices charged for beverages were somewhat prohibitive, and one could infer that the establishment did not cater specifically to those with limited financial means.

"It's Walgreens, three stars, as it's merely a standard, unremarkable establishment offering nothing extraordinary or unique, thereby precluding the possibility of a higher rating; however, I would consider awarding an additional star if they were to diversify their offerings by introducing alcoholic beverages such as wine and beer, which might enhance the shopping experience for patrons like myself."
its walgreens, 3 stars since its just the same ole thing...hmmm...I wish I could give it 4 stars, maybe if they start selling wine and beer!
Pretty good, not the best but very far from bad. Haven't been disappointed yet and we eat here about once a week. The Thai basil is really good as well as the steak salad.

"A conventional dining establishment with a familiar ambiance, devoid of any extraordinary features. The refurbishment from its predecessor within the Tropicana resort primarily involves superficial alterations, yet still manages to create a welcoming atmosphere that dispels the need for post-dining cleansing rituals. The interior design exudes a tranquil coastal charm, incorporating calming hues and elements reminiscent of a seaside setting. Patrons can relish the picturesque views of the Tropicana pool's cascading water feature from select vantage points, while having the option between indoor and alfresco seating areas. The hospitality of the staff is warm and inviting, complemented by the scrumptious fare and generous portion sizes, all of which justify the slightly elevated prices compared to its antecedent eatery."

This particular Dillard's location can be described as merely satisfactory, as my experiences within its confines have been inconsistent and varied. During my previous visits, I have procured several dresses and blouses, yet the service provided by the sales associates in the women's dress department has been either excessively intrusive or utterly absent, failing to strike a balance between the two extremes. In contrast, my encounters with the accessories department personnel have been relatively more pleasant, as they appear genuinely interested in understanding customers' needs and providing appropriate assistance. However, a recent episode involving a return of an item in pristine condition with accompanying tags attached, albeit slightly beyond the return policy time frame, resulted in the store manager offering me a store credit, which I appreciated, considering my awareness of the return policy limitations. In summary, this store can be characterized as average, and while I intend to revisit it due to its diverse selection of dresses and tops, I remain hopeful for a truly exceptional customer service experience, which I believe should be a standard aspect of any shopping excursion.

This Dillard's location is just okay. I have purchased a few dresses and tops from this location over the last couple of months and every time I have been in my experience has only been so so. The sales associates in the women's dress department can be either too pushy or completely non existent but not a good balance of one or the other. I have had a little bit of a better experience in the accessories department and the associates in that department seem to be more interested in what you are looking for and how to help rather than just making a sale. I also had an issue recently with needing to return an item that was in perfect condition with tags attached but it had been just a few days over the return policy limit. The manager was able to give me a store credit which I appreciated because I knew I was over the limit of the return policy. Overall this store is just okay. I will be back because I like their selection of dresses and tops but I am still waiting for that wow customer service experience that I think you should get no matter where you are shopping.

"The consumption of falafel was analogous to ingesting granular particles of earth, genuinely resembling the sensation of devouring sand. Indeed, the exterior presented an excessive crispiness, evoking memories of seaside excursions where the fine grains of sand had an unfortunate propensity to insinuate themselves into my oral cavity. Furthermore, the falafel plate was accompanied by a serving of rice, a mixed greens salad, and a pita bread, yet lacked any substantial dipping sauce, such as hummus, to alleviate the aridity of the meal. A minuscule quantity of tahini was provided in a small plastic ramekin, which proved insufficient in offering respite from the pervasive dryness. In light of this, I implore my fellow Yelp reviewers to opt for either the falafel sandwich or alternative value meals, thereby avoiding the unpleasantness of parched oral cavities at a Greek pita eatery. Additionally, the prices charged for these meals were deemed excessive, with a falafel plate accompanied by a carbonated beverage amounting to nearly $12, while the inclusion of hummus as a means of addressing the aforementioned dryness issue would result in a total cost of approximately $16 to $17 for a single individual."

Falafel was like eating sand.  Yes, real sand.  The outside was overly crispy and it reminded me of beach experiences when sand got in my mouth.

Falafel plate comes with rice, salad, and pita.... yet no hummus or anything substantial to dip the pita into.  Tahini?  No, not that whole pita into a little plastic ramekin of tahini.  Dry, dry, dry and no relief to be found.  

Please, fellow yelper, stick with the falafel sandwich or other value meal.  No need for dry mouth syndrome at a greek pita place.

Also it's overpriced.  Falafel plate with soda is just under $12.  If you order hummus to remedy the dry mouth issue then you're bumping up to $16-17 for ONE person.

So-so food but service from the strangest duo of waitresses I've encountered. \"Strange\" here meaning \"bad\" and \"off-putting.\"\n\nI'll not be back at this location; the experience was too odd to return.

As a fervent Milwaukeean residing at the Wynn, I felt compelled to partake in the culinary offerings of the in-house Bartolotta's restaurant, despite my ignorance of their origins as a Milwaukee export. However, my gastronomical journey was somewhat curtailed due to my personal aversion to seafood (which is flown in fresh from the Mediterranean daily), which I deemed excessively extravagant, albeit comprehensible given the arid climate's dearth of aquatic delicacies. Thus, I opted for a select few pasta dishes and a portion of pancetta. While the pancetta proved to be somewhat chewy and fatty, I anticipated such characteristics; nevertheless, it could have been more refined. In contrast, the sheep's milk ravioli delighted my taste buds, although the spaghetti accompanied by ragu could have been more flavorful. Ultimately, my satisfaction with Bartolotta's was limited, primarily due to the premium pricing; nevertheless, I acknowledge that dining alfresco might have enhanced my overall experience. In my modest opinion, the Wynn would greatly benefit from incorporating Bartolotta's Lake Park Bistro, a Milwaukee staple, into its establishment.

"In the month of June, I composed a review of this corporation that was less than complimentary in nature, primarily due to the fact that our gazebo sustained damage as a direct result of the fallen palm tree branches. Subsequent to this occurrence, we arrived at a mutually agreeable understanding, and the organization demonstrated a commendable level of magnanimity by replacing and compensating us for the aforementioned damages. My sincere gratitude extends to them for their efforts in averting any future occurrences of a similar nature. Throughout the entire process, they displayed an exceptional standard of clientele service, persistently striving to find a resolution that would prove satisfactory to both parties involved."

Back in June I wrote an unsatisfactory review of this company due to them damaging our gazebo from the fallen palm tree branches. We've come to an agreement and they were nice enough to replace/compensate for the damages it caused. Thank you for that so I'm sure it won't happen again. They have been nice enough to work things out with us no matter what and has shown good customer service regarding the issue. It has been resolved nicely.

I visted Edinburgh on my honeymoon in September. Our first full day of exploring must start with a bountiful breakfast so we had energy to explore all day. We strolled down to the Grassmarket from our hotel on Prince's St. Looking up and down, we chose Cafe Jacques because it had the most customers dining. A good indicator is how busy the place is, right?

We squeezed in, and I DO mean squeezed because it's tiny, and found a seat. I had a traditional English breakfast and my hubbie the American. The coffee was SO HOT and I made the mistake of trying to gulp my first taste as I tried to caffeinate my jetlagged self. My mouth was scorched for the next two days at least. Although we received a weird look, the waiter brought my husband two tall glasses of milk on request. Is that an American thing to drink milk with breakfast?

As my three stars indicate, this place was A-OK and got us going on our first full day in Edinburgh.

We decided to partake in a midday repast at this establishment, situated along the famed Las Vegas Strip, based on the copious acclaim it has garnered. Upon arriving on a Friday afternoon, we were fortunate enough to avoid any considerable queues and were promptly seated in close proximity to the expansive windows offering an unobstructed panorama of the vibrant Strip. However, our table was positioned at a considerable distance from the culinary offerings, which proved to be a minor drawback. Nevertheless, we were undeterred and viewed this circumstance as an opportunity to engage in some light physical exertion. 

We began our gastronomical journey by perusing the extensive salad bar, followed by a comprehensive exploration of the entire buffet. The layout was intelligently designed, featuring numerous action stations and an abundance of diversity. While the flavors left something to be desired, the beet salad was a notable exception, boasting an extraordinary quality that surpassed our expectations. Unfortunately, the remaining dishes fell short of impressing us, with most being merely average. Nonetheless, the unrestricted beer and wine selection was a welcome feature, and the root beer available on tap was particularly enjoyable. 

Our server's attentiveness was somewhat inconsistent, as evidenced by the occasional prolonged presence of soiled dishes on our table. Despite this, we harbor a desire to sample alternative establishments prior to giving this one another chance, primarily due to the reasonable $16 price point for lunch that accommodates a wide range of tastes.

Yesterday I needed to meet a client from North of the valley and I had other customers to visit in Deer Valley.  There are not many places in the area open for breakfast that are not chains so I picked here.  Getting there at 8 I probably missed most of the folks getting breakfast or picking up a sandwich to take with them for lunch. The guy who runs the place has almost an attitude but you warm up to him pretty quick.  

I ordered the Max burrito which comes with egg, potato, cheese and your choice of bacon, sausage or ham ($4.29). It was pretty tasty.  It is moderate sized.  Price per ounce is easily twice that of a similar burrito at most of the local Mexican fast food places.  Part of that cost is location (Deer Valley is not cheap) and employee cost.

While I was there there was a steady stream of folks coming in but never really busy.  It is hard sometimes to get in the parking area because of the backup for the Dunkin Donut located at the other end of the building.

I am sure I will go back again because it isn't a chain, the food was OK and the service was pleasant.

I'm going to settle this once and for all, since everyone seems beyond confused about the three China Stars in town. I drive past both of the Murray Ave China Stars every day (both located across the street from a Giant Eagle, presumably just to puzzle us more) and based on the addresses have confirmed the following--

THIS CHINA STAR:
-4219 Murray Ave, in Greenfield
-At the old location of Yen's Gourmet
-No affiliation with the China Star in the North Hills
-Standard American-Chinese food

THE OTHER CHINA STAR (http://www.yelp.com/biz/china-star-pittsburgh-3):
-1900 Murray Ave, in Squirrel Hill
-At the old location of Pacific Ring
-Affiliated with the China Star in the North Hills
-Traditional Chinese food

So, there you have it. A guide to the China Stars of Murray Avenue. I, personally, have only ordered from this China Star and cannot comment on the other.

For Chinese takeout--and I mean cheap, greasy, fried "Chinese" food--China Star is awesome. I mean, yeah, every Chinese takeout place with the infamous red menu is pretty much the same, and I feel stupid even writing a review of one on Yelp. But I get a craving for General Tso's Chicken, Pork Lo Mein, Cold Sesame Noodles, and Fried Dumplings about once a month, and now having tried several of Pittsburgh's Chinese options based on price and convenience, I gotta say China Star is my number one choice. Everything just tastes GOOD. I totally can't justify giving a Chinese restaurant more than 3 stars, but next time you feel the need to pig out on greasy takeout food, I'd highly recommend China Star.
Fish and chips typical irish fare, have some good bands that plays there as well great for happy hour and hang outs great staff as well. U2 tribute band Joshua tree usually plays out there.

This place is cool, but it pales in comparison to the Foundation Room, which sits at the top of the same hotel.  The music here was okay and the atmosphere here is kinda cool, but get yourself on the list for the Foundation Room to check out the cool club at Mandalay Bay.

I think that the Monte Carlo has seen better days. It was once pretty dang nice and one of the best placed to go on the Strip, but it is starting to show some wear and tear. There is a -5 Bar, but it isn't the better one. I can see that there is some renovation going on, so that might mean that the place is on the up-swing. It is right in the middle of the Strip which makes it prime for those that want to stay in a central location. However, I think that I would not likely get a room here and opt for one of the newer, shinier places.

"The ambiance of Beckett's Table is undeniably captivating, boasting an assortment of elements that contribute to its allure, such as the strategic arrangement of the restaurant's layout, the aesthetically pleasing water glasses and table settings, and an atmosphere that exudes warmth and hospitality. However, my culinary experience at this establishment did not quite live up to my expectations, despite my initial enthusiasm.  

While the bacon cheddar biscuits possessed a certain je ne sais quoi that made them enjoyable, the apple honey butter accompanying them was regrettably too firm and lacked the desired spreadability, thereby diminishing my overall satisfaction with the dish. Similarly, both the green chile pork stew and the osso buco failed to elicit any extraordinary praise from my palate, neither dish offering any remarkable features that might have elevated them above the realm of mediocrity.  

Nevertheless, one particular dish managed to surpass my expectations, namely the chocolate-dipped bacon s'mores. By venturing outside my comfort zone and opting for this unconventional dessert, I was pleasantly surprised by its delectable flavors, with the homemade peanut butter being a particularly delightful component that harmonized beautifully with the remaining elements of the dish, resulting in a truly satisfying culinary experience."

I really like the ambiance of Beckett's Table, from the way the restaurant is set up to their water glasses and table settings. I just didn't fall in love with their food. 

I liked the bacon cheddar buscuits, but would have liked them more if the apple honey butter wasn't so rock hard and was easily spreadable. I tried to the green chile pork stew and the osso buco and I definitely wasn't blown away by either of them. Neither dish had anything special to it, not to say they were bad, but didn't overly impress me. 

My favorite dish was probably the chocolate dipped bacon s'mores. I definitely went out on a limb ordering this, but I was pleasently surprised. The homemade peanut butter was excellent and all of the parts of this dessert complimented each other very well.
Didnt feel great after eating this. Poor service. But good veggie options as always. Too expensive.  When i went there they ran out of spring rolls. Definitely not filling either.

Perfect location, fresh food, maybe-a-little-too-small-of-portions.

Just outside of the Henderson Whole Foods, LYFE Kitchen is the ideal restaurant to be found. Before going on our weekly shopping trip today, we decided to walk a few steps over to grab a bite to eat. I ordered the vegan thai curry bowl and a hibiscus tea while my beau ordered the grass-fed burger and a cafe mocha. 

The drinks: to die for. I found the hibiscus tea extremely flavorful and refreshing, and he found the cafe mocha tasty and (as he was hoping) energizing. The meals: small portions, decent flavor. My vegan thai curry bowl tasted great but was a little more spicy than I was prepared for. It also could have stood for more wheatberries and a little more tofu, as well, rather than so many filler vegetables. His grass-fed burger was good and had a slight hickory flavor. 

At the conclusion of the meal, though, we were still kind of hungry and were left wishing there was more food on each plate. I was also left with two questions: Is the tofu organic? What about the grass-fed beef? If not, then I don't see the point of coming to a restaurant that is marketed as health-conscious to eat conventionally grown soy and meat - yuck!

We may return to try a couple of the other menu items, but next time it won't be when we're super hungry!
The food was really good, but the service was bad. The waitress was hard to find and they were far from busy. It also took like 5 minutes just to get a soda & the same amount of time for water.

"Gastronomical indulgences of considerable quality, albeit at a slightly elevated cost. The establishment's signature cable cars, in particular, merit high praise for their delectable flavors. While the culinary offerings were undoubtedly satisfying, they fell short of exceptional. For an economical morning repast, I would suggest patronizing the Bellagio's lavish buffet, which provided a comparable gustatory experience at a more reasonable price point."

"We were compelled to revise our assessment subsequent to sampling the Thin Crust variety, which regrettably failed to meet our expectations in terms of both taste and texture. The pizza was utterly deplorable, and its removal from the menu would be a judicious decision. Despite being persuaded by staff members that it was superior to alternatives offered by Rosati's and Oregano's, we were sadly mistaken. The crust was unyielding and tasted more like cardboard than dough, rendering it nearly impossible to bite into. However, the Penne pasta accompanied by a rich meat sauce proved to be an agreeable exception to the disappointing pizza experience. If pizza remains your primary preference, we suggest adhering to the Butter Crust Deep Dish option."

Gotta update this review unfortunately after trying the Thin Crust.

It was HORRIBLE. Absolutely they should just remove it from the menu.

We decided to give it a go, got a Sausage and Bacon, after being promised it would be better than Rosatis thin and Oreganos. No chance. We had to send it back and ask for it to be removed from our tab. The crust was like cardboard and you could barely bite through it.

On the upside, the Penne pasta with meat sauce was fantastic.

If you come for Pizza, stick with the Butter Crust Deep Dish.

I'll leave my review at 3 stars for now.  This was my first visit to a Panera Bread to get sandwiches for dinner.  We needed a break from getting subs at different places and I chose to try something new.  This location opened recently.  It makes where I live about halfway between to Panera's but I decided to try this one.

Service was great at the counter, but the wait seemed long for the take out until I realized they had a number of people eating in who had ordered just before I got there.  I brought the sandwiches home and they were very good.  My wife had their Cuban chicken panini and I had the signature Steak and white cheddar.  They were both very good.  My panini had a fair kick from the horseradish spread on the sandwich.  With the sandwiches, I opted for the small bag of chips for each of us.

The order was packaged really nice in two small cardboard boxes.  My only complaint with this is there's really no way to tell which sandwich is which unless you peel back some of the bread to reveal the contents.  Some places put a numbered sticker on their sandwiches to match the items on your receipt.  The boxes at Panera have a place you could write the name.  I sent a suggestion to HQ and the responded that they'd look into it.

I'll return and I think I'll eat in.  The dining room is very nice and there's outdoor seating for when it's cooler.

Unfortunately, our culinary exploits did not incorporate a sweet conclusion, as we opted for a midday repast instead, which, despite the lackluster performance of the potato pancakes, was thoroughly relished. In the event of a future visit, I shall endeavor to sample the pastry offerings or patronize the establishment at a later hour and occupy a seat at the bar.
Unfortunately, we didn't have dessert.  Instead, we had brunch, and enjoyed it, although the potato pancakes were weak.  If I go back, I'll try dessert or go late in the day and sit at the bar.

Tequila selection isn't what it used to be, and the menu has a lot of inaccuracies (sorry sir, we don't have that tequila anymore either).  Food was alright but service was a chore, and it wasn't very busy either.

Being that I lived in SC for years I wasn't expecting much from Hokkaido. Some of the seafood dishes were the normal overly cooked american versions of Chinese that you can get anywhere, but they did have some interesting and tasty food. 

My BF liked some of the cooked beef. I liked the crab, and the sushi wasn't as bad as it could have been. The seaweed salad was better than expected. I LOVED the chocolate fountain! (who doesn't?)  

I was overall pleased with the food, but I expected a different atmosphere (I don't know what I was thinking). There were screaming kids in seats and running around EVERYWHERE! Bleh. I know they charge an extra fee for wasting food... they should charge one for bad ass kids too...

Rehabilitation Burger constitutes a quintessential neighborhood dive bar, boasting an ambiance that exudes an air of unpretentiousness, while simultaneously offering a diverse array of delectable beverages at reasonable prices, ensuring a gratifying experience for patrons seeking solace from the mundanity of everyday life. Their extensive burger menu showcases an assortment of mouth-watering options, including the Hangover Burger, which we opted to sample, accompanied by an order of sweet potato tots. Unfortunately, our culinary excursion proved somewhat underwhelming, as the burger arrived cooked to a well-done consistency, despite our explicit request for a medium-rare preparation; this disparity significantly influenced our perception of flavor. Given the abundance of exceptional burger establishments in the vicinity of Scottsdale, we might be inclined to explore alternative dining options in the future, rather than revisiting Rehabilitation Burger.

"On multiple occasions, I have traversed past the City Cafe via automobile, yet I have been unable to allocate sufficient time to partake in a culinary experience at this establishment. However, during a recent pedestrian excursion, I opted to halt my progress and sample their offerings for lunch. Presently, their luncheon menu is restricted, but the proprietor divulged his intentions to augment it in the near future. My repast consisted of a flavorsome burrito complemented by an exceptional glass of freshly brewed green iced tea. The entire experience was truly gratifying. I shall unquestionably return."

I've driven by the City Cafe several times, but I never had time to stop in.  The other day i was walking by and decided to try it for lunch.

They have a limited lunch menu right now, but the owner told me he was planning on expanding it.   I had a burrito and a marvelous glass of fresh brewed green iced tea.   It was great.

I will be back.

"I thoroughly enjoy the culinary offerings and the geographic convenience of this establishment, and the rooftop patio is an idyllic setting in which to indulge in said culinary delights. However, I must express my utter dismay and consternation at the exorbitant prices charged for potations. It appears that the proprietors have adopted a pricing strategy more commonly associated with gentlemen's clubs or high-end cocktail lounges, with beverages priced at a premium that is unprecedented in the local market. As a former employee of various drinking establishments, I am cognizant of the factors that contribute to the cost of libations, and I must aver that these prices are unreasonable and will unlikely resonate well with the local patronage. A more judicious approach to pricing would be advisable, lest the clientele opt for alternative beverages or, heaven forbid, take their business elsewhere. A modicum of fiscal restraint would be wise, lest the establishment suffer financial duress due to an overzealous attempt to recoup investment costs in the early stages of operation."

I love the food, location is great, love the rootop patio...no problems there\n\nBUT...the drink prices are FRIGGIN OUTRAGEOUS, as has been mentioned in other reviews. To get drink prices this high you either have to be drinkin' in a strip bar  or one of the ultra chi-chi bars uptown like Blue.....at least $2 higher on beer and $3-4 higher on drinks than ANY OTHER P-Wood bar. As I've worked in bars before I understand how drinks are priced and these prices are NOT gonna be popular around here. Everyone that I've heard talk about it has the same thing to say: \"great food, great location, plan on drinking tea or soda when you go unless you want to go broke..\"...C'Mon guys, you don't have to recoup your investment the 1st month by gouging folks on drinks; price them reasonably and you'll be around for a long time to make money...

Keep in mind their sign actually reads Taqueria Express.

This is a tiny little taco stand carved out of Fruteria El Pueblo just west of Woodlands on Albemarle. Orders are placed at a window overlooking a stuffed, hot kitchen. Food is quick and simple. Menu's surprisingly large - lots of tacos, quesadillas, burritos - didn't seen any Salva-or-Ecuadorian influences on there. Language could be an issue if you no tengo un pequeno espanol.

I have a thing for tortas, so that's what I got - and it was good. A little pricey (6.50 for huevos y queso) but easily one of the better ones I've had in CLT. Soft, sweet teleras, Monterey-Jacky cheese, shredded lettuce, some jalapenos. A mess to eat, but whatevs.

This isn't the "IT" torta, but it's totally worth a stop.

I have invariably been an ardent devotee of Outback, and my unwavering allegiance to this esteemed eatery has been consistently rewarded with a culinary experience that transcends the mundane and ascends to the realm of gastronomical excellence. Upon entering the establishment, I customarily opt for a seat at the bar, where the hospitable staff, with their unfailing affability and solicitous demeanor, orchestrate an atmosphere of conviviality and warmth that permeates the entire dining area. In a recent visit, I elected to sample their takeout offerings, and my expectations were once again met with an impressive display of culinary prowess, as the salmon and broccoli were prepared to perfection, with each bite showcasing the ideal balance of flavors and textures. However, my enthusiasm was momentarily curtailed by the sweet potato, which, regrettably, had been subjected to an excessive duration of thermal exposure, rendering it tragically overcooked and resembling a culinary casualty of an unfortunate magnitude. Nonetheless, this minor faux pas did not diminish my overall satisfaction with the meal, as the remaining components more than compensated for this isolated lapse in culinary judgment.

"Celebrated my natal anniversary at this culinary establishment in the company of colleagues and found the ambiance to be quite pleasing, thus prompting a return visit during the restaurant's 'happy hour' period, whereupon I experienced an enjoyable social interaction with acquaintances.  

While the prices may be considered somewhat elevated, the attentive and courteous demeanor of our server, a young woman adorned with a robot-themed tattoo, greatly enhanced our dining experience. 

Personally, I found the mixed drinks to be superior in quality compared to the food offerings, specifically the POLYNESIAN CHICKEN SANDWICH accompanied by SWEET POTATOE FRIES, which proved to be a satisfying culinary choice.  

The assortment of beverages available was quite impressive, and I would recommend attempting the Scorpion bowl, ideally in the presence of multiple companions."

Had lunch here for my birthday with co-workers and i liked the atmosphere so came back for the happy hour--had a great time with friends.  

Is a little expensive, but had great service from our server-girl with robot tattoo--so nice!

I think i loved the cocktails better than the food, POLYNESIAN CHICKEN SANDWICH was pretty good with the SWEET POTATOE FRIES!!  

Most drinks were fabulous, need to try the Scorpion bowl with lots of friends!

The ambiance and hospitality were thoroughly enjoyed, specifically pertaining to the arrangement and beverages; however, the deportment of the manager, distinguished by his gleaming baldness and an orthopedic boot, was regrettably tainted by an unmistakable demeanor of haughtiness and arrogance, even according to the assessment of our attentive server, which slightly marred an otherwise pleasant dining experience; nevertheless, the tariffs were reasonable, and although my culinary exploration was limited to hors d'oeuvres, they were satisfactory, albeit unremarkable.

Loved the set up..drinks. .and staff were friendly. .but the bald manager with the moon boot on ..totally had some kind of attitude. .even our waitress said he was a jerk..\nOther then that I would go back amd totally avoid this dick..prices are decent. .I only had appetizers they were ok..

The ambiance of this establishment exudes an aura of conviviality, rendering it an optimal venue for spectating athletic competitions. The personnel appear to be attentive and concerned with ensuring that patrons enjoy their experience. The menu boasts an array of delectable options, and the culinary offerings are generally perceived as savory and satisfying, particularly for a drinking establishment. However, my personal encounters at this location have been marred by instances of lukewarm fare arriving at my table, which has engendered a sense of displeasure and disappointment.

"As a neophyte, I indulged in my first meal of the day at this establishment, which offered an alimentary experience that was somewhat expensive but nonetheless delectable and served in an ambiance that was singularly captivating. Being present prior to the commencement of the midday repast, the venue was remarkably tranquil, with nary a soul in sight. However, my encounter was slightly marred by the youthful mechanical attendants, whose lack of warmth and courtesy, manifested in their failure to proffer a simple greeting or smile, detracted from the overall quality of my visit, thereby rendering it less exceptional than it could have been."

"While the culinary offerings were satisfactory, the ambiance was somewhat marred by an abundance of particulate matter scattered throughout the eatery, particularly on my designated seating area. I was taken aback by the sheer quantity of dirt and debris that seemed to have escaped notice. Compelled to express my concerns, I penned a brief missive. The attentive server, having espied both the grime and my scribbling, responded with a mirthful chuckle, acknowledging the issue with a nonchalance that bordered on incredulity."

Decent service, good food. However I have to admit seeing all this dust everywhere throughout the restaurant especially on my booth was pretty gross. I'm amazed how this went unnoticed. I took it upon myself to leave a little note. The server saw me and the dust and commented \"hahaha yeah there's a lot of dust here.\" Wooooooow really?

"Arrived fifteen minutes prior to the establishment's scheduled closure and encountered a mere ten-minute waiting period for the culinary preparation of the poultry dish.  This particular venue is rather diminutive in size, and the visual representations provided do not mislead prospective patrons.  The poultry was of satisfactory quality, though it is likely most palatable when served fresh and at an elevated temperature.  Some reviewers have noted that the seasoning is somewhat excessive, yet the spicy condiment accompanying the meal was quite enjoyable.  The female staff member was quite hospitable and generously offered a complimentary two-liter beverage and four supplementary pieces of poultry due to the fact that we were unable to be seated at the counter, as well as the fact that they were in the process of concluding operations for the day.  Unfortunately, the establishment did not have any of their signature red velvet pancakes available, which appears to be a recurring theme among the reviews pertaining to this eatery, yet I possess a second Groupon that I can redeem at a future date.  It is interesting to note that Flavor Flav's short-lived restaurant venture in Clinton, Iowa ultimately proved unsuccessful, and one can only hope that this particular location will experience greater longevity and prosperity.  While the food and service at this establishment are adequate, it is uncertain whether it would garner much success without the celebrity association.  Rating: Two stars, with an additional star awarded due to the novelty factor associated with Flavor Flav's involvement."

"It is a peculiar occurrence, indeed, when I opt to dine at an establishment with another individual and, subsequent to perusing Yelp, discover that said eatery possesses a mere two-star rating. The hospitality we received was somewhat unorthodox; specifically, the host's articulations were utterly incomprehensible to both myself and my fellow diner. Furthermore, there was a considerable delay between the arrival of my companion's soup and my own, and the noodles accompanying my duck meat soup were arguably undercooked. Notwithstanding these issues, the broth proved satisfying, as did the duck meat I managed to extract from the murky liquid. However, a dubious, overly salty, and potentially seaweed-like substance floated in my bowl, casting doubt upon its quality. Considering the premium prices charged by this particular venue (located within Caesar's Palace, no less), it seems wiser to venture outside and explore alternative dining options."

"Russ recommended dining at My Florist during the daytime, given our proximity to the establishment, but I countered by expressing my preference for indulging in a meal at a quaint eatery situated directly across the street from My Florist, which I had been eager to experience for some time; thus, we opted to patronize the latter venue instead. Although the culinary offerings at this particular restaurant may not have been particularly remarkable, the ambiance and overall aesthetic appeal of the setting did manage to leave a favorable impression upon me. Specifically, I ordered the chicken feta pita, which, while palatable, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi that would have elevated it to a truly memorable dining experience. Nonetheless, I must commend the proprietors of this establishment for their apparent attention to detail in terms of marketing and interior design, which, in my opinion, merits recognition and appreciation."

"A mid-morning repast on a drizzly Sunday, within the confines of an establishment boasting an aesthetically pleasing interior, was accompanied by an impressive level of customer service. However, the coffee, while visually appealing, failed to elicit even a modicum of enthusiasm. Perplexingly, the culinary offerings, despite their visual appeal and evident attention to preparation, lacked a certain je ne sais quoi; a seeming paradox, given the palpable care taken in their creation. A cursory examination of the menu revealed an array of options, each ostensibly crafted with an emphasis on quality ingredients and skillful technique. Regrettably, such promise remained unfulfilled, as the flavors proved uninspired and lackluster. Upon mentioning this discrepancy to our server, she graciously offered to compensate for the deficiency by waiving the cost of our beverages. Despite this gesture, my buckwheat crepe, cooked to perfection, unfortunately suffered from an unfortunate dearth of warmth in its core (a circumstance which led me to speculate that the ham had not been adequately warmed prior to being incorporated into the dish). This resulted in my only consuming a portion of the breakfast, as ennui set in around the one-third mark. Notwithstanding this underwhelming experience, I might still consider returning, motivated by the hope that alternative dishes will exhibit a more satisfactory equilibrium of flavors."

"Pink's Hot Dogs, I am utterly perplexed as to how you successfully enticed me into consuming your culinary offerings, yet somehow you managed to do so. A coterie of individuals, including myself, opted to partake in a gastronomical excursion to your esteemed establishment, primarily due to the widespread acclaim and praise that it has received from various patrons. My adventurous palate led me to order the Chili Cheese hot dog burrito, which consisted of two frankfurters enveloped in a tortilla along with chili and cheese. Although it provided a fleeting sense of satisfaction during a night of indulgence, I must admit that it had a rather deleterious impact on my digestive system. Perhaps, if I were to patronize your restaurant again in the future, I would be wise to opt for a more rudimentary hot dog, thus avoiding any potential gastrointestinal repercussions."

Pink's, I don't know how you seduced me, but you did. \n\nA small group of us stopped here because we were hungry and have heard people rave about this place. I was feeling brave and got the Chili Cheese hot dog burrito with two dogs, chili and cheese wrapped in a tortilla. It did the trick for a drunken evening, but man talk about super upset stomach! Maybe if I ever ate there again I should just try the basic hot dog.

"One of my preferred destinations due to its proximity to my place of employment, situated directly across from the building, thereby rendering it easily accessible via foot. The parking facilities are quite satisfactory, and even more so for myself, as I am able to traverse the short distance by walking. The prices of consumables are rather reasonable, with a hot dog or soda available for $4, and a combination package consisting of a hot dog, beverage, and popcorn offered at the affordable cost of $11. The vantage points afforded by the seating arrangement are quite acceptable, and provide ample opportunity for enthusiasts to pursue autographs from players. However, it is regrettable that the outfield grass is absent, a feature that has been lamented by another commentator. Additionally, the sensation experienced within one's gluteal region subsequent to occupying the metal bleacher-style seats positioned along the left field line for an extended period of time is less than desirable, although at a cost of $7, coupled with the advantageous parking, favorable location, and economical concessions, I find myself quite content."

I was present at the venue from Thursday until Sunday. Given that the accommodations were arranged through an external agency, I cannot express dissatisfaction with the cost since it was approximately half the price I discovered online through platforms such as Vegas.com, Expedia, and hotels.com. The lodging's site - a five-star establishment - was ideally positioned in the central portion of the renowned strip. The gambling establishment within the hotel merited five stars due to the presence of skilled croupiers and an abundance of engaging activities. Unfortunately, the culinary options only garnered two stars, as there was no Starbucks within the premises of the hotel. Moreover, there was no eatery available around the clock, obliging me to venture to Bally's to acquire a slice of pizza or a sandwich from Subway at three o'clock in the morning when I yearned for sustenance. Concerning the sleeping quarters, I would rate them two and a half stars. The bed was uncomfortable, possessing a springy and economical quality that caused discomfort for my back. Notwithstanding my relatively youthful age of thirty-one, the bed's quality was subpar. For reasons unknown, the television was situated at a distance from the bed, rendering it impractical to view from a recumbent position. Although the room appeared tidy and luxurious, it was predictable given the hotel's location on the strip. Considering the entirety of the amenities offered, I would assign an average rating of three stars. Despite some drawbacks, I would still consider returning to this establishment as it offers a reasonable value for a vacation. It is essential to note that, as a seasoned Las Vegas visitor, the hotel may appear more impressive to first-time guests.

"My grievance pertains not to the culinary offerings but rather to the ambiance and setting in which they are served. Specifically, I have a quibble with the physical location of the eatery as well as its aesthetic appeal, or lack thereof. Upon entering the establishment, my companion and I opted for the 'Lobster for Two' platter, a seemingly reasonable option given the steep prices listed on the menu. Our meal, while undoubtedly delectable, did not justify the exorbitant cost of approximately $150 for two individuals. Furthermore, the Chardonnay we accompanying our repast was quite satisfactory. However, the unpretentious nature of the restaurant, situated within a section of Caesars Palace reminiscent of a shopping mall, detracted significantly from our dining experience. The unassuming facade of the eatery resembled a storefront in a low-end retail complex, leaving much to be desired in terms of ambiance. Considering the tariff, I would expect a more refined dining environment. My attire, appropriate for an evening excursion, seemed incongruous amidst the kitschy embellishments adorning the walls, including cartoonish illustrations and an overall atmosphere evocative of a casual, informal venue. Notably absent were the ubiquitous peanut shells strewn across the floor, completing the unsophisticated ambiance. In conclusion, the costly fare coupled with the uninviting surroundings rendered our dining experience less than desirable."

Food is ok...drinks or ok...beer is beer but I love pubs so if I'm at mandalay Bay I stop for a pint no matter what!!!!  My ex says it's the best shepherds pie he's had in this whole entire life so maybe try that!

"My acquaintance and I are embarking on an expedition to discover the most delectable steak in the Valley, hence every time we gather for dinner, we opt to sample a distinct steak restaurant. Our excursion to Fleming's fell short of my expectations. 

I had been apprised of Fleming's exceptional happy hour offerings, which indeed presented numerous remarkable options. I shall return for that purpose. The service was adequate; we were seated at the bar. Furthermore, they boasted an impressive wine list with reasonable price points. 

Nonetheless, with regard to the steak: mine was cooked beyond my requested doneness (medium) and lacked sufficient trimming (I chose a filet). The sides were forgettable."

"An excellent venue for a rapid and affordable culinary experience. For neophytes to Filipino gastronomy, an auspicious initiation would be via the grilled delights and pancit. For those who crave more exotic flavors, the dinuguan (a savory concoction containing animal blood) or balut (a fertilized avian ovum), when accessible, are worthy alternatives. Although my maternal figure prepares superior renditions of these dishes, this establishment offers a satisfactory compromise between cost and expediency. However, I opt for take-out due to the occasional broadcasting of melodramatic and dismal Filipino soap operas on their televisual devices, which can create an unpalatable ambiance."

"Although I am reluctant to elaborate on the quality of service due to its cultural context, I must admit that the restaurant's hospitality leaves much to be desired. Specifically, the waitstaff's lack of friendliness and inability to display even the most basic of facial expressions, such as a smile, are truly unfortunate. However, it is worth noting that the eatery's culinary offerings more than compensate for the shortcomings in customer service, as they are of exceptional quality. In particular, the lunch special featuring shredded pork pan-fried noodles, when ordered "Hong Kong Style," is an absolute must-try. Likewise, the salt and pepper shrimps, complete with the head still intact, offer a rich and flavorful experience that transcends any initial reservations one might have about consuming the crustacean's cranium. Lastly, the salt fish and chicken fried rice, while perhaps not conforming to traditional Westernized Chinese cuisine preferences, is nonetheless a standout dish that boasts an expert balance of savory flavors."

"The quality of service at this establishment fluctuates depending on the time of day, with peak efficiency observable during non-peak hours.  A peculiar phenomenon we observed was the staff's propensity to inquire about our need for a beverage to alleviate the symptoms of a hangover, which we found amusing.  In light of this, and considering my penchant for sampling chicken fried steak whenever possible, I opted to order the Chicken Fried Steak for breakfast on both Saturday and Sunday.  My culinary experience was satisfactory, as the dish possessed an appropriate batter-to-meat ratio.  However, I must express my disappointment with the coffee shake, as its flavor profile did not resemble coffee and failed to meet my expectations, which have been set by the superior offerings of Jack in the Box.  Notwithstanding, I would still frequent this restaurant when staying at the Hard Rock, as it presents a viable alternative to the Pink Taco, which, while decent, does not compare to the gastronomic experience provided by this establishment."

The service here is ok, depending on the time of day.  What is pretty funny is in the morning the first thing we always got asked was if we needed a drink to cure our hangover.   So on Saturday and Sunday I ordered the Chicken Fried Steak for breakfast.  It was pretty good. Anywhere I go, if a place has chicken fried steak, I'll try it.  This place did not disappoint.  On Sunday everyone at my table ordered Chicken Friend Steak accept one person, because I thought it was good. After they tried it, they were glad they ordered it.  It has the right amount of batter to meat ratio.\n\nI didn't like the coffee shake.  It didn't taste like coffee, and Jack in the box can make a better shake.  But I will go there anytime I stay at the Hard Rock and really there is either this or the Pink Taco. Pink Taco was good too, but that is another review.

"My ardent desire is to wholeheartedly embrace the Daily Dose as my preferred venue for leisurely weekend repasts, owing to its ideal location that renders it a convenient and accessible destination for me. However, despite my persistent efforts to familiarize myself with the extensive and diverse menu offerings, I find myself incapable of fully committing to any particular dish, settling instead for unremarkable options such as omelets or French toast. Notwithstanding, I shall persist in my pursuit of a culinary experience that resonates with my discerning tastes, though my optimism wanes with each successive visit."

It has a Vue Cinema, the entrance to Britannia, Starbucks, Bear Company, M&S Food-Court, H&M, Superdry, Fat Face, HMV, Boots, FCUK, Baxter, GAP,  Debenhams and a beautiful laid out Food Court - with Zizzi, Burger Company etc.. 

I do like the food-court,  with its view over Fife and new developments of Newhaven. (I compare those views with Blade Runner scenes..) 

Not my favourite shopping centre - as it is more like an main street shopping missing the charity shops (apart from the Superdry Store) 
I go shopping here when I have a few hours to spare on a Sunday. 

It is clean building in and out and has got a straightforward layout  rectangular and 3 stories high. 

There is a car park and a bus terminus for Lothian buses 22, 35, 34, 36, 11
Also the tourist buses stop here. 

There are (still) plans to extend the (in)famous tram line to here but those are currently shelved

One of the smallest airport in the U.S.  Flew here for a short layover to Greenville (GSP).  Can't really stand small airport since all the planes are so small and me being 6'4\" is very difficult to sit comfortably in my seat.  Next time I'll fly into big airports.

Last night, we endeavored to partake in the culinary offerings of this establishment, and our experience was somewhat dichotomous. The ambiance was quite vibrant, with a considerable number of patrons present at 9:30 pm on a Tuesday. The interior design was tasteful and effectively utilized the available space. We sampled their miniature burgers, which were rather delectable. However, our interactions with the staff were not entirely satisfactory. A bartender approached my spouse and inquired about his desire for a beverage, yet failed to acknowledge my presence. Subsequently, my husband was served a beer that he had not requested. Two other bartenders demonstrated proficiency in their roles and exhibited a welcoming demeanor. Unfortunately, the initial bartender continued to neglect us throughout our visit, leaving our drinks unreplenished and ignoring us for an extended period of time after we had pressed the button to signal for payment. A fourth bartender proved adept at collecting empty plates and glasses, but did not inquire about our need for any additional assistance. Considering their recent opening, I may grant them another opportunity to demonstrate their capabilities.

"An abundance of exceptional beers are available on tap, including Modelo Especial, Negro Modelo, and Delerium Tremens, among others. The restaurant boasts a unique and intriguing concept, which is complemented by its offering of delectable nachos. While the service was not optimal, it is recommended that patrons sample the Florentine Nachos, a dish that showcases the culinary expertise of the establishment."
Lots of great beers on tap(Modelo Especial, Negro Modelo, Delerium Tremens, etc).  Great concept with the nachos.  Service could have been better.  Try the Flortentine Nachos!

"This particular Whole Foods market, situated within a relatively diminutive retail space, may be perceived as the 'baby bear' among its trio of sister stores within the locality, yet it does not compromise on either the range or diversity of its product offerings. Although I do not frequent this establishment as often as I do its larger counterparts, I must admit that I find the ambiance of this store to be quite appealing, perhaps due to its more intimate setting. 

Upon venturing into the produce department, I was delighted to discover an extensive array of fresh fruits and vegetables, including the presence of nopales, which added a touch of exoticism to the otherwise conventional selection. It is worth noting that the presentation of the produce section was consistently impressive, with nary a sign of disarray or neglect during my visits. 

While the meat counter may be somewhat smaller in scale compared to the other two locations, the deli, salad bar, and prepared foods sections were comparable in magnitude to those of its fellow branches. 

In conclusion, this particular Whole Foods store, despite its relatively modest proportions, manages to maintain a respectable level of quality and variety in its offerings, making it a suitable alternative for patrons seeking a convenient shopping experience without sacrificing the essence of the Whole Foods brand."

This Whole Foods is the baby bear of the three in town, but doesn't skimp on selection or variety. I don't come to this one too often, but I do like the feel it has just because it is in a smaller space.

I did notice they have an attractive produce section that included nopales! Their produce section is always really nicely put together when I'm there and very rarely do I see anything out of place-but again, I don't come in here that often.

Their meat counter is significantly smaller than the other two locations, but deli, salad bar, prepared foods section were about the same size as the other locations.

All in all, a decent branch of this chain.

What's better than mini golf? Mini golf with drunk people! After DW we came here to pass some time before those who did bottomless mimosas red glow receeded. Thanks Anthony M. for treating us to mini golf. You're nice and sassy when you're drunk. 

I think the name Putt Park is accurate as it was more like putting course than mini golf with fun themes. So judging purely from the course though, I wish they tried to at least make a few of them more difficult and unique. There were some that was rather similar. Still it was a good way to pass time and have fun bonding silly time with some of the best people. We did try to play a normal game, at least I did since I was pretty sober, but the drunkeness took over. A few times it took everyone to get the ball in which was entertaining. Aayyeeehehe. 

For $8.50 it is decent enough and at least your ball doesn't disappear into a hole that takes it like a lot of mini golf places does. It could have replay value I suppose if you really like to putt and get the most out of your admission, but once was good for us. 

Best advice - come here after being plastered at DW during brunch and it would be way more fun and be a great way to spend your afternoon like we did.

(Yelp 100 Challenge 23/100)

hmm.. $20 lunch buffet (on a Monday). not bad. definitely cheaper than the Wynn.

I pretty much ransacked the cocktail shrimp station and must've eaten half their supply when we were there. i tried the lamb, duck, turkey, pretty much a little bit of everything. all was decent enough.. but nothing amazing. the lamb with mint jelly was probably the highlight of my meal, along with the napoleon (dessert). dessert is my favorite part of the meal! i was slightly disappointed that they didnt have crab or lobster, but i guess for $20 wut do you expect. sushi was california rolls.. the kind i can make at home. the service (aka the person bringing us drinks) was good. 

hmm.. wut else.. nothing else i can really say about the buffet here.. i think next time i'll try the buffet at Paris.

I ate here w/my gal pal after a late night of poker and we sat at the bar where the bartender was very friendly and accomodating!  We shared a pizza and the dumplings (which come w/duck inside) and it was all pretty tasty.  This is your upscale version of the Cheesecake Factory...it all looks the same inside!

"The culinary delight of the lobster pot pie lived up to its acclaimed reputation, however, the quality of the service did not align with our expectations, as our server vanished for a considerable duration, resulting in a significant loss of potential revenue from beverage sales. Furthermore, it is advisable for the establishment to provide a more accurate estimate of the preparation time for their signature dish to avoid any misunderstandings and ensure a more satisfactory experience for all patrons, regardless of gender or demographic."

The lobster pot pie was fabulous, as billed, but the service was lacking.  Our waiter disappeared for a half an hour.  They could have sold us a lot of drinks in that amount of time, but missed out.\nI realize the pot pie is a signature dish, but they should set a better expectation of how long it takes to get it to table.  Perhaps if we three women instead of fifty year old guys we would have gotten more attention.

"Similarly to Jenny, I must aver that A-ok is an apt description of this establishment in a nutshell. On a recent Saturday visit, I endeavored to alleviate my hangover at this purported burger haven, being an ardent devotee of carnivorous cuisine. While my expectations were partially met, certain aspects fell short of excellence. The service, however, was commendable; the staff exhibited remarkable hospitality and offered insightful recommendations to patrons. My culinary selection included the Pestorica burger, adorned with relish, pesto, and mozzarella, accompanied by a side of onion rings paired with diverse dipping sauces. Upon presentation, the burger's appearance was indeed impressive, boasting a generous size and vibrant colors from the vegetables and cheese. Unfortunately, the patty itself was too diminutive in thickness, rendering it incapable of retaining a desirable juicy, red center. Additionally, a pinch more seasoning would have elevated the flavors. The onion rings, though crispy, lacked the satisfying crunch of a well-executed batter, instead displaying a tendency towards greasiness and disintegration. In contrast, the Oreo milkshake I sampled subsequently proved to be a resounding success, reaching the pinnacle of excellence. In conclusion, while this eatery has the potential to rank among the premier burger joints in town, several aspects require refinement to realize such aspirations."

Much like Jenny I have to say A-ok is this place in a nutshell.

Was there on Saturday in an attempt to cure my hangover. Again being a lover of meat I was really hoping this place would prove to be an awesome burger salvation.

I was ok, it jkust fails to hit the high notes. They get so much right it really is a shame, the service is fantastic - the girls interact with the customers and helpfully advise on their favourites and suggestions.

I had the Pestorica or something to that effect, burger with relish, pesto mozzarella etc. Also had a side of onion rings with dips.

The burger when it comes is visually fantastic and seems huge, the pedto and mozzarella are great, the salad fine. To the burger - its just too thin. When you order they make a point of saying are you happy for the burger to be cooked medium, to which i smiled and said medium rare is fine by me!!

The burger is far too think to maintain a juicy redish centre that I was hoping to see and lacks a bit of seasoning.

The onion rings are dipped in corn flour and fried, i prefer a batter as it sticks to the onion better, these were crumbly and greasy and just not what i had hoped for.

To finish I had an oreo milk shake which was awesome to the max! 

This place could be the best burger joint in town but for now sadly they are letting themselves down!!

This particular setting, classified under the rubric of Paradise, constitutes one of the most sonically tumultuous environments that this writer has had the privilege of experiencing. It is imperative that any individual considering utilizing this space for a business-related gathering during the daytime hours takes cognizance of this factor. In all other respects, the quality of service provided by the establishment's staff is truly commendable.

We chose this place because it was convenient for a Tuesday night show we were seeing at the Luxor.  Hostess reception was beyond rude and completely ridiculous.  There was no wait, but our party went to sit in the bar because we wanted quick service.  After sitting at what we thought was a bar table for about 5 minutes, the long-blond-haired hostess came up to tell us that we were at a dining table and escorted us back to wait for a table (apparently, there are no tables that qualify as \"bar seating\").  We stood there for another 10 minutes, just to have her take us back to the EXACT SAME TABLE!  She then, literally, tossed our menus on the table and walked away before we had even sat down.  Disbelief is the only word I can use to describe this experience.  Thankfully, our server more than made up for this terrible first impression.  There was good teamwork between him and his busser as they both worked hard to accommodate our need for speedy service.  Food was good, but nothing to get excited about.  We enjoyed the steak quesadilla and steak/bacon tacos.

If you want to stop off to see the worlds largest thermometer and have some food, then this stop is for you. The Mad Greek in itself is an ok place. There are two locations; one in Baker (near Death Valley) and then one near the entrance to LV. It's usually packed so if you like Greek food, then this may be for you. From what I remember, the falalel balls were tasty and weren't overly fried. A creamy Tahini sauce accompanies most dishes which is perfect since the weather here is HOT! The restaurant designed with roman statues and columns on the outside so you can't miss it when you are exiting. The inside is more like a greek cafeteria and is congested with a lot of seating space and people to match. The Baker stop has an option for a decent bathroom and like I said before, if you look to the left of the Mad Greek, you will see a large pole showing the temperature. This is the only one found in America and although it boasts that it shows the right temperature, its actually off a couple of degrees.

"A remarkable geographic locale, but it is imperative that you ensure an early arrival and confirmation of your accommodations, as I learned the hard way during my visit in June 2010. Upon arriving well after the appointed hour of 11:00 PM on a weekday, I was dismayed to discover that the establishment did not have a suitable room available, and I was subsequently assigned to a space designated for those with auditory impairments who also partake in smoking; needless to say, this was not ideal. Following an extended period of time, specifically 2:00 PM the next day, I was finally able to take advantage of a superior room, which was indeed impressive. However, I must admit that I was somewhat miffed at having to return to my quarters in the early afternoon to await the upgrade, as it proved to be a tad inconvenient. Aside from these minor drawbacks, the lodging was passable, and the aquatic facility, while not particularly extravagant, served its purpose adequately."

This shopping center appears significantly diminutive in comparison to the expansive retail spaces I had the pleasure of perambulating through in Las Vegas, particularly given the absence of an extensive array of commercial establishments available for perusal. Notwithstanding the aesthetically pleasing nature of the interior design and ornamentation, the boutiques situated within this mall tend to possess exorbitant price points. If one desires to engage in a leisurely promenade within a retail environment, this location may prove suitable for such purposes, despite its relatively modest proportions.

"Aesthetically pleasing establishment specializing in chains. My culinary experiences here have generally been satisfactory, with a higher frequency of positive encounters than negative ones. 

I tend to opt for the grilled cheese with hash browns as my meal of choice, both during the day and in the evenings. The combination of the crunchy bread and expertly melted cheese never fails to impress. However, on one occasion, the sandwich was prepared with the cheese placed between the bread slices, followed by a brief stint on the grill, resulting in an unfortunate lack of melting. Upon bringing this to the server's attention, I received an ambiguous response, suggesting that this was their standard method of preparation, although they would accommodate my request for additional melting. Subsequent observations have led me to question the veracity of this claim. 
Upon the return of my plate, I was dismayed to discover that the entire dish had been subjected to intense heat, resulting in a rubbery texture of the cheese and an unpleasant alteration in the flavor of the bread. It appeared that the server had employed the microwave oven for an extended period. 
In addition to the grilled cheese, I also enjoy ordering the cheese sticks, which are best savored while still hot. The optimal dipping sauces for these delicacies are ranch and marinara. 
Excluding the aforementioned episode, the service has been adequate, with the food being palatable. This establishment provides a suitable setting for socializing with others or enjoying a solitary meal, accompanied by reading material, if desired."

Pretty polular chain. The service is usualy pretty good here, I've had more positive experiences than not.

 I usuay get grilled cheese with hash browns nearly everytime I go there, even in the evenings. I love the way the bread is crispy and the cheese is melted. One time I came here the sanwich looked as though the put the cheese in between, then put it on the grill for a few seconds and took it off. The cheese wasn't melted at all. I asked the lady if the cheese can be melted more and she replied "that's how we always make them, but I'll have them melt it more." I've been there enough times to know that is not the case. When my plate came back the whole thing was hot. She put the whole plate in the microwave. Not only did she put it in the microwave, she put it in there too long. The cheese was like rubber. And the bread didnt taste good. 
Something else I like to get are the cheese sticks. They're really good when the cheese is perfectly melted on the inside. You have to eat them while they're hot. I use ranch and marinara dipping sauces. 

Other than that incident, the service is good. The food is good. Overall its a good place to just come, eat and converse with others. Or come have some alone time and eat, read the paper whatever.

I saw the Blue Man Group last week with high expectations. It is one of the longest running shows in Las Vegas (although it is moving soon to the Monte Carlo) and is performed in a few other cities across the country. Understandably, I was excited.

And while there were many great scenes, I thought the show lacked continuity. The three blue men would spend 5-10 minutes beating on drums and then for seemingly no reason start climbing the chairs in the audience. Then in the next scene they performed a very impressive marshmellow throwing trick (I won't spoil it) that seemed really random in execution. While everything they did was impressive, I've seen similar things done on the streets of Las Vegas Boulevard. I was especially confused with what each had to do with one another.

The show does get points for humor though. The comedic timing of the three blue men was terrific and there were at least a couple full laugh-out-loud moments. They also had some fun audience participation that would presumably make each show a little different. Plus it was very simple, slap stick humor, so it was appropriate for the whole family.

Ultimately, I enjoyed the show but it just didn't live up to the hype or the price.

Welcoming and cool inside. Had a wonderful and relaxing 90 minute full body massage for $40 including tip

Will definitely come back again and tell all my friends and family.

Thanks to Ann Z for the recommendation.

"A-OK.  It is my considered opinion that an establishment purporting to be a 'Tavern' should offer a more extensive selection of beverages, particularly those of the fermented variety.  The culinary offerings, while adequate, did not exactly impress, with the exception of my significant other's buffalo chicken, which I must confess was rather delectable.  Notwithstanding the aforementioned shortcomings, I would still consider patronizing this establishment again in the future, owing to its comfortable ambiance and accommodating staff."

A-OK.  Please have better beer selection, that's my biggest gripe for a place labeled 'Tavern'.  The food was ok, nothing great.  

Typical bar food grub.  My girlfriend ordered macaroni cheese and it was literally out of a Kraft box.  Her buffalo chicken though was pretty good, I must admit.

I'd come back simply because it seems like a good comfy spot to watch a game or two.  Good friendly service too.

It was spa day at the camelback inn spa. We had facials and massages, lunch, and then wanted to have some FaceTime since we don't see each other often. That's when the trouble began. The quiet police were after us! Finally, we escaped to the outside where there were no water spritsers. We found some icy towels to cool us.
