Andrea gave me a great facial and spent a lot of time with me answering questions about my skin, eyebags, and products that could help. If you favor silence to read and relax you will enjoy it! They offer lemon water, tea, and when you leave you can make your own sachet which was awesome. My sachet has lavender in it and really helps me get to sleep. A nice touch!! The food and drink offerings were very good and the attendants were always nearby to help or keep everyone quiet. Shhhh when you go there!

I give it three stars because their coffee was very indifferent to me and I think I should try their coffee twice before judging it. I will say the hours are bad for a coffee house, because they're only open until 7. I will definitely say there are better coffee places to go to then this.

This is close to one of my offices and my co-workers enjoy enough that we are regulars here.  The lunchbox specials are pretty good, especially #1, the Short Rib.  I've also had some of their special sushi rolls.  The AZ Diamondback is pretty good.\n\nService is hit or miss, sometimes they just get over their head with customers and can never make up for the poor service.  Overall the food is pretty good and works out for lunch, sometime I will have to try the Koren Dinner.

"Establishments offering alcoholic beverages along Edinburgh's famed Royal Mile cater primarily to sightseers oblivious to exorbitant prices and lacking a genuine sense of community among patrons, according to my perspective. The Albanach, while conforming to some of these criteria, boasts an interior that has undergone a recent refurbishment, featuring sleek slate flooring and polished wooden accents that diverge from the conventional ambiance associated with age-old taverns in the historic district. A cursory examination of the menu reveals a cheeseburger and fries costing approximately ten pounds, and tourists perusing maps with confused expressions are commonplace in the outdoor seating area. Despite these factors, our group often ends up at this venue during the course of an evening out, attracted by the reasonably priced house wine, available for twelve pounds per bottle, a sum barely exceeding the cost of a single glass of comparable vintage in nearby George Street watering holes. Moreover, the step leading into the entrance requires caution, as it tends to catch my attention (and that of others) every time, making it a conspicuous feature."

Bars on the Royal Mile are, if you ask me, pretty much exclusively reserved for tourists who don't realise how overpriced they are, and aren't looking for a 'local' with any sense of community.

And to a certain extent, The Albanach fits all of those criteria: a cheeseburger and chips wiill set you back the best part of a tenner, and at every second table in the outside area there'll be somebody staring at a map of the centre with a slightly puzzled expression on their face.

That said, if I ever go for a drink with friends in this area we nearly always end up here at some point during the evening. House wine, although not exactly going to win any vintage awards, is only £12 a bottle which isn't much more than the price of a glass of equally average wine in some George Street bars. Not too shabby at all. Also, I don't know if they've recently had a big refurb but inside it is really nicely decorated. Unlike lots of traditional pubs in the old town, where "traditional" means it still smells of the pre-smoking ban days and is always full of old men drinking pints of real ale, The Albanach has lovely slate floors and new polished wood everywhere.

Just watch the step up as you go through the door on your way in. It catches me out every time and yes, everyone can see you.

"I visited Todai with my significant other for a midday meal, as he was yearning for some Shrimp Tempura, and needless to say, he obtained multiple plates of said dish. For a tariff of $20 per individual, the culinary selection was relatively diverse, primarily consisting of sushi rolls, but also including Salmon and Tuna Nigiri, salads, an udon station, and various sweet treats. Regrettably, there was an absence of crab during the lunchtime hours. My preferred aspect of the smorgasbord would have to be the udon station, whereupon ringing a bell, a staff member would emerge to prepare a bowl, allowing me to add ingredients such as fish cake, sweet tofu, green onions, and several other options. However, I must caution that the broth has a tendency towards excessive saltiness, so it is advisable to refrain from consuming it in large quantities. Given the abundance of alternative buffet establishments in Las Vegas, I would not be inclined to return to Todai in the future."

I came to Todai for lunch with my boyfriend since he was craving some Shrimp Tempura. Needless to say, he got plates and plates and more plates of Shrimp Tempura. 

For $20 per person, there was a pretty good variety of food, mostly sushi rolls. There was also Salmon and Tuna Nigiri, salads, an udon station, and some desserts. Unfortunately, there was no crab during lunch. 

My favorite part of the buffet would have to be the udon station. Just ring the bell, and someone will come out to make you a bowl. You can add fish cake, sweet tofu, green onions, and a few other things. As a warning, the broth is on the salty side, so I wouldn't drink it if I were you.

With the plethora of other buffets to choose from in Vegas, I don't think I would care to come back.

My friend swore this was the best place ever for breakfast, true it is good and it does have some signature breakfasts, but the service is hit or miss...  sometimes you will get quick refills on coffee, other times you will sit there with an empty cup...  I still go frequently

My biggest complaint.. the price.. 2 eggs and some bacon shouldn't be anywhere near 6 bucks in my opinion...  there are good deals on the menu and bad ones..   I guess it depends on what you are in the mood for...

Oh and military discount???  Yeah you have to be in uniform to get it.. who in there right mind is going to be wearing their uniform on the weekend, and what does it matter if you are in uniform or not?!?!

If you go on the weekend, make sure you get there early, all the late nighters looking to cure a hangover will get there around 10 ish and the wait will be long, early yelper gets the worm!
It's ok.  I think they survive more on presentation, big portions, and name recognition than actual taste of food.  There are a bunch of better breakfast/brunch options in Vegas in my experience.

I used to come here when opened at first. I didnt come here.for about 2 year but one of friends want to try buffet so i came here to try.

Service is decent as always and their atmosphere is nice. However i dissappointed to food taste.. almost everything is salty and some of food is not taste right.. 

it was way better before.  


Dessets are always good!

My kids love this place.  Cool shirts and gear based upon cable shows and rock groups.  Obviously for a youthful demographic.  Sales people certainly represent that.  Prices seem reasonable for licensed items.  Quality seems good too.

This eatery purports to serve Colombian cuisine, which differs considerably from its Mexican counterpart in terms of the menu offerings. The portions are generous, but the prices reflect the quality, ranging from $13.00 to $25.00. Despite its location, the establishment does not offer particularly affordable options. However, based on my numerous experiences, the dishes are generally worth the cost. My personal favorite is the #25, consisting of succulent shrimp smothered in a rich coconut sauce, served atop crispy fried green plantains known as tostones. In addition, their fruit juices are quite refreshing. Another notable mention is the fried yuca, which boasts a unique flavor and texture reminiscent of French fries.  
The service at this restaurant is satisfactory, with friendly staff members who provide relatively prompt service. However, my experiences have been limited to less busy evenings, so I cannot comment on their ability to handle larger crowds.

This is a Colombian restaurant, not Mexican. Very different menu than you will find in a Mexican restaurant. All very large portion entrees but you definitely pay for it. Being in the part of town it is in you would expect it to be inexpensive but that is not true. Entrees range from $13.00 to $25.00 but are, for the most part, worth it. I can only review one dish here as it is the only thing I have had here all 10+ times I've been. I always get the #25. Shrimp in coconut sauce over tostones (crispy fried green plantains) it has been fantastic every time. Their juices are great as well. Also, try the fried Yuca, it has a taste and texture similar to French fries. \n\nService at the restaurant is decent. Friendly staff and relatively fast service. I have only been there on slower nights so I cannot speak for their service on a busy night.

Being from India, we eat Indian food several times a week both at home and outside the house.  Persi's has a great reputation and they didnt let down on our visit. Good food for a lunch buffet overall.  The selection is not big but it was all pretty good.  My favorite was the chicken tikka masala with white rice.  The chicken biryani was also good but it was a bit on the spicy side.  Intense flavors are good but the heat was a bit overbearing.  The desserts lacked as they only had gulab jumun and fresh fruit.  It was good but I was left wanting something more.

This our 3rd trip to Vegas this year but 1st stay at Mandalay Bay. The 2 previous times were at The Hotel. 

My only major complaint is the room/bathroom: Too cluttered with furniture, and the bathroom wasn't very clean. Some stray hairs in the tub and shower wall, and spots on the counter. 

The Hotel is way better. All rooms are suites. Bathrobes and slippers provided (without asking, like at Mandalay) and bathrooms are clean.

Circuit training constitutes an effective methodology for enhancing physical fitness, as it involves an uninterrupted sequence of exercises, thereby simulating a constant flow of motion. This dynamic approach necessitates a high level of physical endurance, making it a challenging experience for those who are not in peak condition. Our session consisted of six sets of four repetitions, with each set lasting approximately three to four minutes, culminating in a total duration of one hour. 

The incorporation of television monitors displaying participants' heart rates and a friendly trainer were aspects that garnered my approval. However, the presence of numerous individuals and the emphasis on continuous comparison among them had the potential to become a source of distraction, detracting from the primary objective of focusing on one's personal performance and attaining the desired physical state, commonly referred to as the "zone." Despite this minor drawback, I availed myself of a complimentary class starting at 6:30 am on a Saturday, which drew a sizable crowd of fifteen individuals, with a single male participant. The fitness center's diminutive size and welcoming ambiance, complemented by the vibrant hue of orange, created a comfortable environment. While perusing the premises, I noticed a limited selection of items available for purchase, albeit at somewhat elevated prices. 

My assessment of the program's cost yielded the conclusion that it was rather steep. Nonetheless, I acknowledge its potential efficacy for individuals who prefer varied exercises and periodic changes in their routine, as opposed to remaining stationary at a single machine throughout their workout. Wishing everyone success in their fitness endeavors.

"Gastronomical excellence is indubitably conveyed through the consumable delights offered at this eatery, specifically pertaining to the delectable fare which warrants an unwavering five-star rating. However, a caveat exists in the form of inconsistent and unpredictable service quality, particularly during peak luncheon hours when an overwhelming influx of patrons tends to precipitate an inadequacy in staffing, resulting in an unsatisfactory dining experience. It is indeed perplexing that the management has yet to implement an augmentation of personnel, albeit on a part-time basis, to alleviate the aforementioned deficiency. Notwithstanding the aforesaid shortcoming, my patronage persists, motivated by an unrelenting craving for the establishment's signature matzoh ball soup."

For the food I would have to give 5 stars.

The only problem is the shaky service.  If you to during lunch rush except very bad service.  Not sure why they can't hire another part time server.

There have been times that we almost had to leave because of the bad service.

I have to admit that I keep coming back for the matzoh ball soup!

took advantage of the coupons and got the chicken fingers. fast service and friendly. the chicken fingers were good,just be careful ordering hot! I still have much to try here so the jury is still out,but so far so good!

I was a bit disappointed because the service was not very good. Even from first entering the restaurant the service was not good. The decor and atmosphere is nice, especially if you can get a seat outside by the lake of dreams. The vegan food was delicious but nothing to rave about. The show which is played on the lake is quite cheesy. So all in all it was just ok. I was expecting better.

"In pursuit of a delectable late-night dining experience featuring prime rib, my acquaintance who resides in Las Vegas recommended this establishment, boasting an affordable price point of $15. Despite the equine ambiance that permeated the atmosphere, we opted to remain and sample their culinary offerings. The meal was accompanied by a choice of soup or salad, as well as a selection of potatoes. We all requested our prime rib to be cooked to a medium level of doneness, but were instead presented with a more rare iteration. Upon returning the dish, the restaurant staff exhibited commendable customer service by promptly preparing a new portion cooked to our satisfaction. While the texture was somewhat chewy, the flavor profile and crusty exterior of the prime rib yielded a gratifying dining experience. Based on these factors, I would assign a rating of 3.5 stars and would indeed consider revisiting this venue in the future."

Il Bosco Pizza and Handlebar-J were our prior destinations, whereupon completion of our repast, we opted to perambulate in the direction of this establishment, primarily due to its proximity and the fact that it offered a wide range of potables during their extended happy hour, which commenced at the eleventh hour and concluded at the seventeenth hour. Furthermore, we were drawn to the premises by the presence of numerous televisual displays, which afforded us the opportunity to observe various athletic competitions transpiring concurrently. Although we did not partake in culinary indulgences, the menu presented an impressive array of gastronomical options.

We were out and about, having just finished a late lunch/snack over at Il Bosco Pizza and Handlebar-J did not open until 4pm so we wandered over here to get a drink.  It was clean and has happy hour daily from 11am-7pm .  There are plenty of TVs to watch whatever sporting event is on.  We didn't order any food but they have an extensive menu.

"Cool for juveniles...Not so much for grown-ups. I arrived specifically for the mummified cadaver display and I was somewhat disillusioned. I appreciated the diminutive computer terminals that expounded upon Egypt and the authentic mummy. Apart from that, it was unremarkable. I wouldn't advocate for remunerating additional fees to witness it."

"While not necessarily the most exceptional alehouse within the city limits, this establishment does possess a certain je ne sais quoi that sets it apart from its peers, albeit in a manner that is neither extraordinarily remarkable nor utterly deplorable. My personal affinity for the culinary offerings herein has led me to sample the entirety of their beer selection, which, while not exactly possessing the pinnacle of flavorful excellence, does manage to maintain a certain level of mediocrity that is paradoxically satisfying. Additionally, the generous proportions of the dishes served and the congenial demeanor of the staff contribute to an overall ambiance that, while perhaps not the most refined, remains endearing in its own peculiar fashion."

Not the greatest ale house in the city but certainly not the worst.

I like the food and I have tried all the beers.  They're just "OK" as far as beer goes.

Large portions. Friendly staff.

"Gastronomical excellence is undeniably evident in the culinary offerings of this establishment, however, operational deficiencies, discourteous staff, and an absence of managerial oversight have conspired to create an unfortunate dining experience, characterized by protracted waiting periods sans any tangible justification. Despite the delectability of the fare, a second visit is conditional upon the implementation of tangible improvements in service quality, as the patron is unlikely to be accorded any consideration or compensation for inconvenience incurred, and indeed, may be subject to financial penalty for lateness, much to their chagrin."

"I have an immense fondness for this airport, as it exhibits remarkable efficiency in both arrival and departure processes, ensuring a seamless experience for travelers. The organization of parking and transportation services, including taxis and shuttles, is exceptionally well-managed, resulting in minimal wait times. Furthermore, the abundance of retail establishments, dining options, and entertainment facilities provides ample opportunities for passengers to occupy themselves during their stay. Additionally, the provision of complimentary Wi-Fi access serves as a significant advantage."

"This establishment purveys a rudimentary assortment of culinary offerings, with an emphasis on a traditional burger-centric menu, augmented by a select array of supplementary items that, while intriguing, remain untested by this writer. Given the pecuniary constraints inherent in any dining excursion, it is conceivable that an alternative venue, such as Smashburger, might present a more enticing value proposition, particularly in light of its relative proximity. Notwithstanding, the superior quality of the burgers served at this location relative to other nearby eateries renders it a viable option for future dining experiences."

Just your basic burger joint..  They do have a few other interesting things on the menu which I have not tried.  For the money I would rather go to Smashburger if it were closer.  I would eat here again because it is the best burger nearby for sure.

My friends and I got a deal here and I was expecting the worse, but we got good. :)

We got an adjoining suite and the kitchen was well stocked for what you needed in vegas. The pool was heated, which made me want to come back. 

Otherwise, the place was kind of old. I'd come back here if I ever had a family and wanted to do the tourist thing.

We indulged in a midday repast, comprising three individuals, and were presented with complimentary samples by our attentive server, owing to our status as novice patrons. The culinary offerings were served in a timely manner, and their prices were reasonable, yet not excessively economical. My personal selection, encompassing an egg foo young dish accompanied by scarlet-hued poultry and black beans, was merely mediocre, as I have had the pleasure of savoring superior Chinese cuisine on previous occasions. My associates opted for red chicken, friend rice, and pulled pork, deeming them satisfactory. The query regarding a potential return visit remains uncertain, with the possibility of a one-year hiatus preceding my next venture to this establishment.

"Beverages are reasonably priced, however, the ambiance is not particularly characteristic of a dive bar, per se. There is a disc jockey and a minuscule dance floor, yet the absence of exceptional service is palpable. The barback's stature and physical attractiveness captured my attention, prompting me to engage in rhythmic movements with my lower torso. The entrance fee of four dollars seemed somewhat unremarkable. It is worth mentioning that certain patrons appeared youthful, almost juvenile, which struck me as mildly peculiar, given the venue's reputation. Nonetheless, the prices for Jameson, Jack Daniel's, and most beers were reasonable, amounting to approximately 6.50 Canadian dollars. If one seeks an establishment conducive to fostering a sense of hipsterism, this may be an appropriate destination. Despite my personal preferences skewing towards a slightly more mature atmosphere, I must admit that this location possesses certain merits."

Drinks are decent price. Honestly it's not the most divey spot but its cool. There's a DJ and small dance floor. No services to remember. The bar back was pretty tall and handsome so I felt fascinated. I danced, shook my butt everywhere- 4$ cover: meh! \n\nSome of the people in it looked 15 years old which was weird but hey I'm on Vacation. 6,50 CAD for jameson, jack, most beer. If your into more of the I need to feel hipster scene come here. Its a great place just young for my lifestyle.

We frequent this bar every couple of months. Fairly clean place, friendly staff and decent bar food. We almost always come for the maple hot wings. One of the best flavored around!  However, they are usually  \"tiny\" pigeon or Cornish hen sized pieces....but delicious.  \n  Great place to watch a game if you prefer a little quieter group of patrons. Its so nice not to have \"that guy\" screaming at the TV sitting next to you.

"A diverse array of culinary selections, albeit at a somewhat elevated cost, was presented to us at this establishment. Our dining experience consisted of consuming sushi, chicken lettuce wraps, and a shrimp noodle dish, all of which were satisfactory in terms of taste, yet did not entirely conform to the genuine flavors commonly associated with Pan-Asian cuisine."
Solid variety of options, on the pricey side. We had sushi, chicken lettuce wraps, and a shrimp noodle dish. The food was good, but not quite authentic the way pan-asian places often are.

My favorite thing about this comic store is the fact that they just about always have a copy of something I'm looking for. They tend to order enough of books that come out. Other stores might be out but they will usually have some left. They have a bunch of figures and tons of books. Deforest will continue Coming in and maybe even subscribe for a box!

Last week, I had the pleasure of dining at a restaurant with a friend, and while the culinary experience was satisfactory, it did not exceed my expectations in terms of quality. Specifically, the chicken dish that we ordered lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, leaving me with a feeling of underwhelment. Furthermore, I did not get the impression that high-quality meat was a priority for this establishment, which was reflected in the price. Nonetheless, I would give the restaurant three stars for its adequate service and delicious, albeit fiery, rice noodle soup.

Letzte Woche bin ich mit einem Freund im Kikeri essen gewesen. Ging so. Das H\u00e4hnchen (worum es in dieser Gaststube haupts\u00e4chlich geht) lag mir mittelschwer im Magen und ich hatte auch w\u00e4hrend des Verzehrs nicht den Eindruck, dass hier auf qualitativ hochwertige Fleischware Wert gelegt wird. 3 Sterne f\u00fcr den angemessenen Preis und f\u00fcr die leckere, sehr scharfe Reisnudel-Suppe.
Pizza and salad is good, but the service is average. Good place to hang out in evening just before after the movie!

So my girlfriend and I stayed at Aria and had a reservation for 2 months at The Steakhouse and the bubblehead woman at check in sat us at a horrible table so we will never go back.   If you don't take care of hotel guests, what's the point?   A group of 4 walked in with no reservation and sat next to us and complained about the table, so although our waiter was good and the food ok the experience was soiled by an idiot woman who sat us in Siberia.   Bad job!!!!!

I've been to Gilbert pizza many times. It delicious... However the girl behind the counter is the rudest person I've ever encountered in my life. Walked in she looked right at me didn't say a word. Just continued to wipe down the entire counter before slowly walking to the register and just asking me what I wanted... I placed an order over the phone... She snapped at me saying it would be 5 more minutes. Seriously bitch? How much do u care about your job? Let's try a little harder... I'll take my money and spend it else where. Who let's their staff treat their customers like that? She was rude to every single person who walked in after me.

Beware of the nefarious machinations of the EBAY MAFIA and their coterie of crafty accomplices...

In the event that you choose to peruse the offerings at Last Chance, cognizant of a few salient points you must be:

1. A plethora of exceptional deals, unparalleled within the locality, awaits your perusal at this establishment. 
2. Obtaining said deals, however, proves a formidable endeavor, as a cabal of scheming females and unscrupulous individuals, in concert with staff members of questionable ethics, conspire to preclude unsuspecting patrons from accessing said deals. 
3. A coterie of "team shoppers" convenes daily at Last Chance, their mission being to expeditiously procure each item of superior quality the moment the store opens its doors. To maintain their stranglehold on these coveted items, they engage in collusive efforts with staff members, thus ensuring that innocent bystanders are effectively barred from acquiring said items. Furthermore, some of these individuals even resort to peddling their ill-gotten gains on Ebay. 

Seeking irrefutable evidence? Simply navigate to Ebay and conduct a search for such esteemed brands as Marc Jacobs handbags or True Religion Jeans within the Phoenix metropolitan area. You shall observe an abundance of listings originating from Last Chance, easily identifiable by telltale markers, such as unique bag markings and truncated tags on denim apparel, which serve to thwart attempts at returning items to Nordstrom. 

In conclusion, Last Chance holds the potential to be an exceptional shopping destination, were it not for the rapacious machinations of the Ebay Mafia and their malevolent associates.

Beware of the EBAY MAFIA and their evil friends...

If you are going to Last Chance there are a few things you should know:

1. They have the best deals in town.
2. You have little chance of getting these deals, as bitchy women and evil sleazoids plot to keep these deals away from regular consumers.   There is a group of "team shoppers" who go to Last Chance every day. Their mission is to scoop up every piece of good clothing the minute the store opens. They work in teams to keep "outsiders" out. They even work with unscrupulous staff members to keep regular people away from the best clothing. Many of these people even sell the stuff they score at Last Chance on Ebay.

Want proof? Go to Ebay and search for things like Marc Jacobs purses or True Religion Jeans in Phoenix. You will see TONS of items from Lat Chance listed on Ebay. You know it's from Last Chance because of markings in the bags, cut tags on jeans and other things Last Chance does to prevent returns to Nordstrom.

So in summary - Last Chance would be great if the Ebay Mafia and their evil friends would stay away.

It's like Korean and Japanese fast food. You can get sushi (its hard to get good sushi in Pittsburgh so by those standards, its pretty decent). You can also get the usual Korean fare: bulgogi, galbi, and kimchi. My favorite is the galbi bento (although its over $8 so I don't usually get it), or the bulgogi bowl. 

The bento boxes come with a little bit of chap chae (Korean glass noodles), kim chi, a salad with "oriental dressing", japanese yellow pickles, a few pot stickers (not bad, not good), and of course, whatever entree you ordered. 

The bowls are simple: rice topped with meat. Yum! 

The space is small though so its okay for 4-people groups.

"Commenced a corporate gathering with colleagues at this establishment, indulging in a delectable culinary experience that, while satisfying, did not linger in my memory as a standout occasion. The ambiance was vibrant and conducive to socializing, characteristic of Las Vegas venues, and situated within the luxurious Cosmopolitan hotel, amidst an array of dining options. Notwithstanding, the wait times for seating were generally prolonged at neighboring eateries, rendering this particular location a relatively convenient alternative. While not necessarily a personal favorite, it remains a passable choice for casual dining."

---------DINNER ONLY------\nKicked off a work event with my co-workers here. The food was good but it wasn't memorable. It's loud and a great place to get together with friends (typical Vegas place). It's inside the Cosmo hotel on the floor with all the other restaurants. All the restaurants seem to have waits but this one never does. It's an okay place but I'd probably try another restaurant before coming back here

This critique will serve as an exemplification of how the hospitality personnel can thoroughly compromise a culinary encounter. Let me initiate my narrative by emphasizing our profound affection for the Wicked Spoon!! We endeavor to partake in a delectable repast at this esteemed establishment whenever we find ourselves in the city of Las Vegas. The fare provided by this eatery is indeed scrumptious, and the menu regularly features novel and unexpected delights. The manner in which they present their offerings in diminutive, adorable crocks is utterly captivating.

Unfortunately, during our most recent visit, we had the misfortune of being attended to by a surly, elderly server afflicted with a deficient memory. Every time we placed an order for beverages, she either required repeated reminders or erroneously delivered the drinks to the incorrect individual. We would request a couple of Coca-Colas and a cup of coffee, and she would return with three cups of coffee, rationalizing her mistake by remarking, "Oh, someone at the table will consume them."

The most egregious transgression committed by the server was her failure to expedite the removal of used plates in a timely fashion. We were compelled to stack our plates at the edge of the table, all the while observing her attend to an unoccupied table adjacent to us with marked efficiency.

Wicked Spoon, it is imperative that you assess the quality of your staff and undertake measures to restore the exceptional dining experience that characterized your establishment in the past.

The Garage was once my favorite little spot but they're starting to seem pretty basic compared to all the other creative options out there. Nonetheless, they have good food and friendly staff. I've never had to wait for a table either which is great when you're starving or on a schedule but makes me wonder why more people don't come to this place? I wish they still had lamb as a starter. That would win my heart back right away.

I want to shop local .  I appreciate the fact that my local purchase support local people. But I am not sure Next  is really interested in my business.  
The line on a Wednesday was 4 or 5 people in , which first made me think it must be a great place. but then after watching , I am think it's just a matter of workers who are interested in being helpful . They appeared to just leisurely make the orders with  little enthusiam or interest. When  I got to the counter I had a few questions . I was wonderfing about their holiday flavor , if it could be blended etc . But I felt as though getting info or suggestions was like pulling teeth. I felt embarrassed like I was inconvincing him but I then I remembered I was paying them to make my order.
When the equally apathetic barista made my order she also refused to intereact or say anything to me. As I gave her my sweetest Polly Anna smile  she may have even grunted at me. I hate grunters.   Guess the big chain will get my bucks next time.

Please NEXT  make an effort to engage the customer and try using those nifty words , thank you , please and your welcome ....maybe even , glad I can help....

"Having had the privilege of residing in Southern California and Las Vegas, my palate has been accustomed to the rich and diverse culinary offerings of these regions, particularly when it comes to Asian cuisine. Thus, it was with great anticipation that I visited Republic Ramen Noodles in Tempe, hoping to indulge in a delectable bowl of noodles that would transport me back to those halcyon days of gastronomic bliss. Alas, despite my eagerness to bestow upon this establishment the highest praise, I must confess that it fell short of my expectations, garnering a mere three stars from this fastidious critic.  

While the portion sizes at Republic Ramen Noodles are undoubtedly generous, and the flavors they proffer are indeed unique, their interpretation of "spicy" leaves much to be desired for those who crave a truly piquant experience. In fact, I found their notion of heat to be rather tepid, bordering on blandness, which may prove underwhelming for ardent devotees of fiery cuisine. To remedy this deficiency, I resorted to supplementing my meal with a dash of trusty Sriracha, thereby elevating the flavor profile to a more satisfactory level.  

Regrettably, Republic Ramen Noodles does not quite compare to the authentic ramen establishments found in other cities, where the rich broth, tender noodles, and savory toppings conspire to create a transcendent dining experience. However, until I have the opportunity to venture forth and sample the genuine article, this venue shall suffice, albeit with a certain degree of wistfulness for the real thing.  

In conclusion, while Republic Ramen Noodles may not fully satiate the cravings of those who seek an authentic ramen experience, it nevertheless warrants a visit, if only to temporarily assuage one's hunger for this delectable dish. With a return factor of 65%, I shall likely revisit this eatery, albeit with tempered expectations and a healthy dose of Sriracha on hand."

I used to live in So Cal & Vegas, so all Asian food gets compared to those areas.  As much as I wanted to love this place, it only gets 3 Stars. 

The portions here are pretty big and the flavors are unique.  
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/republic-ramen-noodles-tempe?select=ksAFcidCv_BmBaBXB8aXzw#ksAFcidCv_BmBaBXB8aXzw
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/republic-ramen-noodles-tempe?select=qmZ7A6n_Is96cBXnDNw6Tw#qmZ7A6n_Is96cBXnDNw6Tw

Their idea of "spicy" is really mild though....so for spice lovers, you'll have to supplement it with Sriracha.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/republic-ramen-noodles-tempe?select=hfn4x4jMbFl8pF73iXVUgQ#hfn4x4jMbFl8pF73iXVUgQ

It's not like a legit, Ramen place you'll find in other cities....but it will suffice until I travel somewhere I can get the real thing.

Return Factor - 65%

I'm not sure why this is called the Beatles lounge. The night I was there, they did not play any Beatles music. Which was FINE! with me.

They played a decent mix of music, however, no one was dancing. Except the go-go girl on the pole. We received a "free" drink voucher when we got in, when you take it to the bartender inside, she turns down just about any drink you want, and gives you the "acceptable" free drinks. You really need to read the fine print on your voucher. But OK, no worries.

There was a girl walking around with "free" shots, that looked like they had cranberry in them. We declined. This place is GREAT for people watching. There were two older ladies.... I mean, OLDERRRR ladies, who were chain smoking and trying to rob the cradle.

Hilarious.... but don't come here if you want to dance--or hear the beatles.

The host was very rude when I walked up although I wasn't expecting amazing service from an airport bar. I asked her a question about the seating situation and she just shrugged her shoulders. She literally didn't say a word. I think her name tag said Della or something starting with a D. Once I sat down my experience here got better. A young lady by the name of Jack greeted me and took my order. She brought me back the wrong beer but quickly offered to fix my order. I'm not one to let drinks go to waste so I didn't make her fix it.

"Huzzah!  An economical culinary delight!  The corn dog was delectable, indeed!  Although, I must admit that during both instances of partaking in this gastronomical indulgence, I was somewhat inebriated.  Nonetheless, at such an ungodly hour, the cost-effectiveness and accessibility of this comestible cannot be surpassed!  Thus, I highly recommend acquiring a corn dog and then proceeding into the gambling establishment to further enhance your nocturnal exploits."

"Initially, it is essential to acknowledge that the panoramic perspective of the Bellagio, complemented by the captivating water display, is undoubtedly breathtaking from this particular vantage point. However, regarding the culinary offerings, it is somewhat disappointing to note that the quality of the fare does not quite live up to the elevated standards one might expect from an establishment of this caliber, particularly given its prime location atop Las Vegas's quasi-Eiffel Tower. Nonetheless, the experience itself is unquestionably worthwhile, and it may be suggested that indulging in beverages at this lofty perch would be a preferable alternative to consuming a meal."

First off, the view of the bellagio and the water show is AMAZING FROM HERE!!

The food here is just decent. You're paying more for the view and the fact you're on the top of las vegas in a qausi eiffel tower. 

Def worth the experience. Not sure if they have a bar up there, but i'd just get drinks up there if I could instead of eating

These delectable, visually-appealing cupcakes possess an aesthetic quality reminiscent of those that are meticulously crafted and presented at upscale social gatherings, specifically weddings, evoking a sense of refined elegance and sophistication attributed to the renowned lifestyle icon, Martha Stewart; they would undoubtedly be the centerpiece of attention when displayed in abundance and diversity on a serving tray, exuding an air of lavishness and charm. My admiration for their allure is complemented by my fondness for the judicious application of frosting, which strikes a harmonious balance between restraint and indulgence, further enhancing the overall visual appeal of these delightful treats. Additionally, I must commend the creators of these culinary gems, whose expertise and dedication to their craft are evident in the unique and intriguing flavors they have created, imbuing each cupcake with its distinct character and charm. While the cupcake itself may be experiencing an identity crisis, straddling the line between its traditional form and a muffin-like transformation, my curiosity and appreciation for its unconventional nature prompt me to consider revisiting this establishment, provided that I am in close proximity, as the flavors are truly captivating and worthy of further exploration, although I would not undertake a special journey solely for the purpose of sampling them.

These cupcakes have the look of cupcakes that are looked at.

They're very pretty in a well-bred Martha Stewart weddings way. They would look fabulous on a tray in quantity and variety.

I like the prettiness. I like the restrained hand with the frosting. I like the frosting itself, which is unusual. I like the clerks. I very much like the toys!

The cupcake itself is such that, if I made it at home, I'd dub that batch "experimental." This cupcake was having an identity crisis but had not yet fully transitioned to muffin.

I'd go back, if I'm right there, as the flavors are interesting, but I wouldn't make a special trip.
If you have a choice, stay at the one about one mile farther north. (14245 S 50th St) The rooms are nicer, and they have indoor corridors.  Might cost an extra $10/night, but it's worth it.

Was this place good? Yes. 

Are there a lot of better places? Yes!

I had dinner here and we ordered the Jumbo Shrimp Cocktail and the Shrimp Spring Rolls as appetizers. The shrimp cocktail was exactly what I expected, cold shrimp with cocktail sauce.The spring rolls were actually really good and if I came back here I would start my meal off with an order of these.

For the main course I got the Crown Cut Bone In Filet Mignon, 12 oz. This steak really didn't do much for me. At this price point, I can go almost anywhere else for a better steak.

Next time, if I'm in the forum shops and looking for a steak I'll probably go next door to Joes.

The service is friendly.. and the ambiance is cool!  I love the outside benches where you can sit, have a beer, shoot the shit.... and just chill.  On a nice night, it's a really nice place to just BE.  

The waitresses are friendly... as well as the patrons.... 

I do believe that they serve food... though instead of ordering food, I ordered beer.  Beer was excellent.  hahaha!

Prices aren't to bad either.... what I really dig about this place is the outside seating area.  I just like being outside.  

Thanks for the good times Al's!  I'll be back

The Northlake Mall is a fairly big mall with lots of shops. As a guy the only down side it they are mostly women's clothing stores. The book store that use to be in the mall shut down. The mall is clean and has a decent food court. If you need clothing this is the place to go. If you are looking for electronics or gadgets you are better off going to the best buy across the highway.

"The quality of the food can be somewhat unpredictable, with certain items demonstrating a propensity for inconsistency in terms of taste and freshness. However, the tacos and breakfast burritos are generally considered to be satisfactory, boasting a palatable flavor profile and an appreciable crispiness. The salsa, while ostensibly intended to augment the culinary experience, often falls short of expectations, with its spicy kick bordering on overwhelming. It is recommended that patrons opt for a milder, more balanced condiment, such as that offered by Trader Joe's, in order to avoid discomfort or dissatisfaction. Furthermore, the chimichangas are best avoided altogether, as they tend to be rather large and difficult to manage, particularly for those with sensitive digestive systems. Lastly, it is advisable to procure a substantial quantity of horchata, albeit with some difficulty due to its unwieldy size, in order to quench one's thirst and complete the meal."

Can be hit or miss. The tacos are usually pretty good and fresh, as are the breakfast burritos. Salsa seems to be more of a hot sauce... I'd say pick up a tub from Trader Joe's and pile that on instead. (Haha.) Chimichangas are a big NO, especially for ye of sensitive colons. I always get a big ol' awkwardly sized styrofoam jug of horchata that I can barely hold in one hand. \n\nOverall, don't expect a gourmet culinary experience. Also, just park and order from the window when there's more than two cars in the drive-thru or else chance attacking your sleeve, your friend, or yourself out of sheer desperation and hunger.

The food had a nice flavor to it. And I enjoy the fact that they serve breakfast all day. On the negative side of things; the wait to be sat was way too long. The server was mediocre at best and the food was cold by the time that it got to us!

Okay, so I might not be the best person to review Brew Lab as I don't do coffee. At all. The whole coffee thing is properly lost on me. So a place famed for this particular beverage probably has to work harder for me. 

However, I liked Brew Lab when I could finally get some space to sit down and soak up the place. It feels a bit like a train station with people constantly wandering around trying to find a spot to sit, and it's rammed full of rich student types. 

I like the decor, the staff were very pleasant and my peppermint tea was really very nice. Fresh peppermint leaves and all. Lovely. Couldn't fault the cuppa - would happily sup another one.

However, it's losing the fourth star for me just now because it's so busy and I don't find it very relaxing. If I want to enjoy a pot of tea I'd rather go somewhere a bit less packed. But hey, that's just a testament to how popular the joint is :)

"Upon entering the establishment, I was met with an air of skepticism, as if the proprietor was dubious about the presence of my canine companion. I assiduously inquired as to whether it was permissible to admit my pooch into the courtyard area, only to be met with a resounding 'negative' from the hostess. Undeterred, I opted to partake in the culinary offerings, despite the dearth of hospitable treatment by the overwhelmed servers. Suffice it to say, the gastronomical experience was satisfactory, albeit the service was subpar, leaving me ambivalent about the prospect of revisiting the venue."

Eh. 

That's what comes to my mind when I think about this place.
I came with my dog and just opened the door to ask how I could enter the patio with my dog, as I couldn't see any access to the patio from outside. 
As soon as I opened the door the hostess freaked and said "No, No you can't bring a dog in here!"
....Lady, I didn't step foot inside and my dog is sitting calmly next to me.
So we proceeded to the patio and had our meal, which was pretty tasty. 
The servers were clearly flustered dealing with a lot of tables at once so we didn't expect attentive service. 
All in all, food was great, service was lacking, so I'm on the border about coming again.

I have to admit the TB is a guilty junk food kinda thing when you are vegetarian.  Pretty much anything on the menu can be made vegetarian which is pretty great when you are in a hurry.  This location seems to be about the same as the rest. I'm not sure I can bring myself to give them 4 stars, but the food is what you would expect from the TB nothing life changing, but consistent.  The staff at this location are younger people as are most fast food places who always seem pretty cheerful.  I usually go through the drive-thru and they are always very polite and pretty quick.  Not lightening speed or anything, but I have never driven by because there were a few people in line ahead of me.\n\nSo basically they have very nice staff running the drive-thru so if you want some TB then this is a good one.

I totally agree with some of you Yelpers that came from Cali...cause I was a So. Cal gal myself. Your paying twice as much for a sandwich that doesn't taste as good as Lee's Sandwich in L.A., but I'm getting to know Vegas and this place is the only place I know to get my Vietnamese Sandwich fix. Everything at this place is expensive. Was curious about the rest of the food from this restaurant so I brought my hubby back to try, I had the Banh Cuon (a soft rice roll with ground pork filling served with Yam chips/Vietnamese Ham/Shrimp green bean cake and bean sprouts), my husband had the Rice dish with BBQ Cornish Hen and Pho Dac Biet. I have to say...their foods are tasty because they put TONS of MSG in everything except the sandwiches. There was so much MSG in their food that it gave me a headache and I was so thirsty for the entire day.

"While it may be considered an unpretentious and tranquil setting for local patrons, the adjacent Orleans presents a more captivating ambiance, complete with an aesthetically pleasing alleyway and a state-of-the-art theatrical venue. Furthermore, the Gold Coast area boasts an array of establishments catering specifically to the needs and preferences of Chinese clientele, such as the renowned PingPangPong and Noodle Exchange, as well as the ever-popular Baccarat gaming facilities."

It's a nice little spot for locals, but the Orleans nearby is better for the vibe, including a nicer alley imo, and a theater.  Gold Coast caters to the Chinese with PingPangPong and the Noodle exchange along with the bacarrat

"Pros: The presence of my esteemed acquaintance, who hails from Virginia, where this culinary establishment does not have a presence, precipitated a craving for the delectable tacos offered by this fast food chain. My companion relished the experience of consuming them. My own culinary exploits at this venue had been absent for a considerable duration of five years; however, I decided to partake in their sourdough breakfast sandwich, which I shared with my sibling. Our satisfaction with the curly fries was notable. The expediency of the staff left a favorable impression on us. \n\nCons: Unfortunately, my sibling did not share our enthusiasm for the potato wedges. The inherent greasiness associated with fast food was evident. Personally, I harbor a preference for the fries served by McDonald's."

Pros: My best friend was here for a visit from VA, where they don't have this fast food restaurant. She has actual cravings for their tacos. She loved them. I haven't eaten here in over 5 years. Ordered the sourdough breakfast sandwich and split it with my sister. We liked the curly fries. Fast service. \n\nCons: My sister disliked the potato wedges. Greasy fast food. I prefer McDonald's fries.

Worth the money, but not too great.  All of the dishes were less than 10 dollars, and the portions are really big.  However, what you get is basically a bowl of noodles with very few vegetables and meat.  If you're looking for a cheap, filling meal this is a great place.  If you want good Asian food, look elsewhere.

"It is undoubtedly worthwhile to pay a visit to this destination, at least once. The abundance of activities present here is indeed pleasing, and it renders the visit worthwhile in and of itself. The live music performances and the dancing women clad in minimal attire contribute significantly to the lively ambiance, despite their apparent lack of enthusiasm. For those who are interested, zip lines are also available, albeit at a premium price point. Unfortunately, our culinary experiences at this location were less than satisfactory, as both the gourmet hot dog eatery and the Middle Eastern restaurant failed to meet our expectations. Specifically, the latter's inclusion of cheeseburgers on their menu was perplexing and did not align with our preconceived notions of traditional Middle Eastern cuisine."

It's worth a visit. ONE visit, at least.

A lot of activity here, which is nice. That alone makes it worth the visit. Bands playing, scantily-clad women dancing. Too bad they looked so bored.

Zip lines are available (expensive) if you like that sort of thing.

We ate at two places here - the "gourmet hot dog" shop and the "middle eastern food" restaurant. Both were disappointing. Not terrible, but neither do I have a desire to return to those establishments. (What kind of middle eastern restaurant serves cheeseburgers?)

Dave's Dog House makes unique, tasty hot dogs. They have a delightful, back-east bun that's more like a piece of thick, foldable toast. The dogs are high quality and flavorful, and priced well. The fries are alright, but sadly nothing to write home about. \n\nThey've since moved ON campus, just off the Gammage Parkway loop, so it's a bit trickier to get to from Mill during school, but they're a much better dog than some of the other options available on Mill.

I had been fervently anticipating that my experience at Port of Subs would be thoroughly enjoyable, given the plethora of establishments they boast in Las Vegas; however, upon perusing their offerings and sampling their fare, I was left with a somewhat mixed impression, as the quality of the ingredients and the freshness of the meats and cheeses utilized in their sandwiches were certainly palatable, yet the bread itself lacked a certain je ne sais quoi in terms of both texture and flavor profile, which ultimately led me to conclude that while the prices they charge are indeed reasonable, they do not necessarily represent the most judicious expenditure of resources when compared to alternative dining options in close proximity.

"Culinary indulgences served as the pinnacle of my dining experience, precipitating a profound sense of satisfaction. However, certain aspects of the service fell short of my expectations, specifically, the interaction between staff and patron lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, thereby precluding me from assigning a rating of four stars. Subsequently, I ventured to the restrooms, which regrettably, did not meet my standards of cleanliness, ultimately leading me to downgrade my assessment by one star. Notwithstanding this drawback, the complimentary miso soup, iceberg salad, and fresh fruit offered at the conclusion of the meal served as a pleasant surprise, providing a glimmer of hope that this establishment has the potential to attain a higher rating in the future."

"Aesthetically pleasing retail establishment, seemingly situated beyond my customary geographic parameters for perusing consumer goods, yet I chanced upon its premises today while traversing the locality, thereby necessitating an exploratory visit. Observed minimal patronage, with a conspicuous absence of shoppers, while staff members appeared profusely engaged in inventory replenishment. Did not encounter the specific item I sought, presumably due to its seasonal nature and association with scholastic paraphernalia, but opted to peruse other regularly procured items, such as feline sustenance and melodic compact discs, and discovered prices to be reasonable, inventory abundant, and checkout queues uncrowded."

Nice store, seems a bit outside my usual area of town for shopping, but found myself over this side today, so I stopped in for a few items. Found the store to be almost empty with just a few people shopping, a lot of employee's stocking. \n\nI didn't find what I was looking for, it was probably seasonal with school supplies but took a chance to see if I could find it. Since I didn't, I took a look around at the few things I usually buy, like cat food, and music Cd's and found prices to be good, stock to be plentiful, and the lines at check out not crowded.

I was enamored by its contemporary and fashionable ambiance, reminiscent of a vibrant nightlife venue, albeit with an eccentric touch evocative of the Roxybury's unique charm; however, the spacious bar and lounge area, capable of accommodating numerous revelers, proved to be a significant drawback, as the guest rooms were somewhat diminutive in comparison. Furthermore, the culinary offerings left much to be desired, and the unreliable nature of both the wireless internet connectivity and wired ethernet connection within the guestrooms engendered considerable frustration, prompting me to question the efficacy of the hotel's internet infrastructure.

"First and foremost, let us set aside the fact that I am rapidly approaching my thirtieth year and still revel in the musical offerings of My Chemical Romance, whose primary demographic consists of teenagers. Observe, young ones, that I am legally permitted to consume alcoholic beverages and, indeed, I possess a cold brew in hand! Wooooooo ahhhhhhhhhh. 

The ambiance of this particular venue can be described as the less than salubrious, grimy, and somewhat promiscuous sibling of its Disney-inspired counterpart in Anaheim. This may be attributed, in part, to the fact that it resides within the confines of Mandalay Bay. Notwithstanding, the premises boast three fully-stocked bars situated at each corner of the performance area and a sunken dance floor designated for general admission patrons. 

There exists a certain tale, unrelated to the realm of band camp, whereby my closest friend and I indulged in an inebriated girls' night, replete with a visit to this very establishment. Following the consumption of several shots in a futile attempt to erase the memory of a middle-aged couple eager to engage in a'social gathering' with us, we found ourselves onstage, performing the African Anteater Ritual dance from the cinematic masterpiece, 'Can't Buy Me Love.' Does this cinematic masterpiece ring a bell? The one featuring McDreamy, prior to his metamorphosis into a veritable dreamboat."

Ok first off let's get past the fact that I'm knocking on 30's death door and still going to see bands like My Chemical Romance, where the core audience is teens. Look at me kiddies, I'm old enough to drink, and I have a beer! Wooooooo ahhhhhhhhh.

This location seems like the slimier, dirtier, slutty sister of the Disney infused Anaheim location. There is only one level at this one, due in part I'm sure, to the fact that it's in Mandalay Bay. However, there are 3 full bars at all corners of the stage, and a sunken in dance, GA floor.

There was this one time, not in band camp, where my BFF and I were having a drunken girl's night with a stop here. Oh wowwie, after downing some shots to try and forget the fact that a couple in their late 50's wanted to have a "party" with us, we ended up on stage doing the African Ant Eater Ritual dance from "Can't Buy Me Love". You remember that movie right? The one with McDreamy, before he went all, dreamy

I would come back. 

I don't live in Vegas though. My sister and her family took me here before they dropped me off on the strip. It's not too far from the strip. The food is descent for the rice. We mainly ate the bul-go-gi and the marinated pork. They have jap chae along with all the little kimchi sides. I went during lunch so I'm not sure if they put more out for dinner. They have this rule where if you waste food, they will charge you $5 or more. So make sure you eat everything on your late or else you'll be paying more! You pay after so there's no way to avoid it. 
If you want something asian and are willing to venture off the strip, I would say come here and enjoy some korean food. You get to cook on the table!

My maiden voyage to Las Vegas was necessitated by a work-related conference, which doubled as my inaugural exposure to the city's vibrant atmosphere. The arduous trek from my lodgings to the conference venue proved to be a formidable challenge, with the distance spanning at least a mile. This exhausting journey left me yearning for respite in the form of Gatorade, which regrettably remained elusive. However, this rigorous excursion rendered my gym routine superfluous throughout my tenure in Sin City.  

The culinary offerings within the conference hall were indeed delectable, with breakfast boasting a satisfying substantiality, while lunch rivaled dinner in both quantity and quality. The diverse array of options ensured that boredom never set in. Unfortunately, the copiousness of these meals had an unintended consequence, as it often induced somnolence during the latter portion of the conference. 

My sojourn at the Rio transpired on a weekday, thereby sidestepping the throngs of revelers typically associated with weekend stays. The casino presented a diverse array of tables and slots, catering to various preferences. Although I partook in some gaming activities at the Rio, my primary focus lay in exploring the Strip's numerous gambling dens. The complimentary shuttle service connecting the Rio to its affiliated casinos proved convenient. 

While the accommodations at the Rio generally met my expectations, certain antiquated features hindered their overall appeal. Notably, the presence of an outdated CRT television seemed incongruous in such a modern setting. Moreover, the absence of Wi-Fi connectivity in the rooms necessitated reliance on an Ethernet connection. Nonetheless, wireless internet access was mercifully available in the conference area. 

In conclusion, despite minor drawbacks, my initial encounter with Las Vegas proved enjoyable, primarily due to the fact that it did not burden me financially. Furthermore, the city's allure extends beyond the confines of the Rio, as the prospect of indulging in games of chance served as a compelling diversion.

"It is my ardent desire to possess an unwavering fondness for the culinary offerings, comparable to the extent of my appreciation for the panoramic vistas and ambient surroundings. Although my enthusiasm for the edibles does not rival the aforementioned sentiment, I must confess that the assortment of breads proved satisfying, particularly the variety infused with the rich flavor of peanut butter. The shrimp cocktail, with its unique and playful twist, contributed further delight to the dining experience. The beef tenderloin and cod, both showcasing the chef's proficiency in cookery, emerged as palatable options as well. Lastly, the MiX candy bar, an indulgent sweet treat, rounded out the meal on a delectable note. Notwithstanding a few instances of haughty behavior from certain members of the waitstaff, the service generally met expectations."

The gastronomical experiences that this establishment offers are utterly remarkable, with the poultry and beef tacos exemplifying an uncanny resemblance to the authentic street-style fare commonly encountered in Mexico, perhaps even surpassing it in terms of quality and flavor. As a regular patron of this eatery, I have had the pleasure of indulging in their culinary delights on numerous occasions, but unfortunately, my most recent visit proved to be somewhat problematic. Specifically, the staff appeared to be struggling with the task of dividing my order into separate components, resulting in a notable absence of the requested avocado-based sauce in my takeout bag. Moreover, the constraints of my limited lunch break precluded me from being able to return to the premises and address the issue in a timely manner.

Food is awesome the chicken and steak tacos are very close to Mexican street style maybe better and the chicken soup is the best. I eat hear alot but recently had a bad experience in drive thru and inside, employees don't know how to split orders and the guac sauce i asked for never made it in my bag and i didn't have time to go back as i was on a lunch break

"I visited this establishment on a recent evening in celebration of a friend's milestone birthday, having previously frequented the venue on multiple occasions. My experiences have been inconsistent, contingent upon my emotional state at the time of visitation. 

Advantages: The location offers an excellent opportunity for observing diverse and intriguing individuals, comprising a mix of distinctive and aesthetically pleasing patrons. The prices for beverages are reasonable, and I have yet to encounter an entrance fee. The ambiance is lively and engaging, suitable for entertaining younger acquaintances or relatives. 

Disadvantages: The atmosphere can occasionally exhibit attributes associated with pretentiousness or conceit. Patrons may subject themselves to overt examination by fellow revelers, potentially contributing to an uncomfortable experience. Additionally, the bar may lack sufficient space for dancing, leading to an awkward congregation near the entrance. Furthermore, expect to endure an extended waiting period when ordering beverages. 

In conclusion, this establishment may satisfy those seeking a quintessential Old Town experience, such as commemorating a significant birthday. However, it does not rank among my preferred destinations due to its variable nature and certain drawbacks."

Well, I really wanted to love this place based on the reviews, but it's a solid 3 stars.

Service: 5 star all the way, BUT the server totally screwed me on my wine choice.  I asked for a "house" wine, which almost always means the cheapest, well, not so much.  Got the bill and each glass was $13.50.  YIKES!!!  So, he went from 5 stars to 1 star based on that alone.

Food:  Good to very good.  I had the osso buco..not the best ever, but definitely nice.  The insalata bianca I had b4 this sounds great, but it was just okay....nothing to write home about.  My husband got sea bass special.  The flesh was chunky and beautifully grilled.  It was served with a bland spaghetti squash....WHY do people keeping pushing squash...people want to convince you it's good, but it really is never good.

Price:  Not bad, but we were definitely stung by the upsale of the "house" wine.  

Overall 3 is it, could be 4, but that was lost at $13.50/glass

"Upon culminating a vigorous Friday evening jog with the Charlotte Runner's Meet Up assemblage, I decided to halt and partake in a libational pint and a savory burger at this sprawling establishment, which boasts an expansive outdoor terrace and three tiers of bar and dining space.  The venue offers an extensive array of artisanal brews, featuring at least six regional varieties, in addition to a diverse selection of expertly crafted mixed beverages.  My gastronomical curiosity piqued, I opted to sample their signature Ghost Burger, accompanied by a creative sweet potato mash.  While the burger itself was somewhat overcooked, the incorporation of crispy bacon slices within the sweet potato puree elevated its flavor profile.  The spicy undertones of the Ghost Burger were balanced, yet the grilled onion slices added a welcome depth to the dish.  Although the service was not exceptional, it is worth noting that the staff may have been preoccupied with preparations for the impending busy evening ahead.  The prices, however, were moderately steep, totaling $20 for a single burger and beverage.  Given the caliber of the cuisine presented, a more reasonable price range would fall between $10-15."

Stopped in for a pint and a burger after a Friday Night run with the Charlotte Runner's Meet Up group.  Place is huge, with an outdoor patio and three floors of bar / restaurant space.  Lots of beers on tap - at least six local brews - as well as just about any mixed drink you could want.  I tried the Ghost Burger with the sweet potato mash.  Actually preferred the mash to the burger - the bacon slices in with the sweet potatoes were quite tasty!  The Ghost Burger itself was spicy but not outrageous.  A bit overcooked, but the grilled onions on touch were a nice touch.  Waitstaff was not great, but it was a Friday night so they probably were just prepping for a long night.  Prices were high - spent $20 for a burger and beer.  Would expect to pay about $10-15 for the quality of the food served.

After pigging out at the Wynn buffet for lunch we just wanted something simple and quick for dinner. We came here as it is my mom's preferred pho place in town. It was ok. Summer rolls lacked any mint, the veggie sides were only some bean sprouts, sad looking basil and a few slices of jalepeno.  But then we were in the middle of the desert not SoCal or Hawaii.  The broth was ok and overall just ok.

I conducted a search for an establishment that specialized in serving Gyros, and my quest led me to this particular venue. Upon entering the premises, I opted to place my order for takeout, thereby precluding myself from commenting on the quality of the waiting staff's service. However, I must say that the flavor of the Gyro meat was quite satisfactory. Unfortunately, the overall state of the interior and the level of cleanliness left much to be desired. Although I failed to observe any visible signs of pests, I could not shake off the feeling that the place was not adequately maintained, which naturally raised concerns about the hygiene of the food preparation area. Thus, I have chosen not to return to this establishment, and instead, recommend that management consider implementing measures to enhance the ambiance and general appearance of the facility, perhaps through the utilization of more aesthetically pleasing furnishings and a thorough cleaning regimen involving the application of disinfectants such as bleach.

I was looking for a place that served Gyro's and this place serves them. I ordered mine to go so I cannot comment on the wait service but the taste of the gyro meat was pretty good. I was a little put off by the overall condition and cleanliness of the place, I did not see any bugs but would not have been surprised if one came strutting out of the back at any moment. It just didn't look clean and although I did like the Gyro, I have decided not to return because I have a feeling it is not very clean and that means the food is probably in nasty conditions in the back, I would suggest they clean and make the place look better with some nicer furnishing and maybe some paint and bleach. Just sayin'.
Ugly exterior. Nicer than expected interior. Stay here as cheaper get away experience, does the job I suppose. Didn't stay here, visited a friend. That's pretty it.

"The provision of services was woefully inadequate, as evidenced by the prolonged waiting period of thirty-five minutes during the luncheon hour to receive a negi-toro roll and a philadelphia roll, despite the fact that the establishment was not particularly crowded. Furthermore, guests who arrived subsequent to my seating time were served prior to myself, which was utterly exasperating. Notwithstanding the aforementioned subpar service, the quality of the sushi was merely passable, with an emphasis on freshness; however, the rolls were carelessly assembled and appeared haphazardly prepared. While the prices were reasonable, the lunch specials offered limited options, with a distinct absence of sushi alternatives, barring four pieces of a cali roll being considered as such. In contrast, Sooo I Love Sushi boasts superior pricing, fresher fish, and more diverse rolls; regrettably, its proximity to my workplace is not as convenient as Sushi Fever, thereby making it less practical for me to frequent."

I genuinely aspired to cherish this establishment immensely, admiring the concept, commending the excellent service, appreciating the cozy ambiance, and relishing the culinary offerings. Unfortunately, the price point proved to be significantly discordant with the prevailing market rates, rendering the dining experience financially untenable. It is essential to emphasize that the cuisine was not of poor quality; however, the prices charged were incommensurate with the quantity and quality of the dishes served.

The cheese and charcuterie plate, offered at $18, was regrettably minuscule, appearing somewhat lackluster and questionably fresh. My companion and I opted for the lamb bolognese and cassoulet, both of which were palatable yet insufficiently substantial for the price of $24 per dish. Additionally, the portion sizes were relatively meager. We also sampled the Russian honey cake, which, while pleasant, would have benefited from being freshly prepared. Its slightly chilled temperature and faintly synthetic taste suggested that it had not been recently baked.

In light of the above, it is reasonable to assert that the cost of our dinner was disproportionate to the value received. Considering the modest scale of the enterprise and its recent inception, it would be more judicious for the restaurant to cultivate a devoted clientele by providing reasonably priced, refined comfort food, rather than overcompensating for expenses by inflating menu prices. This approach may potentially foster a loyal patronage and facilitate sustainable growth.

An additional observation reinforces this argument: the eatery's decor and tableware appear somewhat economical, employing inexpensive materials. While there is no inherent issue with frugality, the incongruity of consuming a $24 entree with low-cost utensils becomes apparent. The key challenge lies in determining the optimal balance between fiscal responsibility and strategic investment to ensure a harmonious dining experience for patrons.

"Intriguing conceptualization. Construct-your-own sushi roll. I appreciate the ability to select the components that will be incorporated into my sushi, however, the cost is somewhat prohibitive considering the quality of the ingredients utilized. Furthermore, the portions of fish and meat are rather meager. Although the rolls themselves are of considerable size, the primary component remains rice. \n\nThe employment of mechanical devices to distribute the rice and slice the sushi, among other tasks, is indeed fascinating to observe. This establishment is situated within a college town and caters primarily to students, thus, one cannot expect an excessive level of refinement."

They effectively captured the essence of their culinary objectives with a focus on Scandinavian cuisine, but unfortunately, it did not align with my personal preferences, despite the exceptional quality of the poutine.

Meh. \n\nThe food was different, I will give it that. I ordered the reina and the chicken arepa. They tasted like a stuffed sopapilla (sort of). I guess I was expecting something else..HOWEVER, their orange drink was awesome.

This place is probably great for a lot of people but I didn't care for it. I had the enchilada omelet and it had nasty American processed cheese on it I guess that's what they use for omelets and that probably doesn't bother most people but It makes me gag.. Ew on the menu it says jack cheese but it should add that it's processed. Anyways enough of the cheese rant. The service was good and the coffee cake was really good.
Was hoping for more.  Service was ample though kinda felt fake all around, and while most preparations were adequate, I would not laud the kitchen by any means.

"Desiring a transformation from the customary ambiance of the Half Moon for a particular Sunday Night Football gathering, I pursued an alternative sports bar within the 85016 zip code. My search culminated in the discovery of Teakwoods, a venue that boasted numerous televisions, average customer service, and an extensive menu offering, complemented by reasonable drink promotions.

The establishment presented a diverse assortment of patrons, which contributed to its appeal. The clientele comprised five rowdy fraternity brothers, four suburbanites with a penchant for gangster culture, three fashionable hipsters sporting Ray-Ban sunglasses, two gothic ladies enjoying a romantic evening together, and a twenty-something daughter engaged in a heated debate with her middle-aged mother regarding the quantity of martinis consumed. This colorful assembly added to the allure of Teakwoods.

In terms of evaluation, the beverage selection earned a subpar rating of D-, while the food menu received a more satisfactory grade of B. The atmosphere conducive to viewing sports events garnered a respectable score of B+, and the people-watching experience merited an impressive A+. Overall, Teakwoods offered a unique blend of features that made it an enjoyable destination."

Wanting a change from the Half Moon for some Sunday Night Football, i sought out another sports bar in the 85016...  Teakwoods was the answer.  Lots of TVs.  Average service.  Extensive Menu.  Good drink specials.

The Good:  For bar food, nice menu... the Jess Jess wings were pretty good.
The Bad:  The beer list is dreadful.
The Ugly:  God only knows whose nasty fingers have been in those buckets of peanuts.    

The crowd was the best part of this place... it was absolutely eclectic.  

5 drunken frat boys
4 suburban gangsta's
3 hipsters with the raybans 
2 goth chicks on a date
1 TwentySomething daughter arguing with her cougar mom about how many martini's she'd had ("mom, i swear thats your 4th one, why would i lie, i drove separate?!")  
...And a partridge in a pear tree... Teakwoods has it all!   

Beer: D-
Food: B
Sports Watching: B+
People Watching: A+

Watched a preseason Laker game at this venue against the Sacramento Kings, and it proved to be an enjoyable experience, owing to the fact that we had procured relatively decent seats. Upon our arrival, I apprised the attendant of our ticket possession, and she directed us towards the queue designated for purchasing tickets, which, unfortunately, was quite extensive. Following a ten-minute wait, we sought clarification once more, and this time, the attendant informed us that we could bypass the line and proceed directly into the arena, which struck us as somewhat perplexing, considering the unnecessary delay we had endured. Moreover, the lines for procuring sustenance and beverages were considerable in length, requiring a significant amount of time to navigate.

Watched a preseason laker game here against the sacramento kings and it was a fun experience as we pretty good seats.

Upon arriving I told the attendant we had tickets and she pointed us in the line to purchase tickets which was rather long.  We stood in line for about 10 min before asking again to make sure and this time she said we didn't have to stand in line and we can just go in, wtf man what a waste of time!

Lines for food and drinks were rather lengthy and took awhile.

"My spouse and I opted to treat my grandmother to a dining experience at this establishment on a recent Mother's Day, albeit belatedly, and I must say that I was thoroughly delighted that they offered the convenience of booking a reservation, thereby allowing us to sidestep an extensive waiting period, which I had heard was customary. Upon our arrival, we were warmly received and seated in a timely manner, following the clearing of the table by the staff. Our server was both attentive and courteous throughout the duration of our visit. While I did appreciate the ambiance created by the dÃ©cor, I couldn't help but feel that the overall atmosphere was somewhat chaotic and overpowering, potentially due to the large number of patrons present on that particular day. Notwithstanding, I did sample their renowned 'crazy biscuits,' which, while undoubtedly rich and filling, failed to elicit an extraordinary response from my palate. In contrast, my husband enjoyed the pancakes immensely, and my grandmother expressed great satisfaction with her hash browns, although I did not partake in them myself. Considering the immense popularity this eatery seems to enjoy, I might consider a return visit, but I would likely opt for a vastly different culinary selection during my next visit."

My Husband and I took my Grandma here for the first time this past Mother's Day (I know sorry for the late review).  I was really pleased that they took a reservation for the day because I've heard there can be a long wait.  Upon arrival we were greeted and seated quickly (after they cleared the table).  Our waitress was prompt and nice.  Overall, I like the decor, but the atmosphere felt very crowded and overwhelming to me... maybe it was just because of the holiday.\n\nI ordered the crazy biscuits, which I didn't love.  It was very heavy, which was obvious that it would be, but the taste didn't blow me away.  The Hubs had pancakes, which were really good.  My Grandma had the hash, which I didn't try, but she loved.  Based on this experience alone, I would go back considering so many people love it.  I would probably try something completely different though.

"Satisfactory culinary experience with a caveat; exorbitant pricing! If you're willing to splurge, this establishment offers an all-you-can-eat option for $30, allowing you to select your own side dishes, which are merely adequate. Their premier meat options, Bulogi and short ribs, are undoubtedly delectable. The service was impressive, as the staff were attentive, helpful, and enthusiastic about assisting with food preparation. However, an unfortunate incident occurred upon payment; the cashier/server inquired as to why I hadn't left a gratuity, stressing that it was obligatory.
