This encounter left a sour taste, prompting me to reconsider my initial inclination to leave a tip, ultimately resulting in a rating of three."

Good food and service but very pricey! if your willing to spend then its a good place to eat , 30$ alll you can eat you choose your own side dishes which are alright. the Bulgogi is there best meat and the short ribs. Service was great very helpful and they love helping you cook the meat. The reason i gave it a three was that at the end of the meal after paying 100$ for three al you can eat , the cashier/server harassed me why didn't i leave a tip that it was mandatory ,which was very unappreciate i was going to leave the tip but the fact that i was told i had to made me not do it

Trevi is nothing extraordinary, but is quite yummy and only a litte overpriced. I got the cheese ravioli which was pretty delicious but didn't need to be $20. However, in Vegas, Trevi is quite affordable and nicely located in Ceasar's Palace. \n\nI do strongly recommend getting the Polenta Fries. I'd never seen such a cute, creative way to serve polenta, (shaped like french fries with marinara sauce to dip it).

I indulged in a singular excursion to this establishment and suffered an unfortunate encounter with the customer service representative, whose performance was subpar and left much to be desired; however, my subsequent visit proved to be a vast improvement, thanks in large part to the exceptional efforts of an individual named Mariah, whose name I believe was accurately recalled.
I went in one time and had terrible customer service... Went in another and it was really good! Thanks Mariah. I think that's what her name was.
Old school mexican restaurant.  Food was good,  no beer, A/C was marginal.  Not for those looking for the chain restaurant atmosphere.  Very traditional.  I'll visit again when the weather is cooler.

When I went to BRGR, I got The Button Buster. I'll have to say, I was pretty excited because this looked like an awesome burger. However, I was a little disappointed. The braised short ribs on top of the burger were quite fatty and unappetizing. I took off the remaining short ribs and finished more of the burger. I wish that it would have come with a side as well. Overall, if I go here again I will definitely get a different burger.

I've only been here for breakfast and I must say it is damn good. The only reason I'm giving this place 3 stars because I'm not such a fan of the atmosphere for the morning. At 9am I don't want to hear techno music and I much prefer a relaxed atmosphere with a simple menu; not 18 different omelette!\n\nAlthough if you want a fancy breakfast and enjoy the hectic atmosphere, this place is definitely better than Eggspectation, so give it a try!

"The gastronomical experience was superlative, however, the hospitality was subpar and left an unpleasant sensation in one's oral cavity.  Unquestionably, this establishment does not cater to juveniles."

"Comparatively satisfactory liquid refreshment. However, prior to acquiring said beverage, it is imperative that the apparatus utilized for its extraction and dispensing has been thoroughly cleansed, lest the flavor be tainted by residual essences of previous patrons' consumptions, resulting in an unpleasantness akin to a sensory assault. Additionally, the supervisory personnel, specifically the female manager, would benefit from exercising greater vigilance in regards to her vocalizations and demeanor, as her loud and condescending manner towards subordinates in the presence of clientele can be perceived as boorish and unprofessional."

Pretty good juice. Just make sure the machine is clean before getting your juice, or it will taste like the last persons juice. Yuck! Also the manager \"girl\" should watch her mouth. She should not be yelling and talking down to employees in front of customers Rude!!

I think Bouchon probably deserves 3 stars based on my first visit, but I'm willing to give it another try. It is a very pretty dining room and the atmosphere was really nice. My boyfriend and I went for brunch on a Sat. We ordered chicken and waffles, steak frites, 1/2 dozen oysters, and cocktails.

Just briefly...
Bread and butter: awesome soft butter...hard bread
Oysters: really fresh but specify what types of oysters you want to your waitress
Chicken and waffles: pretty good but nothing out of the ordinary
Steak frites: good

My only compliant, which isn't really a complaint because the staff was really nice...is that I wish we were served by one person only so that's it's more consistent and timely. We had our waitress and different servers who delivered each of our items. Our items came at odd intervals. There was a big gap between the bread and butter and our oysters, our main dishes didn't come at the same time...and when I asked the waitress if my drink was still coming after we had started our dishes, she seemed genuinely surprised it hadn't. Maybe it's because the bartender delivers the drinks himself? I'm not really sure, but that would be my only suggestion, one person to take care of everything or better communication.
Don't get me wrong, steiner's is one of my favorite places but, the \"hashed browns\" served this morning were horrible!  It was like a paste that was smeared onto the griddle & cooked.  So sad

"A palpable dearth of essence permeates the ambiance of this establishment, rendering it inferior to alternative dim sum locales I have had the pleasure of experiencing. The service, characterized by an overzealous demeanor, proved intrusive, as the staff persistently endeavored to expedite our ordering process despite the absence of our complete party. Nonetheless, certain items on the menu, specifically the custard buns, shumai, and duck, did manage to elicit my approval. However, the lobster pasta failed to impress, with its unremarkable noodles overshadowing the otherwise satisfying lobster. Furthermore, the practice of removing dishes from the table for reheating in the kitchen prior to serving strikes me as inconvenient and detrimental to the overall dining experience. In light of these factors, I would not recommend revisiting this restaurant, as superior alternatives for dim sum exist."

Feel like the food and drinks are overpriced, the food is good, but for the amount and type of ingredients feel it's too pricey. Have had inconsistent service so can't really comment on it, once it was pretty good, the other two times I've been it felt like it was a bother to them to serve and there were only two other people inside.

My expectations for Vietnamese cuisine are somewhat elevated, owing to my former residence in Southern California, merely a brief automotive excursion from Westminster and Little Saigon, which are recognized for their profusion of delectable Vietnamese eateries. Notwithstanding the fact that the service at this establishment is of exceptional quality, surpassing my expectations for an Asian restaurant, and the ambiance is contemporary and welcoming, my culinary experience was merely satisfactory. Specifically, I requested the Grilled Pork, which unfortunately possessed an excessive amount of fat and saltiness, even for my taste buds, which typically appreciate a higher degree of sodium.

My standard for Vietnamese food maybe a little high given the fact that I lived in SoCal about a 20 minute drive from Westminster/Little Saigon.\n\nWhile the service here is very good for an asian restaurant, and the restaurant itself is clean and modern compared to most vietnamese restaurants, the food was just OK. I ordered the Grilled Pork and it was too fatty and salty (even for me who likes to eat salty) :-(

"Prior to returning our rental car, I implored my spouse to visit this establishment, as the reviews had piqued my interest. Upon consuming their maple donut, I would unhesitatingly award it a perfect score of ten out of five stars. The donut's exterior was delightfully crispy, while its interior was characterized by a satisfying moistness and cakiness, thereby exemplifying the quintessential donut experience. My second favorite variety was the cinnamon crumb donut, which boasted an agreeable flavor profile. However, my enthusiasm waned when I sampled the apple fritter, as it exhibited an unpleasant greasiness akin to double-frying and an overpowering sweetness that rendered it difficult to consume more than a single bite. Furthermore, the coffee served at this venue was subpar and elicited a negative response from me, with one reviewer accurately describing it as 'diner style,' which I unfortunately did not recognize as a pejorative term until after I had ingested it. Notwithstanding these criticisms, I would still frequent this establishment to indulge in their exceptional maple and cinnamon crumb donuts, and perhaps even attempt their old-fashioned glazed variety. Nonetheless, I would unequivocally avoid both the apple fritter and coffee offerings in the future."

I begged my husband to come here prior to returning our rental car due to the reviews. If I was only reviewing the maple donut, I would say 10 stars out of five. The maple donut is absolute perfection - crispy on the outside, moist and cakey on the inside, and everything a donut should be. Next on my list in order of flavor was the cinnamon crumb donut, which was also pretty good. I tried the apple fritter based on the reviews here but found it entirely too greasy, almost as if it had been double-fried, and way too sweet. I could only take one bite. The coffee was also pretty bad. I think one other reviewer described it as \"diner style\" which I didn't realize was an insult until after I drank it. I'd come back here every week for maple and cinnamon crumb donuts, and maybe to try the old fashioned glazed, but I definitely wouldn't get the coffee or the apple fritter again.

I had a really bad experience back home with buffalo wild wings but we decide to give it another shot. Nachos were good the wings were ok they were a little dry for my taste. so compare to my back home experience I will say this is a better spot. One thing is for sure Sunday football this place is crazy crowed.

I attended this gathering with the intention of expanding my professional network and acquiring valuable information, and I must say that the culinary experience was quite satisfactory, albeit not necessarily remarkable. As it was my maiden visit to the Badger State, I felt compelled to sample the local cheese curds, which, I must admit, were fairly palatable. Our server, however, elected to surprise us with an unspecified variety, thereby precluding me from forming a cognizant assessment of their quality. Notwithstanding, a fellow diner professed that they were the most delectable she had ever had the pleasure of consuming, although, in my defense, I must confess that my limited exposure to such fare rendered me unable to offer a comparative evaluation.  
Moving on to the main course, I opted for the Scandinavian-style chicken dinner, comprising a half chicken seasoned with cinnamon, cardamom, and juniper, accompanied by mashed potatoes and stuffing. While the dish was undoubtedly edible, it failed to elicit any particularly striking impression upon my gastronomical sensibilities. The ambiance, however, was quite pleasant, with tasteful adornments that contributed to an overall convivial atmosphere.

Not bad! Nice decor with cute serving dishes. I ordered the triple B burger, almost $20 (you pay for the name) but wasn't really worth the $20. Our hostess ignored us for while (with no one else waiting) before seating us and our waitress gave really poor customer service, however our runner was great and should've been our server! \n\nIf we want a great burger we'll just go to Bachi burger and get a grass fed burger for $8 cheaper! All in all, I'm glad we tried but we probably won't eat here again due to the high prices and not so attentive staff.

The Flamingo is what it is:  one of the original strip hotels trying to keep up with the never ending crop of new, ultra-modern hotels.  The flamingo succeeds on some levels:  full amenities, clean rooms, recent redesign.  It mostly fails though.   Service is poor, casino floor is dingy, the rooms are not up to par with neighboring hotels, and dining/nigh life offerings are poor.  Margaritaville is a nice try, but it comes off as dated and cheesy.  \nFlamingo is centrally located though and the rooms are nice.  The value is high too (relatively cheap).  Not a bad choice and MUCH better than the Imperial Dungeon.

Good food for the price, and one of the better places that is available late night. This location is in need of serious cleaning. Which is the ONLY reason why I'm giving  3 stars and not 5. The best food and great service doesn't make up for filth when it is dead in the middle of the night / early morning and there are employees standing around.

I've been here a half dozen times or so, mostly because it's pretty inexpensive.  If you're looking to fill up after a long day of pressing the slot machine "spin" button, you should probably give it a shot.  The champagne brunch is worth the price, and the servers I've had have all been fast and generous with the mimosas.  

There's probably not a single item on the buffet that you'll "need" to go back for, but as far as overall value for your dollar, it's hard to beat.  

I'll go back.  More than once.

"While the Flamingo Hotel may not boast the same level of opulence as its neighboring establishments along the Las Vegas Strip, it offers an affordable lodging option for those seeking a comfortable stay without breaking the bank. Moreover, the presence of flamingos just outside the window adds a unique touch to the experience, providing a tranquil ambiance that sets it apart from other hotels in the area. The buffet, while not exceptional in terms of quality, offers a reasonable price point that aligns with the hotel's overall value proposition. In essence, the Flamingo embodies the spirit of a flamingo - not as extravagant as a peacock, perhaps, but certainly not as unremarkable as a chicken. Thus, guests can indulge in a carefree atmosphere and enjoy a satisfying meal without burning a hole in their pocket."

We were meandering through the picturesque landscapes of Southern Highlands, questing for an establishment that offered wireless internet connectivity... 
  Following a brief peregrination, we stumbled upon an enchanting edifice known as Perk Up, which piqued my curiosity and prompted an impromptu visitation. 
  Upon entering the premises, my gaze ascended towards the menu, which was embellished with an array of coffee and tea varieties, accompanied by an assortment of delectable pastries and quiches. 
  Initially, my attention was captivated by the beverages, but subsequent to a thorough examination of the menu, I discovered a supplementary list of breakfast and lunch options, articulated on a freestanding chalkboard. 
  Prior to perusing the menu, I requested a pot of tea, and subsequently, I opted for a savory repast, engaging in a dialogue with the hospitable cashier regarding several sandwich selections... 
  The young woman enthusiastically elaborated on the particulars of each dish, even mentioning the imminent emergence of freshly baked pumpkin muffins from the kitchen, which kindled my interest and precipitated an unwavering decision to sample their culinary delights. 
  My order consisted of a slice of quiche, complemented by a modest portion of fruit, which, upon arrival, proved to be satisfactory, albeit not extraordinary, while the fruit appeared slightly wilted, perhaps due to its advanced age. 
  My companion astutely observed that the fruit seemed unappealing and likely remained uneaten for a few days, prompting the staff to expedite the preparation of fresh fruit, which they graciously presented to us. 
  Although the cuisine did not evoke an intense yearning for a future visit, the spotless interior, combined with the attentive service, rendered Perk Up an agreeable venue for socializing over a cup of coffee or tea.

We arrived at this establishment with the intention of partaking in a midday repast and acquiring a panoramic perspective of the famed Las Vegas Strip.  As it happened, our visit transpired on a weekday, thereby ensuring a relatively limited clientele and rendering the process of securing an advantageous table offering an unobstructed view of the aforementioned Strip, Bellagio, and Caesars' Palace a decidedly straightforward endeavor.  My culinary selection consisted of a delectable burger, its price tag set at sixteen dollars, which was cooked to my specifications, specifically the medium rare designation.  My spouse opted for a dish comprising baked vegetable crepes, priced at seventeen dollars, yet the quality of the fare proved merely satisfactory, as the primary draw of this eatery lies in its breathtaking vantage point rather than the gastronomical offerings.  Additionally, the restaurant extended complimentary bread puffs and a delightful pistachio pudding to its patrons.  It is worth noting that my recent excursion to the Hancock's 95th floor Signature Room led me to harbor expectations of ascending to the summit of the iconic Eiffel Tower; however, this particular venue boasts an elevation akin to the fifth floor, a logical decision given the physical constraints of the aforesaid tower's slender structure.

We came here for lunch and a view of the strip.  There's not much of a weekday lunch crowd and getting a nice table with a view of the strip, Bellagio, and Caesars' Palace was easy.  I had a nice $16 burger that was cooked medium rare as requested.  Wife had baked vegetable crepes for $17.  Food was ok, but you're really paying for the view.   They also served complimentary bread puffs and a nice pistachio pudding.   Having recently gone to the Hancock's 95th floor Signature Room, I thought we might be going to the top of the Eiffel Tower, but this place is like at the 5th floor elevation.  Makes sense - they wouldn't have a whole lot of tables at the top of that skinny tower!

An update in my last review, since the improvements have been made. Unfortunatley I wanted to improve my 3 stars...but alas I cant. Yes the improvements have been made and you can see the results, but its still so bleak. Why are train stations always so cold even although they have an indoor waiting area?? \nThis is a well used station, more effort needed !!!
Located at one end of the Miracle Mile Shops.   Plenty of seating and lots of help behind the counter.   You can look out into the pool area during the day.
Basic burger and onion rings were good not great. Decent meal if you're at the Mirage but otherwise I'd look for another option if I was inclined to go elsewhere.

The events center was nice, but nothing special from a trade show perspective. Perhaps I would have liked it better if I were there for a concert or boxing event.

I tried to get wi-fi outside, but it was $500 per day!!! PER DAY! I want to say it was a typo or a bug in the system, but I was so turned off I didn't even try connecting. There's taking advantage of an audience, and then there's straight robbery. $500 for wi-fi is ridiculous. The Las Vegas Convention Center has free wi-fi.

Also, I tried to get a cab afterward, and there were none. I was about the 10th person in line, and I had to wait 20+ minutes for a cab. I'm not sure why that area's not well served by cabs. I would have been better off walking to the front of the hotel which is about 10 minutes from the event center.

Overall, I'd say go for the event, not the event center itself.

"Have you ever had an inkling to witness a hipster Applebee's in all its glory? As someone who has only partaken in luncheon excursions during the workweek, I must confess that the service, while adequate, has been known to exhibit a tendency towards a tardiness that belies its otherwise acceptable quality. Of late, they have implemented those infernal table-side computing contraptions, which, in addition to being an unwelcome distraction, seem to inspire an unseemly eagerness on the part of our servers to coerce us into utilizing them. Suffice it to say, I have deducted a star from my overall rating as a result, and it is likely that this development will lead to a decrease in my patronage. The culinary offerings, while hardly exceptional, are what one has come to expect from such an establishment; pedestrian fare, replete with an excess of sodium, yet still managing to elicit a certain je ne sais quoi. For instance, the chicken tortilla soup and honey pepper chicken tenders, both of which possess a certain je ne sais quoi that renders them palatable, albeit not particularly remarkable. Lastly, the musical selections, though not deafening in volume, vacillate between the merely mediocre and the downright grating. Upon reflection, it is a wonder indeed that we have continued to frequent this establishment with such regularity."

Ever want to see a hipster Applebee's?  I've only come by for lunch during the week, service is usually decent but time to get your food always seems to take a lot longer than it should.  

They've also rolled out the new table side computers, I hate how distracting they are and how pushy servers are about using them. Honestly I dropped a star just for that and it will probably cause me to stop coming by as often as I do.

Food quality is what you expect, Sysco food with way too much sodium.  Saying that the chicken tortilla soup and honey pepper chicken tenders are pretty good.

Last thing is music, not that loud but everything they play is on a sliding scale from meh to truly aggravating.  Wow, after writing this I wonder why we go so much.

"A picturesque setting situated on the shores of the lake, providing an idyllic ambiance for an enjoyable dining experience. Accommodating last-minute reservations, including those for larger parties such as ours, which consisted of seven individuals. However, it is essential to note that the establishment may not be suitable for young children due to its sophisticated atmosphere. Our server was attentive, yet we encountered minor inconveniences, such as having to request additional water and flag him down multiple times to place our orders and receive our checks in a timely manner. While the cuisine was satisfactory, the prices were somewhat exorbitant. The wine and dessert menus offered an extensive selection, catering to diverse tastes and preferences. Unfortunately, a misunderstanding regarding two antipasta plates resulted in an unexpected charge of $72, which we contested. Furthermore, our server failed to accommodate our request for separate checks for four individuals, leading to an unfortunate inconvenience. Considering the current struggles faced by businesses in the Lake Las Vegas Village, exceptional customer service and hospitality are crucial to attract and retain local clientele. Regrettably, our experience left a negative impression, making it challenging to recommend this restaurant without reservation."
If you're a gringo, than this is the place for you. The drink specials here are killer, but the food is better at Taco Bell...

So I don't normally expect a lot when eating at IHOP, but this one isn't that bad! And it's actually quite a busy location. I made the mistake of going here to eat during spring training season - it was insanely packed and we waited quite a while to be seated. However, once we were at our table the service was good and so was the food. This IHOP is open 24 hours, which may be good to know in case I get a midnight pancake craving.

"I thoroughly enjoy this establishment and would unquestionably spend an inordinate amount of time traversing the campus to partake of their delectable sweet and sour chicken, accompanied by a complimentary cup of green tea, were it not for the fact that they do not offer delivery services and appear to be unfamiliar with the utilization of telephonic communication devices. On my most recent visit, the gentleman behind the counter was so absorbed in his duties that he inadvertently neglected to retrieve a caller from hold, leading me to surmise that their dearth of familiarity with phones may be a significant hindrance to their potential success. Furthermore, I must admit that the state of disarray in which the kitchen often finds itself causes me some trepidation, despite my unwavering affection for their culinary offerings. Given the frequency with which I have observed a plethora of feminine figures endeavoring to prepare an excessive number of meals for an overwhelming throng of patrons, I am inclined to believe that a more organized and well-maintained environment might be conducive to a more satisfactory dining experience. Notwithstanding, I find this eatery to be an excellent choice for occasional visits, perhaps a few times per academic term, as its popularity tends to result in an overcrowded atmosphere that does not particularly align with my personal preferences."

I LOVE this place and if I had a million hours to waste I would walk my lazy self across campus and pick up some sweet and sour chicken and have a free Styrofoam cup of green tea every day of my life. Unfortunately they do not deliver and I don't even think they know how to use a phone. The last time I was there the man was so busy he picked up the phone and put them on hold and never picked it back up. I found it funny, but I'm sure that customer did not. \nAnd, you know, if they opt out of delivery they should really clean the place up a bit. I get worried what the kitchen looks like and have peeked back there a few times to see complete chaos (mostly because there's 8 or 9 women cooking for too many customers to handle). \nI love the food, but this place is great to go to maybe a few times per semester. It's just too crowded for my liking.

"Poutine was a culinary experience we were eager to indulge in during our visit to Montreal. Cafe Poutine, situated in the historic and touristy district of Old Montreal, seemed like an ideal establishment to sample this quintessential Quebecois dish. Upon entering the cozy eatery, we were immediately struck by the bustling atmosphere and the tight spacing between tables, which made navigating the narrow aisles somewhat challenging.  

The menu offered an array of poutine options, each showcasing unique ingredient combinations that piqued our interest. In addition, sandwiches served with a side of poutine were also featured, providing an alternative for those seeking a more diverse taste experience. My fiancÃ© opted for the smoked meat poutine, while I decided on the chicken, apple, and brie sandwich, omitting the poutine component. We rationalized that sharing would be feasible since portion sizes appeared generous.  

Upon ordering, we encountered some misunderstandings. Despite requesting no fries, my plate arrived with an abundance of golden, crispy fries, which, although delicious, did not align with my expectations. The poutine itself was satisfactory but failed to meet the lofty standards we had built up in our minds. The flavors didn't meld together seamlessly, and the fries with cheese and gravy didn't live up to their touted reputation. Conversely, my sandwich delighted my taste buds, as the perfectly toasted baguette complemented the richness of the brie and the sweetness of the apples.  

Our server's attitude bordered on brusqueness, as they seemed rushed and slightly indifferent to our needs. Two minor requests - excluding cheese from my sandwich and omitting fries from my plate - went unfulfilled, leaving a trace of disappointment.  

The prices charged at Cafe Poutine were moderately steep, with a total of 35 Canadian dollars spent on two waters, a smoked meat poutine, and a chicken sandwich. Although understandable given the location, the cost didn't quite align with the quality of the meal.  

In conclusion, if you find yourself in the vicinity of Cafe Poutine and are craving a convenient poutine fix, it might be worth a visit. However, if your quest is for an extraordinary, memorable poutine encounter, it's advisable to continue exploring other options."

Poutine was high on our list of things to try in Montreal. Cafe Poutine was a clear stop given it's name and location in touristy, Old Montreal location. The restaurant was small and crowded...it was tough  trying to get between the tables. 

The menu was promising - tons of Poutine options as well as sandwiches with a side of poutine as an option. My fiance had the poutine with smoked meat and I had the chicken, apple and brie sandwich- no poutine (I figured I could share). The portions were huge - I had a pile of fries on my plate (even though I had asked for no fries). The poutine was okay, not as mind-blowing as fries with cheese and gravy promised to be. My sandwich was so delicious. The baguette was perfectly toasted and the brie and apples were a great compliment.

The service was hurried and not very accommodating. i asked for no cheese on the sandwich, which they said wasn't possible. They also missed the no fries request.

The prices were also high- 2 waters, smoked meat poutine and a chicken sandwich set us back 35 CA. It makes sense for the district, but not for the overall experience.

Bottom line - if you're in the area and don't want to dig for poutine, this would be an ok stop. If you're looking for and awesome poutine experience, keep on walking.

"It is truly perplexing to comprehend how such an occurrence could transpire, wherein a flight has been oversold, despite my having secured a reservation and checked in with ample time to spare. My initial reaction was one of utter disbelief and indignation, which understandably stemmed from the fact that I had been eagerly anticipating returning home after attending an exhilarating Iron Maiden concert in Phoenix. However, upon further deliberation, I chose to elevate my rating from a mere one star to three, primarily due to the commendable efforts exhibited by the airline's staff in locating an alternative yet comfortable seat for me on the same flight. Additionally, the flight attendants displayed exceptional cordiality and respect towards me throughout the journey, which contributed significantly to my enhanced satisfaction. Consequently, despite the initial hiccup, I must admit that my overall experience was generally pleasant."

Oversold flight... How exactly that happens? 

Was flying back home from an Iron Maiden concert in Phoenix and found, to my surprise, that although I'd paid for my reservation and checked in early, my flight was oversold. I was pissed to say the least. This review started @ 1 star. I raised it to 3 because the staff actually found me a very comfortable seat on the same flight... and I was able to get out quickly. The flight attendants were really nice and courteous.

So? I was happy.

This theater plays all the recent and popular flicks. The prices are pretty much right up there with the other chains like Regal and AMC. However this theater could use some updating. The bathrooms are horrific; they smell terrible and are always trashed. I suggest going to the very back of the theater to use those reatrooms. The seats in the theater are sticky and have weird stains on them, and many of the arm rests are falling apart.  The best part about this theater is it shows indi films sometimes...so that's cool.

This establishment represented my initial culinary venture within the city of Phoenix, and I was graciously accorded the privilege of partaking in a midday repast at this locale preceding a scheduled appointment, during which my mental state was characterized by a considerable degree of apprehension, thus rendering my recollection of specifics somewhat limited; however, I would unhesitatingly endorse this venue to devotees of Japanese cuisine or individuals seeking a rapid and convenient meal to be consumed at their workstation, and it is worthy of note that the hospitality we received was indeed commendable.

This was my first restaurant in Phoenix. I was taken here for a lunch prior to an interview I had. I was pretty nervous about the whole situation so I don't remember too many details, but I would recommend this place if you're a sushi lover or on the go and need a quick lunch to eat at your desk. Service was great too.

I don't eat fish but my family does. My husband & daughter said the fried catfish is awesome! I got a steak which sucked. Everything on the menu is fried & there isn't one healthy thing offered. It's basically a heart attack in the making. Even the salad came loaded with cheese & bacon. If your even the least concerned about your health you will leave feeling guilty.

We opted to visit the establishment earlier in the week due to my aunt's unwavering fondness for the fried soft shell crab appetizer offered by the restaurant. However, I must respectfully disagree with her assessment of its quality. While it was by no means unpalatable, I have personally had the pleasure of indulging in far superior renditions of this dish at other Japanese eateries of similar standing. Furthermore, we made the mistake of ordering two large boats, which were excessively generous portions of various sushi rolls, including spicy tuna, california, eel, soft shell crab, and skewers of chicken teriyaki, in addition to an assortment of sashimi. Ultimately, our culinary excursion yielded a verdict of middling fare, rendering it an unlikely selection for future visits.

If there existed a button emblazoned with the phrase "not intended for consumption by vegetarians", I would unhesitatingly engage its surface with my index finger, as an expression of my culinary inclinations. Notwithstanding the aforementioned statement, my associates who partake in the consumption of meat products have expressed their satisfaction with the edibles offered by this establishment, and the personnel operating the bar have demonstrated proficiency in their duties during the designated period of reduced alcoholic beverage prices. A considerable portion of the clientele present during the late afternoon and early evening hours consist of legal professionals, likely due to the proximity of this venue to their places of employment within adjacent structures.

This undiscovered treasure trove of culinary delights, nestled within the confines of Planet Hollywood, offers a veritable cornucopia of gastronomical indulgences at a price point that is eminently reasonable and accessible to the discerning patron. Although the speed of service may vary contingent upon the time of day and the influx of clientele, the ambiance of this eatery remains palpably electric and unwaveringly conducive to satiating one's hunger pangs, particularly during the nocturnal hours when other establishments have ceased operation. While the quality of the fare served may not necessarily qualify it as the most exceptional or delectable offering within the city's vast gastronomic landscape, it nevertheless fulfills its intended purpose with aplomb and serves as a welcome respite for those seeking sustenance following an evening of revelry and merriment in the city of Las Vegas. Moreover, the convenience of round-the-clock availability renders it an invaluable asset for those who find themselves in need of a satisfying repast during the wee hours of the morning.

"The accommodations merited a rating of three celestial bodies due to the exceptional benevolence of the personnel and the spaciousness of the chambers. However, the experience was somewhat marred by the unavailability of the room until after the designated check-in period, which necessitated a brief excursion to pass the time. Upon returning to the resort, I was compelled to indulge in some nocturnal slumber in my friend's suite before gaining access to my own quarters at an ungodly hour of 4:15 a.m. Furthermore, the bedding presented an unfortunate state of uncleanness, prompting the staff to effect a replacement with fresh linens, pillows, and a comforter obtained from an external cleaning service. Although certain minor inconveniences arose, the staff maintained a persistently pleasant demeanor, leaving me uncertain about the prospect of future lodging at this establishment."

The ambiance/decor is really great. It's fun and hip. You can sit on the balcony or step out to the balcony during the Treasure Island pirate ship show and have a great view.

BAD: prices are high.

BAD: stir-fry shrimp with sambal sauce. Way too salty, had to send it back.

BAD: kobe beef sliders were way too salty. came with an untraditional ketchup, mustard, and good onion rings.

OK with major potential: Lychee beignets. These arrive in traditional round beignet form but are filled with a substance that tastes like batter with chopped lychees. I guess the chef doesn't know that beignet are supposed to be light and airy. These are more like doughnuts and are too sweet because they're covered in sugar crystals. I loved the lychee taste when I could taste it.

OK: the yellowtail sashimi with jalapeno preparation was tasty but the slices were really thin and the fish could have been fresher.

GOOD: edamame. served warm with some salt.

GOOD: sushi. Hubby is very picky and he enjoyed his nigiri and hand-rolls.

GOOD: hubby really liked the steak yakitori in the sauce that has a long name starting with a K.

I visited on 10/26/11 for lunch. The girl working at the counter seemed almost annoyed we came at an off-peak hour. I asked if they served coffee and she there's two coffee shops next door. A little sarcastic, not very friendly. Had I not already paid I would have just gone next door for coffee AND lunch. The bread for the caprese sandwich was good,  warm and slightly toasted. I understand that caprese salad is generally served chilled but on a sandwich, it tasted off. Like warm and flakey on the outside, cold on the inside. Decent but not enough to entice me back anytime soon.

Second time visiting this burger joint, I do have to say I really like this place the burgers rock! They are real juicy burgers. You will definately walk out of there full and happy. They have burritos and bowls too,but I just can't get past the burgers. Its always clean and the workers are always nice and helpful. They never look to busy though, hope they stick around.

"Gluten-free cakes and scones; an ostensibly delectable indulgence, we presumed. Preceded by anecdotal acclaim, Mimi's was our destination of choice, and in tandem with a fellow gluten-intolerant companion, we ventured forth to the shore. Prior notification of our impending arrival had been conveyed to Mimi's, thus ensuring an inventory of gluten-free products. Disappointment ensued, however, as our expectations were not entirely fulfilled. While the taste of the scones was satisfactory, their texture proved problematic, disintegrating into minute fragments that necessitated consumption with a spoon, accompanied by jam and cream. The cupcake, though visually appealing, was merely an unremarkable iced fairy cake, lacking the extravagant embellishments characteristic of Cuckoo's creations. It is worth noting that fellow Yelpers have expressed positive sentiments regarding Mimi's and the cakes do appear appetizing; nonetheless, for gluten-free devotees, the experience was underwhelming. Alternative, superior cakes can be found in proximity, negating the need for an excursion to The Shore."

GF cakes and scones :-) Or so I thought. I had heard great things about Mimi's so I was keen to go and with a fellow GF amigo, we headed down to the Shore. We had told Mimi's we would be in so we knew there would be some GF products available.

If you are coming for GF cake, then there are better options. We had great tasting scones, however, they crumbled into little bits and we ate them with jam and cream with a spoon. Our cupcake was just a normal iced fairy cake, so no lavish creations like those at Cuckoo's. 

I know fellow Yelpers speak highly of Mimi's and the cakes do look amazing, but for us GF gals, it was really disappointing and there are better cakes to be had around town, without shlepping to The Shore like we did...

This is not the most authentic Ethiopian food, but it is one of the better ones in AZ. The food was full of flavor and spice. The sour injera (spongy bread) with alicha sega wat (beef stew) is delicius. I also enjoy getting the combos which includes three different stews. It's a great way to find out what you like.

I really wanted to like Tao. It was my first clubbing experience in Vegas.

I love the decor and theme.  The buddha, the girls in the bathtubs, the restroom doors you have to lock to make opaque are all fun.  

Unfortunately it gets wayyyy too crowded and the crowd was just ok.  We won't be back.  Head over to the clubs at Encore/the Wynn instead.

There's good and bad here.  

Good = Happy hour is pretty solid.  There's always a good crowd.  The atompshere is as good as it gets for Chandler.  Staff is pretty nice.

Bad = The tables are packed in tight.  Tight like a fat kid's waistband after a no-holds barred Golden Corral session.  Parking is bad.  You'll probably have to park by the other businesses in the complex and huff it over.  The food is mediocre at best.  

All in all if you're looking for a happy hour spot to start the night, you could do worse.  If you're looking for a meal, head elsewhere.

this is a pretty cool little, unasuming pit stop if you're in downtown phoenix...
the gallery also houses a bookstore and bakery/restaurant.
the gallery is HUGE, with brick walls and concrete floor, it's a cool little historic building that stays true to its origins.
the art tends to be of the ridiculously overpriced, nothing special variety, but, like i said, it's a nice little meal/book browse/gallery pit stop if you're in the are and have time.

Gotta love Groupon....Sometimes. This time, the buzz wasn't ready for the flood of people. They were too slammed for their own good. Service WAY SLOW. Wrong stuff delivered, but we were too hungry to care!! Our neighborhood sushi joint couldn't handle the pressure, but, we will still be back...

Rudy's is a pretty decent place to get a BBQ Sandwich.  

Pros:  -There is sauce a-plenty and they are all pretty tasty
            -Creamed Corn is OUT OF THIS WORLD 
            -Big space with plenty of seating
            -Location is easy to find and near lots of shopping

Cons: -Service is a bit unprofessional flirting and weird comments abundant
           -There are no french fries (BBQ without fries is kind of un-American)
            -"General Store" is pretty lame.  Nothing like a Cracker Barrel.  
           
I say try it.  If for no other reason than that freaking amazing creamed corn!  I know this sounds weird.  As a rule I am not even a big fan of creamed corn, but WOW!  This stuff is GOOD.

Went here for an \"employee meeting\" today and was pleasantly surprised. The host and waitress were really nice, and we had some good service. Ended up ordering a Bleu & Black burger and it was good - fries were okay, a little soggy from the huge ass pickle with all its pickle juice but I didn't mind all too much... probably because I was so hungry. \n\nI won't go out of my way to come back to BW3, but I also wouldn't object either. So this place gets an okay from me. If anything, I can always update my review!

Honestly, the food was probably 2-star quality, but I'm giving it 3 because it was late, and we were hungry, and it was open. That said, it was very generic quality breakfast/diner food, and while it satisfied my hunger, it didn't quite hit the spot.
The ultimate skillet was more like vegetable skillet. Barely any sausage. Pancake is good. Food is decent too. Overall just an average.

"While not an unsavory location for a pre-game libation, it is crucial to be cognizant of the potential throngs that may congregate at this establishment, rendering it challenging to secure a tranquil drinking experience. Furthermore, it is worth noting that the absence of a dedicated culinary menu may necessitate a brief excursion to an adjacent section of the bar to procure sustenance, prior to returning to one's seat with said victuals. Conversely, the expansive outdoor area boasts an impressive magnitude, which undoubtedly contributes to its appeal."

not a bad place for a pint before a game.... but it can get packed!!!  i also found out that they don't have a food menu... you get your food from a different part of the bar and bring it back to your seat.... \n\nthe large outside area is awesome because it is so big...

I applaud the look of this place and the artistry of the setup at the sushi bar. My primary goal was to relax for half an hour or so between professional obligations and grab an appetizer and a beer, and Fujo definitely accommodated those needs in a timely fashion.

Being in the Carolinas and craving something with a bit of heat, I opted for the Cajun Roll which featured crayfish with shrimp and crab. It was nothing mind-blowing, but neither was it repulsive. Since moving the South I've learned that one was must accept, I've learned to be thankful for what I can get in the sushi department. However, I was really not a particularly big fan of the hot-and-sour soup. The ingredients were not particularly fresh, and the un-nuanced broth was just on the verge of being genuinely unpleasant  to get down.

This place still has a certain charm to it, but it's probably not Charlotte's best work from a culinary standpoint.

Food was ok. Never expect amazing food from any of the India Palaces and Taj Mahals. There was a private party going on and the kids were running around, yelling and misbehaving. The restaurant should have closed admission to general public or have asked the private party for courtesy.\n\nService was good, food was mediocre. We went because this was the closest place and everything else had waiting. Rightfully so.

Went to Fuel to grab lunch.I had two slices of The Extreme Fuel Pizza which is pepperoni,Italian sausage,meatballs,ham and ground beef for the uninitiated as well as the Garlic Knots.There have been several restaurants in this particular spot over the years but I believe this one is gonna stick around on a while.The pizza was great and the service even better.Call and order ahead if you can because this place gets crowded really fast.This is a definite step up from your local corporate pizza fare.Enjoy.
Not as good as the sign says, but for the price its not so bad. Old dinner feel in glendale. If u have the time, check it out once.

I cannot speak to the food here, but drinking beer in a church seems so wrong and so right at the same time.

We sampled 3 or 4 of the beers brewed in house and they were all wonderful. One of the Belgian Style Ales (I forget the name) was absolutely delicious.

Along the same lines as many other reviews the service left a bit to be desired. Oh Church Brew Works I wanted to give you 4 stars but servers that get salty because we aren't ordering food? Minus 1 star. I mean c'mon the name of the place has Brew in the name. Maybe we should've stayed sitting at the bar...

Regardless, an awesome place to check out simply for drinking beer in what used to be a church!

This used to be the closest pub to my old flat, so we would often pop over for some afternoon relief. Its your standard pub, nothing out of the ordinary here folks. The prices are quite good, at one stage they did a 99p glass of wine. Although with ever changing licensing laws, that probably doesn't happen anymore. I used to get a Kopperburg for \u00a32.85 which was pretty reasonable for Edinburgh.\n\nThis pub is located just along from Edinburgh bus station, so its a good stop off if you have time to kill before you hop on a bus. Just a relaxed pub which is good for a quick after work drink or a catch up with a friend.

"It is what it is; an indubitable reality that the cost-effectiveness of utilizing the services of this postal facility surpasses that of its privately owned counterparts, thereby substantiating the notion that efficacy is indeed being achieved. This particular establishment, while not devoid of areas for improvement, does possess certain attributes that render it relatively satisfactory. Spaciousness, for instance, is one such characteristic, as it mitigates the sensation of confinement commonly associated with queuing at post offices. Unfortunately, a perpetual queue is an unavoidable aspect of visiting this location, regardless of the time of day, thereby necessitating the allocation of additional time for the duration of one's visit. Furthermore, a dearth of personnel manning the windows contributes to the prolongation of wait times. A once-available automated stamp dispenser has been removed, obliging those seeking to procure stamps to join the queue, thereby exacerbating the aforementioned delays. However, a self-service kiosk designed for the dispatch of smaller, standard packages has been implemented, facilitating a swifter and more efficient experience for those who require neither the assistance of a desk clerk nor the processing of bulky items. Additionally, the expansive parking area accommodates numerous vehicles, obviating the need for patrons to circle the block in search of a vacant spot, a convenience that cannot be overstated. In conclusion, while not perfect, this post office generally meets expectations."

My sibling and I ventured out into Chinatown on a Friday evening, hankering for sushi, but upon discovering a ninety-minute waiting period, I inquired of my sibling whether she had ever indulged in Korean BBQ, to which she responded affirmatively, thereby leading us to our destination.

I pose this inquiry due to my reluctance to sample unfamiliar cuisine without prior knowledge and guidance, as I prefer to rely on someone else's expertise before embarking on a solo adventure and introducing others to novel culinary experiences.

Upon entering the establishment, we encountered rows of compact booths, each equipped with a central grill, facilitating an indoor BBQ dining experience. Patrons could select from an assortment of beef varieties, such as tongue and rib, succulent shrimp, and pork alternatives, rendering this venue an unadulterated carnivorous haven.

Apart from a meager selection of vegetarian options presented in a salad bar format, other prepared Asian delicacies included sweet and sour pork, sushi, tempura vegetables, and diverse additional salads, albeit with an Asian twist, leaving me uncertain of their specific designations.

Throughout our visit, our beverages remained consistently replenished, and the staff diligently maintained a tidy grill surface, ensuring a pleasurable dining atmosphere.

Ultimately, this excursion offered a distinctive and captivating experience that I wholeheartedly endorse and encourage others to attempt.

We just sort of ended up here.   This one is full of the old folks with coupons and oxygen tanks from Sun City. Dinner here starts at 3:00PM.  We usually sit at the bar and just enjoy some appetizers and drinks.  They have some decent mixed drinks and some tasty apps.  The bartenders are great and appreciate when young'uns like us show up.    There's always better seafood out there, but in a pinch Red Lobster is solid and will suffice.

Not one of my favorites...too much shabby chic and country store new stuff...real antiques are hit and miss, and prices vary wildly.  More often than not staff seems  aloof - either that, or I feel like me and my kids are being followed.  Sometimes you'll find a bargain, and some of the new dealers have created some space with real ambiance, so I will keep trying!

I had a Papa Kelsey's Special Pizza while my wife had a Calzones with extra toppings  like tomato, green bell pepper, olives and onion. We both ordered two Italian salad with blue cheese and ranch dressing. Can't believe I had so much root beer.\nOver all the food was alright. We had a good lunch. One of their booth seats, the upholstery is torn. Not a good thing. But, Folks like what I said we have to continually support our local restaurants.

Go here for the strong margarita's to escape the heat of the strip. .

The margaritas we had were great.  Try them on the rocks or frozen--doesn't really matter.  I was pretty surprised to be honest, as they just make huge batches of the stuff and pump it out en masse. 

The food wasn't anything spectacular, but you most certainly could do worse on the strip for your money.  You are really paying for the atmosphere here.  Everything is tacky and very Vegas, but that's why you are there in the first place.

Definitely would go again, just nothing incredible or mind-blowing in my book.

"Enthusiastically endorse the establishment's ambiance, specifically appreciating the provision of billiard tables, colossal displays, exceptional acoustics, and an overall convivial demeanor. Particularly fond of their gourmet grilled cheese sandwich, which surpasses expectations and brings joy to my culinary companion's countenance. However, the vegetarian burger option does not resonate with my taste buds. Nonetheless, I generally approve of this dining venue."

Love the setup, love that they have pool tables, love the big screens, great music, great atmosphere, great servers, good food.  Ultimate Grilled Cheese is indeed ultimate...it's a stand out dish that put a smile on my foodie friend's face; not a fan of the veggie burger tho.  But overall, I can dig it...

This specific site is characterized by a high level of activity and traffic, which is indicative of its popularity and appeal to a diverse range of patrons seeking convenient and satisfying dining options. Notably, it offers an advantageous promotion on the iconic Big Mac sandwich, which is a significant draw for customers seeking a substantial and gratifying meal at a reasonable price. Furthermore, the speed and efficiency with which this establishment provides its culinary offerings make it an ideal choice for busy parents seeking nourishing fare for their children while on the go.
This location is quite busy. Had a good deal on Big Mac's. Quick and easy food to pick up for the kids on the go ...

I have been to three locations of this establishment and have been prettty pleased with my visits. I always opt for  breakfast here... The Acapulco express omelette is excellent..chorizo, avocado, green chilies and onions, melted cheeses, sour cream and their fresh made salsa.  I also love their french toast, which along with pancakes and waffles are made from scratch. The Floridian french toast used to be Arizona french toast and had the most delectible prickly pear butter with it, but it's newer incarnation is covered in berries and kiwi and is tasty nonetheless. I have never had bad service here. I've mostly received 25% tip worthy attentiveness.  I like how there seems to be delightful little bowls of fruit on the side with most entrees. (And not just crappy melons and grapes) Also, the coffee isn't bad and they have the courtesy to leave a fresh caraffe full so I am never caffeine deprived when leaving. All in all its a solid joint for breakfast in my humble opinion.

I was so disappointed. I'm still disappointed. This place was supposed to be the best Italian food ever and quite frankly it wasn't. I like the layout of the place, its beautiful and the people that work here are awesome, but my expectations were so high for the food to be so low. I would come back though. I dont know when since there are so many other restaurants to try in LV, but if this was one of the only places open on a certain day then yes count me in. I don't even remember what I ordered. THAT is a bad sign. Their bread was tasty though.

Good pub with a great selection of beer. Food was pretty damn good but our waitress was a little slow to start but on Point after we got our beers. I definitely will come again but maybe not for dinner. Over all, I was happy with my visit.

"Satisfactory experience overall, with a few notable exceptions - specifically, the presence of burnt garlic in the sag paneer was particularly unpleasant and detracted significantly from the dish's overall quality. However, the naan bread was quite good and the mango lassi was exceptional. 

Furthermore, the signage on the entrance regarding the availability of alcoholic beverages was somewhat perplexing, as it gave the impression that the establishment only offered beer and wine, whereas in reality, patrons are permitted to bring their own alcoholic beverages, albeit limited to beer and wine. 

Aesthetically, the interior design and ambiance were pleasing and well-appointed."

We were just in Vegas and saw 4 shows: Mystere, Le Reve, O and Criss Angel-Believe. While theatrically beautiful and some amazing moments, it's definitely not all that it's hyped up to be. Way too expensive to make it worth it and a lot of boring moments. Mystere was by far the best! Maybe not the most theatrically intricate etc, but definitely the most entertaining.

Went to shoku ramn about 3 weeks ago. I ordered the tonkotsu ramen and the potstickers. the potstickers were good they were slightly burnt thats usually how i like it. its a lot crunchier when you bite into them. the ramen...now the ramen needs work the broth was extremely salty and the noodles were way too overcooked. basically when you bit into the noodles it was mushy. i definitely did not like that. i felt like the broth was so overly seasoned i couldnt taste anything but salt. i wouldnt go back to shoku unless i was really hungry and i was extremely close to it. i wouldnt drive out my way to go eat there again.

For a pharmacy on the Strip, the service was terribly slow and all checkers had long lines.  This is on the boring side on the street; there is a Walgreens on the other side.  Once again, no one offered me or asked me about a their ExtraCare discount card.

A truly exceptional and indulgent spa pedicure experience that not only elevated my day but also enhanced my entire week, characterized by a pristine and welcoming ambiance, albeit with a pressing need for upgraded massage chairs, which did not, however, deter me from thoroughly enjoying the treatment and enthusiastically returning for future appointments, irrespective of whether the aforementioned chairs are replaced or not.
A very nice spa pedicure that made my day!  Heck, my week!  They are clean and friendly but need new massage chairs.  Will definitely go back again and again, new chairs or not!

I gotta say, I do not see where the rave reviews for ATS come from. I get the niche vegan group but, aside from the chain being named best carne asada by a local paper, I find the restaurant underwhelming. Don't get me wrong, it isn't bad -- the place is clean, has its own style, and has found success with shops all around town now. But I find the menu limited, the prices high, and the food just okay.\n\nBut when out of towners visit looking for the Best Mexican food, I steer elsewhere.

I am not the biggest fan of fast food ever. But I really like Five Guys and this location is superb! 

They have really yummy fries and they give you so many! Like your bag overflows with the greasy buggers. Say what? Yeah they are really greasy. But good!

The burgers are really quite the bang for your buck too! Not the best burgers in the world but it is fast food not gourmet burgers. Be considerate for what you are eating and enjoy it for what it is. 

The pop machines are radical. You can pretty much have flavoured any beverage you like. 

The staff here is really friendly and that is a plus anywhere you go!

I arrived at this establishment at approximately 8:40 pm on a Monday evening and observed that there were already several gatherings present. Prior to taking a seat, I elected to visit the restroom, whereupon I was confronted by an enormous blattodean creature that appeared to be gazing back at me while I was engaged in the process of urination. Subsequently, my companion and I opted for the all-you-can-eat dinner option priced at $22.95, which included an appetizer identified as "THE SHIT! must try," although its quality was subjective and varied between individuals. Furthermore, we took advantage of the two-for-one Sapporo promotion, which yielded two substantial bottles that sufficed to fill four cups. The sashimi salad was assembled with sashimi, a welcome feature since I tend to avoid consuming excessive amounts of rice at all-you-can-eat establishments, as it often leads to unnecessary satiety. Additionally, I requested salmon, yellowtail, and albacore sashimi, whose freshness was satisfactory, albeit not exceptional, and characterized by thin slices. The sashimi roll was also enjoyable, consisting of various raw fish enveloped in cucumber and devoid of rice. My companion ordered a spicy crab roll, essentially a California roll with spicy crab, along with a monster roll, baked lobster roll, and baked scallop roll, all of which were palatable. It is worth mentioning that the atmosphere of this venue was slightly redolent of Clorox, although the intensity was not overpowering.

I came here around 8:40pm on a monday night and there were around 3 parties already there. I went to the bathroom before sitting down and, low and behold, there was a humungous cockroach staring back at me while I was peeing! Ew

My friend and I both got the AYCE dinner for $22.95 and the appetizer labeled "THE SHIT! must try," which was more shitty than the shit in my opinion. My friend really liked it though. We also got the 2-for-1 sapporo deal, which was pretty awesome because we got 2 huge bottles that was enough to fill 4 cups. 

The sashimi salad was hooked up with sashimi, which is good because I don't like eating a bunch of rice at AYCE places, as it gets me unnecessarily full. I also ordered salmon, yellowtail, and albacore sashimi, which all tasted pretty fresh, but definitely not the best fish. Really thin slices too. The sashimi roll was good too, stuffed with assorted raw fish and rapped in cucumber (no rice). My friend ordered a spicy crab roll (basically a california roll but with spicy crab), monster roll, baked lobster roll, and baked scallop roll, which were all pretty good. 

This place kinda smelled like clorox, but it wasn't anything too overbearing.

I cannot express an excessive amount of dissatisfaction with this establishment, primarily due to the fact that my stay was complimentary, courtesy of my platinum player status. Although the hotel's age and lack of modernity may have contributed to its relatively low level of appeal, I did not find it particularly bothersome during my brief period of occupancy. However, I must admit that certain aspects of the service left much to be desired, specifically the housekeeping staff's tendency to disregard our explicit requests for privacy by entering our room unannounced, even when the 'do not disturb' sign was prominently displayed. This particular incident occurred in the early afternoon, when my companion and I were attempting to take a brief nap, and the sudden intrusion left me feeling understandably uneasy. Furthermore, I must caution potential guests against the inconvenience caused by the live music performances that take place on the strip side of the hotel, which can be heard throughout the day and late into the night. Specifically, the band responsible for these musical offerings possesses a questionable level of talent, and their prolonged sets can prove to be particularly grating on the nerves, especially for those seeking a peaceful rest. In light of these factors, I would advise future visitors to exercise vigilance when booking their accommodations, particularly regarding the chapel hours, as my acquaintance discovered that the third-floor chapel was already closed by the time he attempted to utilize its services. Despite these drawbacks, I do not wish to discourage prospective guests from experiencing the hotel's amenities firsthand.

I seriously can't bitch too much about this place....it was Comp'd for being a Platinum Player. Of course this hotel is older and not as "hip and trendy" but for the little time it's used I honestly didn't mind it.
It was a little creepy though with house keeping...we had out "don't disturb" door hanged outside the door and it was around 3pm we were trying to quick-nap and she didn't even knock and just tried making her way in...I was like "No No Please leave" I was so hungover I couldn't really bitch but yeah total creeper haha

Also if you happen to stay on the strip side with a view HEADS UP!!! 

They have this shitty band that plays from 11am until 2am it's HORRIBLE and on the last day when I wanted to SLEEP I couldn't I seriously almost went to the local grocery store just to buy a few dozens of eggs and throw it at them (I know classy right) 
Anyhow overall not a super bad experience be cautious on their Chapel hours as well my buddy tried to marry some random and the chapel on the 3rd floor was already closed (not sure who lucked out on this one) but anyway Enjoy your stay :D

"Gastronomical indulgences of a rich and savory nature, ardently desired by yours truly, yet hampered by an excessive utilization of a particular staple, specifically the tortilla, which unfortunately diminishes the overall gustatory experience of the salad, rendering it less than satiating; furthermore, the beverage dispensary appears to be inadequately provisioned during the noontide repast, leading to an unfortunate dearth of hydrating options for patrons; lastly, the personnel responsible for facilitating the acquisition of sustenance during this peak period demonstrate commendable proficiency in expediting the process, albeit accompanied by an irksome delay of approximately twenty minutes, which serves only to exacerbate my personal dissatisfaction with the culinary experience as a whole."

Fatty, tasty food.  I wish the salad did not have a huge tortilla to make it filling.

The drink station never seems well stocked at lunch.

The staff does a good job moving people through line at lunch, but I always have a difficult time waiting 20 minutes to order this food.

Hof Kelsten is the latest addition to Mile End's boulangerie scene, and it instantly became recognized as a city-wide contender.  Baker/owner Jeffrey Finkelstein built up a reputation supplying many of Montreal's top restaurants with their bread before opening up to the public.  The approach leans towards Central Europe (caraway rye, rugelach, babka, etc.), but Hof Kelsten bakes some French loaves too (including my favourite Montreal baguette at the moment).  \n\nThey also serve meals (lunch, brunch), but so far I've stuck to the baked goods.  The pastries are generally good, and they're definitely refreshingly different from the kind of fare one tends to find in Montreal's bakery scene, but I've encountered problems with undercooked items from time to time, so now I just focus on their bread.

So many great reviews I had to try.  First try I didn't check and went on a monday and they were closed boo....

I had their regular burger with bacon, eggs, lettuce, tomato, ketchup, mayo....and....drum roll....the Bacon was really tasty.  That was the only thing that really stood out.  The presentation was good too...But the burger itself was pretty bland.  Maybe ive been spoiled with so many gourmet burger joints in california and vegas....but the bachi version was ok.   I didnt try any of their other specialty version as im not too fond of some of the items.

The seating arrangement was nice, i liked the decor, and service was good as well.  Looked liked they may be able to some outdoor seating?  shrugs...perhaps it is too hot in vegas....

I would come again if i was hosting an out of towner who wanted an away from the strip experience...

we ordered 2 versions of the fries...and both were just a ok.  the truffle fries and some other ones with cilantro in it.  

I think they tried to get a bit too creative ... at least for my taste.

An unpretentious, traditional watering hole offering libations, billiards, and a convivial atmosphere for socializing with companions. Unfortunately, the ambiance is somewhat marred by the presence of cigarette smoke, which permeates one's attire upon exiting the establishment. Nevertheless, this venue remains a popular gathering spot for a diverse clientele comprised of gay men of varying ages, body types, and interests, as well as their female counterparts who are fondly referred to as "fag hags." Despite its shortcomings, this bar serves as a suitable precursor to a nightclub visit, owing to its daily drink promotions. Moreover, its vintage charm evokes a sense of nostalgia reminiscent of Old Las Vegas.

An unpretentious, good ole' fashion bar that provides drinks, pool tables, and a place to just socialize with your friends. The only thing missing is a mechanical bull and chicken wings. They blast gay club mixes all night. And it attracts a diverse crowd of chubby lonely gays, twinks, bears, old-timers, and fag hags. Just to refute the idea it's a bear bar. (If you don't know what bear, twink, fag hag is, I'm not telling you. Urbandictionary.com) So it's all inclusive, y''all. They have drink specials on the daily and is a good pre-drink if you're going to the club across the street. However, smoking is permitted and you leave smelling like an ashtray. It does have that old Vegas vintage feel, I guess. But with the lack of options for Las Vegas gays to visit, I can't really complain too much.

"Upon each visit to this establishment, typically during weeknights, I have been assaulted by an intense and pungent odor of regurgitated matter, ostensibly stemming from the previous evening's revelry and debauchery. Following my successful navigation of the unpleasant ambiance, I was greeted by a hostess whose attire seemed to be incongruous with the conventional standards of dress for such an esteemed dining venue. Subsequently, our server, sporting an eccentric bandana-inspired garb, approached our table to take our order in a manner that struck me as peculiar. We opted to commence our culinary journey with the pretzel Gouda fondue appetizer, which, while undeniably delectable and rich in flavor, was perhaps slightly overseasoned with sodium. My dining companion savored the salmon, while I elected to sample the French Dip. Unfortunately, the latter failed to meet my expectations, as the generous application of a mayonnaise-based dressing imbued the presumably tender and juicy roast beef with an unpleasant creamy texture and flavor. Furthermore, the accompanying au jus, reminiscent of a robust French onion soup, did not harmonize well with the sandwich. In conclusion, my impression of this restaurant is that it strives excessively to project an image of trendiness and uniqueness, compromising the quality of its offerings in the process. A rating of 4 for the cuisine and 2 for the atmosphere seems appropriate, considering the inconsistencies in both aspects."

I can't decide if I like this place or not. They have really good happy hour and brunch specials on drinks, but I'm still undecided on the food. I've been here three or four times, and I've tried a variety of their foods...I just don't know. I can't really point out anything that was wrong with it. The first three or four bites are always delicious...but then it just gets boring. It's just the same flavors repeated over and over again. 

I've never experienced good service while I was there either. It wasn't horrible, but it wasn't good. Today, I had to ask the waiter to bring me another iced tea after I had been sipping on empty for a few minutes. He got side tracked once he started waiting on some cute gay guys who came in and never did bring me another drink. 

On the flip side, we went there for happy hour once and they accidentally charged my friend only $0.03 for 2 drinks. When we pointed it out, they said it was their fault so not to worry about it. 

All in all...it's just okay. It will never be my choice as a restaurant, but if someone else wants to go I wouldn't be upset.

I recently had the pleasure of discovering this establishment through the popular review website, Yelp, and decided to partake in a culinary excursion to sample their offerings for dinner. Upon perusing the menu, I opted for the Chow Mein and Thai Tea, anticipating a delectable repast. My expectations were largely met, as the Thai Tea proved to be an absolute delight, boasting an unparalleled flavor that eclipsed its counterparts at other Thai restaurants I have visited. However, my satisfaction was somewhat mitigated by the Chow Mein, which deviated from the conventional style I am accustomed to, possessing a slightly diminished thickness akin to Lo Mein (a broad, flat noodle). Despite this variance, the culinary aspects of the dish were satisfactory, save for an excessive salinity that permeated the dish. The quality of service was adequate, yet lacked a certain je ne sais quoi that would have elevated the overall experience to a truly exceptional level. Notwithstanding these minor drawbacks, I intend to revisit this eatery in the future, perhaps indulging in their Pad Thai, and will most certainly order the Thai Tea again, given its extraordinary quality and proximity to my domicile, situated merely five minutes away.

"An optimal location for novice patrons to familiarize themselves with the intricacies of Thai cuisine, provided they have not had the pleasure of indulging in such gastronomical delights previously, which, admittedly, would be a rather unusual circumstance given the widespread popularity of Thai food. Upon entering the establishment, it becomes apparent that the staff are inclined to steer customers towards partaking in a buffet-style meal, as opposed to selecting individual dishes from the menu. This preference is conveyed with considerable enthusiasm by the waitstaff, to the extent that one might infer that their livelihood is contingent upon the success of the buffet option. Furthermore, a financial analysis of the bill reveals that the cost per person is Â£21, which, when juxtaposed with the quality and quantity of the culinary offerings, does not constitute an unreasonable expenditure, particularly in light of the fact that the buffet provides an excellent opportunity to sample a variety of dishes and thus, enables patrons to make informed decisions regarding future dining experiences."

A great place to cut your teeth if you've never tried Thai before (although I can't imagine many people not having tried something). This place seems to trying to sway you towards a buffet rather than giving you things straight off the menu. My waitress seemed very adamant that we give that a try, almost like her life depended on it.\n\nI understood as soon as I got the bill, \u00a321 a head. The buffet was good, but I certainly didn't eat \u00a321 worth.

Dear Breadfruit,

While I would unhesitatingly confer upon you a rating of four stars if your prices were not exorbitant and prohibitive, I must confess that my ardent admiration for your delectable sweet potato pie and, to a lesser extent, your coffee, impels me to overlook your egregious pricing policies and accord you a modicum of approbation.

Sincerely,
Rachel

"While it may not be the optimal dining establishment, it is by no means the worst. One drawback is that they do not publicize their special offerings, yet they are of satisfactory quality. The prime rib unlimited, which has since been discontinued, was a culinary masterpiece worthy of high praise. Its removal from the menu has led to my reluctance to return. Upon further examination, the cost did not align with the gustatory experience provided. Ultimately, it falls within the same category as Denny's."

"The culinary offerings presented at the midday repast were merely adequate, lacking the gastronomic excellence that one might anticipate from such an establishment, despite a diverse array of options."

I need to per-qualify this rating by saying that I'm rating this off one dish. Unlike other posts here our server was very respectful and nice.  OK, let's get to it. I had the chicken Madeira. I cook a fabulous chicken Madeira but when I go to a classy place such as this I expect to be wowed. The anticipation was great as the build up came from the surroundings of such a modern restaurant with a very balanced darkness which completed the experience with atmosphere lighting.  You certainly felt upscale. Seeing the rest of my party being served certainly had an impact as their orders were very visually appealing. However, when I was served I found their chicken Madeira leaves a lot to be desired. It was definitely  a let down from first sight which unfortunately continued until the last uneventful bite.  The sauce was bland and not seasoned at all and carried none of the tastes you would expect from such a dynamic dish. While the sauce required more flavor for sure, the three chicken pieces I received were so small I almost laugh out loud, but managed to keep it under my breath. The only thing salvageable were the homemade French fries which I'm convinced you can't really mess that up having deep fried many homemade fries myself.  Didn't justify the $17.00 charge.. no way.    Just saying... stay clear of this dish...

"It must be conceded that my initial acquaintance with the Krispy Kreme phenomenon transpired approximately a decade ago in Canada, and I must admit that the ardent assurances of my unwavering fondness for these confectionaries struck me as somewhat dubious. Nonetheless, upon receiving an abundance of said doughnuts from a magnanimous colleague hailing from Edinburgh, I must confess that their delectability was rather impressive. The team's collective enthusiasm for the sugary bounty was palpable, and it became apparent that the Krispy Kreme craze had indeed permeated our workplace in diverse, saccharine, and deep-fried forms. However, despite the munificence of the complimentary pastries and the ensuing euphoria, I cannot help but harbor reservations regarding the necessity of such copious amounts of sugar and grease. Furthermore, I am compelled to ponder whether we have, in some manner, reverted to the early 1990s. Consequently, I shall assign three stars in recognition of their gustatory appeal, but that is the extent of my endorsement."

I have to admit I first came across the Krispy Kreme fuss about a decade ago in Canada and was kind-of put off in principle by the assertiveness of the guarantees that I would LOVE these doughnuts. 

A generous colleague arrived in this week with an enormous amount of doughnuts from Edinburgh's latest purveyor and, yes, they were very nice. The team was quite taken with the gesture and resultant greasy joy. The Krispy Kreme fuss had truly arrived in multifarious, sweet and doughy form. Everyone was entranced.

I have to say though that despite the generosity of the free donuts, etc, and the pleasantness, I just don't see a hole big enough to require filling with so much sugar and grease. 

I also can't help wondering if we're back in the early 90s!

So, 3 stars for good taste. But that's it.

Eh, the server seemed too busy to actually take care of our needs. The food was kind of dry. I ordered the Steak Gorgonzola and the pasta was dry. We also ordered the Pappardelle Pesctore. Didn't look anything like the picture and was very \"fishy\" smelling. The Norther Tour of Italy was OK too. The salad was also lacking in dressing, like it was coming out of the servers pockets!
