The calamari was also bland tasting. We asked for more lemon for the calamari but didn't get it toward the end. The \"new\" Italian style buffalo wings was dry. Why a three, because we are loyal Olive Garden people! We come here once every other month and normally we\nget EXCELLENT FOOD AND SERVICE. Maybe it was an off day?

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."
The text starts off by expressing disappointment with the slow service, which is emphasized by the use of the word "sloooooooooow" to convey the duration of the delay. The writer then describes the cramped waiting area and lack of seating, highlighting the discomfort caused by the limited space.
The writer then describes their meal, starting with the positive aspect of the delicious mussels, which were small and flavorful, accompanied by a tasty white wine sauce. However, they express disappointment with the French fries, which were soggy and not up to their expectations, despite the server's recommendation.
The main course, bouillabaisse, is described as "pretty awesome," with its rich saffron sauce and generous portion of seafood. In contrast, the writer's husband found his brie-stuffed chicken to be merely "OK," indicating a less satisfying dining experience.
The writer concludes by expressing frustration at the lengthy two-hour duration of their meal, which they attribute to the restaurant's lack of staff. They suggest that they might return during the week, but would not consider bringing a group due to the inadequate service. Overall, the review highlights the restaurant's strengths in terms of food quality, while criticizing its shortcomings in terms of service efficiency and staffing.

"My culinary experiences at this establishment have been limited to the wonton soup, which I have had the pleasure of indulging in on multiple occasions. Upon ordering, I request that the noodles be omitted, thereby allowing me to fully appreciate the rich flavors of the broth, which boasts a subtle sweetness and an aroma that is simply captivating. The dumplings, too, are quite impressive, with their delicate texture and savory filling. While I cannot attest to the quality of the other menu items, as I have not had the opportunity to sample them, I can confidently assert that the wonton soup is truly exceptional. In fact, it has become a staple of my dining repertoire, and I would highly recommend it to anyone seeking a satisfying and delectable meal. Additionally, I must mention that the Crown Bakery, located upstairs from this restaurant, is also worth visiting, as it offers an array of delightful pastries and baked goods that are sure to satisfy one's sweet tooth."

We had the pleasure of indulging in a delectable culinary escapade, yet the gastronomical offerings were merely satisfactory. Nonetheless, the establishment presented an array of enticing mixed drinks at a discounted price point during the hours of 3-6 pm, which we found to be quite appealing. It is our sincere desire that we had opted for an earlier dining time, as it would have enabled us to partake in the full scope of epicurean delights available.
We had a great dining experience, however the food was just average. Great cocktail specials from 3-6pm! Wish we would have gone for an earlier dinner.

This was my first time here. We sat in the bar and caught the tail end of happy hour. 
Apparently that have complementary hors d'oeuvres, although I did not have any. 
We had a few cocktails and ordered some Salmon and Yellow tail sashimi and nigri. I love good salmon and I must say their salmon is pretty good. The Yellow tail sashimi was cut too thick for my liking. 
My biggest complaint was the smell of the restaurant. It smelled like a mix of disinfectant and cheap cologne. It was really strong and made me a little sick to my stomach...

Golden Phoenix is the kind of place you visit when you want a decent, inexpensive lunch. The place is rarely full during the week, especially if you arrive closer to 11am, so be prepared to eat your meal while the (slightly creepy) waitstaff sits at a nearby empty table and watches you eat.  The food is nothing spectacular, but it's decent quality, flavorful (although \"very, very spicy\" is really closer to \"my tongue has a slight tingle\"), and dirt cheap.  Today I paid $16 and change before tip for myself and my friend, including soft drinks.  I'll keep coming back for the reasons I listed plus its close proximity to my office.  You can't beat a good deal!

I have made a couple visits over the years (I don't live in Champaign). Located along a major thoroughfare for the city and near campustown. The donuts are pretty good. Quick service. However, not all the donuts are in stock at a given time. I was just there and didn't even see glazed yeast donuts (the classic).- just glazed cake and the glazed minis. I appreciate having someplace to grab a snack with early morning Black Friday shopping.

"If you seek an establishment that offers a tangible representation of southern hospitality amidst the extravagant indulgences synonymous with Las Vegas, then this venue is worth considering. Located within the Treasure Island Hotel, this particular destination boasts an impressive array of amenities designed to cater to patrons who appreciate a more laid-back atmosphere reminiscent of the Deep South. Featuring a spacious dance floor illuminated by vibrant lights, the ambiance is further enhanced by the sounds of country music that permeate the space, creating an environment ideal for enthusiasts of line dancing and two-stepping. Moreover, for those who harbor a sense of adventure, there is a mechanical bull available for riders to test their mettle. However, be cognizant of the proficient skills exhibited by a specific blonde cowgirl, whose prowess on the bull may inspire awe in onlookers. Although the kitchen had closed by the time of our visit, the bartenders remained accommodating and friendly, ensuring that drinks were served promptly despite the modest crowd. Notably, the demographic comprising the majority of patrons appeared to be older, ranging from their late thirties to forties, although this did not detract from the enjoyment experienced by our group, which included ardent country music devotees."

"Indulged in a delectable repast at this eatery and discovered it to be a satisfying and economical experience. Opted for an albacore sandwich, featuring a tantalizing tuna salad, and paired it with the pecan dijon salad, savoring the harmonious blend of flavors and textures in a 1/2 and 1/2 portion for a mere $7 plus. The salad presented itself as a warm compote, boasting an assortment of chopped pecans, succulent chicken, crunchy vegetables, and a tangy dijon cream dressing that elevated the dish to new heights. Meanwhile, my companion selected an egg white veggie omelet, skillfully tailoring a meal to accommodate her strict dietary requirements."

Had lunch here and found it to be tasty and a good value.  I chose an albacore sandwich (tuna salad) and the pecan dijon salad for the 1/2 and 1/2 for $7+.  The salad was more like a warm compote made of chopped pecans, chicken, crunchy veg and a dijon cream dressing.  \nFriend chose an egg white veggie omelet and was able to make up a meal to fit her stringent diet.

"Fairly satisfactory, but I can conjure up alternative Mexican establishments that I might favor over this one. The hospitality at this venue was ATTENTIVE, yet somewhat unsystematic. I solicited three separate individuals to provide hydration for my companion and myself (we were the final members of our gathering to arrive), and we ultimately received a solitary water vessel. Nonetheless, they were prompt in delivering replenishments of triangular tortilla chips and savory dip, and they regularly checked in on us throughout the duration of the meal. The water vessels may have been an isolated occurrence, considering the large number of patrons and the fact that we didn't encounter any further difficulties with the service. \nThe culinary offerings were adequate, albeit slightly piquant for my taste buds. Indeed, I am aware that it is Mexican cuisine and that I possess a relatively low tolerance for spicy fare. Nevertheless, none of my dining companions appeared to be troubled, so it is worth considering that perspective. It did seem to sit somewhat lighter in my stomach compared to the majority of Mexican dishes, which was a welcome aspect. The margaritas were potent and a pitcher sufficed for the four of us."

"Satisfactory for a rapid Asian-inspired culinary experience. Maintained establishment with amiable personnel. A casual, unpretentious eatery that, while not exceptional, does not warrant criticism. Efficient, affordable, and of passable quality."
Good enough for fast asian style food. Clean place with friendly staff. what the heck it is what it is and it is not horrible by any means. Fast, convenient, good price, and decent.

Surprising there was no assembly required, no special tools and no missing parts to our meal. However it also lacked the value I would have expected from such a venue.

Just to be clear this is the "fancy" upstairs cafe not the food stand down stairs.

The selection is wider, including wraps, salads soups, and a hot tray line of what I assume are sweetish classics. 

My wife had a veggie wrap, that was almost a chicken wrap as the shelves and labels were in disarray. It was neither great nor terrible at $4 it was acceptable.

The smoked fish plate for $7 was quite good, creamy horseradish sauce and mixed greens with a few beans accompanied the well smoked fish. 

The nice touch was the vegan sweet potato soup.  Flash your ikea family card for some free stuff and you have a meal. at $14 for the two of us it was not pricey but we were eating in a self service furniture store. 

If you are looking for some mild food in a kid friendly environment with great views of furniture this may be your spot.

Other than the lack of an apostrophe there's very little wrong with this establishment  service was good (although the thought that we might have wanted food after having longer to study the menu whilst our teas were being prepared seemed to get lost somewhere), decor is pleasant (some very comfy chairs to stretch out in) and it benefits massively from the large expanse of window facing onto Frederick Street.\nFood and drink-wise there is nothing on the menu that you wouldn't expect from a cafe of this kind so if you're after a surprise or a new taste sensation you'll probably be out of luck but, whilst not breaking any records, they do what they do well.\nHaving not checked out the toilets on this visit (or the food for that matter) I'm hedging at 3 stars but would expect on current evidence that either of those things would easily push it to 4 the next time I pop in.

I went here today feeling a bit meh. I was going to meet some clients, and they had chosen it - and I kept thinking of all the other groovy places in the area that we could have gone to instead. Cafe Grande just seems a bit old school, and the menu was all burgers and paninis...

But, in fact, i did have a pretty good lunch. The fishcake was small but tasty, with chips and a little salad - and the cheeseplate afterwards was good, with a choice of Scottish cheeses. Various desserts round the table looked decent too - the banoffee pie got a rave review.

Other lunch choices weren't quite as good - the soup and sandwich in particular seemed a bit dull and "like something you'd make at home", while the beanburger arrived looking forlorn on a plain bun.

So - a nice enough lunch if you're in the area, but I wouldn't go out of my way.

In my relentless pursuit of gluten-free culinary delights, I serendipitously encountered Nello's, a restaurant that, despite having limited gluten-free options, offered an unparalleled dining experience, showcasing their commitment to catering to the diverse dietary needs of their clientele. Upon perusing their menu, I opted for a ham-pineapple pizza, which, much to my delight, proved to be an inspired choice, as the flavors melded together in perfect harmony, the gluten-free dough serving as a worthy canvas for the savory toppings. Furthermore, I was impressed by Nello's dedication to transparency, evident in their provision of a comprehensive list of ingredients and toppings, thereby enabling patrons to make informed choices and avoid potential allergens or dietary restrictions. The exceptional service I received during my visit further enhanced my overall satisfaction, as the friendly and attentive staff ensured that my dining experience was nothing short of exceptional. While it is worth noting that Nello's may not cater exclusively to those with gluten intolerance or sensitivity, their willingness to accommodate such dietary requirements is undoubtedly commendable, making them an excellent choice for those seeking a welcoming and inclusive dining environment, where the absence of lofty expectations allows for an authentic and enjoyable culinary encounter.

The eyebrow threading used to be $8, but recently raised to $10--the typical price for threading around LV.  She does a good job not taking too much off and maintaining the natural shape of your brow.\n\nFacials are good here too, but they don't stay true to their coupon deals:  The usual facial is 1 hour full price.  My mom got a coupon for 50% off, but instead got 50% off of the time!  30 minutes for half the price = NO 50% DISCOUNT

"As I continue to gaze towards the right-hand side of my visual field, I have recently observed a message that advocates for the superiority of a particular eatery's poultry dishes over those offered by Roscoe's. However, I must respectfully disagree with such a claim, as my personal experiences with Roscoe's have led me to conclude that their chicken is, in fact, an addictive substance that rivals the potency of crack cocaine. While Lolo's may boast an aesthetically pleasing atmosphere complete with vibrant decor and large containers of Kool-Aid, their chicken and waffles fail to measure up to the lofty standards set by Roscoe's. Although the breading on Lolo's chicken is noticeably dry and distinct from Roscoe's, the waffles and accompanying syrup are undeniably delectable. In order to elevate their chicken to the level of Roscoe's, Lolo's would need to significantly revamp their recipe. Despite this, I shall return to Lolo's, as it offers a superior alternative to fast food fowl, even if it cannot compare to the gustatory nirvana that is Roscoe's."

Just okay.  Service was good.  Beer was cold.  I'd prefer a good IPA though, which they didn't have.  

Food was just average.  Standard chicken wings.  Sandwich bread was a little stale, fries not very crisp.  Ho hum.  

Nice decor inside, and lots of televisions, so it's a good spot for a beer and a ballgame.  Wood smoke from the pizza oven creates a great aroma, so maybe a pizza is the way to go next time.

I unfortunately fell into the trap pf ordering chips and salsa first. Way too much food. But other than that, it was exactly what you would expect from a Mexican place. Big serves, as often happens in Mexican, and fresh ingredients. Nothing earth-shattering but reasonably priced. I would go back, next time I am in the area and in the mood for Mexican.

"My mother and I visited this establishment due to her unrelenting craving for sweets. Upon inquiring about the presence of caffeine in the coffee-flavored gelato, the young lady behind the counter responded with a dismissive attitude, stating that she was not aware of its contents as she did not participate in its preparation. We were taken aback by her response but decided to continue with our order, requesting a dairy-free option. The same individual demonstrated a lack of knowledge regarding the ingredients of their products, claiming that she did not possess the information we sought. Perplexed by her responses, my mother opted to seek a recommendation for a complementary flavor to pair with chocolate. Unfortunately, the employee's ignorance persisted, as she admitted that she did not consume the product and thus could not offer any insight. Despite the subpar customer service, the quality of the gelato was impressive, and the prices were reasonable. The banana flavor, in particular, was quite satisfying."

The food was average and everything is overpriced. My friend and I were playing video poker the whole time yet only 1 drink was comped. Kinda disappointed because I was hoping to find a good hole-in-the-wall Mexican joint with video poker.

"It is utterly perplexing that individuals who have ostensibly partaken in a culinary excursion to Las Vegas would lavish such effusive praise upon a buffet that patently fails to deliver an adequate gastronomical experience, leading one to wonder whether said individuals have indeed sampled the myriad of other superior buffets available in the city. The allocation of a mere quarter of the buffet's offerings to bread, a staple that is hardly worthy of such prominence, is particularly vexing, especially considering the exorbitant cost of $40 per person. Furthermore, the quality of the fare is not commensurate with the price, as the standout dish, a California roll, relies solely on the utilization of authentic crab meat to salvage its flavor. The service, while satisfactory, is rendered inconsequential by the fact that it is only accessible to those seated at the bar. One must ponder what distinguishing characteristics this buffet possesses that warrant such lofty acclaim, as prime rib, cold shrimp, and crab are ubiquitous items offered by every buffet in Las Vegas, and certainly not at such an extortionate price. In contrast, the Rio Carnival World Buffet, Rio Seafood Buffet, and Wynn Buffet are infinitely superior options."

"It is utterly astounding that individuals actually consume sustenance within these premises, considering the numerous occasions I have visited this establishment have been characterized by varying levels of inebriation, ranging from a moderate degree of intoxication to a state of complete incapacitation. It appears that neither myself nor my associates prioritize dining as the primary purpose of our visits, as our primary focus lies in indulging in potent beverages. Notwithstanding, the happy hour menu boasts an impressive array of appetizers, encompassing conventional items such as California rolls and gyoza, as well as more distinctive offerings including seafood dynamite and coconut shrimp skewers. Nonetheless, it is in the realm of alcoholic beverages that this establishment truly excels, offering special deals that are unparalleled in their generosity and variety. While nourishment may be requested when the need arises, coinciding with a state of inebriation, it matters little whether the quality of the culinary offerings falls short of expectations, much like the way in which beer goggles can render an individual impervious to the aesthetic shortcomings of a potential romantic interest. Despite this, I cannot bring myself to assign a completely negative rating to this establishment due to the abundance of fond memories I have formed here, albeit occasionally hazy and fragmented."

"My spouse and I visited this establishment in the company of acquaintances, having previously explored the surrounding area of Luxor together. Upon arriving at the restaurant, we were immediately struck by the vast array of culinary options available on the menu. Indeed, the sheer diversity of choices proved somewhat overwhelming, making it challenging for us to arrive at a decision regarding our meals. Nonetheless, we were unanimous in our satisfaction with the food, which we deemed to be of exceptional quality, warranting a rating of five stars. Unfortunately, the same cannot be said of the service we received, which left much to be desired. Specifically, our server's curt response to my inquiry regarding the virgin margaritas was utterly unprofessional and bordered on disdain. Had I been aware of the manner in which he had addressed the previous patron, I would have refrained from posing the question altogether. Furthermore, the server's demeanor was generally unfriendly and conveyed a sense of reluctance to be present at the establishment. This unfortunate state of affairs significantly impacted our dining experience, thereby precluding me from providing an unequivocally positive appraisal of the restaurant. In essence, had the service been more satisfactory, I would have been far more inclined to offer a glowing endorsement, rather than a mere 'okay' assessment."

a good tho not great buffet. peel n eat shrimp and the dessert variety were the standouts. prime rib not very good, but oh they do get an extra star for the tequila-infused watermelon, you could get drunk off that stuff. also rice krispy pops & candy apples. i would have liked to see more salad variety to at least create the illiusion that I was eating healthy but i did like that there was a wide array of breakfast options even at 2 pm. I would probably go back but then Aria and Paris have much better choices on their buffets, I would probably chose those over Wynn. Sorry Steve!

AAAAAA...Excalibur is in a great location.....We checked in on a Saturday and we had a rooom in the newly remodeled tower 2. So we get to our room and we notice something funny the door isnt shut all the way, We just push our door open and the room is all clean and ready to go but apparently something is wrong with the door and it won't shut all the way.So we call and they say we'll be moving next door. They bring the keys up and everythings all good , room was nice remodeled flat screen nice beds etc......But what do you know the next day the same thing happens with the door in our room it wont shut all the way. What a joke we call and the send someone up to fix it.Pool area is nice, windy  as hell why we were there. Walls are paper thin could hear the tramps next door discussing certain things. Check out time is 11 am which sucks when youve been out getting intoxicated the night before. We called down and they extended our checkout till 12...so generous ......so to sum it up stay here if you want some place cheap in a good loacation with ok rooms.

This buffet aligns itself more closely with the likes of Golden Corral and Hometown Buffet, rather than the more upscale offerings found on the Strip. We opted to partake in the brunch selection, which boasted an array of de rigueur items such as a salad bar, carving station, dessert bar, pizza, pasta, corn, mashed potatoes, roasted potatoes, green beans, fish dishes, sushi, and a smattering of Asian-inspired dishes, as well as an assortment of breads. While the menu may not have been particularly inventive or inspired, it did provide a satisfying and filling experience for a reasonable price, especially when compared to other establishments in the area. Furthermore, the wait time was minimal, making it an accessible option for those seeking a hearty meal without the burden of an extended delay. However, aficionados of fine cuisine may wish to explore alternative dining options.

"The waitress exhibited a remarkable level of cordiality and proficiency in her customer service, which greatly enhanced our dining experience.  The steak boxty, a traditional Irish dish consisting of a thinly sliced steak wrapped in a boxty pancake, was not only delectable but also generously portioned, thereby rendering it a superlative value for the price.  Moreover, the pairing of this culinary delight with a frothy pint of Harp, an iconic Irish lager, proved to be an inspired choice that complemented the flavors of both the food and the beverage in a most harmonious manner."

I think Abuelos is very good for a chain Mexican food restaurant. They are pretty consistent with nice servers and decent food. I remember a time when there were huge lines out the door and hour long waits, but maybe that was in spring training season because the last time I visited, we got right in with a party of 6. I will go there again with out of town guests because they seem to love it but i prefer to frequent local establishments if I can.

I haven't had a chance to eat the food yet but I came on a night where there was a frat-party...I was a little skeptical about the age of the kids allowed in, during the frat party they did allow people who were underage in, and those who were of age wore wristbands...however that really didn't seem to stop kids from drinking; remove that and it was a fun atmosphere. They have beer pong, and the drinks are good. The design is really fun and alternative and my husband and I enjoyed watching the music videos, dancing around and having a few drinks.

Good for a hangover.  It's a little loud however.  I've thrown up in the bathroom many times, not due to the food.\n\nThe fries are thin and kind of disappointing.  The food is good.  Not spectacular. It's decent.  The specialty drinks are strong, and that's a plus.

I opted to visit this establishment for a haircut due to its proximity to my location and my urgent need for a trim.  I customarily request a conventional men's scissor cut, which is readily available at numerous salons, thus, I did not anticipate any significant divergence in the quality of service.  Upon entering the premises, I was greeted by a welcoming atmosphere and an accommodating staff, which facilitated a seamless and expedited process.  I was attended to promptly, and the stylist demonstrated a proficient and meticulous approach to her craft, ensuring a satisfactory outcome.  While the price point of $20 for a standard men's haircut may be slightly elevated in comparison to neighboring establishments, the value lies in the attentive and skilled service provided, rendering it a reasonable and worthwhile investment for an above-average hairdo.

"It is imperative that I initiate my discourse by highlighting the restaurant's culinary proficiency, as the gastronomical offerings at this establishment are indeed exceptional. My numerous visits have consistently confirmed the superior quality of the bruschetta, which is unparalleled in its flavor and texture. However, it is unfortunate that the service at this venue falls short of meeting expectations, particularly during peak hours. On a recent Friday evening visit, despite the presence of three bartenders and a relatively empty bar, obtaining assistance proved to be a formidable challenge. It appeared that the bartenders were more engrossed in their own conversations than attending to patrons' needs, as they neglected to offer refreshments and removed empty glasses without replacement. Indeed, it required nearly ten minutes of patient waiting to finally capture the bartender's attention and secure an additional glass of wine or beer. Notwithstanding the aforementioned issues, the restaurant's appeal lies in its impressive happy hour offerings, featuring $5 glasses of wine, which serves as a motivating factor for our repeated visits. In light of the subpar service encountered, we shall endeavor to explore the alternative location, in hopes of encountering a more satisfactory dining experience."

My assessment is largely consistent with the general consensus expressed by others.

Good aspects include:

* The culinary offerings (once procured) were undoubtedly impressive, particularly the lobster and corn, which elicited a profoundly enthusiastic response. Additionally, the beverage named in honor of nobility, although forgotten, was indeed commendable.

* The menu boasted an array of diverse options, providing ample opportunities for exploration and discovery.

* The beverages, both alcoholic and non-alcoholic, were meticulously crafted and presented in abundance, complemented by an assortment of innovative weekly specials.

Conversely, the following drawbacks were observed:

* The quality of service was subpar, characterized by an excessive number of personnel clad in black attire, alongside two hostesses, which seemed disproportionate to the needs of the establishment. Moreover, the bartender demonstrated remarkable dedication to their duties, reminiscent of the cinematic portrayal of someone possessing exceptional skill or aptitude. However, management would benefit from addressing this discrepancy within the staff.

In conclusion, the eatery offered delectable cuisine, superlative drinks, yet was marred by deficient service.

Below are the daily drink specials:

Margarita Monday: Enjoy $3 off specialty margaritas from 7 p.m. until closing time.

Guys Night Out Tuesday: Relish 1/2 off whiskey, bourbon, and scotch from 7 p.m. until closing time.

Paper Bag Beer Special Wednesday: Savor a randomly selected beer encased in a paper bag for a mere $1 from 7 p.m. until closing time.

Ladies Night Thursday: Indulge in $3 off glasses of wine and $3 360 vodka drinks from 7 p.m. until closing time.

Fireball Friday: Partake in $2 shots of Fireball from 7 p.m. until closing time.

$10 Mimosa Carafes Saturday: Obtain a mimosa carafe for $10 between the hours of 11 a.m. and 3 p.m.

$10 Bloody Mary Carafes Sunday: Acquire a bloody mary carafe for $10 between the hours of 11 a.m. and 3 p.m.
"A culinary establishment offering authentic Italian cuisine in a pleasant ambiance with generous servings at an affordable cost, strategically positioned near the central plaza."

"Beneficial hospitality, somewhat antiquated accommodations, yet the cost-effective nature of the establishment renders it a profitable venture for families, particularly those accompanied by juveniles, who can capitalize on the convenience of connecting rooms."

The gastronomical experience associated with the consumption of this particular burger does not, in any way, shape or form, qualify as optimal, let alone satisfactory; rather, it falls short of expectations due to various deficiencies, one of which pertains to the cramped and congested nature of the area surrounding the beverage dispenser, rendering it arduous for individuals to navigate through said space, thereby creating an unpleasant atmosphere that detracts from the overall enjoyment of the culinary offering.

"Personnel exhibiting cordial demeanors and a predominantly youthful clientele characterize the establishment, with a palpable sense of urgency permeating the atmosphere, as though patrons are eager to engage in romantic or sexual liaisons. However, the subterranean section of the venue appears somewhat uninspired, lacking the vivacity and pizzazz that would encourage conviviality among the patronage. A designated dance area, devoid of any actual dancing, exists within this space, its absence of a mirrored sphere, illumination, or laser beams contributing to an overall dearth of ambiance. If the proprietors desire to foster an environment conducive to merriment and movement, they might consider investing in elements that would enhance the experience, such as suitable lighting and perhaps even a DJ spinning melodies that might entice revelers to sway in unison."

Champaign is a great restaurant city, but the options for Middle Eastern food are rather limited, so I'm glad that Holy Land Grill exists.  It isn't the best Middle Eastern food I've ever had, but it's pretty good.  I was there yesterday and had the falafel and a Greek salad and enjoyed both.  Service was attentive and friendly, which was a welcome change after the last few times we'd been there.  They started our meal with complimentary bottles of water, which seemed odd and wasteful (but I suppose washing water glasses wastes resources, too.)  They also serve Mexican Coca-Cola, which was an interesting change of pace.  Dessert was baklava-very good but came topped with a simple syrup that didn't do much for it.  Serving the baklava plain or with a drizzle of honey would have been better.  One more thing;  I know I'm always complaining about loud music in restaurants, but there was no music at all at Holy Land. Some soft Middle Eastern music would have been a nice touch.  All in all, I enjoyed my meal at Holy Land and plan to return soon.

The Golden Nugget buffet is under construction so we were able to use the buy-one-get-one-free coupons at Carson Street Cafe.  Sweet.

As a Golden Nugget guest, I loved that the Carson Street Cafe was located so close to the elevators.  After a long day walking up and down the Strip, it was nice to be able to grab a bite to eat and then head back to the room.

The food is decent.  I would recommend sticking to the basics.  My BLT was fine and the chicken in the Caesar salad was really tender and tasty.

The customer service varied from person to person but it did seem to be on the slow side overall.

A rather refreshing venue offering beverages and edibles, where patrons may opt to settle transactions using physical currency to circumvent potential embarrassment. However, it is not advisable to visit this establishment with expectations of exceptional clientele service.

Update: An excess of an excellent entity can transform into a detrimental factor. For a span of sixty days, we visited Big View with a frequency of twice a week. The quality of the culinary offerings and hospitality appeared to diminish during the festive season, and shortly after Christmas, we purchased cookies from their bakery that were not only stale but also displayed evident signs of aging. As a result, we have refrained from patronizing the establishment in the new year.

Previous Review: My spouse and I partake in culinary indulgences at Big View with a regularity of approximately once per week. We have sampled a considerable number of items on the menu, and each dish has consistently demonstrated exceptional taste. Breakfast plates, French toast, pancakes, shrimp and grits, chicken souvlaki, spinach pastry, Greek salad, and crab cakes have all contributed to our gastronomical satisfaction. Furthermore, we hold their bakery in high esteem. The servers generally exhibit cordial behavior and maintain attentive attention to detail. However, we advise against consuming meals at the bar while facing the kitchen due to the potential for chaos. Nonetheless, we wholeheartedly endorse enjoying a dining experience at Big View. Indeed, we strongly advocate for its recommendation.

This location was right across from the campus theater, and we were in the area for a show, so this was definitely a convenient spot.  We walked in and were seated right away and our drink orders were taken really quickly too.

It was a little rough in the middle of after drink orders, since it took about 15 minutes after that to have our orders taken and to get our drinks. The hostess ended up stopping by our table to take the order - which we guess was due to the fact that our waitress probably was a little overwhelmed. 

The food came out about 15 minutes after ordering and we had to eat quickly to ensure we didn't miss our show time. I had the Turkey Dinner and he had one of the pancake combos (the white chocolate raspberry I believe was the name). My turkey dinner was just okay.  The turkey was cut into small pieces, and definitely wasn't the long cut strips like it was in the picture on the menu (but it never is right?).  His pancakes were a good pick - the Egg Nog pancakes looked like they would have been a good pick, too!

I paid our ticket as soon as I was done eating so that we could take off as soon as my fiancee was done.  

Overall: B-
Service was good.  Food was okay - definitely an "A-OK" visit.

"I had the privilege of partaking in a Bachelorette Party at the illustrious W hotel last night, and, admittedly, I am not accustomed to frequenting such high-end establishments in Scottsdale; thus, the exorbitant price of the beverages served at the bar came as a considerable surprise to me. Specifically, the cost of a single drink was a staggering $16, which, needless to say, prompted me to opt for water instead. 

The atmosphere of the lounge was quite vibrant, with an array of fascinating individuals, including a young woman who captured my attention with her striking attire, specifically, a diminutive turquoise bikini, which, although eye-catching, struck me as somewhat incongruous given the indoor setting and lack of sunlight. Nonetheless, she seemed to be enjoying herself immensely. 

The waiting staff, comprising attractive females clad in tight-fitting black dresses, exhibited exceptional cordiality and accommodation, efficiently separating the tab into smaller portions for our sizable gathering. 

In conclusion, while the W unquestionably offers an excellent venue for indulging in extravagant spending and observing the peculiarities of the Scottsdale crowd, it does not particularly align with my personal preferences."

I am subtracting two stars here based on an experience I had this week.  Was here for drinks on a Tuesday night, the place wasnt packed so my friend and I sat at the bar.  There were two bartenders but obviously their friends were at the bar and they had zero interest in serving anyone else.  It took 15 minutes to get the menu, the bartenders could not have been ruder!!!  When i asked for a beer they didnt have she threw the beer list at me and didnt come back for another 15 minutes.  It was probably some of the worst service I have seen in Charlotte!  Take some midol beotch!!!

We came down to the buffet since it was the closest place to get some breakfast food on a Sunday morning. It was pretty good for taking the elevator down and have a choice of just about any kind of food you want. I don't think you can expect lobster and crab at 11:00am in the morning, but you will get some things like prime rib and other nice cuts of meat. \n\nIf you're not gambling then you're probably going to pay full price at like $25 or more. Coming from Chicago this is a pretty steep price. You're only in Vegas so much, so why not right? I would probably go back here again if I could eat twice as much or if I had a huge amount of comps. If you got money to blow, you're really hungry and don't want to go far from the hotel, then you can get away with eating here and being happy about it.

The Yard House, for me anyway, is strictly a happy hour stop.  The beer selection is first rate with too many on tap to count.  The food specials during HH are great.  The entrees are ok but if you're in this neighborhood you have dozens of better options.

The Big Dogs on Sierra was closed, we always went there when we were in town at least twice for the beer and Nachos so we trekked over to the Draft house on Rancho.  Nachos were a disappointment compared to what we used to get.  The beer is good but we were sadly disappointed in our favorite nachos.

Close to my house so I like to go get their vegetarian or supreme pizza and enjoy a pitcher of cold beer with wings while watching sports on their numerous tvs.  The place has gotten a little pricier with the food quality not staying as good as it was, but I like the atmosphere, service and take out.  Big selection of pizzas available and this is what you come here for.  The other foods are just for those who want variety.

Love Grand Lux. Corned beef hash is excellent.  

One big problem during his visit was the Mrs found a hair in her fries. Waiter and manager handled it properly tho. Took it off our check and profusely apologized. 

Desserts r fantastic.

"The reality is such that the hospitality extended by Tea Lite's staff is truly commendable, as they exhibit remarkable kindness and efficiency in serving patrons, and the culinary offerings are both wholesome and promptly prepared. Furthermore, the cost-to-quality ratio is quite favorable, making it an appealing choice for a nourishing repast. However, my reservation concerning their rating stems from the fact that their menu selections appear to be overly predictable and lacking in boldness, which may be attributed to the eatery's concentration on providing expedited lunches and a simplified menu. Specifically, the pho broth is conspicuously absent of tripe or tendon, and no alternative exists to incorporate these elements should a patron desire a more adventurous dining experience. While various seasoning options are available, they fail to provide the depth of flavor customarily associated with Vietnamese cuisine. It is conceivable that this dearth of variety stems from Tea Lite's emphasis on catering to the local demographic, yet I cannot help but feel a sense of disappointment when comparing it to its competitor in the vicinity. Despite this, I wholeheartedly endorse paying a visit to Tea Lite and expressing gratitude for their exceptional service, all the while politely requesting that certain ingredients be included in their phá»?so that, in the future, they might reassess their menu and warrant a higher rating."

I went here based on a couple reviews and I was expecting something fabulous.  The food was really good! Four stars for the food but two for the service equals a three star review.  What went wrong?  It took about 45 min's for a couple of pita sandwiches and we were the only ones there, and when the order came it was wrong!  My friend had to get his to go while I ate mine.\n\nDon't get me wrong the food is really good and I would probably go back but come on people please get the order right, and speed up the service a little! Maybe somebody should tell them or leave a Yelp card to let them know that we love the food, but the service needs to be improved!

Ive been here a handful of times and it is always packed and a good time for me.  We had a VIP table which always helps getting in and enjoying the time spent there. The DJ music was good to dance to, but the dance area is tight. They offer a platform pole where several women get up and dance on so that is fun to watch. This time the large private back room area was closed....renovations?! The private area last time is separated from the main area and offers private tables and dance areas for larger groups and a separate DJ.  Not a bad place to come with a group, but not so great for just a couple guys. There are better options in Vegas.

"I procured the onion and mushroom poutine, in addition to a Montreal smoke meat sandwich.  The latter was of superior quality; the meat was warm and succulent, which greatly enhanced its flavor.  However, the former was merely average, as I failed to specify any additional meaty components to augment the dish's flavor profile.  Although, I did appreciate the onion and mushroom elements, I couldn't help but ruminate on the potential for greater culinary satisfaction. \n\nIt is worth mentioning that, due to my hasty nature, I inadvertently under-tipped.  The server inquired as to whether the service was subpar, but in reality, it was neither exceptional nor deficient.  It so happens that I visited the establishment during its opening hours on a Saturday morning, thus my lack of attentiveness and subsequent desire to offer a fixed amount of $30 following a $26 meal seemed somewhat parsimonious.  Perhaps I am indeed frugal.  Prior to my entrance, my sibling and I attempted to ascertain the price of their poutine, only to be met with vociferous declarations that the eatery was not yet open for business.  Hence, while the edibles were delectable, the service left much to be desired.  Nonetheless, I opted to provide them with another opportunity."

One of the most pleasant and aesthetically pleasing accommodations I have had the privilege of occupying, this particular room boasted an unparalleled vantage point that afforded breathtaking panoramic views of the surrounding environs, with nary a trace of hyperbole or exaggeration in my assertion that it was situated in close proximity to the renowned Miracle Mile Shops, an upscale retail destination that offered an array of exclusive boutiques and specialty stores catering to discerning clientele with refined tastes and preferences.

"I appreciate the expansive nature of this establishment, which offers a diverse array of seating arrangements tailored to accommodate various preferences and requirements. Its proximity to the freeway renders it an ideal venue for gatherings among business associates, as well as casual meetups between individuals engaged in academic pursuits, such as myself, who have benefited from the convenient setting for tutorial sessions. Consistency in the quality of beverages, specifically coffee and tea, is a notable aspect of this location. Complimentary Wi-Fi access is also available, although patrons are advised to request the relevant password upon ordering their drinks. Unfortunately, a single star has been deducted due to the prevalence of untidy tables and littered floors within the premises."
Good drink selection with some interesting cocktails and was pretty empty when I was there in the afternoon. I didn't try any food but it looked pretty good.

3.5 stars.

Like others say, it's better than airline lounges in US in terms of food and beverage offering. Cookies, cheese, some vegetable/hummus/cold pasta salad, cous cous and spring rolls and mini quiche. And full bar with wine, liquors and beverage. Also soup...

Sitting area can get crowded and it's closed after morning around 10:30 am and re-open at 2:30 pm.  Well.. better than sitting in the hallway..
The calamari was fantastic. The tacos were nice but there are better ones around. Our server was very funny and definitely enhanced the experience. Worth checking out.

It was an enjoyable experience, reminiscent of the renowned television show, The Amazing Race, albeit with a few caveats. Specifically, I had anticipated a greater emphasis on intellectual puzzles that could not be readily solved through the utilization of modern technology, such as smartphones. Additionally, physical fitness and swiftness were essential components of the competition, as the victors were required to sprint to the finish line in order to emerge triumphant. Notably, the organizers neglected to present the winners with their promised $100 gift certificates; however, upon being apprised of this oversight, the staff assured us that they would mail them to the recipients at a later date.

"A coterie of four individuals partook in a morning repast, whereupon two members of our group opted for the $5.99 steak and egg special, which encompassed a delectable array of house-fried potatoes and toast, while the remaining duo selected the veggie omelet, an edible masterpiece replete with an abundance of fresh vegetables, smothered in a layer of melted cheese, accompanied by potatoes and toast. Our culinary excursion concluded with a pecuniary outlay of less than $35, inclusive of gratuity and coffee. The quality of service we received was superlative, as our servers exhibited unwavering friendliness and provided copious refills of water and coffee. Encouraged by our previous day's experience, we revisited the establishment for an evening meal, during which two of us indulged in the penne al forno, a dish whose rich creaminess was nothing short of tantalizing. The remaining pair opted for burgers, the quality of which elicited no complaints whatsoever. The crowning glory of our gastronomical adventure lay in the $2.25 20 oz. beers, expertly brewed on the premises. Both the Hefe and Light varieties possessed an unparalleled smoothness, contributing to an overall sense of satisfaction. Our financial investment for five beers and four main courses tallied $45, an eminently reasonable sum given the proximity of the venue to the renowned Las Vegas Strip."

It's a small hole in the wall place that my boyfriends co worker told him about. We went for his birthday dinner . The place is small with a few booths and tables but clean. The service was good and we didn't have to wait long to get our food. They have happy hour all day everyday so the price is pretty good. The food was good but not great. I really like the baked salmon and baked  scallops and the fried tofu appetizer. Do not get the fried calamari! No flavor and it just tasted like tempura batter

"I procured a Groupon voucher for a haircut, encompassing an all-over color and style, and upon redeeming the service, I was thoroughly impressed with the proficiency and attentiveness of my stylist, who not only listened meticulously to my preferences but also executed them with remarkable precision. However, despite the exceptional quality of the service, I must deduct two stars from my rating due to a couple of issues that left me feeling taken aback and underwhelmed. Firstly, my stylist had premixed the color in her bowl, and just as she began applying it to my hair, she revealed that if she required more color, I would be charged an additional $15, which I found both surprising and unsettling, as I neither had the option to refuse nor modify my hair design at that juncture. In my opinion, such information should have been explicitly communicated to me either through my Groupon or during our initial consultation regarding my hair. Secondly, my shirt was stained by the hair color that seeped through the robe provided, and when I brought this to the stylist's attention, her manager responded nonchalantly, suggesting that it would likely come out in the wash, without offering any concrete solution or assurance. Although I have yet to test this theory, I harbor doubts about its feasibility."

"Maintaining a straightforward approach, we shall delve into the intricacies of this establishment. Firstly, the ambiance is commendable, boasting numerous televisions dispersed throughout the venue. The service, provided by friendly and attractive females, is quite satisfactory. Notably, the beverages, particularly beer, are served at an optimal temperature. However, the menu selections are somewhat restricted, albeit adequate for bar food. Patrons can choose from various options such as sandwiches, which are palatable, and salads, like the Cobb Salad. 

Regarding drawbacks, there are several areas that could benefit from improvement. To sustain a loyal customer base in a highly competitive environment, catering to local preferences is crucial. Currently, there is no happy hour, limited menu options, and a lack of advertised food and drink specials. Additionally, the establishment is not open 24 hours, and the pricing for beverages is somewhat steep. Furthermore, the UFC viewing experience comes at an additional cost of $10 per person, although they do offer it. The wine menu is meager and unimpressive, failing to provide adequate choices. Lastly, the absence of pitchers of beer and bottles of wine for purchase may deter some patrons. However, considering the novelty of this establishment, a willingness to address these concerns is plausible. Ultimately, a visit to this venue is worthwhile, especially during football season when unique promotions and offerings may be introduced."

This review is long overdue! I honestly find myself at Miller's very often.... there is always someone at working promoting a happy hour and since Miller's is close to the office and convenient for most, we always end up here.  They always have drink specials and the beer selection is good. The food is ok, bar food and nothing that stands out as a must try item. There are lots of tv's to watch filled with the sports events of the day.  The staff can be hit or miss.... I have had excellent service here and then I have had some horrible service.\n\nBut when you have a great group of friends with you- you can always have a good time here!

"The coffee is of an acceptable quality, although it cannot be considered exceptional. The ambiance of the establishment is pleasant, with a designated area for patrons who wish to engage in literary pursuits or academic endeavors in a tranquil environment. It is advisable to carry sufficient funds, as they do not accept electronic payment methods. In the event that you require access to liquidity, there is an automated teller machine located within the premises, albeit with a surcharge of two dollars. Additionally, the male barista possess a certain physical attractiveness."

Looking for old fashioned soul food? You have defiantly found the right place. The fried chicken and cornbread was really good. Lots of sides to choose from.\n\nThe service was good. Defiantly a good place for lunch if you are downtown!

"It is my fervent hope that the powers that be at The Mirage have taken the necessary steps to terminate the employment of the irresponsible and hazardous valet driver who, with callous disregard for the safety of others, nearly struck me with his vehicle while attempting to beat a red light, resulting in a collision with another hotel guest's Hyundai. Notwithstanding the fact that the hotel management had hired a driver with questionable mental stability, I cannot express excessive dissatisfaction with The Mirage, as rooms are offered at a reasonable tariff, albeit slightly higher than in previous years. The picturesque gardens situated at the main entrance provide an excellent opportunity for photography. Each dining establishment within the hotel offers an unparalleled culinary experience that should not be missed. Specifically, I highly recommend Japonais, Kokomo, and Samba. Furthermore, there are numerous tables scattered throughout the casino floor, providing ample opportunities for gaming enthusiasts. For those who are novices in the realm of gambling, the minimum limits for blackjack begin at $5-$15, making it an ideal location to initiate one's gaming endeavors. It is regrettable, however, that the poker room does not offer additional remuneration for quad aces, despite the fact that I have been fortunate enough to win substantial sums of money at this establishment. In conclusion, taking into account its advantageous location on the Las Vegas Strip and proximity to various points of interest, I would unhesitatingly suggest staying at The Mirage, but exercise extreme caution when traversing the street."

The rooms are dark. They should have more light in the room. Also there's no fridge or microwave. I understand not having an microwave. The LCD TV is small, I think it's a Phillips 32". The hot water is not hot enough when you take a shower or bath. The big negative is that here's a Resort Fee (about $20). They should just add this to grand total not try to hide it. 

I watched the Pirate show in front of the hotel which was okay. My room was in the back on the 8th floor and I was surprise that we can not hear the sound from the pirate show which is a plus.

The good part about Treasure Island is that the hotel is in the middle of the strip. Well, to me the hotels between Wynn and Paris Paris/Bellagio (maybe Planet Hollywood) are the central of attraction. Anything beyond it you're not missing much. You might want to visit Fremont Street also.

"Panchos presents itself as a veritable cornucopia of culinary delights, boasting an extensive array of delectable dishes that cater to an assortment of palates. Upon entering the establishment, one cannot help but be struck by the vibrant color scheme that permeates the interior, imbuing the atmosphere with a festive and lively ambiance. In order to partake in the gastronomical offerings, one must first navigate a cafeteria-style line, whereupon a diverse selection of comestibles becomes readily available. Encompassing everything from succulent chili rellenos (colloquially referred to as 'cheese sponges') to various iterations of enchiladas, tamales, diminutive chimichangas, flautas, and taquitos, in addition to staples such as rice, beans, tacos, and tostadas, the menu showcases a veritable smorgasbord of options sure to satiate even the most discerning diner. Furthermore, the tariff for such a copious amount of fare proves eminently reasonable, making it an attractive proposition for those who relish rich, savory, and decidedly non-authentic Mexican cuisine. A unique facet of Panchos' service model lies in the implementation of a small flag, which patrons may utilize to signal their desire for additional items from the buffet; this innovative approach ensures prompt attention from the attentive wait staff, who materialize at one's table with alacrity. While opinions regarding the eatery's overall quality remain divided, there exists a general consensus regarding the efficiency of the aforementioned flag system, which undoubtedly enhances the dining experience. Moreover, the restaurant's cleanliness and the availability of fresh, hot sopapillas post-meal contribute to its enduring popularity among those who crave a hearty, satisfying repast."

This is one of the newest Starbucks located on the strip, but it's not a real one, but a Starbucks in name only. 

Yes they except the Starbucks gift card, but they also except the total rewards cards which makes it not an official Starbucks. Another giveaway is they jack up the prices!

I ordered a passionfruit iced tea with a splash of strawberry. Normally my drink would cost me about $2.85. The young lady told me my drink cost almost 6 dollars. I did not question them, I just gave them my Starbucks card and took my drink.

This place is pretty big, plenty of outlets to plug-in, and plenty of selection of other items including the "you are here" Vegas mugs, juices, sandwiches, etc. 

I'm giving this place three stars because of the outrageous price increase. I understand it's a business, but doubling the price for a drink that normally cost me less than three dollars is insane.

There is a long hallway to get in so it is definitely pretty secret. There is not much seating inside, about 6 seats. You have to wait for your pizza, atleast 20 minutes so I would call ahead. \n\nThe pizza was alright, I honestly like Slices in Dublin, CA so much more. If I were in Las Vegas again I would not come by here but it was a nice expierence.

This is a solid three. I'm still not sure how I feel about super thick pepperoni as I do prefer the thin sliced stuff. Overall, the pizza wasn't bad, but not exactly what I think of when I think of New York style thin crust. I tend I picture something a little different, maybe more like a Villa or Verrazano.  I'm not a fan of black edge crust either, a dark golden brown is my own preference. They definitely spent a bunch remodeling it from the old Atlanta bread Company that was there.  That being said I'm not from New York although I have been there and have had a couple different slices of pizza.  I will probably go again, but not sure if this will make it to the regular rotation.

They no longer put the chicken back on the grill when you order. The chicken is not big chunks of white meat anymore, it is stewed chicken sitting in a broth all day and I'm not even sure it is all white meat anymore. Another issue is the woman who was making the burrito used her gloved hands to fill the burrito with all the toppings. That is fine for rolling, but when your sticking your hand (gloved or not) into each bin of lettuce, corn, tomatoes, cilantro, etc, it just doesn't seem normal. They need to use spoons on thongs for the fillings.

"Ah, the wistful sentimentality of reminiscence! I was perpetually perplexed, was it Lu-Lu's Noodles or Yum Wok? Being a student at the University of Pittsburgh, one did not have an extensive array of culinary options that were financially accessible. However, these establishments offered a reasonable price point and proximity, which made them appealing. Unfortunately, they did not provide delivery services, which was a disappointment during the frigid months when navigating through the campus presented a formidable challenge due to the presence of frozen precipitation. Nonetheless, for myself and my associates, the experience was worth the discomfort and amusement as we endeavored to maintain our balance, avoid falling, and safeguard our sustenance during the arduous trek back to our residence halls, affectionately referred to as 'cardiac hill.'"

Nothing special, but a bank. \nThey have a convinient, safe on-location drive thru and walk up service. Of course, personal safety is always an issue so just be 'aware' of your surroundings. \nThere is a Smith, Nail place and other business in this corner. Definitely a convinient location.

I infrequently venture into American Apparel establishments, primarily due to my penchant for vintage attire and the fact that form-fitting garments do not invariably complement my physique. However, upon finding myself in need of an article of clothing suitable for concealing excessive epidermal exposure while masquerading as a mythical aquatic creature, I decided to peruse the inventory of said retailer. Despite feeling that I overcompensated for the item I acquired, I must admit that my excursion yielded the desired result, as I managed to procure an appropriate piece of apparel in the form of a lustrous, skintight (and flesh-colored) top.

The Saloon feels very corporate and a bit overpriced.  However, the service is also good, and the beers are always cold.

I do not like the set up of the Saloon and the Comedy Zone.  I don't like how you have to go through the Saloon to get to the Comedy Zone.  Poor design lay-out.  I have been here on more than one Saturday night and had my night somewhat interrupted by huge crowds waiting in line to get into the Comedy Zone.  It sucks for everyone that is in the Saloon chillin, having a good time.  The bathrooms are packed and there is literally a human traffic jam towards the rear of the Saloon.

I usually go to the Saloon when looking to pregame before a show at the Fillmore, or before heading to another location within the Music Factory on Friday and Saturday nights.   

It is what  it is.  The live music and DJ there on Saturday nights are a huge plus.  Its still your standard, corporate, expensive bar in Charlotte.  With that being said, I would definitely go back again.

I am commencing to experience a moderate degree of perplexity regarding the purpose of establishing and sustaining video/DVD rental outlets in the present era, given that freshly released DVDs can be acquired at a cost of approximately Â£5 within a brief period of time following their launch, thereby rendering it somewhat enigmatic as to why individuals would opt to expend nearly that sum merely to temporarily borrow a single title; however, it is worth acknowledging that such establishments have taken cognizance of the emergence of economical DVDs and have responded by offering patrons an array of relatively recent or exceptional films at a marked-down price, in addition to providing advantageous deals on video games.

I genuinely aspired to bestow a perfect rating upon this festival, but unfortunately, certain aspects precluded me from doing so. Last year, my fiancÃ© and I participated in the celebration and thoroughly enjoyed ourselves, indulging in delectable cuisine and reveling in the diversity of melodies. However, our experience was marred by an unfortunate encounter with the host of the jousting match, who exhibited reprehensible behavior. 
  Initially, he publicly embarrassed a spectator by demanding she bounce for him, proceeding to offer her financial compensation for the task, only to subsequently admonish her daughter not to emulate her mother's conduct when she declined. This incident left a sour taste in our mouths, as Renaissance festivals are traditionally intended to be lighthearted, family-oriented gatherings where attendees can immerse themselves in merriment and escape reality temporarily. Moreover, it is reasonable to expect that all cast members maintain their characters consistently throughout the day, which sadly, was not upheld in this case. 
  Although I would relish the opportunity to revisit this festival in October, the presence of that individual would compel me to reconsider my attendance.

I was really looking forward to this:  A burger.  A nice, BIG, juicy, fresh, yummy burger at a sit down restaurant that specializes in burgers.  This was going to be my first visit to Fuddruckers and I had high expectations.

Well, eh.

Yeah, it was a burger.  Good but not great.  Not bad, just not exciting.  Nothing special to see here--just a burger.  I thought In n Out tasted a good deal better.  They're a lot cheaper too.

If someone suggests Fuddruckers to me sometime again as a place to eat, I'll go, but if you ask me for a destination if you're looking for a patty between two buns, there are a number of other places that I would suggest instead of it if you gave me the chance.

First, let's be clear. The Mickey Mouse mural came with the restaurant (it was on the wall before Pho Nhat moved in). OK, now that THAT is out of the way...

#42, how I love you! I love you for your barbecued beef, shrimp, and eggroll all lovingly plopped onto a giant bed of vermicelli noodles with leafy greens beneath! I cannot help but adore your fish sauce, and I will keep coming back for more. I shall not stray from you, #42. You are the only one for me.

Update: The last time I went here, the staff didn't seem very happy to have my (and my friend's) business. Maybe I will try some other pho. It's a bit sad that they haven't upgraded anything in this place either. You would think that a bit of paint wouldn't cost TOO terribly much?

"My experience at Rehab was relatively satisfactory, as I attended the venue today at approximately 1 pm, anticipating lengthy queues and exorbitant entrance fees. However, my expectations were pleasantly subverted, as the admission price was merely $60, and the waiting time for a solo male patron like myself was a mere fraction of an hour. Additionally, the security measures in place were nowhere near as stringent as previously described by other patrons. My entry was expedited, owing to the fact that I possessed only a few essential items: a car key, credit card, and identification. 

Upon entering the premises, I was struck by the considerable number of attractive individuals present. Nonetheless, the crowd was not as dense as it appears in videos and photographs. Even at 4 pm, the venue was not overwhelmingly crowded, which I found somewhat surprising. Furthermore, the atmosphere was not as frenzied as one might expect, with only a couple of individuals engaging in intimate activities. In essence, Rehab is not nearly as chaotic as one might imagine. 

It is worth noting, however, that the prices of beverages at this establishment are quite steep. A single drink can cost upwards of $28; however, buckets of Heineken Light were available for $25, which includes five beers. While I would not categorize my experience at Rehab as exceptional, I cannot deny that it was an interesting diversion. Therefore, I would not necessarily return to this venue, as it did not quite live up to my expectations."

"Although my sole consumable indulgence consisted merely of a singular glass of beer, I must confess that I derived immense satisfaction from this particular brewery's unique interpretation of a traditional wheat beer. The spacious bar area, strategically configured in a square layout, boasted an aesthetically pleasing design, complete with televisions and bartenders positioned at the center, as well as a modest-sized aquarium housing a variety of marine life. Furthermore, the atmosphere was enhanced by the presence of a sizable yet intimate gathering of patrons, which, although not excessively crowded on this particular Super Bowl evening, still managed to maintain a convivial ambiance. Additionally, for those seeking a more secluded drinking experience, an adjacent bar featuring tabletops and stools was also available. All things considered, I would highly recommend this establishment to any individual residing in Middleton and seeking a convenient, quality drinking establishment without the need to venture excessively far into Madison."

Me and the boyfriend decided to stop by this spot one night for some cheap drinks. This was my boyfriend's go to spot for a cheap drink when he lived in AZ. I already knew it was a dive bar when I pulled up so I'm not going to complain about the ambiance and restrooms... it's a dive bar! It was pretty low key the night we went so I ordered my Tokyo tea and asked the bartender for the gadget thing so we could play the trivia game that shows on the screen. I also ordered the honey hot wings which were surprisingly delicious!! On our way out we peeked in the karaoke room and it looked like people were having a ball! A good no frills spot for cheap drinks and wings!

"My culinary predilections incline me towards establishments specializing in Greek cuisine, as I find myself enamored with any dish harboring an abundance of phyllo and/or spinach. Thus, I deem it imperative to sample the offerings of any restaurant boasting these ingredients, at least once, in order to satiate my gastronomical desires. Upon partaking in the Spanikopita, I found it to be quite satisfying, and opted to augment its flavor profile by incorporating the feta cheese from my accompanying salad, a practice I commonly engage in, both when consuming this dish at home and while dining out. Furthermore, I appreciated the ample serving size, reasonable price point, and welcoming ambiance of the eatery, which fostered a sense of comfort and tranquility, prompting me to return for a second time during my stay in Madison, and ensuring that I will unquestionably revisit this charming establishment in the future."

"Indubitably, I would be delighted to partake in a Beerarita, my good fellow! As for the culinary offerings, while the quesadilla was indeed copiously filled with poultry, it regrettably lacked a certain je ne sais quoi in terms of flavor. However, the complementary chips and salsa proved to be an utterly delectable accompaniment, the latter of which supplied precisely the piquant zest that the quesadilla itself was deficient in."

I thought this restaurant was just okay. My rating is based on the food vs price. The one thing I didn't like is that everything is a la carte. I ordered the Caesar salad which was good. It was pretty big and I didn't finish all of it. My husband ordered the basic hamburger. It was just okay, nothing special for the price with no sides. I would only dine here again if the other restaurants were too crowded.
Good coffee & tea. A little loud on the radio and blenders constantly whirring... But good wifi and now that I know how to get there will use often...

Service is good. Was kind of hard to find bc it's located in a strip mall facing rural north of Guadalupe. Food portions are huge but taste wise just ok. I had the everything omelet and hubby had the Scottish eggs Benedict. The Benedict sauce was good but bread a bit tough. Omelet was just ok w home fries and English muffin.

I had the pleasure of indulging in the culinary delight known as the "Juan Turkey Wrap," and unfortunately, my expectations were not entirely met. Despite my predilection for gastronomical indulgences, I opted to sample this establishment's fare, hoping to broaden my epicurean horizons. However, upon consuming the wrap, my taste buds were not adequately stimulated, as the texture and flavors failed to distinguish themselves from one another, resulting in an unfortunate blandness that even the copious application of hot sauce could not salvage. Notwithstanding this disappointment, I am resolved to persevere in my pursuit of a satisfying dining experience at this venue and shall endeavor to explore the "happy" side of the menu on my next visit, with the hope that it shall yield a more gratifying culinary adventure.

Stopped in for breakfast and tried the Mediterranean Omelette (it was JUST ok). I wouldn't consider this food 'gourmet' as they advertise. The prices are fair for the amount of food you receive; I spent $22 on three people. There is not a huge variety of items, what you see is what you get. 

I SO appreciated the plastic utensils; most restaurants use 'dishwashers' and you just NEVER know. What irks me is that most restaurants--this one included--give you one napkin. What can I possibly do with one napkin? I'm far from sloppy, but if you're not going to have a dispenser of sorts on the table please leave more than one on the table.

The service was mediocre at best. But the appearance itself is nice; nestled in Old Downtown Chandler across from the park (it was easily accessible and there was plenty of parking. 

OAN...they have one bathroom, which creates a ridiculous line in the narrow hallway.

My overall experience wasn't horrible, I just can't say that I'd be back anytime soon.

"Bearing in mind the geographical context, it's not entirely unpalatable. Not the most delectable Chinese cuisine I've had the pleasure of consuming, but neither is it utterly reprehensible. It precariously teeters between the realm of Panda Express and genuine, authentic Chinese gastronomy."

"Juicy Pho beyond the gastronomic boundaries of the strip

This culinary establishment offers a relatively satisfactory Vietnamese noodle soup experience, albeit with notable differences from its Southern California counterparts in terms of quality and quantity of protein. 

Sampled the pork chop rice, which failed to impress due to its meager portion size and mediocre flavor profile. 

Partook of my companion's Korean BBQ ribs, which demonstrated a modicum of gustatory appeal. 

Also consumed a portion of my companion's Pho, which exhibited passable taste and texture. 

The genuine highlight of the repast was the egg roll enveloped in lettuce, an edible masterpiece that elicited unbridled enthusiasm and delight. 

Located at a considerable distance from the strip, necessitating a minimum of 10-15 minutes of vehicular transportation to arrive at the premises."
Cheap burgers for a fancy price. Reminded me of those rubber burgers you got in grade school. Not worth the $10 I spent. I won't be going back soon.
This place was \"OK,\" but I probably wouldn't go back. Food was kind of low end Chinese although service and atmosphere were fine. Not really bad, just not good either.

Colectivo is an aesthetically pleasing and contemporary coffee establishment situated in a prime location on the northeastern corner of the Capitol square, boasting an ambiance that exudes a rustic yet trendy vibe, replete with an eclectic selection of musical offerings, visually appealing decor, and ample seating options both indoors and outdoors, including a spacious "porch" area that invites patrons to linger and enjoy their beverages in a relaxed setting. Patrons can indulge in a diverse array of expertly crafted coffee and tea beverages, complemented by a select assortment of delectable edibles and potables, all while availing themselves of the complimentary wireless internet access available throughout the premises, with the exception of weekends.

Now, upon reflection, it has become apparent to me why I was advised to remain at the Westin; however, I was not particularly keen on traversing a considerable distance to reach my place of employment.  Initially, upon obtaining the room, I began to perceive an anomalous auditory phenomenon, which, at the time, I failed to attribute any significance to. Following the deposit of my belongings, I proceeded to the office, only to return and discover that the noise was still persisting; further investigation revealed that the source of the disturbance was, in fact, a toilet that refused to cease functioning properly. In order to rectify the situation, I descended to the ground floor to seek assistance from a staff member, subsequently departing to acquire sustenance. Upon my return, approximately one hour and thirty minutes later, I was dismayed to discover that the issue remained unresolved. Prompted by my growing frustration, I elected to descend once more to remind the hotel personnel of the problem. Fortunately, the matter was ultimately resolved within a span of forty-five minutes. However, my relief was short-lived, as I soon became aware of a pool of water accumulating behind the toilet, indicative of a leak. I promptly contacted the hotel staff and awaited the arrival of a maintenance worker, who, much to my relief, arrived in a timely manner and efficiently addressed the problem. Notwithstanding the aforementioned inconveniences, there exists a silver lining; specifically, the majority of check-ins occur around three o'clock in the afternoon. Moreover, I must express my gratitude towards the accommodating nature of the hotel staff, who graciously allowed me to check in at eight o'clock in the morning, facilitating my transition from the Hilton Garden to the aforementioned Hilton property.

"Upon my initial visit, I must admit that my expectations were not entirely fulfilled, as the culinary offerings, although fresh, were somewhat limited in scope, particularly with regard to the lunch menu. However, I did appreciate the extensive breakfast selection and salad bar, which provided a satisfactory array of options. Unfortunately, the absence of salmon from the menu proved to be a significant disappointment, and the dearth of delectable desserts further contributed to my dissatisfaction. Given the steep price point of $65.00, I cannot say that I will be inclined to return in the near future. Nonetheless, I must commend the staff for their attentive and courteous customer service."

2.5 stars.

Stopped by tonight after having dinner at a pizzeria nearby.  Never been, but had prepared myself to expect a smaller location compared to that at Ray Rd. and the 101 (my fave!).  Was surprised to notice an unpleasant smell (akin to what Asian supermarkets tend to smell like with their stocks of rice and the odors that emanate from their meat shops) just as I entered the market, which continued as I entered the produce department.  

This place is small!  The "olive bar" consisted of maybe 8 (max) containers the size of small bread loaves.  Pathetic, but what can you expect from a converted Wild Oats?  The selection of meats looked fresh, though (beef top loin is on sale at $5.99/lb., while center-cut pork chops are $2.99/lb!).  While the cheese counter is small, it did showcase fresh-looking items, and the whole store, in general, looked clean and was brightly-lit.  I couldn't find my favorite Wellshire bacon (peppered uncured), but I was able to find the only tasty whole-grain whole wheat bread I can enjoy w/o pain (Natural Bread Co.'s Honey Whole Wheat), albeit there was only one loaf available to buy!  And I quickly had a glimpse of their bulk section... Thank God I was full, or I'd have stopped for some sweets!

In a pinch, I'd stop here for emergency re-stocking, but I'll probably head over to the Tatum/Shea or Mayo locations (both of which I haven't visited, yet!) to get my dining-at-Whole Foods fix!

"My sentiments regarding this establishment are rather tepid, as the accommodations, although pleasant, fail to exceed my expectations. However, I must acknowledge that the personnel have been courteous and helpful during my stay, despite the minor inconvenience of being assigned a room on an incorrect floor. It is worth mentioning that the hotel is currently undergoing renovations, which has resulted in a significant amount of construction activity and the presence of numerous work vehicles. Notwithstanding, I would not recommend this particular lodging to prospective travelers, primarily due to the subpar service I received upon check-in. Nonetheless, the physical structure of the hotel itself is quite impressive, and the staff members have been exceptionally hospitable."

"Although I have yet to visit the authentic cronut bakery, the extensive queues have proven to be a formidable deterrent.
