However, my culinary endeavors have been graced by the presence of La Cornetteria, thereby affording me the opportunity to sample the renowned croissant-donut hybrid, much to my delight. :)"

Following the unfortunate occurrence involving a subpar burger from Carl's Jr., I surmised that a restitution of sorts could be achieved by placing an order for two straightforward cheeseburgers at Burger King. Given the ostensible simplicity of the request, I anticipated a brief waiting period before receiving my culinary delights. However, much to my dismay, an inordinate amount of time elapsed while other patrons received their respective orders, including chicken nuggets, Whopper Jr.'s, and Extra Long BBQ Cheeseburgers. During this interval, my gaze was fixated upon the restaurant's order board, whereupon I noticed that my order was displayed in crimson letters and had surpassed the five-minute mark, whereas the majority of the other orders were denoted in verdant letters and were fulfilled within a minute or less. For two uncomplicated cheeseburgers, I thought to myself, surely this could be accomplished with greater expediency! Ultimately, I did indeed receive my cheeseburgers, which served as a satisfactory compensation for the unsatisfactory meal I had previously endured from Carl's Jr.

Out of the gate i called for a reservation. they said no need.. just come on in. So i was upset to find a 30 min wait for a table. they told me they dont take reservations. it vegas... sat night... you guys should take reservations. just my opinion.

menu is small... food is over the top. 

truffle fries were incredible.. everything else was good.. not great.. but good. i had good company which made the meal fun. so all in all we had a good time there. Its a pretty good place. i guess i would return under the right circumstances... but wouldnt run back there on my own...

Good brunch and the atmosphere on the patio was very nice, but a pretty significant (I won't call fatal) flaw that merits no more than an A-OK.  If you cannot remove an ingredient from a dish on request you either do or do not, there is no try.  We asked for no onions, answer was yes, but when the dish came it had onions in it.  When we pointed it out we were told the cook tried to remove them but couldn't from the pre-made mix.  Appreciate the flexibility in trying to accommodate, but what if instead of a food we preferred to avoid it was in fact an allergy and you knowingly passed it onto us? Why not just tell us it's a mix and you can't really separate it from the meal ... instead of just serving it up anyway? The general lack of interest shown by the waiter on this left us with a bad feeling.  Despite their efforts and a few bright spots, there were some breakdowns in customer service (not just the one mentioned) and staff training, which add up to a lack of compelling reason to return.  So we probably won't.

"Having experienced an extended hiatus from the delectable delights of an authentic Asian buffet for a duration of two days, I decided to indulge in a culinary excursion to this establishment, which, according to the esteemed review platform, Yelp, is designated as 'E-Z Buffet,' although the proprietors have opted to interchangeably refer to it as either 'EZ Buffet,' 'EZ Chinese Buffet,' or 'Easy Buffet,' depending on the specific signage or promotional materials in question. Thus, allowing me to partake in a gastronomical journey that encompassed a diverse array of 75 primary dishes, showcasing an eclectic mix of traditional Chinese cuisine, such as Clam Chowder, beef roast, Stuffed Bell Peppers, Calzone, pizza, and even pink marshmallows, which piqued my curiosity and left me feeling both intrigued and amused. Furthermore, this spacious eatery, characterized by its refined ambiance and hospitable staff, offered an extensive selection of customary Chinese fare, including Sushi (albeit being of Japanese origin), Kim Chee (being Korean in nature), Egg Foo Young (prepared authentically), and an assortment of fried chicken, boneless spare ribs, stuffed mushrooms, various chicken preparations, fish, shrimp, and numerous other options, ultimately culminating in a satisfying medley of desserts, highlighted by genuine ice cream of superior quality. Consequently, I would confer upon this commendable dining establishment a rating of three stars, denoting its well-rounded appeal and reasonable pricing, with lunch buffet prices set at $6.75 or $6.08 for seniors from Monday through Saturday, $8.75 or $7.88 on Sundays, and the availability of a standard menu for patrons seeking alternative dining options."

"The sushi served at this establishment consistently boasts an innovative and delectable quality, and the ambiance created by the interior design provides a suitable setting for bringing along any individual, including a romantic partner. However, my recent experiences have led me to deduce that the service here has been subpar, as the servers appear to lack a systematic approach to attending to their patrons. Specifically, during my most recent visit, which included a group of six individuals, we had multiple servers attend to us, resulting in a lack of coordination and communication among them. As a result, we experienced prolonged periods of neglect, ultimately leading to a 45-minute delay in receiving our order. Furthermore, despite the friendly demeanor displayed by the staff, the inefficiency in their service resulted in unnecessary inconvenience for us. To add insult to injury, a 20% gratuity was automatically added to our bill, and we were informed that the maximum number of ways we could split the check was three, thereby necessitating additional calculations and transactions among ourselves. These issues have diminished my inclination to revisit this establishment in the future."

If I'd never been to wicked spoon, I would have thought this was fantastic. The quality was good/ok, but it was crowded, and expensive for what you get unless you are just planning to Hoover mass quantities.\n\nIt was a little Disneyland-buffet ish.

We have had the pleasure of visiting this establishment on multiple occasions, and our experiences have been rather dichotomous, with the service being either exceptionally impressive (5 stars) or subpar (1 star), while the culinary offerings have consistently met our expectations. Thus, we have arrived at an overall rating of 3 stars, which we deem to be a fair assessment given the variable quality of service we have encountered. However, if there is a decline in the gastronomic experience, we would be compelled to reevaluate our patronage of this venue.

I almost feel bad giving this three stars, but we went today earlier in the day with my 7 year old and three adults.... 7 year old played in the fort thing and found a friend, had a great time. We walked down to the Fremont street experience and decided to have dinner there in the park. We walked back and ordered our meal (at about $20 a plate for tacos and beer!!!!) around 8:48 and my daughter asked if she could go out and see the mantis on fire... I told her yes! Then my husband went to get her and they told her she couldn't come back in!!!!!  She walked back in anyway. At 9:00 they announced that if you are under 21 the park is closing.  Mind you we were still waiting of our meal! This was Saturday night. So we then felt like we had to rush through our  meal we had JUST purchased in order to leave with the under age one. Not so great. If they are marketing this for families, then it needs to be that- 9pm is not that late for families on a weekend. If they aren't, then market it that way but they do need to decide what it is. I didn't appreciate having to rush through my meal.

"I visited this establishment during the Labor Day weekend, utilizing a Groupon, and had a generally pleasant experience. The exterior areas of the property were well-maintained; however, the guest rooms required some refurbishment. Specifically, the bathroom tiles and shower curtain needed replacement, and an empty cabinet beneath the television appeared to have been previously occupied by a refrigerator, evidenced by scratches and dents. Furthermore, the televisions functioned intermittently. My interactions with the staff were limited to check-in and check-out, and they were adequate during those brief encounters. The resort offered various recreational activities, including two swimming pools, outdoor movie screenings, marshmallow roasting, live music, miniature golf, and a playground for children. Additionally, guests could rent paddleboards and kayaks to explore Lake Las Vegas for a fee of $30 per hour. Observing other patrons with their canine companions, I inferred that the resort accommodated pets. Perhaps, my own furry companion will join me on a future visit. Considering the price I paid for the Groupon, the quality of the hotel was satisfactory; however, had I paid the full price, I might have felt that I had overpaid."

My family visited this restaurant during restaurant week, and it offered the most extensive and diverse menu options among the four establishments we contacted. The ambiance was vibrant, sensual, and welcoming, which made us feel comfortable and relaxed. We enjoyed their creative cocktail selection while waiting for our table at the bar. Our server was friendly, charming, and attentive, which added to our delightful dining experience. The restaurant week menu offered an impressive variety of dishes, and the crab cakes were undoubtedly the most flavorful and well-prepared I have had in Charlotte. The steaks were cooked to perfection, and although the dessert could have been more satisfying, it was still a delectable treat. I would highly recommend returning to this establishment, particularly for happy hour with friends.

Red Ridge Park constitutes a mere ten-minute pedestrian excursion from my present domicile, which I shall be vacating in the near future, thus rendering my erstwhile frequent visits to this picturesque park a distant memory. During my days of unyielding physical fitness regimentation, I would endeavor to circumnavigate the park's perimeter, whose distance approximates a mile, albeit with slight variations in elevation, owing to the park's topographical configuration, comprising of two inclined sides and two flat expanses, thereby facilitating an unencumbered running experience. Moreover, I have always appreciated the park's nocturnal illumination, which engenders a sense of security, particularly when traversing the premises singularly. 

The park's amenities include a diminutive water-themed recreational area for juveniles, an extensive playground for older children, a smaller play area designated for younger offspring (refer to visual depictions), basketball courts, and a baseball diamond (visual representation provided). Despite its constant throng of patrons, I have yet to experience a sensation of overcrowding within the park's confines. Observations have revealed that visitors indulge in various activities such as ambulating, interacting with canine companions, or simply luxuriating in the sun's radiant warmth while partaking in gastronomical delights. 

Of late, residential dwellings have begun to materialize directly opposite the park, specifically, the Dunhill abodes, whose prices range from approximately 200,000 units of the local currency as a starting point, and the neighborhood is undergoing rapid development. These habitats merit consideration, especially for those who harbor an affinity for the southwestern sector. Furthermore, the proximity of these residences to the park grants the benefit of verdant vistas, whereas alternative perspectives may encompass views of neighboring structures. Additionally, the recently established Wet n Wild Water Park lies in close proximity. Notwithstanding, a certain feature that I ardently desire to witness within this park's precincts is the presence of an enclosed canine recreational area, akin to those encountered during my peregrinations to other parks.

"Rating: 3.5 stars. Gastronomical aficionados who relish the delectable delights of small plates will undoubtedly venerate the salumi and grilled asparagus offerings, while those who crave more substantial fare may find the fish and chips underwhelming due to the lack of culinary depth, but can be salvaged with a squeeze of citrus. Other patrons enjoyed their main courses, with the exception of a singular beef dish marred by an excess of sodium. The fruit-based conclusion, featuring an assortment of fresh berries, was truly exceptional, whereas the ice cream, though palatable, suffered from an unfortunate pairing with bowls that facilitated its rapid dissolution. Additionally, the caramel treat was once again too saline."

"The culinary offerings were merely adequate.  It is an establishment specializing in alcoholic beverages.  It would be more suitable for individuals who partake in such libations.  Unfortunately, I do not possess a predilection for beer.  I opted for a black bean burger, which was presumably a product of Morningstar Farms.  The supplementary fee for this item was $1.99, a cost I deemed dubious.  The hospitality was inconsistent, but we did receive a replenishment of our beverages upon the delivery of our bill."

Based on the reviews I was disappointed with my entre...chicken pasta (linguini, basil and cream sauce). Too heavy and thick with an excess of heavy cream. Service however was 5 star so I'd give it another try. Might just have been an off night. Glad they had one of my favorite brews...Dos Equis amber!

I've been to Osteria twice now. Once to grab a sandwich for lunch, and then to get a takeout pizza for dinner. I've really hoped this place would be good as I live across the street. My experience has been mixed. Sandwich was a very good Italian deli sandwich. Pizza was mediocre though. While the pizza had the unintended positive effect of reminding me of free pizza consumed when I was in grad school in NYC that's not the best sign of quality. Not bad but could be better. \n\nThere's a lot of potential for Osteria and I hope they succeed. Maybe a weekend brunch would be a good addition? And make pizza less like basic takeout pizza and more \"fancy\" (tasty too).

I don't know that I have ever felt dirtier.

Still, I had a blast the couple of times we floated the river. 

We did the tie-everyone-together-plus-a- beer-cooler thing and enjoyed being wet and dirty. 

Wear a big hat.

"The current state of affairs is satisfactory. Indeed, it is more than satisfactory; it is positively acceptable. Allow me to reiterate that my previous response was not tinged with even a hint of sarcasm or irony. In point of fact, I am entirely serious in my assertion that the present situation is thoroughly adequate. Incidentally, this assessment pertains specifically to the morning repast, which I have had the pleasure of partaking in on multiple occasionsâapproximately 10 to 15 times, to be preciseâas I have a propensity to patronize this establishment whenever I find myself in the vicinity of Pittsburgh."

You know going in that the food isn't going to be incredible, but you'd at least expect the staff to be friendly. This particular OG is very hit or miss. I've had both good and horrible dining experiences due to the waiter/waitress.

The food is good.  It's a nice breakfast spot and I'll probably end up eating here a lot.  The savory crepes are better than the sweet (in my opinion) and the coffee drinks are tasty.  

There are a few things I'd like to see change though:  

- A hostess would be welcome.  Being my first time here I walked in and was unsure of what to do.  There's a register and a long counter so there was no clear indicator as to whether it was counter service or table service.  I had to track down an employee to find out.  
- The service is spotty.  There were two waitresses working when I was there.  Every table was full so it was 15 minutes before we got to order.  
- The wait times for food.  After ordering it was 20-25 minutes for two crepes.  That's way too much.  I didn't mind as I wasn't in a hurry but it made me sure to never come here if you have anywhere to be in the next 90 minutes.  

I like crepes and  I like coffee and I like good service.  Two out of three ain't bad.

working in the gyle industrial estate this shopping centre is the closest thing for a lunchtime escape from the office.  so maybe i see it through rose-tinted shades while others may find this place a bit run down and lacking.  but for me, it's a beacon of clothing shops, food options, and starbucks that i can visit during my lunch break and enjoy a bit of freedom from the office.

i'm pretty sure when the gyle was first opened it was shiny and state of the art, but i do feel that might have been awhile ago.  however what's on offer is still quite good, one of the largest marks & spencers food halls, a good sized morrisons, a huge boots, a decent new look and dorothy perkins, and my beloved starbucks.  they also have a millie's cookie stand which Kelly F can confirm i have a serious love affair with.  omg cookie cake anyone????

yes it is a bit dark and the food court has a lack of options if you're looking for healthier food, but it's still a decent place to spend a lunch hour or make an emergency run to boots for when you're run out of mascara or concealor.  or when i've decided i just desperately need that new dorothy perkins dress i saw in my gossip magazine.  i like this place, it's a-ok and despite being slighty aged still has a fair bit to offer.

Ever since this was built a number of years ago, I've been wanting to check it out but whenever I'm in Vegas, I usually hang along the strip most of the time and never made it out here.  My last trip I finally did.  

The things I do like about the "experience" is that it's an outdoor party and I have to say the screens are pretty impressive.  

This is "Old" Las Vegas where everything is dirt cheap.  All the drinks and food are inline with the prices I want to pay when I come to Vegas.  

But.......   
It's pretty damn ghetto here.  At least the night I came.  There were a lot of street people.  You could see some paperbags with some "8 Ball" protruding from them.  But I guess that's part of the charm here cause you can just have an open container here with no damn worries....  

It's all good I guess but whenever I looked up at the screen, I had to make sure I looked back to street level here and there just to make sure my wallet was not leaving me.  haha..  

Maybe the earlier shows are not so seedy.  I did come for the very last show of the evening so maybe I was asking for it....

My spouse and I opted to halt our itinerary at this establishment subsequent to attending Zumanity on the eve of All Hallows' Eve, primarily due to the fact that there were an abundance of individuals roaming the vicinity, donning an array of elaborate costumes. Our desire was to discover a setting where we could partake in a refreshing beverage and observe the passersby. This particular venue fulfilled our requirements admirably.

Fortuitously, we possessed a pair of complimentary beverage vouchers, thereby eliminating the necessity for financial expenditure. Nonetheless, the prices for artisanal and microbrewed beverages ranged between $6 and $7, which we deemed reasonable considering the extensive assortment available. I opted for a Sin City Amber, while my partner selected a Sam Adams Cherry Wheat. This establishment boasted an impressive collection of superior quality brews from notable breweries such as Sierra Nevada, Alaska, Abita, Rogue, Stone, et al. In comparison to numerous other watering holes within Las Vegas, this one offered a more extensive variety.

On a Friday evening, New York-New York was teeming with activity; however, this particular establishment did not appear excessively crowded, despite the frenetic pace of the bartenders. My sole grievance pertained to the service, which I considered somewhat subpar, particularly given the complimentary nature of our beverages. Notwithstanding, I shall attribute this to a singular unfortunate experience and intend to revisit this location, particularly as a meeting spot for acquaintances lodging along the Strip.

In summary, this establishment exuded an atmosphere of merriment, and we eagerly anticipate our return visit.

"Lucca, an eatery of Italian cuisine, boasts a superior quality of culinary expertise and hospitable service, rendering it a superlative dining establishment within the urban confines, and particularly, within the district of Oakland. While the cost may be considered prohibitive by some patrons, the gastronomical indulgence proffered by Lucca's menu selections, in conjunction with the welcoming demeanor of its personnel and the non-pretentious ambiance, constitutes an exceptional value proposition for those seeking a memorable epicurean adventure. However, the tariff associated with this gustatory experience may be better suited to the economic paradigms of metropolitan areas such as New York or San Francisco."

"While my expectations were admittedly elevated, I must confess that I was somewhat underwhelmed by the overall experience. Notwithstanding the undeniably breathtaking panorama afforded by the establishment's strategic location, the ambiance and culinary offerings failed to impress me to the extent that I had anticipated. In fact, I would venture to say that the quality of the fare and the aesthetic appeal of the surroundings were merely adequate, and certainly not exceptional. Be that as it may, I must acknowledge that the singular aspect that truly sets this eatery apart from its competitors is, indeed, its unparalleled view. However, as a local resident, I cannot help but feel that there are far more exceptional dining options available in the city."

Unfortunately, it appears that this establishment has recently undergone a change in proprietorship, and my experiences with the quality of the eyebrow waxing services provided have been less than satisfactory. Specifically, the new owner seems to have neglected to maintain the standard of excellence previously upheld by the former proprietor, as evidenced by the fact that one of my brows was left uneven and noticeably thinner than its counterpart. This disparity has necessitated an extension of the time interval between waxings, which unfortunately precludes me from patronizing this business further.

Second time i have been to a culinary dropout, first time at this one.

As always love the atmosphere, especially because the Yard was right there as well.

Happy Hour beware are only at the bar, hightops, or outside. We didn't go for that so it wasn't too big of a deal, but could have been.

Only had the hip bar type food when we were here for a work hang out. It was good from what I had. 

Definitely a fun place to come to hang out and just kick it with friends. Consider it an adult playground.

"The seared tuna carpaccio, ninja roll, and elephant roll exhibited an impressive culinary proficiency, boasting a flavor profile that was undoubtedly tantalizing. However, the ambiance, while trendy, suffered from a somewhat claustrophobic atmosphere, which was further exacerbated by the low rise sushi bar counter that, although functional, proved to be aesthetically displeasing to this writer. Nevertheless, the price point for the all-you-can-eat dinner option remained reasonable, rendering it an accessible indulgence for those seeking a gastronomical adventure. Furthermore, the ample parking and melodious background music contributed to an overall pleasant dining experience, despite minor quibbles regarding the physical space. Ultimately, the fare served at this establishment demonstrated a satisfactory quality, thus ensuring a positive outcome for those who partook in the culinary journey."

"I acquired my initial two body art pieces at this establishment, collaborating with Jessy, who demonstrated remarkable proficiency and expertise in her craft, prompting my sibling to seek her services for a personalized design, resulting in an exceptional piece that garnered immense satisfaction. Subsequently, I opted to return to Jessy for a second piece, featuring an inverted color scheme, thereby emphasizing her adaptability and dedication to ensuring a unique and satisfactory experience for each client. Moreover, the shop's pristine condition significantly contributed to my positive encounter."

Go to Bang if:
You enjoy Billy Joel, Elton John, top 40 done via piano, people watching, standing if you can't get a table (and you probably won't unless you show up at 7pm), singing loudly to Journey while the drunk girl screeches next you, sweating.

Don't go to Bang if: 
You hate all of the above, have issues with bachelorette or birthday parties, fear being dragged onstage to sing or dance while people judge you, you like your piano straight up - none of this guitar/drum nonsense at a dueling piano bar. If you have a headache or a stick up your ass, this place will not help. 

Cover at the door. Overall, fun place to visit but I wouldn't want to live here.
Good place to watch a game, the bartenders were fairly attentive but food service time was poor. After 30+ minutes waiting for an app, I canceled the order and asked for my check.

I was expecting great things from this sandwich shop but was disappointed to find basically a glorified lunch counter. The ingredients just didn't seem to be very high quality. The steak melt didn't have enough steak in it. The sandos sound good but the execution didn't seem to be there. For the inflated price tag I want a great sandwich. This wasn't.

I was decidedly more taken by the charms of Squirrel Hill than those of Bangkok Balcony, and my companion and I chanced upon this venue via a website proffering guidance for vegan travelers to Pittsburgh, which we found appealing given their late hours of operation. We encountered minimal difficulty in securing street parking, and while my enthusiasm was somewhat dampened by the preponderance of shuttered boutiques, owing to an unfortunate temporal confluence, I must admit that my attention was captivated by the diverse array of vintage and contemporary attire on display. Digression notwithstanding, I must confess that the layout of Bangkok Balcony did strike me as rather appealing, what with its elevated position and modern appointments that stopped short of sterility. My companion and I were both enamored of the flatware employed by the establishment, which, though perhaps seeming a trivial detail, did indeed warrant mention. Furthermore, the menu boasted an impressive selection of tofu options, and I must say that I appreciated the consideration evinced by the staff in inquiring about my desired level of spiciness, scaling said preference from one to ten. Additionally, the prices charged by the restaurant struck me as quite reasonable, especially considering the bustling atmosphere and aesthetic appeal of the premises. In conclusion, while my culinary excursion did prove satisfying, albeit with a tinge of subsequent indigestion, my fervor for Thai cuisine knows no bounds, and thus, I feel compelled to assign three stars to this establishment.

They gave us a great table right next to the floor to ceiling windows. overlooking the strip. the HUGE Jumbo screen and parking lot that were in view aren't very romantic but the Eiffel tower in the distance was. 

Drinks - great cocktails

My only comment is the live music is on the other side of the bar from the windows. so you have to choose -  view or live music.. not both. :P kind of sleepy. everyone here was paired up. good for the "mature" or "date" crowd. I wanted to meet people and laugh so we had one drink and left. still worth checking out.

"I opted for the frozen hot chocolate, electing to consume it extramurally, as the temporal duration preceding its procurement proved to be rather protracted. Notwithstanding the lengthy delay, the beverage's quality was sufficient to justify its consumption, rendering it an acceptable culinary experience. While I am not inclined to endorse the exorbitant price point of $9 for a limited quantity, I acknowledge the existence of certain circumstances that may warrant such a tariff. Upon fulfilling my long-standing desire to sample this item, courtesy of its prominent placement on Oprah's list of preferred products, I shall endeavor to partake in their gastronomical offerings at a future date."

"An early morning repast, comprising of eggs, potatoes, bacon, coffee, and fruit juice, commonly referred to as 'breakfast', was procured at a cost of $22.00. This sum consisted of a $10 entree, a $3 beverage, specifically coffee, and a $6, 10 oz serving of orange juice. A supplementary, plate-sized side dish of hash browns was also obtained, for an additional $3. Although the quality of the culinary offerings was satisfactory, the overall experience did not warrant the expenditure. In contrast, Waffle House, a nearby establishment, provides a more copious amount of nourishment for approximately half the price, and their coffee is of superior quality. Ultimately, this particular dining excursion was deemed acceptable, yet overpriced by a margin of 25%."

It was OKay but I don't see what all the hype is about.  I'm from Maryland and made Price's one of my "must go" spots when I visited Charlotte in May 2012.  The wings are SOOOO small...OMG!!  They were just ok to me, the best part of the experience was getting tater tots instead of fries.  (Reminds me of my high school days..ahhhh)  

Anyway, I can get the same pressure fried cooked wings from any of the Armish Markets here in Maryland and the wings are much more satifying.  

Price's is now off of my list of places I MUST visit.
The food is alright, Only place I could find around for a quick bit to eat. I stayed at the Mandala Bay which is next to this place.

When I saw that a Korean BBQ place had moved in to the empty Mcdonalds store front, I was pretty excited! I would finally be able to try Korean food at a good price..Which was partially correct. They are pricey for 'fast-food', with most of their options, including a la carte, being around $7-9. I have tried their Bulgogi, with steamed vegetables and kimchi, which was all really good! The sweetness of this dish was great with the garlic and spice of the kimchi! 

I really want to try their Mandu and tempura, but they keep it under heat lamps in the front, which makes me wonder how long it has been there..but will probably try it one day ( I was watching ABC 15 and saw they got a D for their health inspection in July. It was for things like improper holding temperatures, kimchi made at home(was removed from service), thermometers, ect. BUT Most of these problems were solved on the same day)

I see now that they have added Boba tea, which I'm also really excited for, seeing as how it's hard to find without driving to the far west or Scottsdale to find!

Hopefully the busier they get, the lower prices will become, but being one of the only Korean places on the East side of Phoenix, they might not.

Not too bad. I am not at all the Old Town Scottsdale nightlife kind of gal anymore, so this wouldn't be my scene during those times. However, about 12 of my girlfriends and I went to The Mint for Happy Hour on a Friday and had a pleasant time. The food is really good! The drinks are good and the 1/2 price makes them very reasonable. The interior was pretty cool. Later at night you probably wouldn't be able to notice all the cool details. The co-ed bathroom is weird - just weird. I really didn't like that. The staff while very attractive and friendly, seemed a bit new. Our very sweet server had a lot of trouble with our big group. She didn't want to do separate checks at the beginning and told us doing one group bill would be easier for everyone. Then, when we tried to pay, it was a problem and someone else told us we should have done separate checks...we tried! I waited 30 minutes for my bill when there might have been 3 other patrons in the Mint other than our group. I would definitely come back for another happy hour and check out the outdoor bar, but would probably insist on separate checks.

"This venue possesses an ambiance characterized by an abundance of artwork and large televisions in the primary bar area, which creates a captivating atmosphere that attracts a diverse clientele. Additionally, the upstairs section boasts pool tables, arcade games, and skee-ball machines, providing entertainment options for patrons of all ages. An outdoor patio area is also available, much to the delight of those who partake in smoking activities. It has become a popular destination for locals to congregate on Sundays to observe sporting events, further enhancing its appeal. Although their menu does not include food, they occasionally host special events such as a complimentary chicken wing buffet, which is readily availed by patrons. Furthermore, they showcase an impressive selection of locally brewed beverages, which aligns with the preferences of many visitors. Lastly, ample parking facilities are provided, both on the street and behind the building, ensuring convenient access for all patrons."

I must admit that my experience did not quite live up to the lofty expectations engendered by the plethora of glowing reviews lavished upon this establishment, with many patrons effusively extolling its culinary virtues in effusive fashion, going so far as to assign it a perfect score of five stars; personally, I found the fare to be satisfactory, but by no means exceptional, particularly considering the rather steep tariff of sixty dollars for a single burger, fish sandwich, fries, and a pair of sodas, which, in my estimation, failed to justify the cost, leaving me feeling underwhelmed and unimpressed, and, I might add, my lovely companion concurred with my assessment, thus necessitating a rating of three stars, denoting an experience that, while certainly passable, fell short of excellence.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."
That's how I would describe my visit to Canyon Ranch Spa at the Venetian. My expectations were high, based on what I had read in literature and reviews about the original Canyon Ranch. Unfortunately, the reality was far from it. Firstly, the price was exorbitant for the services offered. Additionally, the size of the spa was minuscule compared to the one at The Venetian. But what really left me perplexed was the signature energy massage, which lacked any tangible contact. It was akin to a mystical experience, but not in a good way. To say I was unimpressed would be an understatement. Needless to say, this spa won't be my top pick for future visits.

All Apple stores, for the most part, possess expansive interior spaces that are well illuminated, allowing their products to be prominently showcased, thereby creating an ambiance conducive to a pleasant shopping experience, which is further enhanced by the friendly and professional demeanor of the staff members; however, it is worth noting that the prices of their products are exorbitant and disproportionate to their actual value, hence, it is advisable for ardent admirers of the brand to exercise fiscal prudence and consider alternative options that offer better value for their money, and, if they are inclined to make charitable contributions, they can do so by donating to organizations that support worthy causes, thus contributing to the greater good, while simultaneously enjoying life's indulgences in a responsible and festive manner.

The food was good with a decent selection, not amazing. The atmosphere isn't anything special. It's not lively, especially for Vegas. Went with a groupon, so it was a good price. Otherwise it is overpriced

Did a detail there, they did a good, but not oustanding job, but for a reasonable price (like $150).  Tons better than Danny's would ever do!\n\nI've had other, better, details in the area, but they were closer to $250... so comparing the quality of the work versus the price, Airpark was a good/very good value.

"At this particular Panda Express location, a drive-thru facility is available, which proved to be a highly convenient feature during my recent visit, especially given the sweltering temperature of 103 degrees Fahrenheit outside. Upon entering the establishment, I was greeted by a relatively brief queue, which expedited the ordering process. However, upon receiving my order, I was disappointed to discover that the quality of the food did not meet my expectations, specifically in regards to the orange chicken and Beijing beef entree, which suffered from an unfortunate lack of moisture and flavorful sauces. Despite these shortcomings, I must admit that the dining experience at this Panda Express was generally on par with my expectations for a fast-food establishment of its caliber, albeit with a few notable exceptions."

Although I go here a  lot when I'm in Vegas be advised if you're white some dishes will be heavily 'sanitized' to suit  your perceived taste without asking.  For example,  on a recent visit I ordered the super combination pho (the one usually at the top of the list at any pho place) and it came without any tendon or tripe...and they didn't throw in more of the 'regular' meats to compensate.

While I am absolutely in love with the Galaxy Luxury theater, sometimes, I can't drive across town for a movie, or they don't have enough seating for the one I want.\n\nBrenden is a comfy theater, and I've always had good experiences here.  The employees are polite, and prices are standard.

"Alas, my dear fellow, it appears that Mamma Mia has seen fit to revise the boundaries of their delivery area, rendering my humble abode, located a mere 0.7 miles from their esteemed establishment, no longer suitable for their courier services, according to their online system. How vexing! It seems that those residing east of 20th Street, west of 64th Street, north of Washington, or south of Lincoln are now compelled to partake in the arduous task of driving to acquire their pizza, a culinary delight that I have had the pleasure of enjoying on numerous occasions. Fear not, however, for their pizza, offered by the slice, remains quite delectable."
This review is for the Mexican Restaurant.  It's pretty good.  The salsa bar is great.  Big portions.  I would give it 4 stars but the decor is old

3.5 stars

I'm a fan of Flamebroiler (do they have those in AZ?) so I'm trying to find a decent teriyaki bowl place close to me. I want to say rice bowls are for Asian/Indian people what sandwiches must be for White people lol; quick, cheap, tasty and a usually healthy meal. I think this place fits the bill! 

I got the cayman which is a combo of two of their items. I got the Fiji and Singapore curry. Fiji is like slow cooked chuck roast in teriyaki sauce, good but still a little tough. Singapore curry had chicken and carrots in like a Japanese curry (like the cubes you buy at the asian market) but with a hint of sourness. The meat (chicken) was stringy because it was also slow cooked, a texture I didn't care for.

Overall I enjoyed my meal and serving size was good, I couldn't finish my bowl.Price was cheap, 5 bucks! Even less if you get one item. I appreciate their unique menu, away from the typical chicken or beef drenched in teriyaki sauce, but its nothing mind blowing. Probably will be back since its so close to Midwestern, and so cheap! I'll update this review after I try some more items. Looking forward to trying their appetizer items, crab puffs and egg rolls.

10% discount for Midwestern students!

They had a pre opening party for Trader Vic's at Planet Hollywood last week .
Tikipug had this to say about the party.
We ate like Kings. Lobster, shrimp, duck. It was awesome. They took us up to a banquet room in the hotel. They had hula dancers, mai tais, and free mugs. We got to meet Eve, Trader Vic's granddaughter and tour the unfinished restaurant.
Executive chef Rick Giffen, previously at Mon Ami Gabi at Paris next door did the cooking. That's not your average Pu Pu platter.

The three stars so far is based on their  the food and drinks. The decor one star. Maybe they should offer VR (visual reality ) helmets
 I love Trader Vic's where ever they may be including the Polynesio in Havanna (thats another story) but this is a Trader Vic's Lounge like the new one in Beverly Hill's.
.

Great hotel room but can be really overpriced depending on when you go. I came here over Memorial Day weekend with a few people. I loved the hotel room but they charge for everything! For a roll-away bed was an extra $20 per night, you couldn't even use the mini-fridge without being charged. 

There are some perks that included it was in a central location, minutes from the strip. They host Rehab, which is a concert. When I came Drake and Lil Wayne was there but guests still have to wait in line to get their complimentary tickets that are for only 2 guests. And make sure you get in line early because prices double, they will stop selling tickets, and the line will be close to 2 hours and up to get a ticket. Then the casino, restaurants, and night club in the hotel so you don't have to leave the hotel at all to have a good time! 

After all of that  I'll still try another hotel next time I'm in Vegas or try on a less crowded weekend.

We commenced our culinary excursion with an order of Waffle Fry Nachos, which featured an abundance of waffle fries enrobed in a rich, velvety blanket of white cheddar and sloppy joe, further accentuated by a tangy salsa and spicy jalapenos. Although delectable, I might suggest to the kitchen staff that they refrain from incorporating the sloppy joe in future iterations, as its presence proved somewhat superfluous and detracted from the overall enjoyment of the dish. 

In contrast, my companion opted for the Crispy Four Cheese Burger, a gastronomic masterpiece characterized by a symphony of four distinct cheeses, each carefully fused onto the patty to create a delightfully crunchy and creamy amalgamation. While the brioche bun proved somewhat overwhelming and desiccated, the burger itself was skillfully prepared, boasting a perfect balance of flavors and textures. Notably, my spouse preferred the onion roll, selecting a beef patty adorned with pepper jack cheese, jalapenos, and caramelized onions, all situated upon the aforementioned onion roll. The resulting dish was exquisitely crafted, bursting with flavor and juiciness.

Unfortunately, our experience was marred by sluggish service, a common pitfall for establishments in their nascent stages. However, we remained optimistic that with time, the kinks would be ironed out, leading to a more seamless and satisfying dining experience for future patrons.

A-OK describes Steve's Greenhouse Grill perfectly in my opinion. It's somewhat like a Cracker Barrel minus the company backing and plus sports... a rather kitsch design scheme with loud colors, loud TVs, and loud alcohol advertisements hung all around, a large and  eclectic menu with something that will surely please all types of eaters, your very typical bar menu of slightly overpriced drinks, and somewhat over the top servers singing praise over every single menu item (\"You can't go wrong!\" \"They're all my favorite!\"). I had some chicken fried steak with fries and Kristen G. had \"The Special\", which was fish and chips with a bowl of New England clam chowder. Everything was A-OK. Some things were a little salty, some things were just right, some too bland... I'm telling you, if you took a Cracker Barrel, cut the budget by three quarters, and told the manager to attempt to please every kind of patron that would be walking around this area of Phoenix, you would get Steve's Greenhouse Grill.

Like others in the surrounding vicinity, we patiently awaited and attentively observed as this particular space underwent transformation into Central Bistro, boasting a captivating ambiance that, while quite vibrant, was not without its auditory intensity; with the windows open, allowing the gentle breeze to permeate the establishment, it was truly sublime. However, one cannot help but ponder the potential impact on the sonic landscape once the windows are sealed, effectively enclosing the space.  
The culinary offerings were undoubtedly delectable, and the service was generally satisfactory, yet one glaring concern marred our overall experience: during two separate visits, we noticed bartenders engaged in the preparation of garnishes with uncovered hands, exemplified by the peeling of an orange, resulting in the release of juice that flowed down their arms and hands, followed by the slicing of said fruit for use in various beverages. Moreover, during our most recent visit, a bartender was observed inserting his hand directly into an olive jar, retrieving a handful, and depositing them into the garnish tray, prompting us to swiftly remove the olives from our martini.  
To the esteemed personnel of Central Bistro, we implore you to address these issues forthwith, lest a visit from the Maricopa County health authorities prove problematic.

I decided I would like all my dining to be done at the bar of old renovated homes in downtown Phoenix.  Lucky me, I found Coronado Cafe.
We stopped in for lunch so I did not order as much food as I normally like to when trying out a new restaurant ( it was a work day ).  Unfortunately, I will only be reviewing on item.  I'll make it up to you; I promise.
We went during lunch and there was a wait for a table for two, so we sat at the bar.  The place is pretty small.  The bar was big enough for four people, five tops.  There was a nice selection of spirits and wine that I could see but not drink.  I ordered the roasted chicken sandwich and chose the potato salad over the baked beans.  It was deliciously moist and the chiles had the right amount of heat.  The potato salad was very tasty satisfying side.
It was a simple, satisfying lunch.  I would like to come back another time when they aren't as busy.  It was hard to get a server/bartender's attention and there's some cozy seating outside that's too hot to use at lunch in August.

"Concurring with both Pierre and Donald, I must emphasize that there are indeed two menu items worthy of consideration. Whenever I opt for takeout, I invariably select the lettuce wedge and the willy burger, as they prove to be consistently satisfying options. It is unfortunate, however, that the steak dishes fail to meet expectations, as the chef's heavy-handed application of a certain seasoning renders the meat inedible. Furthermore, there appears to be a fundamental misunderstanding regarding the distinction between medium rare and well done, leading to an unfortunate disparity between my order and the actual preparation of the rib-eye. Notwithstanding these shortcomings, I must admit that the bread, when served fresh from the oven, boasts an impressive quality. Additionally, the wrap up burgers merit praise, while the lettuce wedge remains an undisputed highlight of the menu."

Liked this place. Went on a Sunday so the guy didn't make much because he said their slow on Sundays. We tried a little bit of everything and liked it. I would have given more stars but the service was bad, maybe the guy was in a bad mood, not sure. Make sure you have somewhere to eat after you buy the poke unless you want to eat outside in the Vegas heat! No indoor seating. Would recommend you come here to pick up poke because overall the food was good.

"Satisfactory victuals are proffered at this establishment, with prices that are reasonable and within the means of most patrons. My spouse and I opted to partake of a morning repast at this venue, situated in the midst of a workweek, subsequent to perusing numerous laudatory assessments. We were particularly eager to sample one of their loaves of bread, which had been the subject of extensive acclaim. 

Upon our arrival, we were pleased to discover that there was no waiting period, as the restaurant was only moderately occupied. Our server was exceptional, exhibiting a combination of cordiality, attention to detail, and promptness. 

The menu presented a diverse array of options, which led to a certain degree of perplexity on our part, as each item appeared equally appealing. Following a prolonged deliberation, I elected to indulge in Jamm's French Toast, while my better half selected an omelet. 

In conclusion, the culinary offerings were adequate, albeit perhaps not exceptional. It is conceivable that we did not select the most suitable dishes from the menu. As there are numerous alternative establishments serving breakfast in Las Vegas that remain to be experienced, it is unlikely that we will return to this particular venue in the future."

SO much better now that they have changed the entrance. The girls line used to make you hike up 5 stories of industrial parking garage-esque stairs only to make you hike up another 2 floors to the main dance floor. Now, they just make you take a random guest elevator to a random floor where you have to navigate through a freaking pool-side concert and up another flight of stairs to the promised land. So yay. 

I still hate the tiny dance floor that they close off access to, and the inability to even see the dance floor when the place gets crowded. If you want any room to stand and breathe, you have to go outside, which is quite suboptimal in the winter. 

Thus it is OBVIOUS that the same lunatics who designed TAO designed this place as well. No flow, no ambiance, no comfortable partying to be had. Back to XS it is!

Upon venturing out with a coterie of companions on a Sunday evening, we encountered a diminutive entrance that led to a cozy interior, albeit somewhat cramped in terms of spatial expanse. However, an external area was also available, featuring a heating apparatus that rendered the ambiance pleasant for our gathering. The menu presented an extensive array of culinary options, allowing each member of our party to select a distinct dish tailored to their individual tastes. Notwithstanding the generous proportions of each item, we were mindful of the potential difficulties that multiple dishes on a relatively small table might pose in terms of maneuverability during consumption. Nonetheless, we relished the fare, particularly the potable served in a metallic receptacle, which exhibited a profusion of sauce that lent a rich, velvety texture to the cuisine. While the hospitality we received was not without its shortcomings, the overall experience proved satisfying.

Great pizza, HORRIBLE customer service. The black girl at the cash register did not acknowledge my presence when I came up and was very rude when she did. After I paid for my slice, I asked if I should just sit down and she just rolled her eyes at me. No answer, nothing. 

One guy, kind of reddish hair actually greeted me when I walked in and the man making pizzas behind the window actually said thank you to me, but at one point I heard the red haired boy and the black girl get into it because she was yelling at him before he walked out for a delivery. Very unprofessional.

Not to mention how dirty this place was. I couldn't find a table that wasn't filthy and when I ordered my pizza, it was from a pie that was just sitting out on a stool and thrown in the oven for a couple minutes. 

Good pizza, but please work on the customer service.

"Halting our culinary excursion at this establishment for a brief interlude, my spouse and I opted to partake in a sweet indulgence, as her fondness for red velvet cupcakes is unparalleled. Arriving post-luncheon on a Sunday, our expectations were tempered by the meager assortment available. Notwithstanding the dearth of options, each cupcake commanded a price of three dollars, a sum hardly exorbitant for an eatery purporting to offer gourmet confections. \n\nWhile the cupcakes did indeed boast an abundance of frosting, my own sample featured an incongruous caramel flavor that fell short of my expectations. Furthermore, the red velvet varieties were conspicuously devoid of cream cheese frosting, a characteristic that might have elevated their appeal. In conclusion, while not without merit, our experience proved underwhelming."

"An ideal location for culinary indulgence within the confines of the Phoenix airport, this eatery boasts a hospitable ambiance, an accommodating staff, and a delectable menu offering an array of savory delights. My personal preference was the grilled chicken-stuffed pita, complemented by a fresh lettuce and tomato salad, creamy hummus, and a tangy vinaigrette dressing. Additionally, they provide charging stations for convenience. A veritable gastronomic haven amidst the hustle and bustle of air travel."

"The club boasted an ambiance of unparalleled elegance, which was undoubtedly enhanced by the predominantly masculine demographic that comprised the clientele on the evening in question, given that my particular industry's trade exhibition was concurrently being hosted in the vicinity, resulting in an anomalously skewed gender ratio that was decidedly disproportionate, with a veritable plethora of gentlemen in attendance, in contrast to a marked dearth of feminine presence, rendering the atmosphere decidedly testosterone-charged, to say the least; however, despite the conspicuous absence of estrogenic influence, the experience remained enjoyable, as I had the opportunity to socialize and imbibe libations in the company of both acquaintances and colleagues, as well as the occasional visually striking female model, albeit at a price point that could be considered somewhat prohibitive, and with a potency that left something to be desired, yet, notwithstanding these drawbacks, I would still consider returning, provided that entry was not contingent upon an exclusive familiarity or connections, as the case may be, with the establishment's gatekeepers, which, regrettably, appeared to be the prevailing policy during most instances."

I was looking for best Peking duck in town and found Blossom. According to our server, it takes 2 days to prepare. I had a very high expectation for this place since it is $79 per duck. Fyi: I had pecking duck from one of the best Peking duck restuarant in Beijing. The duck was served with skin and meat and sauce on a wrap. Ummm. It should be served with skin only? The skin is not crispy enough. The sauce is ok. After that the duck was brought back to chop. The meat was juicy but have a bit of distinct smell of the duck. Overall, the Peking duck is better than other places in So cal like duck house. But it is far from comparable to the Peking duck I had in Beijing.  And for the price, I would expect better quality.

Always exemplary. Unequivocally eschew the pasta entrÃ©e. Lamentably unimpressive. 
  Moreover, they purport to serve a Pizzookie that is ostensibly half-cooked; regrettably, it was not even partially prepared, with an unacceptable level of doneness barely surpassing a meager twenty percent. 
  I brought this to the attention of our server (whose name was Thomas, I believe), who responded with an apathetic and dismissive attitude, callously stating, âItâs supposed to be like that,â?before hastily departing, leaving us feeling ignored and disrespected. 
  Consequently, owing to the subpar service we received, our rating has been downgraded from its previous standing of four or five stars. However, we remain optimistic that future visits may yield more satisfactory experiences.

Came here on a Thurs night and there was no wait for dinner. They had a fancy dinner menu with fish, poultry and meats, but we opted for their lighter fare summer dinner menu which had sandwiches, pastas and pizzas. We tried the chicken buffalo wing \"lollipops\" as our appetizer, it was your run of the mill buffalo wings but prepared so that one end was the bone and the other end was the chicken which made it super easy to eat. I'm big on italian food so I was trying to decide between either the pizza or pasta and ended up choosing the \"pasta a la bolognaise\" which was a huge mistake. It was penne-like pasta with tomato and meat sauce which looked like something I could have made and I'm not a cook. It wasn't horrible but I just wasn't expecting something so mediocre in taste and presentation. Portions were big though, I'll give them that. Service was good and the pizzas at the surrounding tables looked good so I would probably try that next time if I ever came back.

"As an individual who adheres to a vegetarian dietary preference and has a penchant for light beverages, my patronage of Alchemy is predicated upon the establishment's willingness to accommodate my culinary inclinations, which, in recent times, they have endeavored to do by augmenting their menu with an increased variety of vegetarian options. However, I must confess that my expectations were not entirely met during my most recent visit, as the menu's emphasis on Southeast Asian cuisine struck me as somewhat incongruous and, regrettably, the Vietnamese Rice Noodle Salad that I opted to sample fell short of my gastronomical standards, thereby necessitating my advice to potential patrons to exercise caution in their selection."

Not a bad place to hang out or swing by for dinner, but it's pretty pricey in terms of drinks and the food is meh. Sandwiches are always very salty and the meat doesn't seem so fresh. However, if you're here just for beer or UFC night, it is a pretty decent place to relax with friends. Karaoke night is fun too.

This establishment is evolving into a hub for local hipster students, where the consumption of tea has become a trendy phenomenon. Indeed, the contemporary parlance among youth dictates that tea is now considered "cool," or whatever colloquialism is en vogue at present. The crux of this success lies in the fact that everything about the establishment exudes vitality and youthfulness, a stark contrast to the conventional, dimly lit tea houses that have historically been associated with an older demographic. Upon my initial visit, I harbored some reservations, which were promptly addressed by a remarkably young staff member who suggested that I seek answers online. Although somewhat taken aback by the response, I opted to reserve judgment until a subsequent visit.  
Upon my return, I was greeted by employees who were eager to provide me with what they termed the "DavidsTea experience" - an encounter characterized by an atmosphere of freshness, liveliness, and an unmistakable sense of excitement. It became apparent that patrons could either purchase tea for home consumption or opt for a more portable variety. The prices for the latter were conspicuously displayed, with each selection labeled at $2.50. While some might consider this price point to be steep, I rationalized that the cost was justified given the reputed benefits of tea consumption. Thus, I elected to sample a chocolate-orange blend, augmented by whisked soy milk and agave, at a total cost of $4.50. However, my enthusiasm was tempered by the realization that nearly every aspect of the tea-making process was seemingly optional, leading me to wonder if the price was truly worthwhile. Furthermore, I couldn't help but feel a twinge of dismay as I watched the tea-making specialist discard any excess brew into a sink, rather than allowing it to be savored by those who might appreciate its flavor. Notwithstanding these misgivings, I must admit that the tea was quite palatable. Nonetheless, I cannot help but regard this establishment as more of a convenient stopover for a hasty caffeine fix, rather than a setting conducive to lingering over a leisurely cup of tea. Additionally, the space tends to become congested rather quickly, making it challenging to fully enjoy the ambiance. While the shop does offer a diverse array of tea-related accoutrements, I would advise against purchasing a glass kettle from them, as the prices appear to be inflated.

"Acknowledged, I shall proceed with an update pertaining to the economical rental car service offered by Thrifty. It appears that my experience necessitated the utilization of their roadside assistance program, specifically due to an unforeseen encounter with a large nail that had somehow become magnetized to my rear right tire. Fortunately, the promptness of their roadside service proved to be within a five-minute timeframe. Furthermore, upon contacting their customer service department at the corporate level, I was impressed by their exceptional proficiency in facilitating an expedited exchange of vehicles. Notably, the entire process required less than thirty minutes, and I was afforded the opportunity to select the replacement vehicle of my choice. It is apparent that Thrifty has made significant strides in enhancing their customer service, leading me to surmise that they may have taken my previous review into consideration."

"I had the occasion to partake in a professional sojourn at this establishment earlier this year, and my experience was somewhat lackluster. The check-in process was tediously slow and appeared to be plagued by an antiquated system, which contributed to the prolonged delay. Furthermore, there was an issue with the delivery of a package I had requested, which was not only late but also seemingly misplaced within the premises. Despite the aforementioned setbacks, I did sample the culinary offerings of one of the on-site cafes, specifically the one renowned for its delectable pastries. However, the persistent French theme became somewhat tiresome after a couple of days. In terms of the accommodations themselves, they were adequate, perhaps slightly superior to the standard fare typically encountered. Nonetheless, my overall impression of the hotel was rather unremarkable, and I would not consider it as a prime choice for a personal vacation."

"I transiently entered this establishment with the intention of ascertaining whether they possessed any antenna balls; however, upon inquiring, it became apparent that they were momentarily depleted and awaiting restocking, though the precise timing of their replenishment remained uncertain. Despite being presented with a visual representation of the item in question, my comprehension of its appearance remained limited. During my brief sojourn within the premises, I opted to consume a Jumbo Jack, which, much to my satisfaction, proved to be flavorsome and provided me with a fleeting experience of JITB that, regrettably, cannot be obtained in Canada."

I was not thoroughly impressed by this establishment. It possesses an unremarkable ambiance reminiscent of a Fox restaurant within the Scottsdale Quarter. 
  The menu exhibits limited options and lacks comprehensive descriptions. The culinary offerings are unexceptional and fail to tantalize my taste buds. I opted for the roasted chicken, influenced by my server's description of it as "half a chicken," which led me to anticipate the presence of breast meat. However, I was disappointed to receive a meager thigh and drumstick, accompanied by an excessive amount of sodium-saturated baby spinach and runny polenta. 
  While the dishes appeared inventive, their flavors fell short of impressive. This dining experience proved to be underwhelming. 
  Observing the waitstaff, I noticed a sense of disarray, as they presented us with various appetizers that we had not ordered. This raises concerns about the potential impact on TK's profit margin. Nevertheless, they seem to compensate for it through modest portion sizes. 
  In conclusion, this restaurant does not warrant a repeat visit in my opinion.

"Satisfactory Chinese take-out experience with a few notable exceptions.  The Lo Mein entrÃ©e was palatable, as were the beef and shrimp dishes.  However, the shrimp and lobster sauce did not meet my expectations, and the pork ribs were inconsistent in terms of tenderness, with some bites being too fatty.  Additionally, the Wonton soup and egg drop soup failed to impress.  On the other hand, the fried rice was above average, although it is worth noting that I have generally been pleased with fried rice dishes at various establishments."

"I recently had the privilege of visiting the authentic location in Fort Lauderdale, and let me tell you, it was an unforgettable experience. The cuisine was exquisite, and the ambiance was truly captivating. However, my recent visit to this particular location fell short of my expectations. Despite being a busy Wednesday evening in Florida, the atmosphere was lackluster, and the quality of the food did not live up to the standards set by its predecessor. 

The meatball was disappointingly dry, and the pasta was undercooked. Although the chicken parmesan was palatable, it failed to impress me. The sauce, however, remained a highlight. 

It's intriguing to observe that the vast majority of favorable reviews for this establishment mention Steve's presence. Perhaps his involvement does have a bearing on the quality. I recall him meticulously examining nearly every dish that emerged from the kitchen at the original location. Unfortunately, such attention to detail was absent during my visit. 

Consequently, I shall confer three stars upon this eatery. While our server was attentive, the culinary offerings did not measure up to the lofty standards established by its sister restaurant. I must confess that I am unlikely to return to this specific location, given the abundance of exceptional dining options in Las Vegas. Nonetheless, my anticipation for my subsequent visit to the Florida location remains unwavering!"

Gave Chang's another chance this week, and this time the service was much better. Quite friendly and efficient, as a matter of fact. Shared the Salt and Pepper Prawns and Shrimp Fried Rice, and both were delicious. I've always liked their food. No, it's not the greatest or most original Asian food around, but it's pretty good. It's the service that I've struggled with - but if they're able to maintain the level they displayed the other day, I will definitely continue to grace their restaurant with my presence. Ha!\n\nOh, also told our waiter about my fortune-less fortune cookie on my last visit, and he apologized profusely, said they got a bad batch last month in which one out of every three cookies was empty. The problem had been resolved, he assured me, and sure enough this time I got a fortune. Not a very good one, something about me having a deep appreciation of the arts and music (Well, duh), but hey, it was a fortune. Sort of. Ok, not really. But it was a saying on a little piece of paper, which was all I really wanted..

"The embellishments alone solidify the transaction for me. Mid-Century contemporary, and the eatery is executed impeccably. Preferred destination for socializing with a companion and engaging in conversation. The booths provide an unparalleled sense of seclusion. The chopped salad is my consistent selection due to my profound admiration for it. The green goddess dressing is sublime. They offer rolls and butter, and these particular specimens are authentic; a true blast from the past... extraordinarily soft and warm! I may be developing a dependency on iced tea (the jury is still deliberating) and I find myself enchanted by its presentation here...a sizable, towering glass, mint, a side of simple syrup for customized sweetening, and an iced tea spoon! It's the uncomplicated aspects at times that significantly enhance my encounter :) Uncertain if they continue to offer this, but their cake & a shake for dessert is utterly captivating. Minuscule chocolate shake presented alongside a minuscule chocolate cake. A flawless petite indulgence!"
Is a family restauran nothing exaiting the place is ok but she burn my Padd see u every time and i stop eating there

"Although the culinary offerings at this establishment are satisfactory, they fail to meet the exceptionally high standards of gastronomic excellence synonymous with premier steakhouses in Scottsdale. The pricing, however, remains on par with its more illustrious counterparts, thereby creating an expectation of comparable quality that, unfortunately, is not fully realized. While the fare served here is undoubtedly palatable, it falls short of the uncompromising benchmark set by other top-tier restaurants, such as City Hall, where the culinary prowess is unparalleled. Notwithstanding, this venue does differentiate itself through a few unique touches, such as the popover bread, and some of its primary dishes, which provide a welcome respite from the norm. Nonetheless, the steaks, though certainly enjoyable, do not attain the pinnacle of gustatory perfection, and the overall quality remains somewhat inconsistent. Despite these limitations, the possibility of a future visit still exists, albeit with the hope of a slight improvement, but it is unlikely to rank among the top three steakhouses in Scottsdale."

"This location possesses an ambiance that exudes both coolness and affordability, yet it is essential to recognize that the quality of the merchandise is commensurate with the price point. I acquired a keychain for my mother at a cost of twelve dollars, only to witness its sudden demise approximately one week subsequent to my purchase, during which time I was in close proximity. Following this unfortunate occurrence, I opted to exchange it for a replacement, but unfortunately, the new item suffered a similar fate, breaking once again after a brief period of time. Considering my previous experiences, I decided to procure a gift card, given that I had paid in cash and lacked both the receipt and any tangible evidence of my purchase. It is important to acknowledge that this establishment can be somewhat unpredictable, as certain items are reasonably priced, while others may not be worth the investment. Furthermore, due to its location within Tivoli, there are numerous parking options available."

"It is the team of employees who are responsible for the smooth operation of this retail establishment, and it is their exceptional level of customer service that motivates me to return time and time again, as they consistently strive to surpass expectations by providing assistance that extends beyond the scope of their assigned duties."

This is the closest Dairy Queen to me, so my brother and I frequent here a lot. We mainly go for the shakes and blizzards as well as the ice cream cakes when it's someone's birthday. The ones that we've tried are actually pretty delicious. The only reason I didn't give it five stars is because the people who work here are 90% crap whenever we come here. There are a lot of times where I've encountered rude staff, but it's not something that I can't tolerate. I go for the food anyway and not the service.

Once upon a time, you could walk into Uncle Sal's on a Friday night with no reservations and be seated immediately. (Holy crap - has it really been 20 years since I lived in the area?!?!)
Those days are long gone. Dinner was on me for coordinating - and I dropped the ball.

Luckily, the Blind Pig was right next door, and we 4 hungry patrons could be seated and served right away.

We shared a couple plated for the table, and nibbled each other's entrees. The steak salad was a winner. The short rib was well cooked and flavorful. And everything else was perfectly OK. I had a trio of tacos  - none of which really stood out. Nothing wrong with them. Fresh, flavorful, well executed. I am just spoiled by other places in my current 'hood.

If I am in the area, and someone suggests the Blind Pig, I won't object. 
I also don't think I'd plan another meal there. Nothing in the world wrong with the place - just no "wow" factor for me.

The first night we arrived, it was close to midnight and this place was still open and serving.  Service was a little slow, but understandable for it being 12am and with a party of 12.  I don't even remember what I had there [I think a steak?], but the highlight of the meal was the fact that they did serve up a mean cup of fresh watermelon juice.

Although service was a little slow, it was still friendly and courteous.  Prices are a tad pricey for a "Cafe", but expected for a place like Aria.  We later discovered Aria's room service, the buffet and then we finally wised up and tried the local cuisine instead to save $.

Not bad, but not worth it.  =(

If you take a plate of breakfast potatoes, au gratin potatoes, and vegetable chow mein, then you cover the whole thing in melted  butter, what do you get?  You get the reason why the terrorists hate America... 

The place was clean, the service was decent, and the food choices was what I expected for a downtown LV casino buffet: ordinary and plentiful.

But the large vat of melted butter?  You can put that sh*t on everything!

This is the place you want to go after a night of drinking. The food is typical Mexican food. The drive thru was quick and efficient. The major issue i had with this location is that the portion size on my Carne Asada fries was ridiculously small. Every other location i've been to usually gives you a good chunk of everything, but this location really got  stingy. That was a major disappointment. Ill revisit again in a couple of weeks and ill see if i have the same experience.

"The culinary experience was somewhat unremarkable, with the burgers exhibiting a satisfactory level of taste and texture, while the onion rings demonstrated a commendable degree of crispiness. However, the prices charged for these edibles were somewhat prohibitive, given the relatively unexceptional nature of the fare provided, particularly when juxtaposed with the elevated standards of gastronomic excellence commonly associated with the city of Las Vegas."
No complaints about the food or service. I can think of a few places in Vegas that make a better burger for a better price.

This location is between my house and my parents' house so I'm a frequent visitor. Between my 2 girls and I, the drink orders can be quite challenging and this location is sort of hit or miss. The ever changing staff could be the culprit, but nonetheless the convenience of the location still draws me in. The lines tend to get long during the morning commute, yet they seem to move people through pretty quickly. On the occasion that I've had to send drinks back, they have been very apologetic and cooperative.

Came here on a friday night for drinks. Fun place to check out. People said its like being at a beach, definitely didnt get that feeling. However, drinks were good. Bartender didnt make a three wise men correctly. DJ played really good music. Probly wont come here for tacos though.

"Without encountering a delay, we were able to secure entry, which is partially attributed to its association with the Westin Hotel. Although the ambiance of the OFM exudes an air of refinement, it appears that the patronage has opted to venture elsewhere. 

Our server exhibited exceptional hospitality and provided us with recommendations on what to order. Upon inquiring about suitable sushi rolls to initiate the meal, he suggested a pair of options that harmonized effectively. Both variants were tuna-based, with one showcasing a milder flavor profile while the other offered a spicier experience. Indeed, OFM's sushi offerings live up to their acclaimed reputation. 

Subsequently, we placed orders for our primary dishes, and my selection was the cioppino. Now, my customary expectation of cioppino entails a hearty stew featuring chunks of fish immersed in a savory broth. Nonetheless, the culinary expert at OFM chose to present an entire slab of mahi, resting atop a shallow layer of the broth and accompanied by assorted shellfish. While the dish was prepared proficiently, the unconventional presentation (absence of a genuine stew) left me yearning for a more comprehensive experience. 

The caesar salad demonstrated a commendable quality, boasting authentic anchovies positioned atop. 

The Hawaiian waluu entrÃ©e garnered approval from those who sampled it. 

Likewise, the crab cakes were described as quite delectable. 

In summary, the visit transpired in a pleasant and tranquil atmosphere, complemented by hospitable service. However, a revitalization of the menu items, excluding the sushi, may be necessary to elevate OFM's culinary experience to compete with the latest establishments in the area."

"Upon my return on multiple occasions subsequent to the transition of ownership, I have observed a marked improvement in the quality of service, precipitating an upward adjustment in my rating. The reinstatement of certain culinary artisans previously associated with the establishment has contributed significantly to the enhancement of the dining experience. While the proprietor's persistent presence near the sushi bar may engender a sense of scrutiny regarding the portioning of seafood delicacies, it is my belief that a visit to this restaurant is indeed warranted."

"I placed an order for two eggs and potatoes, which amounted to a mere $3.85, a veritable bargain!  Upon requesting that my eggs be scrambled, they arrived accompanied by home fries and toast.  While my meal may have lacked a certain je ne sais quoi, it is indeed challenging to botch such fundamental fare as eggs, toast, and potatoes. 

The eggs and toast, while unremarkable, were adequate â?a far cry from the uninspired effort exhibited in the preparation of the home fries.  It appeared that someone had merely boiled some potatoes, carelessly plunked them into a pan, and then served them without so much as a cursory seasoning.  My futile attempts to enhance their flavor with salt and pepper notwithstanding, the potatoes seemed resolute in their blandness.  After a few half-hearted forkfuls, I relinquished my efforts.  

My visit took place during a morning meeting, and the establishment was relatively unfrequented.  Although there were a smattering of regular patrons present, the ambiance was generally subdued.  It is conceivable that this venue might appeal to individuals seeking sustenance following a night of revelry, when the craving for nourishment often surpasses concerns regarding culinary refinement.  However, I would not deliberately seek out Ritters except in the event of an unexpected late-night hunger pang or the need for a 24-hour eatery.  It is worth noting that payment is restricted to cash transactions."

You know - I wanted to write "I love Sunset Grille", but then I thought about it and it really occurred to me that I don't love Sunset Grille.  I like Sunset Grille, and I will return to Sunset Grille, but it's not my favorite place in Charlotte.  

It's OK.  The service is great, the layout is cool and it appears to have a happening bar if you hit it at the right time.  Food-wise, it's just OK.  I love breakfast sandwiches (and you should try this place for brunch...), but they do not have a typical breakfast sandwich, which was disappointing.  I had an Eggs Benedict's, sans Hollandaise (because you should not really eat that in a restaurant unless you know they made it right then - Thanks Anthony Bourdain for that tip).  The canadian bacon was really, really, really salty though.  

Other things I have had: An open face turkey sandwich, which now that I think about it - was salty too.  I also tried a blackbean burger with fries that was OK.  

So, as I wrote above - the more I think about it, Sunset is OK.  They try hard and are extremely attentive there, but there are better places for food in my opinion.
