I love Thai food.  The food here is okay, the price is too much for the portions at lunch.  I told him I did not want it too spicy, he did not add any seasonings.  I may go back just not on my dime.

After complaining about NC BBQ in another review, I feel guilty admitting that the chicken sandwich here was not too bad. The fried pickle was delicious, firm and warm and just the right amount of batter. I'd go back just for the pickle! The price was okay for an airport establishment and afterwards I could enjoy the free wi-fi (and power source) from one of the rocking chairs. Charlotte Airport is not too bad, and this restaurant is worth a stop.

"Culinary excellence. An atmosphere marred by excessive commotion and a dearth of seating due to inadequate table clearance, resulting in an environment that falls short of the tranquility and aesthetic appeal typically associated with establishments offering comparable gastronomic experiences at slightly higher price points."

Maybe the novelty of In-n-Out has worn off on me. I didn't find this location to be any different than the ones I used to eat at in California, but I guess my tastes have matured. For all the hype and history, in the end it's just a fast food burger (although a decent one).

I made the mistake of arriving for my 11PM reservation with a hangover, so I didn't quite get to enjoy the full excellence. Seating was very cramped, but in full view of the kitchen, which made the experience much more enjoyable. Food was good, but expect to spend $$$. \n\nOh, and make reservations EARLY. The night before my reservation someone offered me $500 for it, so that's a good indication of the popularity of the place.

The BEST THING about this hotel is the made-to-order breakfast.  We received a ticket to take down to the dining room and selected an entree:  eggs, french toast, or pancakes, which came with potatoes and sausage or bacon.  Also provided is a selection of cereals, oatmeal, bread/toast, muffin, and fruit, as well as juice, milk and coffee.

The LOCATION is great!  It's right across (a block or so away) from the mall and several restaurants; it is also right off the interstate too.   

We liked how spacious THE ROOM was (King with sleeper sofa)  The room was like a little studio/efficiency with a full refrigerator, stove, and microwave.  The room was clean.

The not-so-good things are as follows:

1.  The room felt stuffy every time we entered.  We kicked up the air conditioning but got too cold.  There was no happy medium for crisp, cool air at a comfortable temperature.  

2.  The pillows were flat; using two pillows didn't help.  

3.  The stairs are steep in this two-story hotel, which lacks an elevator.  If you have trouble with stairs or have lots of luggage, you may be better off to request something on the first floor.

OVERALL, this is a very decent place to stay.  It's not too expensive; it's not too fancy; and it provides an amicable atmosphere for an overnight stay.

Apparently this is the largest restaurant in the state of Arizona. From the outside and the dining area I ate in, could have fooled me. A good friend of mine was working his last shift as a server so that is why I went. Not a huge fan of steakhouses. 

The atmosphere was pretty throw-back, 70s vibe, someplace your grandpa and dad would take you for your first real steak experience. It was dark inside and they sitting area had a retro feel like an Arizona mobster may be biting down into his steak right next to you. I was told there's a lot of history in the building so I respected the decor. 

I order a wonderful shrimp salad that came topped with the biggest, juiciest shrimps I've seen in a long time. I saved them for last because they were so crunchy to eat. My roommate ordered a sirloin and sadly had to send it back twice to get it recooked. Our wiater said that wsn't the first time that evening that had happened with someone's food and that particular chef. But the bread basket made up for it. With wonderful rosemary topped, the bread was light and buttery. 

Best part of the night? Check in on Foursquare and you can get a beer for .5 cents at the bar. We knew the waiter so he hooked us up at the table, but I have NEVER seen a deal that insane on Fourswaure before.

"Our most recent dining excursion to this esteemed establishment proved to be somewhat disparate from our previous visits, as various aspects of the experience appeared to be somewhat disorganized and lacking in coherence. Specifically, there was a considerable delay in being seated, despite having made a reservation well in advance, and certain technical issues pertaining to the processing of our club benefits arisen, which hindered our ability to fully enjoy the dining experience. Furthermore, the Caesar salad we ordered was of an inferior quality and quantity compared to our expectations, and the lobster entree we shared failed to meet our expectations in terms of both its size and visual appeal. Throughout the meal, we encountered numerous minor yet cumulatively significant mishaps and inconsistencies, leading us to surmise that perhaps there have been some recent changes within the restaurant's management or staff that may have contributed to the overall feeling of 'glitchiness' that permeated our visit. Despite these issues, the taste and preparation of the food remained satisfactory, and we shall indeed return to this establishment in the future, albeit with a heightened sense of vigilance and caution, in light of the aforementioned anomalies."

Steak and Eggs!!!

After a night of drinking and dancing, this is the place to stop by before heading back to the hotel.  Cheap food (although not the best quality... but you get what you pay for) and a place to rest your head while waiting for the food.

Usually there is a long waiting line because everyone has the same agenda as you (eat before going back to their hotel), but if you put your name on the list and wait around, you will see that the people ahead of you in line will start to disappear because they are tired of waiting or a slot machine nearby was calling their name.  LOL

I procured an almond taro milk tea, which proved to be moderately satisfactory. Nonetheless, the popcorn chicken did not conform to my preconceived notions of its composition, and I was left with an abundance of breaded fragments.

This marked my maiden visit to Smash Em Up, Bash Em Up Burger, and I must say that the staff members were incredibly cordial when taking my order, and they were quite forthcoming regarding the estimated time of preparation for the culinary delights.  I opted for the signature Classic Smash 1/3 pounder, which, while delectable, was not cooked to my precise specifications, as I would have preferred it to be slightly more well-done.  It did strike me as somewhat surprising that the restaurant's personnel did not inquire about my desired level of doneness, especially considering the $10 price point.  Although the victuals were indeed scorching hot and flavorful, I could not help but feel that their visual appeal was somewhat lacking, relative to the cost.  For a marginally lower price, I might be inclined to favor Culver's over this establishment.  The eatery's aesthetic can best be described as minimalist, with an unmistakable corporate ambiance that permeates the premises.  My companion, who recommended this venue, and I were curious about the method of cooking employed by Smash Em Up, Bash Em Up, and we discovered that they utilize an 80/20 ground beef blend.  This revelation was mildly astonishing, given the slight sheen that the patties appeared to possess.  While I would not rule out a future visit, I must confess that this particular burger joint does not rank among my top five favorites.

"The poultry served at this establishment is among my preferred selections from any other rapid service eatery in the vicinity. The manner in which it is prepared, with its crispy exterior and southern-style seasoning, renders it exceptionally delectable. Furthermore, the restaurant boasts an impressive array of side dishes, encompassing mashed potatoes, various types of beans, coleslaw, and even macaroni and cheese (which, in my opinion, is the most superior option). 

However, despite the culinary excellence, the customer service provided by the staff leaves much to be desired. I have yet to encounter such a high concentration of individuals who appear to detest their occupations as I have at this specific location. Upon entering the premises, the cashier greets you with a haughty expression that seems to convey, 'HOW DARE YOU DEIGN TO PATRONIZE THIS ESTABLISHMENT.' It is almost as though they expect you to tender their firstborn child in exchange for your meal, rather than merely providing courteous and efficient service. 

Moreover, I strongly advise against utilizing the drive-thru option at this location, as my experiences have consistently demonstrated that the staff tends to botch orders or neglects to provide essential utensils. On top of that, the young woman manning the drive-thru window possesses an unsightly complexion, replete with acne, which can be quite off-putting and potentially ruin one's appetite."

"We arrived at this establishment on a Sunday afternoon with the intention of viewing a football game and partaking in a culinary experience. Fortunately, we were able to secure a seat at the bar in a relatively expeditious manner, which was certainly advantageous. 

The portions served here are quite generous, and the menu boasts an array of intriguing classic dishes as well as special items that deviate from the norm. However, the quality of the cuisine was merely satisfactory, fulfilling our hunger but failing to impress us culinarily. We would not recommend visiting this venue solely for its gastronomical offerings. 

Unfortunately, the service we received was subpar, as our server and bartender, Randi, despite her amiable demeanor, encountered difficulties when processing our payment. A complimentary code was involved, and the transaction proved problematic, prompting Randi to seek assistance from her manager. He devoted approximately 30-40 minutes attempting to resolve the issue but failed to communicate his progress, leaving us feeling neglected. Eventually, our meal was compensated for through gambling, and the manager successfully rectified the situation. While this establishment may be suitable for viewing sporting events, one should not harbor high expectations for a superior dining experience."

Some of the varieties of pizza taste much better then others.  However, none of them are overly great.  This location used to be much cleaner but it appears management may have changed and the service has gone downhill a bit.  I do find the cinnamon rolls to be addictively good though.  So I keep going back to get my fix.
It is a small crowded place serving inexpensive and ok food. But I think it is over rated in yelp.

Nothing to do on a summer night? Head out to a Hounds game. Prices are cheap - certainly more so than about any other sports team in the area, and most nights you'll get to hang out with a bunch of other folks and see and be seen.

The only problem? While lacrosse may be an up-and-coming sport, it's in the same boat as soccer when it comes to being a spectator: It just isn't that great to watch. That isn't to say that these guys don't play hard, because they do. But since there just isn't much to do other than hang out and watch them run around, and occasionally score, the best thing to do at a Hounds game is to socialize and enjoy a nice summer evening.

Also, huge kudos to the Hounds for making use of Memorial Stadium. Have to love that this oldie isn't going to waste, or even worse, being demolished to make use for some new development that may never even happen.

I give this pace 3.5 stars but can understand why some people give it 4. The food and service are 4 stars but the tapas are very overpriced. I have been in Spain many times and have tried many tapas (in fancy and not so fancy Spanish restaurants), but the prices in Jaleo are ridiculous particularly the cheese tapas. Highly recommend the paellas.

This place is alright. Kitschy name, fine food. Nothing spectacular at the bar. Nothing amazing on the menu. \n\nThis is a neighborhood bar, there are always regulars in. Not a bad sort, some of them can be quite drunk at times though.

"It was utterly impossible to consider purchasing a divided pizza due to the exorbitant cost, which was tantamount to an astronomical figure, rendering it unfeasible and unjustifiable to indulge in such an extravagance. The sum of twenty-six dollars for a single large pizza was nothing short of preposterous and egregious, especially when juxtaposed with the superior quality and comparatively reasonable pricing offered by Athens Pizza, located just down the road. In point of fact, the latter establishment's culinary offerings were not only more affordable but also boasted a markedly superior taste and overall experience for the consumer."

its always good to have some Chinese food after a few buffets...

came here for lunch... food is pricy for chinese food and dim sum... but i came here on comps... so it didnt matter...

the salmon cold noodle was superb... apart from that... everything is just slightly about average...
We all need a good British pub in our lives. The bar tenders are down to earth. No frills just drinks and ok food. Great to watch games and after work HH.

"Satisfactory legume and dairy amalgamation, albeit the dairy component lacks adequate thermal energy and optimal viscosity. Oil utilized in preparation constitutes a positive attribute, however, the absence of crispy fried tortilla fragments accompanying the piquant sauce of green hue is conspicuous by its absence. Folded corn tortillas containing copious amounts of shredded iceberg lettuce are a notable characteristic of the hard taco variant, yet the verdant leafy matter overshadows the other constituents, rendering the overall experience less than optimal."

3 Stars.

This place is big and I dig the decor.  It was cold so we did not go outside but there is an upstairs balcony area which apparently is pretty neat when the weather is appropriate.  There were two rooms with two different DJs.  One was just hip hop and the other was a top 40 type.  I actually thought the DJ in the top 40 (main room) was terrible...the guy had trouble beat matching playing top 40 stuff...lame.  Given that its Vegas and that it was New Years Day (not eve, but still) I would expect that some of the areas best DJs would be at most of these Vegas clubs.  Maybe he was just having a bad night.

I must say, in most clubs the staff/bouncers are rude as hell but they were quite nice here.  The cover charge if your a normal dude is $40 on the weekends and $20 for ladies.  STEEP!  Especially when that allows you to buy $10 beers at the bar.  I was not going to pay $60 to get me and my girl in.  The bouncer let my girl in for free and I just paid the $40 so for two people $20 a pop if you don't "know anyone" is normal Vegas club pricing I suppose   

I dont think I would go back unless I was staying at Ceaser's, not because it was a negative experience but I just think I would want to try a new club.

Just ate here (take out) and I had the pad tai and PH\u00d2.... The restaurant was bright and u could tell it was new it was very cute. Service was very very friendly and prompt. Pad tai was excellent everything I expected and I tried my friends beef which was also great... I mainly went there to get ph\u00f2 because we don't have any PH\u00d2 on the NW side and I was sick so ph\u00f2 was exactly what I needed... Boy oh boy was I disappointed!!! After reading all the reviews I was excited but when I opened the container to the broth it didn't smell like it usually smells so I sipped it and it tasted sweet and a little thick disgusting!!! It was also dark brown even though I ordered chicken ph\u00f2... I gave it the benefit of the doubt and added the noodles and spices and chicken like I like and tried it again but I couldn't bare the smell and taste... Instead I drained the juice and just ate the noodles... Would have given this place 5 stars if it wasn't for the terrible ph\u00f2... Maybe i went on a bad day?

"Inexpensive potations for a convivial interlude, indeed! A diminutive watering hole with authentic 'creekers'... very smoky and boisterous, teeming with dedicated imbibers. A veritable haven for local denizens. The diversion may be hit-or-miss, but the assemblage itself provides ample entertainment. On occasion, I have indulged in delectable fare on the premises. Complimentary popcorn within the indoor bar awaits those who venture forth. P.S. The dartboard leaves much to be desired; consider bringing your own plastic projectiles if you wish them to adhere properly. The staff exudes cordiality and proficiency, ensuring a hassle-free experience."

Best fast food in this area of T-bird and 59th Ave.  I don't know why Del-Taco even bothers to be there on the same corner.  

Chipotle is relaibly good quality food, especially the bean or veggie burritos.  However I don't like that they upcharge for the chips/salsa so much, because I'm spending nearly $8 for a simple burrito, coke, chips/salsa lunch.  

This location could do a better job at keeping the dining area clean.

I've been to Daisho sushi twice, once when it first opened, and earlier this evening. It was ok. Their nigiri was good & fresh, and their green tea ice cream was yummy. The service was ok, and the rolls we ordered didn't have much flavor. Perhaps we ordered the wrong rolls... Since I live across the street I thought I would give it a try, but I'll keep going to my regular sushi spot for the same AYCE price.

"Upon frequenting this establishment, I opted to investigate its offerings, despite not experiencing hunger pangs. My purchase consisted of a single loaf of sourdough bread, which, granted, may have been influenced by the proximity to the Christmas holiday, thus potentially contributing to an augmented patronage. Notwithstanding, the meager population within the premises at the time of my arrival did not exceed ten individuals, yet I endured a protracted waiting period of approximately ten minutes prior to completing my transaction. Admittedly, my patience waned, and had I tarried any longer, I would have departed the location without acquiring the coveted bread. It is my conviction that the employees demonstrated sluggishness, which, in my experience, is undesirable in the realm of retail, particularly when dealing with a fundamental commodity such as bread. However, I must acknowledge that the quality of the sourdough bread was quite satisfactory, and I would consider continuing to procure my bread from this venue in the future, provided that the cashiers enhance their efficiency."

My family and I have an ardent affinity for the culinary offerings at this establishment, and we typically procure our sustenance through the convenience of the drive-thru window. Our orders have consistently been prepared to our satisfaction, with the food being fresh, hot, and delectable. However, of late, the elderly female employee with the heavily pencil-thin eyebrows, who has been tasked with the responsibility of attending to customers at the drive-thru window, has displayed a marked propensity for irritability and a perceptible lack of enthusiasm towards her occupation. Her behavior has been characterized by an air of superiority and a palpable reluctance to accommodate even the most trivial of requests, thereby creating an unfortunate ambiance that has significantly diminished our overall dining experience. It is with great relief that we have discovered the recent opening of an alternative Mexican food restaurant located further down Greenway, which we eagerly anticipate will provide a more pleasant and hospitable dining environment. Notwithstanding, we cannot help but express our profound disappointment and discontent with the unfortunate prevalence of surliness and discourtesy exhibited by said employee, which has regrettably tarnished our erstwhile favorable impression of this eatery. Consequently, we feel compelled to confer a rating of three stars, accompanied by our fervent hope that a concerted effort will be made towards rectifying this unacceptable state of affairs.
Great location overlooking the pool and the food was good!  A little pricey for how basic the meals were, but nothing above the norm for the M.Bay.

I was amazed how large the place was once inside and how quickly they were able to seat me even though they appeared busy.  I had my drink order in quickly and was reviewing their menu within minutes of sitting down.

I ordered the AYCE which is a great price of $20 especially given the majority of the rolls were $10 or more each.  I ordered 5 in total, so it was a great deal for the quantity of food I received. The quality however was just about average to maybe a little better.  The presentation of the food was bland and once my initial order was in, it took several attempts to stop my waitress, even though the place had cleared out completely by then.

I felt a little uncomfortable having to keep asking for more tea and waiting almost 20 minutes after asking for the bill.  The food was good for $20 AYCE, however the service wasn't.  I will give them another try in a few months as I could have caught them on a bad night, but for $20 and the fact I was stuffed when I left, it is worth another try.

Just because you are in Vegas don't expect to wine and dine here.  This is meant to be a quick service restaurant with food to satisfy hunger, not give you the \"wow\" factor.\n\nHad the prosciutto sandwich and it tasted just as I anticipated.  Crusty baguette, prosciutto di parma, mozzarella, arugula, and balsamic.  Simple, fast, and on the go.  The cheese pizza would have used some extra time in the oven because the under crust had gone soggy.

I halted my activities temporarily earlier this month in conjunction with an acquaintance. We ventured forth on a Tuesday evening, and nearly had the entire establishment to ourselves, which was acceptable as we were able to converse without raising our voices and also engage in a brief colloquium with Heidi. A most agreeable young woman, she provided us with hospitable service. My culinary selection consisted of the Oggie (The Traditional Pasty), an assortment of mushy peas (prompted by my comrade's visible delight upon perusing the bill of fare...a manifestation, no doubt, of early recollections of childhood), and chips (potato wedges). I did not experience an overwhelming sensation due to the victuals. Nevertheless, is English cuisine capable of eliciting such a response? The pastry enclosure was somewhat arid and the wine gravy necessitated acclimation. Although the bovine flesh was lean, its tenderness left much to be desired. I cannot assert that I would advocate a visit solely for the purpose of partaking of sustenance, but the Strongbow Cider and the Hoegaarden proved to be satisfactory. Furthermore, I remained on the premises to engage in a game of Cricket @ the dartboard, an activity that might not have been accessible under normal circumstances. It appears that this establishment has the potential to serve as a suitable venue for imbibing beverages in the company of companions and immersing oneself in a convivial ambiance during peak hours.
Not bad for Vegas but any one from Chicago will tell you the bread is wrong fix that and you got a great sandwich

Stopped by here because we needed a quick bite to eat before the Michael Jackson One show.  Thought it would be faster if we went to the bar. Took a while for the bartender to show up, but once she did service was fine. We had the chili cheese kobe beef fries, which hit the spot. Decent place to watch sports as well.

Going to Avalon always seems like a really great idea until I actually go. Don't get me wrong, this is hip and you can find some pretty cool stuff occasionally, but for me it's really hit or miss. Sometimes I have a really hard time understanding how they price their items. Once I picked our a tshirt that had holes in it and it was $14. As far as "thrift stores" go, I wouldn't exactly say its super thrifty, but I have gotten a few items priced lower than they would have originally been stores (AE jeans, Urban Outfitter top). 

Another thing I don't understand is how their buying process works. I've taken clothes here a few times to sell...and that process is also hit or miss. I've taken almost new, "in-style" clothes there and they didn't take anything, but then you look on the racks and they have clothes that look like they should belong to someone's Grandma. 

In conclusion, shopping here is definitely always a mixed bag, however any time I'm in Squirrel Hill I make sure I stop in just to see what they have. They also always have a very good selection of Halloween costumes in October.

This store makes every other Sally Beauty Supply I have been into look like a closet. It's seriously about double the size, with tons more product on the shelves. 

When I stopped in recently after work, there were 3 people working. I was greeted by one employee as I came in, she didn't exactly look stoked to be there but she was polite. 

All I was doing was quickly picking up some nail polish (using the $5 coupon I had from joining the Sally Beauty Club!) so I didn't need any assistance. The cashier was friendly as she rang me up, and I am sure I will be back.

3.5 stars for cheap Jameson, somewhat decent food, and a fun patio.

Never thought I'd be a Yelp app regular at Gilley's, but lo and behold, there was my golden checkmark (of shame). I visited a while back with Dana S (the S is for Some Hot Bitch) where we got cheap Jame-O and loled at karaoke. 

Visited again recently for food and more drinks, and I was not disappointed (but then again, I was not paying). The nachos were alright--tasted like my beloved Taco John's  which is a pretty good compliment coming from me. The chicken strips were just that--frozen animal flesh fried in un-food batter and grease--but the vinegary mustardy sauce sold me. Also had a bite of the jalapeno grits which were the highlight of the meal.

Overall, not a terrible place, but not the best either. The Strip has so much more to offer but in a pinch, this place wasn't horrible.

"Consequently, my rating of this establishment would have been lower, had it not been for the presence of prominent figures, who graced the premises with their illustrious presence...It remains uncertain whether a dance floor existed within the confines of the venue, as its diminutive size rendered it nearly imperceptible; however, the musical offerings were passable, and the ambiance was conducive to relaxation. It is worth mentioning that during our visit on Valentine's weekend, ladies were accorded gratis admission, and champagne was provided compliments of the house. Our intention to depart at midnight, motivated by the uninspiring nature of the music, was abruptly reversed upon the arrival of LMFAO, whose electrifying performance rendered the remainder of the evening thoroughly enjoyable. My associates have also frequented this club on previous occasions, specifically last year, when they had the privilege of encountering Far East Movement, thus it is advisable to exercise judicious selection when choosing the date of your visit."

If you like half naked, drop dead gorgeous waitresses and alcohol, you should have no problem enjoying a night here. 

If good service and 5 star food is more your speed, travel elsewhere. 

Sure, you might get the wrong bill brought to your table, twice, and maybe the drinks are inconsistent and the food sub par, but let's face it. You shouldn't be coming here for much more. The beer is cold and the women are beautiful and really, everything else you can get somewhere else.

"An invariably judicious decision. The pace of service may be somewhat languid, but the culinary delight of the corn chowder more than compensates for any temporal inconvenience. A diverse array of gastronomical options graces the menu, and the hospitable demeanor of the staff consistently enhances the dining experience. Additionally, an assortment of succulent breads and muffins complements the meal, rendering this establishment an excellent venue for any of the three daily repasts."

I had the pleasure of partaking in a culinary excursion to Enso, in the company of a singular companion, on a recent luncheon outing. Upon perusing the menu, my eyes landed upon the ginger salad, which, much to my delight, proved to be a flavorsome and visually appealing dish, its ingredients expertly balanced to create a harmonious union of taste and aroma, reminiscent of those delectable offerings commonly associated with the traditional Japanese cuisine that the establishment purported to embody. However, my enthusiasm was somewhat tempered upon sampling the sushi, which, while aesthetically pleasing, failed to distinguish itself from the myriad alternatives available at numerous other eateries specializing in this particular genre of gastronomy. Happily, the spider roll, with its judicious blend of flavors and textures, proved to be an unexpected highlight of our repast, its quality surpassing my expectations and providing a welcome respite from the relative mediocrity that had thus far defined our dining experience. Unfortunately, the ambiance of the restaurant left much to be desired, with an excessive emphasis on opulence and dim lighting that bordered on the excessive, creating an environment that struck me as contrived and lacking in authenticity, particularly given the fact that the proprietors themselves were not of Japanese extraction; furthermore, the cost of our meal, which amounted to a hundred dollars, exclusive of any alcoholic beverages, seemed decidedly steep in relation to the quality of the fare provided, leading me to question the overall value proposition offered by this particular dining establishment, particularly when compared to such competitors as the New Zealand Cafe, where one might obtain comparable, if not superior, culinary delights at a fraction of the cost.

First and foremost, I have an unwavering fondness for their delectable sandwiches, specifically the Turkey, ranch, and bacon variant. However, my ardent affection for their culinary offerings is unfortunately mitigated by my utter disdain for the novel beverage dispensers they have recently installed. It appears that every time I attempt to quench my thirst with a carbonated beverage from these machines, I am met with an unpleasant, lime-infused flavor that permeates the entirety of the drink, leaving a disagreeable aftertaste that lingers long after the beverage has been consumed. Regrettably, this has rendered dining at these establishments an unpalatable experience for me, despite the exceptional quality of both the sandwiches and the staff. Consequently, I am left with no alternative but to opt for takeout or forgo the pleasure of partaking in their edible delights altogether.

We entered the establishment with the expectation of capitalizing on one of the most optimal rooftop settings within the city limits, only to be informed that while we could indeed consume food and beverages upstairs, we would be responsible for tidying up after ourselves and procuring any necessary items independently.  Such an underutilization of exceptional terrain! 
The hospitality we received was adequate.  Our server was quite personable, though perhaps a tad distracted.  She delivered two beverages of the alcoholic variety to my spouse and me, despite the fact that we had only placed an order for a single drink. 
The culinary offerings were unremarkable.  While not utterly deplorable, they failed to impress us to the extent that we would actively seek them out.  We sampled the pork queso dip, which, while lacking the fiery zest we customarily associate with queso, was undeniably palatable.  I would certainly consider ordering it again in the future.  My spouse opted for the Cuban sandwich.  Following the waitress's recommendation, he attempted to consume it with both lettuce and tomato, but unfortunately, these additional elements overpowered the inherent flavors of the BBQ, rendering it somewhat unpalatable.  Upon removing the produce from the sandwich, the BBQ itself proved to be fairly satisfying.  My better half relished the flavor of the meat, but, much like the rest of the dish, it did not particularly stand out. 
While this eatery will not be incorporated into our regular dining rotation, I would not object if others wished to frequent it.

I live down the street from this WH so my circle of friends often finds ourselves here after a night of debauchery. It's really nothing special, trucker food at it's best, but the staff is really nice and there's something about it that makes my hangovers feel better.

What I liked about this place was that it looks like you have landed on Mars. Just check out some of the rock formations outside. What I do not like about this place is that it is in Arizona. Enough said.

"I find myself in a state of ambivalence regarding this critique, as our dining experience at the establishment was marked by both exceptional service and delectable cuisine, yet unfortunately marred by an unfortunate incident involving two members of our party who suffered from food poisoning, which we suspect was caused by the mussels. Despite this setback, we opted to sample a variety of dishes, including their signature jumbo lump crab cake, braised short ribs pierogies, arancinis, potato gnocchi & lobster, and the aforementioned mussels. During the meal, I thoroughly enjoyed all of the dishes, with my particular favorites being the lobster gnocchi and the arancinis, although the latter were slightly tainted by the bitterness of the port wine. In addition, we also indulged in a selection of their beverages, ranging from the Braddock's smash to the Moscow mule and Prohibition pear martini, as well as the option to create one's own Manhattan cocktail. Considering its status as a hotel restaurant, this venue within The Renaissance proved to be a truly exceptional choice, were it not for the unfortunate occurrence of food poisoning, which sadly reduces this review's rating to three stars."

I visit Chili's with my kin and acquaintances approximately two times per month. We typically frequent the establishment located at the intersection of Bell and 7th Streets or 27th Avenue and 101st Street. The culinary offerings, for the most part, are at least average to slightly above average in quality. The complimentary chips and salsa are a remarkable value, and the green chile and enchilada soups are particularly delectable. The consistency of the fare across all Chili's locations we visit is quite gratifying. However, there appears to be a persistent issue with the service at the North Valley Parkway branch. During their initial opening phase, we attempted to dine there twice due to its proximity to our domicile. Unfortunately, both experiences were marred by botched orders and friendly yet menu-ignorant servers. The prolonged delay in receiving our cuisine was further exacerbated by the absence of any contrite sentiments. Following a brief hiatus, we opted to give them another chance, presuming that the novelty had worn off and any glitches would have been ironed out. Alas, our expectations were not met, as the wait time for our edibles was extraordinary, and securing a replenishment of our beverages proved to be a futile endeavor. Fast forward over a year, and our most recent visit transpired last Saturday. Our server was quite pleasant, and the hostesses were cordial, yet the duration between ordering and consuming our soup and salad, accompanied by water as our beverage, spanned an unacceptable ninety minutes. It is reasonable to surmise that four instances of subpar service are unlikely to be mere happenstance. In stark contrast, the Chili's situated on 7th Street consistently delivers exceptional hospitality and customary waiting periods. It is my ardent hope that this anomaly shall be rectified, as Chili's poses a respectable dining option.

A delectable smorgasbord of regional culinary delights, this local buffet boasts an impressive array of fresh seafood, including sashimi of exceptional quality, notably the succulent salmon. The traditional Chinese dishes are expertly prepared and presented in generous portions, ensuring a satisfying experience for gastronomes who relish the rich flavors of the Far East. The crab legs, in particular, are a highlight, with their tender flesh and subtle nuances of flavor. However, the spring rolls fail to impress, lacking the delicate touch and finesse that distinguish the establishment's other offerings. Dumplings, too, could benefit from greater attention to detail in their preparation. Notwithstanding these minor shortcomings, a visit to this buffet is highly recommended, particularly for those who appreciate the diverse and intricate flavors of Chinese cuisine. Moreover, it is imperative to note that a careful perusal of the sign positioned on each table is essential prior to partaking in the bountiful spread, lest one incur an additional fee of $8 due to excessive consumption and waste.

"In the event that a reservation at Pied Au Corchon proves unattainable, this establishment serves as a suitable substitute. Freshly prepared dishes, judiciously portioned, and an refined rustic atmosphere characterize this eatery, rendering it a suitable selection for out-of-town visitors or intimate gatherings. Drawbacks include a leisurely pace of service and a boisterous dining environment. My evening meal was delectable and, for the most part, justified the cost. I sampled the veal heart tartare, which displayed remarkable freshness and a robust flavor profile, albeit with a subtle yet indescribable lacking quality that eluded my attempts at identification. Accompanying this dish were paper-thin frites, expertly cooked and seasoned with precision, as well as a raw vegetable salad, finely sliced and dressed with a vinaigrette. For dessert, I shared the apple tarte intended for two individuals. The presentation of the tarte was aesthetically pleasing, featuring a unique combination of slightly vinegared apple slices and a minuscule scoop of apple sorbet as a garnish. While not extraordinary, the tarte was pleasant, served at a comfortable temperature, and boasted a flaky crust. In conclusion, this restaurant merits consideration as a worthy alternative to other renowned upscale establishments in Le Plateau."

"This establishment possesses considerable potential; the television sets are strategically positioned in optimal locations, including within the bathrooms. I would unquestionably confer a five-star rating upon this venue if they were to upgrade their culinary offerings and expand their selection of draft beers and premium spirits. Specifically, I have attempted to procure Crown Royal Cask No. 16, Jack Daniel's Honey, Kraken, Captain Morgan Private Stock, and Jack Daniel's Single Barrel, but unfortunately, they do not carry any of these top-shelf liquors. Half Moon, take note! It is imperative that you address these two issues promptly, as I am eager to provide an updated review that accurately reflects the full scope of your amenities and services."
Just came here and ordered a caesars salad. It was a snack between meals. It was dressed nicely but slightly overseasoned. Nice casual place.

Restaurant review
My first venture into Korean food in Champaign was good. We decided to stop for a quick lunch and ended up at the first restaurant that opened at 11 AM on a weekday. It was easy to order because we were the first customers of the day. They have a nice laminated menu at the desk to chose your entree. It would be nicer if they had pictures instead of a word description of each item. I selected the combo platter of bulgogi which was 9.99. Afterwards it was a long wait of approximately 25 minutes before we got our food. The dish itself came with a large amount of rice and 2 ban chae along with a bean soup. Based on the pictures I could have chose the beef bulgogi paid less and likely gotten the same amount of food except less variety. The bulgogi was well seasoned, but the meat was cut into smaller slices which detracted from it. Prices have gone up according to my wife since she was in college. Overall slightly above average, I will have to find another korean restaurant to compare too.

Pro: average price korean food, large portion

Cons: long cook time, higher price than average lunch places

Hidden gem:
Your meal comes with rice, soup, and 2 korean ban chae

Food is hit and miss, I noticed that the food is horrible in the afternoon (salty fries, bland meat etc..) but fantastic at night. Sandwiches are good. their BBQ ribs when they have them are a joke. I am not much of a drinker so I cannot comment on the Bar but just the grill :-)

During my independent travels in Arizona, I felt compelled to indulge in regional delicacies that accurately represented the area's indigenous population, rather than simply consuming generic tourist fare. In pursuit of this goal, I made a point to visit establishments renowned for their authentic preparation of Native American cuisine. My maiden venture to The Fry Bread House provided me with an opportunity to sample the cultural essence of the region through their delectable offerings. The bold flavors present in their dishes were undoubtedly a pleasant surprise, as they deviated from the monotony of standard fast food fare. The aromatic flatbread, freshly prepared upon order, proved to be particularly satisfying. Although I cannot offer recommendations with certainty, given my limited exposure to their menu, I can confidently assert that their flatbread is indeed palatable.

I don't know why, but this Bruegger's stands head and shoulders above the location three blocks away on Grant.  Employees are almost always in good spirits and much more efficient at taking orders.\n\nLike most Bruegger's, they have the standard Bagel, Sandwich, Soup, Coffee and Tea selection.  They also have nice booth seating along an outside window.

The atmosphere is great. The prices are right. The wine-a-ritas are different, tasty but just ok. The local wines are a bit light, I prefer CA wines but they were still good, a bit over priced. I would have bought the pinot grigio but didn't think it was worth $25. I would go again and definitly will order the flight for $6. Pick any 6 for $6. whatta deal!

This is a very average to above average sushi restaurant.  The bar is nice, seating is limited (like most sushi places).  The sushi is good, but completely unremarkable.  On par with Ra, but not in the same league as Sakana.  I agonized over a fourth star, but it was just so average.

"Enormous aerofoils, unfortunately, their operational status has transitioned to closed, and upon perusal of previous patrons' feedback, it appears that sluggish servicing was a contributing factor to such an unfortunate fate."

"Adequate pizza, albeit with some reservations regarding the texture of the wings, which seemed slightly desiccated, yet attributable to an isolated production mishap, rather than a systemic flaw. The sauce, however, demonstrated a satisfactory level of flavor and richness, although it failed to fully satiate my yearning for an authentic New York-style pizza experience in Pittsburgh."

"The culinary offerings were of exceptional quality, as per usual. The novel edifice provided an ambiance that was both aesthetically pleasing and spatially accommodating. Nonetheless, the seating arrangements left much to be desired in terms of comfort and functionality, while the sonic accompaniments bordered on the excessive, rendering communication with fellow diners a rather strenuous endeavor. In order to enhance the overall dining experience, it would be advisable to procure more ergonomic seating options and modulate the volume of the musical selection during the evening hours. Failing this, I shall opt for the 'take-out' option in the future, as it seems the only feasible means of circumventing the discomfort and auditory distress engendered by the prevailing conditions."

It's nice to finally find an uptown lunch spot that focuses on honest health instead of hiding behind vague menu descriptions and health information from the 1980s, like so many others.  This place really impresses me with their commitment to healthy, natural ingredients.
Overall, I think the food is very good, and the menu options are as extensive as they need to be to make this a weekly lunch stop.  However, I have one issue with the price point, particularly with breakfast.  The cost of a breakfast sandwich is pretty outrageous for what you actually get.  For $5, i don't expect someone to reach into a steamer and pull out a 2 hour old poached egg, place it on a stale wrap, and throw a pinch of turkey bacon on it and call it a decent breakfast.
In contrast though, the lunch is spectacular.  You definitely get a decent bang for the buck, especially if you eat in (tea refills and complimentary froyo).  In my experiences, it always tastes fresh, healthy, and delicious... and I'm actually somewhat full afterward. 
For breakfast this place gets 2 stars, but for lunch it gets 4.  So an overall 3 it is.

Sally's constitutes an ideal venue for pursuing post-last call evening exploits, distinguishable by an unparalleled quality in comparison to neighboring alternatives beyond the realm of expedient nourishment. The ambiance within Sally's exudes a captivating charm, replete with motorcycle paraphernalia, retro trinkets from the 1950s and 1960s, vintage guitars, and an overall aura imbued with rockabilly elements, fostering a unique dining experience. While the culinary offerings at Sally's may not serve as the primary draw, the establishment functions as a welcoming hub, providing a setting where patrons can partake in leisurely repasts and engage in prolonged conversations, fortified by delectable delights and spirited libations until the wee hours of the morning. The hospitable servers at SPS contribute significantly to the inviting atmosphere, while the spacious, comfortable booths and exceptional ice cubes further enhance the dining experience, eliciting peculiar yet fervent praise. Although Sally's may not qualify as a paragon of gastronomical excellence, it remains a suitable venue for nocturnal revelers seeking a relaxed, convivial environment. Were smoking permitted indoors, a five-star rating would likely ensue; alas, this decision lies beyond the purview of Sally's management.

"This venue possesses an acceptable level of quality. They play a diverse array of musical genres, including oldies, hip hop, rap, and rock. Our visit occurred on a Friday evening, and my estimation of approximately half of the patrons in attendance was that they exhibited characteristics associated with a lower socioeconomic status. The dance floor is rather diminutive in size. However, there are certain advantages to this establishment, such as their practice of distributing complimentary items to those who arrive early and queue up promptly to gain entry to the club and await the distribution of said items. During our visit, they were offering articles of clothing, but it is essential to note that the quantity of items available was limited, with approximately fifteen items being disseminated, and the majority of these items were size medium or large. Each individual was restricted to receiving a single item."

Firstly, I must emphasize that I am not a member of the younger generation who customarily socializes within the confines of Old Town. However, having resided in Phoenix for over three decades, I have had the privilege of experiencing the city's culinary landscape, including numerous upscale dining establishments. Our recent visit to this restaurant took place during Restaurant Week, in the company of friends. Unfortunately, our experience did not warrant a repeat visit in the near future. While the service was indeed attentive, the ambiance, though unique and quaint, was somewhat exaggerated by previous reviewers. The cramped spacing between tables and the ensuing high decibel level precluded an intimate dining experience. Furthermore, the cuisine, while undoubtedly palatable, fell short of exceptional quality. My venison entrÃ©e, in particular, was served in an undercooked state, bordering on sashimi raw. Notwithstanding the absence of a query regarding my preferred level of doneness, I had anticipated a more well-done preparation. My fellow diner, who favors a medium-rare finish, opted to return her dish for further cooking. Our shared dessert selection, consisting of foie gras and donuts, proved unconventional and failed to resonate with our collective taste buds. Although intriguing, the cocktail offerings were not sampled, as we are not habitual imbibers. In conclusion, while the regular menu appeared overpriced relative to the portion sizes we received during Restaurant Week, the novelty of the dining experience motivated our single visit.

We recently had the privilege of dining at Vogue, a culinary establishment that has been highly recommended by various sources, and thus, our expectations were suitably elevated. Upon perusing the menu, we elected to sample the meatloaf and lasagna, respectively, as our primary courses, and decided to share the calamari fritta appetizer, primarily due to its intriguing combination of flavors and textures. Our initial impression of the entrees was overwhelmingly positive, as both dishes demonstrated an unwavering commitment to quality and presentation, making them undoubtedly worth the expense. However, our enthusiasm was momentarily curtailed when we sampled the calamari fritta, which, unfortunately, did not live up to our expectations. Despite the novel incorporation of ginger amidst the julienned carrots, the overall execution of the dish seemed somewhat lacking, with the tempura-fried calamari pieces being sparse and somewhat lost amidst the abundance of vegetation. Notwithstanding this minor setback, we generally enjoyed our dining experience, albeit with a few reservations regarding the service, which, although polite and relatively prompt, seemed somewhat detached and unengaging, leaving us with a lingering sense of indifference.

after 1 visit

ambience B+ loved the decor, however, the lighting was quite dark. it was hard to see anything. 

service B+ i would have given pin kaow an A, however, they over-killed on the table touches. i think we had 5 people check on us in the matter of 5 minutes. 

food B+ i enjoyed the dishes, but it didn't make me say, "wow, this is REALLY good."

chicken satay
the chicken was grilled perfectly. the peanut sauce (most likely an authentic sauce), fell a little flat on my palate.

tom ka koong
lemon grass soup with coconut milk, galanga root, mushroom, and shrimp
great in small doses. i could only eat one small bowl, because it was a rich and slightly sour broth. the sourness wore on me at the end of one bowl. that same sourness is why so many people love this soup. it's just not for my palate.

roasted rice beef
beef, cabbage, roasted rice, thai basil and spices
roasted rice is a new concept for me. basically, it is crushed rice that has been roasted and scattered on the beef. interesting texture and a great experience. but not my favorite dish. 

chicken yellow curry
delicious.

overall: B+
hope to be able to visit this place again. sample some other dishes i've never sampled before.

This Dillard's has metamorphosed into a mere outlet center, with the entire lower level lying dormant and uninhabited. The upper level has transmogrified into a terminus for last season's, damaged, and irregularly sized designer attire, eliciting a sense of familiarity with Ross, albeit sans the plethora of inferior brands and foul-smelling changing areas.

The minimum reduction observed was a substantial 40% discount, while the majority of racks flaunted a 50% price decrease, and a select few were adorned with a remarkable 75% markdown. Furthermore, the assortment was methodically categorized by size, facilitating a seamless shopping experience.

Prominent designers were responsible for the majority of the merchandise, including a stylish Michael Kors top that originally retailed for approximately $50 but was acquired for a mere $18, exemplifying a substantial savings.

Garments constituted the primary focus, complemented by a medley of bedding, accessories, and footwear. However, the selection of shoes proved to be underwhelming, catering only to diminutive feet, colossal sasquatch feet, or those enamored with flamboyant styles, leaving the rest in a state of dismay.

As far as chains go, Bravo is dependable. I can always count on getting a decent salad. This location offers reservations, which is helpful in avoiding long lines and 45 minute waits.

I enjoy the Romano crusted chicken salad as well as the balsamic chicken salad. The Parmesan dressing is delicious, and I have even tried to recreate it at home.

I am not a big fan of the entrées here as they are loaded with salt, but I do enjoy stopping in to grab a salad while shopping at the Waterfront or catching a movie.

There is always plenty of parking, which is key.

I am with Jamie C. on this one.  I think maybe I will have to come back to make my final decision.  Our server was great!  I wish i would have got his name so I could mention him by name... very attentive!  I enjoyed the 2 glasses of sangria I had, but Michael was not that enthused about his mojito.  He switched to Stella for his second:).  For our entrees we shared the calamari and their special which was a blue corn chicken enchilada.  The calamari was very tasty!  I really liked the sauces that came with them and we ate it all!  The enchiladas were very tasty too.  There were many shared plates that I wanted to try so I will definitely come back!

We've heard and seen on the Food Network great things about Bouchon and certainly was not disappointed with the service. The dining hall is elegant and proper. Brunch was good, but not blow- your- mind great. We tried the Salmon Baguette, a take on salmon and smear on a bagel only for $15, but this is to be expected. Nevertheless, it was good. We also had the Bouchon French Toast which is done in a bread pudding- like style. It shouldn't be be called French toast because it does not resemble anything like it. It really should be called bread pudding. It was more like dessert-- too sweet to be had as a brunch meal.

"Ah, the quaint charm of Kamakura, how it has captivated my family's taste buds for an array of years, emerging as a culinary sanctuary of sorts! My father, a gourmet visionary, introduced us to this haven when it first sprouted onto the gastronomic scene, as sushi was merely a nascent delight, savored by a select few. We revisited intermittently, reserved for momentous occasions (my senior prom ensemble graced its presence here), given its elevated pricing relative to our modest standards at the time. Presently, I make it a point to partake in their delectable Teppan offerings during my visits, yet I cannot help but sense a subtle metamorphosis in the wait staff's enthusiasm. Or perhaps, my perception has matured, mirroring the evolution of my palate. Despite this, Kamakura maintains a sturdy foothold, boasting an impressive record, particularly amidst the unforgiving culinary landscape of Los Angeles, where I currently reside. In fact, I would venture to assert that this esteemed establishment would comfortably secure a respectable 3.5-star rating, a testament to its enduring appeal and the region's discerning epicurean inclinations."

I got the Gold Standard, he got the Longhorn. They were pricey dogs with minimal toppings. These are no Buldogis dogs...look it up and go there now and get one! You won't regret it. \nThey were edible and satisfied our hunger but I wouldn't go any further. Las Vegas Pinks is below them, so they have something going for them. Staff was helpful and pleasant. We expected high prices...it's the strip.  I say skip it unless your a hot dog fiend.

RESULT: The parent company, Frias, effectively addressed my concern by dedicating sufficient time to investigate and locate the specific taxi and driver in question, utilizing our credit card information. Their thorough approach and diligence in the follow-up process were impressive, although the severity of the driver's consequences remains unknown. Despite the uncertainty, I would still consider using Ace Cab in the future, but I will certainly exercise greater vigilance to ensure that all personal belongings are retrieved before exiting the vehicle. 
  EDITED: Below is my initial post. One day after posting, I received communication from the parent company, and they are actively examining the situation. I appreciate their efforts and will update everyone on any progress made. 
  ORIGINAL POST: The driver displayed both rudeness and dishonesty! We discovered that our iPad was missing and, subsequently, left a message on the taxi company's lost and found number without receiving any response. However, we received a call from an individual who acquired the iPad from the taxi driver, raising suspicions of a potential scam. Regardless of the circumstances, the driver failed to return the iPad, and the company showed indifference towards my concerns by neglecting to follow up. Considering that Ace is merely one of numerous cab companies operated by a single parent company, I will deliberately avoid them all if this is how they conduct their business practices. At the very least, I expect them to demonstrate a pretense of concern and follow through on their responsibilities. While it may be challenging to monitor every driver, a mere show of effort in customer care would suffice.

TIP:  use their free wifi here (very spotty though)\n\ni only fly southwest here at McCarran, and the layout is very disjointed.  I can't say for other airlines but southwest has two areas with available gates.  So if you went to the wrong gate (or wanted to visit a friend from the other gate) , and that gate happens to be on the side, you have to pretty much run to the other side of the airport.  Also, the rental car center have to be shuttled (wastes time).  There is also one rental car company that is not even in the rental center (i think it's fox).  Do not rent from them!! they are far away, which is a waste of time.  Rentals in LV are cheap anyways.

We indulged in a culinary excursion at this esteemed establishment during the previous week, predicated upon an array of laudatory assessments. Although our gastronomical expectations were not entirely fulfilled, our repast did boast certain notable highlights. Specifically, we sampled their duck, steak, and salmon offerings, with the duck proving to be the most satisfying, while the steak fell somewhat short of our expectations. However, the cheese plate appetizer preceding our main courses elicited unanimous praise from our party. Furthermore, the hospitality we received throughout the evening was quite commendable. Notwithstanding some minor shortcomings, we shall afford this venue an additional opportunity to demonstrate its full potential prior to rendering a definitive verdict.

"The culinary offerings at this establishment are of satisfactory quality, albeit at a somewhat elevated cost. Specifically, the roasted duck appetizer did not meet expectations, possessing a lack of succulence in the meat and an absence of crispiness in the skin. However, the sweet and sour pork dish was quite delectable, and the coconut rice was truly exceptional, eliciting a desire to consume it on a daily basis. Notwithstanding, the total cost, inclusive of gratuity, exceeded our budgetary constraints by a considerable margin. We shall return to sample the coconut rice in conjunction with the satay, and will provide an updated assessment at that juncture."

"I placed an order for brisket accompanied by nacho fries, in conjunction with an outlaw burger. However, my cousin, who placed his order subsequent to mine, received his meal prior to mine, despite the fact that I had ordered before him. Furthermore, I noticed a patron who had placed his order after mine, and yet, he received the identical burger before my order was served. Upon inquiring about the delay in receiving my meal, the server responded nonchalantly, implying that my order was forthcoming. Following a ten-minute interval, my fries were brought out, devoid of the burger. The server assured me that it would be delivered shortly. After an additional ten minutes had elapsed, I finally received my burger. Unfortunately, the prolonged wait made it challenging to fully appreciate my dining experience. Notwithstanding, the fries were quite satisfying, and the burger was equally impressive. The prices charged for the cuisine were reasonable. Had it not been for the blunder in handling my order and the server's attempt to downplay the error, I would have awarded four stars. Despite these issues, I would still consider returning and hoping for improved service in the future."

"My dining experiences at this establishment have primarily involved large gatherings or instances where I have been unable to settle on a specific culinary preference, as the restaurant's diverse offerings cater well to such situations. Following numerous attempts to sample various items on the menu, I have found the quality to be generally satisfying, albeit not exceptional. Noteworthy mentions include the Chicken Madeira and the Farfalle with chicken and roasted garlic, the latter of which I recommend requesting with a reduction in garlic intensity. Additionally, their assorted cheesecake selection boasts an array of flavors such as Snickers, turtle, tuxedo, and strawberry, all of which have proven to be delectable. However, my unwavering enthusiasm for cheesecake has yet to encounter a slice that I did not promptly consume in its entirety."

Not impressed with dinner at Davio.  Service can make or break a dining experience and I have to admit, I felt as though I was eating at Eat 'N Park.  The food was ok, but not on par with other similar restaurants.  The server was unprofessional and had no idea what was on the menu, or how to answer questions regarding it.  Do not waste your time, spend a few more dollars and go to Arlecchino or Alla Familia.

Visited 5/8/12...

Came across this location in travel while looking for a something a little different for lunch.  I think this is pretty new. 

It is located on same building as gas station at Northeast corner of Southern and Higley. 

I only wanted something simple. Ordered Gyro and Fries.  Did it as take out. At 12:15 p.m. there was only one other person there eating.  Not sure if that says something or maybe they just have not been discovered yet. 

It tasted good. However, I have had a better at some other locations.  I was disappointed in portion.  Three pieces meat, two slices tomato.  For a quick lunch it was satisfying.

I looked at menu and saw some interesting items on menu.  Might be interested in trying these at some point later. 

It is a nice option to other fast food.  Not a place that I would go out of my way for, at least at point.  But would definitely return for a Gyro if in the area. 

Will try back again in a month or so and see if they are still up and running.  Difficult location and visibility from street..

I indulged in a three-night sojourn in the City of Light, during which I had opted for an accommodation equipped with a regal King-sized bed. However, my request was not fulfilled initially, as I was allocated a room furnished with two Queen-sized beds instead. Fortunately, owing to availability issues, I was subsequently relocated to a room that matched my initial preference. The Queen-sized beds proved to be rather uncomfortable, whereas the King-sized bed offered a more satisfactory sleeping experience. The rooms were meticulously maintained, while the bathrooms boasted impeccable cleanliness, generous dimensions, and practical functionality. Notwithstanding a substantial queue, the check-in process was executed with remarkable efficiency. One aspect that particularly appealed to me was the presence of a secluded cabin shower and a standalone bathtub in the bathrooms. Although the television offered only basic channels, it served its purpose adequately. To my delight, the hotel upheld a tranquil ambiance, devoid of any bothersome noise. Its strategic location was a significant asset, placing me at the epicenter of all attractions. The elevators operated with remarkable speed and reliability. Unfortunately, my view was limited to the rear of the building, facing the direction of the airport. Nonetheless, I availed myself of the opportunity to patronize their spa services, which warranted a separate review. Parisian cuisine within the premises was undeniably delectable, and I wholeheartedly endorse ascending the iconic Eiffel Tower for a breathtaking panorama. Additionally, the proximity of the monorail metro ensured that accessibility was never an issue, rendering it unnecessary to venture beyond the hotel's confines. My sole grievance pertained to the restriction imposed on my spa usage on the day of my departure, which proved somewhat disconcerting. In conclusion, this establishment offered a commendable temporary abode.

Came here for dinner a few days after my first visit.

The nice looks of the place started to feel misleading pretty quickly.

The booze pours are super stingy. Both the beer and the wine glassware was modern and nice to look at, but the volume of liquid they were filled with made me feel like I was getting shafted by the bar tender.

To eat, we got the Louisiana Chicken pasta dish and the Bibimbap.

The Louisiana Chicken pasta tasted great and, in all seriousness, probably checked in at 2,000-3,000 calories. A significantly heavier meal than a double cheeseburger and fries at Five Guys. It was a huge bowl of heavy whipping cream and melted cheese, with some pasta for texture. The whole time I was eating it, I felt like the waitress should have been wearing a vest with flair pins and saying "Welcome to Applebees!" Totally not what I expected to be served in a restaurant like Miga.

The Bibimbap was super sexy looking, but left everything to be desired on the eating side of things. It was missing the most important component of that famous dish - the dolsot, or hot stone bowl. It tasted only okay. Bottom line is that it was closer to a cold salad than any Bibimbap I've ever had.

I'm sure I'll come here again, but I'll give the menu some time to work itself out.

Distrito exhibits a palpable shortfall in its capacity to evoke a memorable dining experience, despite the extensive promotion it has garnered.  This deficiency is particularly discernible in the eatery's ambiance, which is characterized by an excessive dimness and an uninspired lounge-like quality that ultimately renders the setting rather monotonous.  
The meal initiated with an order of guacamole and chips accompanied by salsa, yet the latter was regrettably overseasoned with salt, rendering it nearly inedible.  Notwithstanding this flaw, I persevered and consumed the chips while endeavoring to remove the excess salt by utilizing my fingers to brush it off.  The guacamole and salsa, however, demonstrated appreciable quality.  Subsequently, we progressed to sample the vegetarian tacos, which were adequately prepared and presented a satisfying taste, in addition to a type of Mexican flatbread embellished with mushrooms and complemented by a huiltacoche sauce.  
The rice, prepared with corn, cream, and habaneros, had the potential to emerge as a delectable Mexican risotto; unfortunately, it was once again marred by an excess of salt, thereby diminishing its overall effectiveness. 
Distrito boasts an assortment of marginally diverse margaritas, and we opted to sample both the watermelon-cucumber and cilantro varieties, which yielded satisfactory results. 
It has been rumored that the restaurant's service can be somewhat problematic; nevertheless, our server, though unremarkable in their performance, delivered competent and attentive assistance.  Ultimately, Distrito proved to be a passable dining option for us, yet we do not find ourselves yearning to revisit the establishment.
The food is tasty. But the fact that they don't take credit cards and that coffee refills are not free will keep me from going to this place very often.

I have had the pleasure of visiting Aunt Chilada's on multiple occasions during my time in Arizona, and while each experience has been relatively uneventful, there was one particular visit that stands out as particularly memorable. It was an evening when one of my companions and I decided to engage in a playful activity, inspired by the iconic Disney character, Ariel, from The Little Mermaid, where we used plastic forks to groom our hair before entering the establishment. Furthermore, I recall that shortly after making a humorous observation regarding individuals from rural areas, we felt compelled to utilize the aforementioned utensils to tidy up our coiffures. The motivation behind this behavior remains unclear, but it seemed amusing at the time. Moving on, the culinary offerings at Aunt Chilada's have never been exceptional or remarkably poor; they are perhaps adequate enough to warrant a visit if one is in close proximity and desires to partake in a leisurely meal accompanied by refreshing margaritas on the outdoor seating area. In conclusion, while not outstanding, the eatery does not necessarily warrant avoidance, and thus, I shall confer an additional star in recognition of its mediocrity.

We conducted an exhaustive examination of various dishes featured on the menu, whereupon we discovered that certain items possessed exceptional quality while others fell short of our expectations. Specifically, the pork sliders proved to be delectable, as did the mushroom burger, which was cooked to a precise medium rare, thereby showcasing the culinary prowess of the kitchen staff. Furthermore, the fries exhibited a satisfying crunchiness that enhanced their overall appeal. However, the mashed potatoes failed to impress us due to their stale and uninspired flavor profile. The most notable disappointment was the buttermilk fried chicken, which, despite its perfectly executed crisp exterior, lacked any discernible flavor, rendering it a bland and unremarkable dish. It is conceivable that celebrity chef Aaron Sanchez, who allegedly created the menu and recipes, inadvertently overlooked the glaring absence of seasoning in the fried chicken recipe or, alternatively, the restaurant's staff neglected to incorporate salt into the dish, resulting in an unfortunate deficiency in flavor.

I don't know how to review this place.....I have been coming here for years and honestly it was great but I have not been crazy about it lately...everyone try's to be Italian host,waiters bussboy...but they are all Eastern European which is fine but speak English instead of butchering the Italian language.  I have tried most of the menu in the past, my favorite is the veal ouso bucco everything else is borderline chain restaurant quality....however if you get a table in the outdoor veranda you will likely not even know the food is just ok because the obeisance is terrific. I still would recommend this place but if you have good Italian food in your area you will not be Impressed.  Not the best in Vegas but worth trying at least once.

There are days where I want a nicely prepared meal. And then there are days where I want to stuff my face at a buffet. Our friends chose Bouchon for brunch because we were itching for the former.

I tried a small piece of the sourdough waffles with fresh strawberries and vanilla bean butter. It was very tasty, like a fried waffle. The vanilla bean butter was a nice touch.

The vanilla bean yogurt with granola was tasty, and boy do they give you a LOT of granola! A bit too rich for my taste, but the granola helped ease it.

The Cobb salad - didn't take a picture, but it was kinda meh. Limp iceberg lettuce, scarce pieces of chicken, and a small portion to boot for a $17 salad.

This is a good stop for some carb-loading for any pre-intense-cardio on the dance floor at a club later in the evening. The service is great and our waters were constantly filled.

Price-wise, it's high for a mediocre meal at The Venetian hotel. I think I'll stop by Grand Luxe the next time around, as their menu contains better choices. Not recommended for those looking for healthy options - everything tasted very rich and heavy.

I have had the privilege of partaking in the culinary offerings of TGI Fridays on two separate occasions, and while the experience has been somewhat inconsistent, I must commend the establishment for its commitment to providing excellent service. During my initial visit, I opted for the filled potato skin appetizer, which, despite its generous portion size, suffered from an unfortunate lack of moisture. A dipping sauce or condiment would have greatly enhanced the dish's overall satisfaction quotient. On a subsequent visit, I decided to sample their Caribbean chicken sandwich, which featured a grilled chicken breast complemented by fresh tomatoes, avocados, and a dubious "Caribbean" sauce. Unfortunately, this particular condiment proved to be a disappointment, boasting an unsettling combination of cinnamon and cloves that seemed wildly incongruous when paired with the chicken and avocado. In fact, my husband and mother-in-law, who also had the misfortune of sampling this sauce, concurred with my assessment. Disappointed but not defeated, I elected to replace my meal with the turkey burger, which, while palatable, failed to fully satiate my gastronomic desires due to my heightened state of stress caused by the delay in receiving my food and the fact that my fellow diners had already completed their meals. However, I must acknowledge that the service at TGI Fridays has consistently met high standards of friendliness and professionalism, and I appreciate the fact that they did not charge me for the initial order.

Fun, casual place to eat with your friends. If you're looking for authentic Southern barbeque, move along, but if you want to chow down on some good cheap ribs and chicken, Bar-B-Barn fits the bill. 

We came here hoping to watch the hockey game (well, the guys wanted to watch the hockey game, and we girls were wanting a place that wasn't filled with drunk hockey lunatics) while eating dinner. No TV, so no dice, but the homey barn-y environment still made for a fun night. 

Good cheap ribs. The meat was pretty tender. Sweet sticky sauce. Mmmm. I got the small portion with three ribs and fries and that filled me up.

I took my adorable wife here on a tapas date before a late showing at the Manor Theater across the street. 

We had some strong cocktails, including a delicious ginger cooler with so much real ginger! We shared a variety of tiny plates, little spring rolls and puffs of taro. The veggie offerings were all delicious, although there were not too many to chose from. Actually, I think that is a blessing in disguise because too many choices among delicious little tapas makes for some tough decision making. 

The atmosphere was elegant, the lighting was romantic, and the staff was attentive without being intrusive. We held hands over the table, and played footsie underneath, and ambled into the warm summer night satisfied with our food & drink. 

The prices are pretentious, like the presentation, but it's difficult to say it's not justified with the atmosphere & attention to detail. It's something I need to drop cash on like, once a year.

Our server appeared to be incredulous towards our assertion that our party consisted of individuals whose ages surpassed the threshold of twenty-one years (specifically, we are all twenty-four and twenty-five years old, it must be noted), and this skepticism precipitated a series of events characterized by an excessive scrutiny of our identification documents. Following this episode reminiscent of my freshman year of college, we opted to place an order for several rolls. Unfortunately, none of these rolls managed to elicit any remarkable sentiment among us - Lava (a "special" roll possessing the potential to be significantly more extraordinary), Dragon (the most exceptional of the group), veggie (a vegetarian option unexpectedly deemed satisfactory by the sole member of our party abstaining from consuming meat), and tempura shrimp (remarkably lacking in flavor). The edamame, although palatable, failed to exhibit any remarkable quality that would set it apart from others of its kind. The highlight of the meal materialized in the form of the cheesecake constituting our dessert, accompanied by dual sauces - raspberry and dark chocolate. This establishment may function adequately as a venue for a romantic date, provided that one successfully avoids the throngs of patrons. Additionally, it is worth mentioning that the physical appearance of the servers is quite captivating. Ultimately, there exist numerous superior sushi restaurants; I am convinced of it.

"An exceptional venue offering remarkably affordable happy hour specials, complemented by spacious, immaculately maintained accommodations. However, it appears that an attempt is made to excessively surcharge, and a gratuity is requested, which raises questions regarding the propriety of such a practice."
It was \"ok\" there wasn't much of a selection and it was a little high priced! i might try this again. The server was very nice but wasn't very attentive.

My better half and I had been cognizant of the acclaim surrounding Freddy's for quite some time, thus opting to partake in a culinary excursion to the establishment. Upon our arrival, the dining area was brimming with patrons, further piquing my expectations. I elected to sample their flagship offering, specifically the #1, comprising a double burger augmented with cheese. Alas, upon its presentation, I was dismayed by the meager proportions of the entree. It appeared that the beef patties were of a comparable dimension to those of cold cuts, thereby rendering the bread slices excessively dominant. Notwithstanding the palatable nature of the burger, my overall satisfaction was compromised by the conspicuous absence of meat. While Freddy's remains a viable option, my underwhelming experience precludes me from venturing out of my way to frequent the establishment in the future.

Beautiful view at North Show Terrace .... kind of makes the $16 margarita worth it.  

Kind of.  

Also, the misters are a great idea in theory when it's 106 outside, but they aren't so great when the water starts trickling off the umbrella and onto your head.

Limited menu (mainly noodles and dumplings); reasonable prices; fast food service; this place is usually packed during lunch/ dinner hours because price is right and food tastes great! I had a bowl of pork feet noodle soup here on a cold winter night so the hot noodles was especially delicious to me! Portion size was just good.  Service was accommodating; the servers were very busy but still trying to accommodate everybody by getting the people seated and bringing the foods out ASAP. Good job!
