"I must admit that my expectations were not entirely met during my recent visit to this establishment, as the reviews prior to my arrival had led me to anticipate a more exceptional experience. While I do consider myself somewhat discerning when it comes to comedic performances, I found the show to be merely adequate and, at times, even underwhelming. The seating arrangements, characterized by their antiquated, golden theater-style design, were also less than ideal, providing a level of discomfort that detracted from my overall enjoyment. Furthermore, the interactive nature of the performance, while intended to enhance the experience, proved to be hit-or-miss, with references to popular culture, such as World of Warcraft, being tossed about without much consideration for the unfamiliarity of certain audience members. Unfortunately, I found myself more often bored than amused, as the sketches tended to drag on excessively at times. All things considered, I do not foresee a future visit to this venue, although I do acknowledge its merits as a family-friendly destination."

"Culinary excellence, ambient surroundings, and satisfactory service converge to create a positive dining experience, albeit at a moderately elevated cost for the fare served during the luncheon period; however, the quality of the cuisine and the absence of overcrowding render the establishment worthy of future visits."

Grabbed a cab and headed over to Del Friscos arriving to find a dated kinda worn feel to it. Not comparable to a classy Chicago Steakhouse but more of a casual comes as you are feel,  The martini was well prepared and the portion was nice.

I am one for aesthetics and the first one that grabbed me was that the salad fork is the same size as the dinner fork. Call me weird, but I like big man sized utensils  for $50 dollar steaks. 

Now about that crab appetizer.  Being from the wine country, I know I am spoiled but if a big hunk crab mixed with a monstrous amount of Old Bay is your thing, you have come to the right place.  I will eat crab served with cardboard I like it so much, but truly just so so.

Next was the Wedge salad with blue cheese. This dish can be great when done right but if the lettuce is wet and leaking, the dressing and everything else turns mushy and bland.

But, drums please, the steak shines.  There I was with my miniature fork drinking some great cab and enjoying the heck out of my tender flavorful steak with some pretty tasty corn, spinach and mashed potatoes. (Yes I did order three sides.)

So maybe skip everything else and have a steak.

Great bartender was very well versed in the wine offerings and made the night a fun one.

I was walking on the strip and thinking which club to visit. A Bank representative outside Bellagio was handing out \"free entrance\" wrist bands, so I decided to give a try. Turns out it's not free, you still need to pay $20 (reduced price I was told) but you get a free drink. Line was not too long so I was in within 5 minutes. Used coat-check but they charge $5 (better pay than not lose it). I went to bar straight and presented my free-drink coupon, bar tender told my options, I picked one, it was an okay drink. I enjoyed my drink while watching gogo dancers and other girls dancing and partying. GoGo dancers were okay, beautiful but they barely showed some good moves, beautiful though, an friendly because people got pic with them. Girls in the club were beautiful. Did not get chance to dance but enjoyed the music, it was mix dance music and speakers were just loud enough. dance floor looked decent size. They also have VIP area for private parties. I might repeat.

"I have had the unfortunate experience of traversing both terminals within a single day, and let me tell you, it was an utter debacle. Terminal 1 caters exclusively to domestic flights, boasting a parking garage replete with covered parking spaces, albeit lacking the erstwhile coin-meter parking system, which I lament profusely. Nevertheless, the convenience of card payment has been implemented as a consolation prize. Passable cleanliness is all that can be expected from an airport, and Terminal 1 barely meets that standard. The staff manning the information desk exhibit remarkable friendliness and competence, while the departure and arrival signs are displayed clearly on modern LCD screens. However, the absence of signs indicating which escalators lead to specific flights from the floor level is a glaring oversight that warrants rectification. It is advisable to avoid scheduling flights during peak days such as Fridays and weekends, as the airport becomes congested and chaotic. 
Terminal 2, on the other hand, is designated for international flights and those bound for Hawaii. Unfortunately, the signs demarcating Terminal 2 are rather inconspicuous, making them easily missable. Efforts should be made to enhance accessibility and visibility by installing a prominent Terminal 2 sign. Uncovered parking spaces are available at the same rate as Terminal 1, but the ambiance leaves much to be desired. The atmosphere feels grimy, and visible dirt and grime are ubiquitous. To ensure a hygienic experience, it is imperative to bring sanitizing agents. Although there are only four baggage carousels, their limited number does not significantly impact efficiency, making it relatively straightforward to locate your belongings. Vigilance regarding personal effects is crucial, as Terminal 2 exudes an unsettling atmosphere that could be described as 'ghetto.'"

While the culinary experience I had the pleasure of indulging in boasted an unwavering commitment to authenticity and freshness, albeit with an excess of allium vegetables that slightly surpassed my personal preference; I was, unfortunately, constrained to opt for the pre-determined menu item, due to an absence of flexibility in customization. As a discerning gastronome who places great value on the judicious utilization of my hard-earned financial resources, I firmly believe that the realization of my precise culinary desires is essential when partaking in a dining establishment's offerings. Romeos, seemingly, adheres to a philosophy that emphasizes the uncompromising excellence of their carefully crafted dishes, and any divergence from this standard would ostensibly compromise the overall gustatory experience. Although I did not encounter an ideal harmony with the menu, I must admit that the assortment of sweet treats available was truly captivating, and if I were to return, it would be exclusively for the purpose of indulging in their delectable desserts.

Sigh. I really wanted to like this show. There were aspects of it that I did like but I didnt leave thinking "wow that was so good!" or "that was worth the $$" and I didnt even pay! 

The first part of the show, all you see is holly's back. -__-'' But no worries her boobies will come out later. 

Overall, I really liked the Green pole dancer. The chosen guy was really awkward cute n__n  Most of the girls surprisingly had real boobs. I've never seen so many boobies in my life. 

I suggest just waiting for discount tickets the night of or before the show. We watched it Christmas weekend and the row in front of us was completely empty.

I'm not really sure how to rate Kung Fu Tea, because it looks like a wonderful and hip boba addition to Vegas. However, our teas left a little to be desired. I think I would rate 3 stars for the actual drinks, 5 stars for the tea quality, and 5 stars for the service = 3.5 stars overall. 

We had the milk black tea and milk oolong tea. We chose 70% sugar, so it was not very sweet. I felt like that took away from being able to taste the flavor or the tea, because the drink tasted more diluted. I would definitely recommend just doing normal sugar, since their drinks are not too sweet. 

The tea leaves taste of high quality. Perhaps too high for us... the oolong is very woodsy and smoky, so you definitely have to really like oolong. The black tea has bergamot oil in it, so it tastes more floral. I thought it was nice, but my friend and bf thought it tasted soapy. My bf went back to the store and told them that he didn't like the taste, and they generously offered to make him something else. It was extremely nice that they were accommodating to personal preference. That alone will get me back to try some other teas next time I'm back in Vegas!

The best place to go for a mid-day pick me up. I love their banana Nutella one. It's not too sweet, just right. You can also try their smoothies, which are the same price as the Beaver Tails (probably a better deal 'cause you get actual fruits instead of sugar).

I've been gunnin' for a Mongolian stir fry in the QC for a long, long time. I have great memories of heading to a similar style of restaurant when I was a wee girl. So, it wasn't too much of a surprise that I was jacked when I read that we now have a Genghis Grill in Charlotte! 

The Good: 
As others have said, you really make your own meal here. As in - if you don't love the components, well, it's your fault. There are a ton of topping options - proteins, starches, veggies, sauces, spices, etc. The instruction from the staff is definitely on point and helpful as you navigate the bowl bar. Overall, I liked my bowl and was able to make it super spicy with plenty of dragon sauce, jalapeno and red pepper. My mouth was on fuego. Plus, prices are pretty affordable at $8.99 for a lunch bowl and $9.99 for a dinner bowl. The kiddos will love this place. 

The Meh: 
It's a chainy chain, so I didn't really find much character in the restaurant. While the service was great, I really didn't have a desire to stay any longer than I needed to. Plus, the quality of the proteins was definitely lacking for me...the shrimp are incredibly tiny and quite a bit of my steak was a bit grisly. 

Would I head back to Genghis Gril? Surely. You have the opportunity to make a healthy meal that's quick and pretty affordable. It's absolutely A-OK in my book.

Played here on 11/26/05\nCourse was in great shape. Greens were slow. Some amazing views and some not so amazing views on the course. Great course for ladies as their tees only play to 4400. Good value for 100 bucks not quite as challenging as Wildfire.

Visiting town from Colorado, my friend and I love Hawaiian restaurants. Moki's was good. Nice menu selection. Got the chicken katsu and short ribs. Pretty good. Ribs were a little tough, and the katsu sauce was t great. A little pricey also.

It's a hassle to get served if you don't have a reservation.  The bar area is packed and you really have to move fast to score a place to sit.\n\nThat being said, the swedish meatballs were excellent!

Affordable eatery and the food tastes pretty good too. Changs Spicy Chicken is pretty good though the Hot and Sour soup could go easy on the sodium. Dimly lit interior fits in with the whole vibe and style of cuisine. Pretty friendly waiting staff and the service is above average. Lots of drinks to choose from. PF Changs is a nice establishment to venture to every few months.

First visit and I had a drip coffee and the tuna sandwich. Both were excellent. Sandwich though was borderline pricey @ $8.  Service was efficient and prompt. Ambiance was nothing special and had a very much starbucks feel. \n\nOverall impressions: not bad, not great

So let's start with 5 stars....well they lose a star just on service.   When I was there this afternoon there was only one other customer.   From the time I ordered to the time I received my food. ..15 minutes...a car pulled up behind me and eventually pulled over and the couple walked inside.  Another star lost due the food  being very heavy on the salt.   However on the plus side the man who took my order was very polite and made sure my order was correct and that I had all my extras condiments.   This place was first known via Food Network's Diners DriveIns and Dives....well this location is a dive. So that is factored in as well. Evidently they filmed at the Decatur St location.   My Pastrami Burger was as delicious as advertised.   The highlight however were the garlic fries.  Absolutely awesome!!  They are thin but moist and flavorful. .....Overall I will go back to try again but maybe try the other location.   It is also rather expensive but you do get a lot of food. ......

My biggest complaint is that the restaurant was FREEZING!!! I realize it's winter, but the AC was on inside. \nThe pico and guac were delicious! I also got the fish tacos which were great. The ceviche wasn't what we expected... Not bad though. \nI wouldn't go out of my way to come here to eat, but I would come back again.

As a gambling lover, I always love coming to vegas.  I've been to many casinos in northern california such as red hawk, cache creek, thunder valley, and even one in redding called win-river casino.  I have never been asked if I wanted a massage while playing cards until today at a pai gow table.  We had a full table and the player on the right of me accepted the massage offer from the worker, which then turned the player's chair around and put a giant cushion in front of him to relax on.  During the game, the massager was going all out on the player beside me.  After ten minutes, the massager told the player that it was $20 and if he wanted to continue for more.  Pretty sweet deal if you ask me.  

As far as their cocktail waitresses, they rarely ever came by to serve us drinks.  I'd say they came by once every 2 hours.  Overall, I'd go back for sure some day to gamble.

Three stars for being an average casino that was good, but nothing stood out from the hotel to me except for the massage therapist.

"Audibly boisterous ambient sonance permeates the atmosphere, precipitating an exclusive reliance on paper currency for financial transactions, while simultaneously accentuating the prominence of mammary glands in the visual realm. Patrons are advised to prepare themselves for prolonged periods of standing, as the prospect of seating appears improbable, given the densely packed nature of the venue. The musical offerings, characterized by their cacophonous quality, are likely to induce euphoria among aficionados of the genre. Furthermore, the presence of female patrons engaging in rhythmic movements atop the bar serves as a testament to the establishment's convivial ambiance. However, it is worth noting that certain staff members, specifically those tasked with the dispensation of potent beverages, exhibit a propensity towards facetious behavior. Notwithstanding the aforementioned attributes, a significant segment of the patronage, including this pale-complected, flaxen-haired individual, experienced feelings of apprehension and discomfort amidst the throngs of rugged, leather-clad bikers, whose demeanor seemed to convey a sense of disapproval."

i was just driving by to my hotel and one of my friends spotted this place on the side of the road so we went and tested it out i didnt get fries but my buddy said it was a terrible choice and wishes he got fried zuchini instead which was outstanding by the way it was so good i had the farmers omelete it was so good and the hash browns were so good i had way to much food def had the itis afterwards and passed out food was delicious though

Cute spot. Good food.

The only thing I wanted from Eat was not available--the beignets!! Ugh. My heart was crushed to learn they didn't have any :( Alas, I opted for a chicken sandwich and it was good; nothing too special. The service was okay and given how small the menu is, I expect the staff to know the ingredients of the menu items which wasn't the case.

Would I return? Only If I happened to be in the area but wouldn't be my first choice.

if you're into heavy, rich food, Cowboy Ciao is your place.  i wasn't thoroughly impressed with the food, but the service is good.  very welcoming hostess, if i do say so myself.\n\nhonestly, i'd rather walk around the corner to fnb - it's way better.

This is one of the many MGM-Mirage properties on the strip.  The casino and hotel staff are all welcoming and friendly.   The casino floor and selection of shops and eateries is  decent and complete.\n\nThe casino floor and shops are all looking very nice with the New York theme design and  layout (Obviously very well maintained). The hotel rooms, however, are starting to look a little dated and might be due for updating (My room had a tube TV, which seems like a ancient relic now in 2009 - especially for a large, reputable, mid-strip property).

"The female individual stationed at the forefront of the establishment exhibited a profound lack of courtesy and respect towards us, leaving me in a state of considerable perturbation. Despite having placed an order for seven separate batches of dumplings to be taken away (amounting to a total of seventy individual dumplings), we were provided with only fifty, with the expectation that we would fail to notice the discrepancy. Furthermore, the manner in which the dumplings were handed over to us was utterly unacceptable, as the container was leaking copiously and the woman in question bestowed upon us a most disagreeable facial expression and audible gesture of disdain when requested to furnish us with an additional receptacle. It is utterly confounding and vexing to be subjected to such egregious mistreatment, particularly when taking into account the exorbitant price we paid for the meal. The culinary offerings themselves, however, were quite delectable and satisfying, and we extend our gratitude to the younger waitress who demonstrated a pleasing demeanor and generosity by providing us with supplementary condiments."

"A visually stunning lodging facility, yet the culinary establishments affiliated with said premises possess pricing structures that are marginally prohibitive for local patrons. Notwithstanding, the live entertainment options, specifically the 'Yellow Brick Road' and 'Steel Panther' performances, are of considerable quality. The aquatic recreational area is quite impressive, but unfortunately, we were compelled to vacate the premises on a recent Saturday afternoon to accommodate a nuptial ceremony, which resulted in an abrupt and hasty departure, thereby necessitating the settlement of an outstanding financial obligation."

I think I was a victim of over-hyped burgers.
There was nothing bad about "the burger," and it was good, but there wasn't nothing particularly mind-blowing, either.  
The quality of the meat was very good, and my burger was cooked fine; however, I appreciate a well-seasoned burger with a lot of flavor more than just good meat.  I actually had to put a tiny dash of salt on the burger to help it out.  

The side salad I got instead of homefries was small but good, with excellent dressing.  My date ordered a grilled chicken sandwich that was good, but, again, no seasoning.  

I recommend you try Tessaro's at least once, but don't go in with lofty expectations.

The culinary experience offered by this establishment during the evening hours was merely satisfactory, barely meeting expectations and falling short of exceptional quality. No, I must emphasize that it was indeed subpar, lacking in both flavor and presentation. Absolutely ordinary, it failed to leave a lasting impression on my palate or memory. While the ambiance was somewhat notable, the hospitality was merely sufficient, with servers exhibiting a perfunctory attitude towards their duties. In conclusion, this restaurant did not excel in any particular aspect, offering an unremarkable dining experience that would not warrant repeat visits.

La Place Dupuis est en quelque sorte un fant\u00f4me. Aujourd'hui convertie en un centre commercial associ\u00e9 \u00e0 un h\u00f4tel et \u00e0 une tour \u00e0 bureaux, elle n'a pas vraiment de personnalit\u00e9 et vit en quelque sorte dans l'ombre de la vocation premi\u00e8re de cet \u00e9difice. En effet, la Place Dupuis occupe une place importante dans l'histoire du Qu\u00e9bec, puisqu'on y trouvait jusque dans les ann\u00e9es 1970 la grande surface Dupuis et fr\u00e8res, une sorte de Wal-Mart fond\u00e9e et exploit\u00e9e par une famille de Canadiens fran\u00e7ais. Si vous faites des recherches dans les archives des quotidiens existants et disparus de Montr\u00e9al, vous allez d\u00e9couvrir que le plus important annonceur \u00e9tait le plus souvent Dupuis et fr\u00e8res, dont les sp\u00e9ciaux s'\u00e9talaient le plus souvent sur plusieurs pages. Cet \u00e9tablissement fond\u00e9 au 19e si\u00e8cle n'\u00e9tait pas seulement un grand magasin tr\u00e8s populaire, mais \u00e9tait en quelque sorte un symbole de r\u00e9ussite pour les Canadiens fran\u00e7ais. Aujourd'hui, on y trouve surtout des comptoirs de restauration rapide, tr\u00e8s populaires aupr\u00e8s des employ\u00e9s de la tour \u00e0 bureaux et des \u00e9tudiants de l'UQAM, qui y mangent le midi. On y trouve \u00e9galement plusieurs d\u00e9taillants, dont un Bureau en gros, mais je ne crois pas qu'il s'agit d'une destination de magasinage pour qui que ce soit. On passe par la Place Dupuis, qui est connect\u00e9e au m\u00e9tro Berri-UQAM, et on y fait des achats en passant s'il y a lieu, mais sans plus.

We stopped in again for a chocolate concrete which comes with one add on, in this case toasted coconut which did nothing for the shake.  A great shake, but I am glad we decided to share since it was very filling.

I love my chinese food - so I always jump at the chance to go and review a chinese restaurant. We chose this place because of its excellent happy hour deal; something which seems to be amiss throughout the area's chinese restaurants. However, even without the happy hour deals, I would venture this place is a pretty low budget night out as it is. This is reflected in the quality and taste of the food - its not the best I have ever had, and one of my dining companions questioned what type of meat was in his dish more than once. However, as I mentioned, this place is cheap, and you get what you pay for - something not to great, but filling and cheap.

We visited this restaurant for an evening meal in the company of my significant other's relatives. This establishment was a familiar setting for them, and it was my initial visit. The cost-to-portion ratio was reasonable. Upon entering with an empty stomach, I departed feeling thoroughly satiated.

The ambiance was not particularly luxurious, but the cuisine was satisfactory for the items we ordered. I opted for the walnut shrimp and wonton noodle soup. The shrimp possessed a gratifying crunchiness in the appropriate regions, while the broth accompanying the soup lacked flavor and the noodles exhibited a somewhat rigid texture. My companion enjoyed the duck dish, devouring the entire portion. He expressed satisfaction with his meal, although I have sampled more flavorful duck at Sam Woo. The sweet and sour soup conformed to its name, and the crispy noodles were characterized by their delicate thinness and crispness.

The staff provided commendable service, displaying kindness and helpfulness throughout our dining experience. They maintained a clean table setting, repeatedly clearing away our used dishes and keeping our water glasses consistently replenished.

The facilities for personal hygiene were adequate. However, a cart containing soiled dishes remained stationary near our table, prompting mild curiosity regarding its purpose. Nevertheless, the staff members addressed this concern by periodically removing it. Ultimately, the affordability of this eatery made it accessible for families.

As I have said many times I love Italian. When I ended up at near by Best Western I looked up the best rated restaurant on Yelp that was nearby. I ended up at the small Restaurant Foccaccio. It was Italian but it wasn't up to the quality I have had in other restaurants. My biggest complaint was the Parmesan cheese. When i eat Italian I like fresh Parmesan, not something out of a bottle. Food was tasty, but portions were a little on the small side. I would eat here again, but if you are looking for an above average mom and pop Italian restaurant, this isn't it.

I would definitely stay here again. I wasn't expecting luxury by any means but I also wasn't expecting it to be as decent as it was. We needed a last minute place to stay and booked a room for that night for $50. You get what you pay for, and those that complain about how grungy it was should have known that when they booked it. It is pretty far off the strip, but not nearly as far as Hard Rock. They sell $1.50 Bud Lights at the bar inside which is always a plus. I joined the Owl Club to get the $200 free slot play. I didn't win anything but I didn't lose anything either. The people that worked the counter were friendly and accommodating. The room was clean and had a television, what more can you ask for? Like I said, I definitely would stay here again when I was looking for a cheap hotel option in Vegas.

Oh and just a warning, the walls are REALLY thin and you can hear pretty much everything going on in the room next to you. If you are going to Vegas for a quiet experience you are in the wrong place anyways.

Also, DO NOT go to the Hooters inside the hotel. Its absolutely awful. (see my other review)

Last evening, in the company of a companion, I had the pleasure of partaking in a culinary excursion at this esteemed establishment, whereupon I must say that the hospitality we received was somewhat inconsistent. Specifically, our server, a young woman of considerable charm and expediency, provided us with attentive and timely service. However, my associate and I were rather dismayed by the extreme tartness of the margaritas we ordered, which regrettably bore a stronger resemblance to frozen drinks of a less refined nature than the sophisticated cocktails we had anticipated. Nonetheless, my gastronomic experience was not entirely unpleasant, as I did derive satisfaction from the Bleu Cheese Chopped Salad, an intriguing composition featuring a vegan cheese substitute of Danish provenance, which lent a unique and subtle flavor to the dish. Furthermore, the side of potatoes that accompanied my meal was quite delectable. In conclusion, while certain aspects of our visit fell short of expectations, I would not rule out the possibility of a future return.

Wine list is ok, not what I would have expected for a Wine Spectator award winner, and the markup is ENORMOUS. Generally the fish menu is sustainable but when I commented to the waitress about the CRITICALLY ENDANGERED Chilean sea bass she didn't even know the difference between farmed and wild caught fish let alone what sustainable meant - wait staff needs to be trained on that. Quality and flavor of the dinners was great overall, but the risotto side dish had zero flavor - where's the salt?? Beautiful view but in my opinion NOT totally worth $100 per person for dinner...and that didn't even include an appetizer or dessert!

"Four years have elapsed since their inauguration, and upon entering the establishment, I observed a dearth of patrons, with merely two individuals occupying the chairs, engaging in conversation. The absence of a queue afforded me the luxury of immediate attention, as I was promptly escorted to the station previously utilized by my threader. Following a succinct inquiry regarding my exposure to this treatment, she embarked on the process, initiating with a thorough sanitization of both her hands and my brows. 

The specialist executed her tasks with utmost efficiency, employing a systematic approach characterized by rolling, grasping broad sections, and exerting forceful pulls. My apprehensions concerning the potential for discomfort were quickly dispelled, as my initial encounter proved to be remarkably painless. However, during the subsequent session, I experienced an unanticipated jolt of surprise, as the cleaning procedure produced an intensified sensation that caught me off guard. Upon completion, my countenance allegedly reflected a state of perpetual astonishment, according to my companion's observation. Notwithstanding, I appreciated the benefits of having well-defined brows with a conspicuous contour, complemented by a gentle brush and clip at the conclusion. The entire process transpired within a span of 10 to 15 minutes. 

Although my previous exposure to this technique was somewhat more satisfying, as it yielded a more natural outcome with the bottoms being merely cleaned up and not artificially shaped, thus providing me with a fuller appearance, I must acknowledge that the precision displayed in the work merits praise. To ensure optimal results, I shall strive to communicate my preferences more effectively during future appointments. With a price point of $10, this service falls within the standard range offered by most threading salons."

I tried the regular coffee. Average. Haven't tried the flavors like the other folks have so I will be looking for some " must have " suggestions! 
Average cup of Joe, but.. that said the staff is awesome and gets my morning going. I am not a morning person but on my way into school they totally get me ready for people interaction or... maybe that is the caffeine. Well, I like the staff so I say its them. Will be going back and may just have to adjust the gold stars if I like what my fellow yelpers recommend!! Post those suggestions. 

Overly Caffinated and so loving it!

I'd been here a while back for a Yelp event so we headed here when we were looking for a place to chill rather than get onto a crowded Light Rail train. Extremely loud music and really, not all that good. But we had a couple of beers and managed to shout over the racket for a bit.\n\nIf you're planning a visit, I'd recommend avoiding the band. Why does it have to be so damn loud?

"During my recent visit to Las Vegas, I opted to indulge in one of the city's renowned buffets, having heard tales of their extraordinary culinary offerings. While Caesar's Palace is often lauded as the premier destination for such indulgences, I chose to explore an alternative establishment boasting an equally impressive reputation. My expectations were admittedly high, and while certain aspects of the meal did not entirely disappoint, several elements fell short of my lofty standards. Specifically, the meat selection was subpar, with the prime rib and roast beef lacking the succulence and flavor I had anticipated. Furthermore, some of the side dishes failed to impress, with their flavors being described as uninspired and insipid. Although the ambiance was pleasant and the variety of options extensive, the quality of the food did not justify the exorbitant prices charged. The saving grace of the meal proved to be the delectable desserts, particularly the Creme Brulee and assorted pastries, which truly excelled. However, a superior dining experience should not rely solely on its sweet offerings; the entire meal must deliver an exceptional taste and value. Additionally, the service left much to be desired, as my server was frequently unavailable, leaving me to fend for myself amidst a mounting pile of dirty dishes. In summary, while the experience was not without its merits, significant improvements in both food quality and service are necessary to warrant such extravagant pricing."

"Prioritizing primacy, I would never consider patronizing Digger, as my decision is predicated on an unwavering commitment to personal preference, rather than any personal animosity towards the establishment; albeit, I can appreciate the aesthetic appeal of its sunshine-colored facade, complemented by an array of charming hanging decorations, artisanal greeting cards, and visually striking ornaments, et cetera. Nonetheless, it regrettably fails to resonate with my individualized sensibilities, thereby rendering it incongruous with my distinctive tastes and preferences. Notwithstanding, I can conjecture that the shop's quaint charm may hold appeal for certain demographics, such as mothers and daughters, who might relish the opportunity to peruse its 'twee' assortment, as characterized by my mother."

The steaks we had were disappointing for the price. We both order medium rare, my wife got a rare steak and I got medium. They argued that they we're cook correctly.  \n\nI have better steak at Outback, longhorn.

My third favorite steakhouse. They have the best blooming onion and green vegetable selections with brocolli, string beans, and asparagus. Texas Roadhouse edges them in the steak department. Outback also had the better mushrooms. Delfrisco's has the best steak with a steak called the Wygul but it is pricey. The front entrance position is a little weird to me. That's just my 2 cent.

"En route to Noodles of Asia for a 6:00 pm luncheon prior to our 11:30 pm dinner reservations at Raku (conventional dining hours do not apply, as it is Vegas!), we chanced upon Pinot Brasserie and, after a cursory examination of the menu, deemed it innocuous enough to warrant further exploration. The prices were reasonable, with $9.00 for a bowl of French onion soup and $15.00 for mussels and frites. Upon partaking of the culinary offerings, I found myself already yearning for the mussels a mere hour later, which is a testament to their gastronomical appeal. The white wine, butter, and garlic sauce combination was truly divine, particularly when one submerges the frites in said sauce for a brief interlude, allowing the flavors to meld together in a most harmonious manner. The French onion soup was also noteworthy, as it was one of the more superior examples of this particular dish that I have had the pleasure of consuming. It is all too common for establishments to rely on salt as a means of masking the absence of genuine onion flavor in their soups, but at Pinot Brasserie, the onion broth is allowed to shine in its unadulterated form, much to my gustatory delight. In conclusion, the edible aspects of our experience were indeed satisfactory. However, the quality of service left much to be desired. Our server was abysmal, displaying a complete lack of warmth or welcoming demeanor. She seemed taken aback by our expressions of gratitude, failing to demonstrate even a semblance of cordiality. Her attempts to promote dessert were also overly zealous, bordering on annoying. I must stress that a smile and a modicum of friendliness would greatly enhance her tip earning potential."

"If you seek exceptional lodging experiences, it is advisable to explore alternative options. My personal encounters with various Las Vegas establishments have led me to conclude that the MGM resort falls short of expectations. Upon arrival, I discovered that my reservation for a spacious suite had been erroneously oversubscribed, and the staff offered to downgrade me to a significantly smaller accommodation. This proposition seemed utterly inadequate, considering the premium price point and my anticipation of an indulgent stay. A comprehensive assessment of the property reveals a pervasive lackluster quality, extending from the guest rooms to the gaming facilities, outdoor pool, and customer service. Those seeking a truly memorable and luxurious getaway would be well-advised to redirect their patronage elsewhere."

Still a solid three stars from me, which again needs to be put into context of what I enjoy from a bar and a night out. It's a proper pub-bar with a cheeky Australian theme. Postcards of boobs and bums above the bar, a sign saying "dickhead" pointing to an empty space where an unsuspecting punter will stand, slightly sticky and dusty. Reminds me of a slightly better kept student union.

But the crowd are friendly, the bar staff fare no-nonsense friendly. There's one side of the bar that has a big sign saying NO SERVICE do not stand here. If you stand there, they'll be upset. If you don't, they'll be a-ok.

There's two pool tables though, and for me that's a total winner. Just take note of the method of getting a game (adding your name to the chalk board list). The players are friendly and just adding your name up means you'll probably get chatting to some interesting folk.

Standard drinks (as in, no cocktails) for a bar. Good wee location. Inundated with Australians on Australia Day. Not too shabby.

The most recent Vegas trip was the first time I got to eat in China town and I was excited to find out they had a ramen place. We arrived just in to time to beat the crowd. I went with a group of five and we got seated within 15 minutes. I ordered the \"screaming for vengeance\" with corn because I love spicy ramen but was disappointed it wasn't spicy enough. I am still in search to find the most spiciest ramen. The broth was on the saltier side, I am not sure if its because I've been drinking and my taste were off. The broth was ok but I was disappointed that the food was not piping hot. However, the really like the pork belly, talk about fatty goodness. The noodles were cooked al dente and had a really nice texture. This place is a solid 3.5 stars in my books.

This place is pretty fun. The drinks are neat concoctions and pretty expensive. We went last night and got two entrees and two drinks. With a $20 off coupon it was still $60! But we have gone there before and it is a fun place to go in Vegas! The food was delicious and the staff was friendly

A ton of tea on offer and my raspberry hibiscus iced tea was brewed perfectly. I'd frequent this place if it were closer and not in the middle of Tempe Marketplace.\n\nLess stars because they were out of my first choice and the guy running the till went into an anti-Starbucks rant not knowing I was with a Starbucks manager. Have your opinions but it's not really something to start going off about in front of first-time (or really any) customers. You never know who's listening!

OK. The owner contacted me and was rather disconcerted about my one star rating and review. He should genuine interest in ameliorating the problem and expressed thanks for my review information to help him do so. He seems to be an owner who really does care and doesn't just discount a review as \"some idiot out there\" as many owners do. I raised the review from 1 to 3 stars because of his pro-activeness. He offered for me to come in when he was working to discuss the matter further. I will probably go back in again and amend the score if it warrants.

I work late somtimes and they are open rather late and do not mind if you show up 5 min before closing time. The food is better then the normal cheap chinese/asain type places. Ask for a suggestion and they will give it. \n\nChicken fried rice is my usual.

"As an employee on the North Side, I decided to take a stroll in search of a novel lunch option, having grown weary of the monotony of dining at Eco Bistro, located directly beneath my office at Allegheny Center. During my peregrination, I chanced upon this eatery situated at the confluence of Ohio Avenue and the onramp leading to 279; the luncheon special was offered at a reasonable price, and I opted to accompany my meal with a carbonated beverage, bringing the total cost to approximately $6. The culinary delight I selected was the Kung Pao Chicken, which was cooked to my exacting specifications. The gastronomical experience was satisfying, economical, and expedient, and I chose to consume my repast within the establishment, which boasted a modest number of tables and maintained a level of cleanliness that was, at the very least, decent."

This place has awesome ratings on both yelp and zagat, but i was so disappointed. My expectations must've been too high. I WILL give them props for having the *best* and most smooth Thai Iced Tea I've ever had in my life though. Onto their food? The waiter suggested their duck in red curry. The duck meat tasted a bit... expired.. and rotten. It was also rough, and the curry lacked in flavor. We also ordered a green curry with chicken, which wasn't bad, but it didn't amaze me. I've had much better green curry at any reg Thai joint back home in New York. Now... the appetizer that the waiter said we HAD to order was GROSS. It's some crispy rice sort of thing.. and it's sour, and sour, and sour, and also expired tasting. Why is it their most popular item? People in Vegas must be weird then, sorry guys. \n\nOh, the lady behind the bar area was also rude. She had a huge diamond on her finger and wasn't in a uniform, so she might be some kind of owner/manager. To me though, that means you should step it up a level and be even more nice, not be a snotface. Skinny face, medium long black hair, pale, slender asian woman with a big rock -- BEWARE OF HER, she will make your whole meal unpleasant.

Casanova is a cute little Italian restaurant in the Venetian. Unfortunately, I didn't know how small it was. I had a table reservation for 13 people and was seated outside the actual restaurant which was really the middle of the walkway of the Grand Canal Shoppes. It was extremely loud, especially since there is a bar not 10 feet away. It's also right before the food court so there was a ton of food traffic throughout dinner. I would definitely reccommend this place if you were in a small group, up to 4 at the most. They would most likely seat you inside where it is very adorably decorated.

For an Italian restaurant at The Venetian, the food was extremely affordable. I got the Timballo which is basically penne in a creamy pesto sauce baked with parmesan on top. It was so flavorful and very filling; I wasn't able to finish my plate. The bread they serve you is so good too and delightfully roasted and warm. 

If you want good Italian at a reasonable cost, I definitely suggest Casanova.

"A profusion of commercial activity permeates this establishment, rendering it a veritable hub of transactional velocity. Frequently, an abundance of patrons seeking to avail themselves of the wares offered within results in the formation of protracted queues; however, such lines tend to dissipate with reasonable celerity. Certain items available for purchase at this location possess a quality that renders them particularly advantageous, often at a cost of $0.99 or, on occasion, two items for $0.99. While this store may not boast the most extensive inventory of such establishments in the vicinity, its proximity to my domicile renders it a convenient option. Despite the occasional untidiness of the premises, I customarily enter with the intention of acquiring a specific item, only to find myself succumbing to impulsive purchases totaling no less than $5-$10."

Due to location (convenience factor) I decided to check out Beijing instead of my usual fave Ho Ho Cherry House.

I ordered the Sesame chicken (extra crispy) and was pleasantly surprised that for 8 and change you receive a generous portion of chicken, fried rice, egg roll, choice of soup - I went won-ton, and even a little steamed broccoli. Ho ho cherry house doesn't offer soup or broccoli- so I was really pleased.

My order took only 10 minutes - and it tasted cook-to-order. 

I really enjoyed their egg-roll's - definitely better than Ho-Ho's.They use more than just cabbage which is key. The rice was tasty- and the soup was awesome! I actually gave some to the girls that I was babysitting and lets say Ive never seen a 4 year old  down won-ton soup broth versus the chocolate ice cream in front of her! 

Where they fell off the wagon was the crispiness factor. Unfortunately, that is kind of my main test for Chinese and the chicken just wasn't crispy at all. I would hate to see what it would be like if I didn't order extra crispy- it would have been mush! I also didn't care for the sauce as much as Ho-Ho's.

The sides were all cooked so well- and you can't beat the price or the location so I think id try it again and really stress the EXTRA crispy part!

"Our culinary escapade at this eatery can be summarized as a predominantly satisfactory encounter, with a few nuanced exceptions. My dining companion and I opted for the slider trio, accompanied by a side of jalapeno coleslaw. While our expectations were elevated in anticipation of an unparalleled gustatory experience, the slaw failed to surpass our already lofty standards, instead eliciting a rather tepid response. The texture of the pulled pork left something to be desired, its resemblance to pork roast rendering it somewhat unremarkable. However, the hot link proved to be an unmitigated delight, its fiery zest leaving an indelible impression on our palates. Unfortunately, our enthusiasm was temporarily curtailed by the underwhelming country berry cobbler, which regrettably lacked the requisite sweetness we had eagerly anticipated. Notwithstanding these minor drawbacks, the ambiance of the establishment exuded a warm, welcoming quality, ably complemented by the charming personal touches embodied in their murals. Suffice it to say, our initial visit has kindled our desire to return and sample their other offerings, particularly the smoked meatloaf, which we have been led to believe is a veritable gastronomic masterpiece."

A good friend of mine is a secret fan of gift shops- he can spend hours in them- so long as they are the official ones. Well this one is an official one and despite the twee gift ideas and corny souvenirs there are some more classier and elegant gift ideas in here. 

The quality is also much better than the cheaper alternatives on the Royal mile, minus the bad and loud music and bright colours the later ones have. 
So it really depends on your budget and how much you want to hunt around for gifts or souvenirs. I like the service in the gift shop- the lady is always so nice and didn't mind my friend browsing for an age either. (and didn't follow us around like a certain other cheaper gift shop did). If you payed to get into the Castle might as well have a walk around even if you do choose the cheaper options down the street.

I like the atmosphere , it seems familiar but it's not . 

We tried the lunch special that was an open faced green chili meatloaf sandwich and the grilled salmon salad . Both dishes came out pretty as a picture with the food stacked high .

The meatloaf sandwich had mashed potatoes over the bread and a tasty cole slaw on top of the meatloaf . Unfortunately the potatoes were very over mixed and were extremely gummy .

The salmon salad overall was good and I am not sure if I didn't like the chive risotto cake or maybe the flavor of it clashed with the citrus dressing .

Service was fine .

I would come back again but I am not in a hurry .

I had 40 mins to kill and the place was packed, so I was worried about how quick service was based on other reviews.

I snagged a tabled, within 5 mins I had a drink, and even though I was quoted 20 mins on buffalo wings, I got them in under 10. 

Service overall was great.

The wings were vinegary, and they had the heat, but I wouldn't get them again. Two guys next to me got the fish and chips and they said they were good. 

Also, food is priced well, but 9$ for a 22oz Stella? Yikes!

Although I wasn't ecstatic about the food, the service was good. The guy who served us was very accommodating to our needs. Honestly, I don't think I can even give a proper review because I'm a vegetarian. Being named Mr.Tofu, I wrongly assumed that there would be some veggie dishes. To my dismay, there was 1. It was a cold tofu noodle soup. It literally had 3 ingredients. There was noodles, tofu broth (which I'm guessing was made from tofu juice), and ice. It tasted like tofu, which is bland without incorporating any outside elements. I had to eat kimchee with the soup in order to taste anything. The side dishes were good because they added flavor to my meal. I probably won't stop by unless I go back to eating meat.

Can someone tell me why these are so posh?  Name? Comfort? Style?  \n\nBecause my opinion only is that they don't look comfortable, and the style is very old looking, not for someone in their 20's.  But maybe I'm wrong, and it I am, for all you lovers, half the store was 50% off as of last week!!

5 stars for the concept itself (bringing a cupcake store to Scottsdale) and the bright airy store environment. I am totally not a big fan of sweet so maybe my overall rating is a bit biased, but I've had cupcakes at Magnolia (NY) and absolutely loved every single bite.  Sprinkle's, however, didn't really strike me in the same way. I thought they were extremely overtly sweet =/\n\nOne other thing when we were sharing a red velvet, the top came off ! WTH?!

Interesting food creations, using lobster in sandwiches, salad, fried food, and ice cream!  However, the foods in fact tasted just A-OK and prices were sorta steep.  $23 for a 6\" lobster roll was pricey, I think.  The lobster salad came with lots of small chunks of lobster meat and was good for the price.  Lobster bisque was just standard.  Lobster-n-chips was cool though! Beer-battered and fried lobster huh? Yummmmm~  Last but not least, the lobster ice cream that sounded out of the ordinary was actually vanilla ice cream with itsy-bitsy lobster meat.  The ice cream tasted alright but was worth a try!  Just ask for a free sample before you buy, so as to make sure that you would like some savory ice cream that tastes like seafood. *wink*

Located inside the Tuscany Casino where we stayed while in Vegas for a convention.

Our party of ten came for dinner.  Plenty of seating for large groups.  Our server was very patient and didn't get frazzled when we all wanted to use our 2 for 1 dinner entree coupon.

Food was decent.  Prices decent.  Portion size decent.

"While not an epicurean extravaganza, this unpretentious eatery offers a satisfactory dining experience, suitable for a casual luncheon or evening meal, and provides an appropriate ambiance for socializing with companions."

"If you possess an unwavering predilection for carne asada, and I mean a genuine, unrelenting fondness for this delectable dish, then it is imperative that you pay a visit to this culinary establishment. However, if your gastronomical inclinations lean towards a more diverse array of options, you may find the menu offerings to be somewhat restrictive. The primary dishes available are carne asada tacos, burritos, tostadas (dubbed 'Vampiro'), and quesadillas, with a solitary vegetarian entrÃ©e and, naturally, chips and salsa accompanying them. Be that as it may, the carne asada itself boasts a commendable quality, as I can personally attest to having sampled both the Vampiro and the quesadilla. While some patrons have expressed discontent regarding the supplementary cost of chips and salsa, it is essential to note that such an additional expense is customary in the realm of counter-service eateries. Moreover, the chips are freshly prepared, and the salsa, though lacking in piquancy, presents a flavor profile that is undeniably captivating. In conclusion, this restaurant merits a visit, particularly for those whose taste buds crave the savory allure of carne asada."

"This assessment pertains exclusively to the eyebrow-waxing service provided by the establishment in question. Upon entering the premises on a Saturday afternoon, I was promptly attended to and ushered to the rear of the facility within a mere five-minute timeframe, thereby circumventing any potential delay. Notably, my customary eyebrow-waxing venue is located approximately thirty minutes away from my current location and typically boasts a sixty-minute waiting period solely for eyebrow waxing. In contrast, this particular establishment enjoys a significantly more convenient proximity to my residence. Previously accustomed to a greater emphasis on plucking rather than waxing, I opted to take a chance on this salon despite my reservations. Unfortunately, the outcome left my eyebrows appearing considerably more diminutive than anticipated. However, I have yet to observe any regrowth nearly a week post-service, which constitutes a positive aspect of the experience. The price point for the service itself proved reasonable, set at ten dollars. In the event that I find myself in a predicament wherein I require an expedited eyebrow-waxing procedure, I would consider returning to this establishment. It is worth noting that while they do indeed accept card payments, they express a preference for gratuities tendered in cash."

"On a Sunday, I ventured into this establishment for the first time, taking advantage of their extended hours until midnight, which was quite convenient. However, my experience with the sushi was rather unremarkable, warranting only three stars from me due to the usage of non-organic edamame and soy sauce. As an advocate for sustainable and natural food sources, I find it challenging to support restaurants that serve genetically modified soybeans, which unfortunately, seem to be the norm nowadays. Despite this, I maintain hope that more establishments will prioritize organic and non-GMO verified ingredients in the future, even if it may appear futile at present, considering the majority of consumers remain oblivious to the implications of GMO consumption."

I chose Mesa Grill after hearing Delmonico's is way overrated. Having eaten at the Bahamas location, and despite my aversion to Bobby Flay, I decided to give the Las Vegas MG a try.

1. Awkward seating arrangement: We had a table of six, and it seemed like they had to put a table in the middle of a seating arrangement in order to fit us. We would've been perfectly fine if the wait staff wasn't continually bumping into my friends' chairs and then asking them to move out the way. That was uncool.

2. Food was great. Everyone was really happy with their dishes. Amongst the six of us, we ordered the duck, ribeye and pork tenderloins. For sides, pesto mashed potatoes, baby carrots, tiger shrimp tamale and sauteed spinach. We had to wait a bit for a couple of the sides because the waitress forgot them, but it wasn't too bad. Food came out hot and tasty.

3. Desserts were okay. I enjoyed my spicy chocolate creme brulee in the Bahamas more than the profiteroles I had. I thought they were really stingy with the iced cream which put me off a bit.

4. Service was alright. Our waitress was chatty and came around a few times to check on us.

Mesa Grill Las Vegas didn't disappoint and I wouldn't be against visiting BF's other restaurants.

"Obsolete and antiquated, the existing Target establishment situated at the intersection of Camelback Road and Seventh Avenue, is slated for a comprehensive renovation and metamorphosis into an upgraded, state-of-the-art 'Super Store' format, much to the delight of local patrons who eagerly anticipate the unveiling of the revamped retail hub. However, it is worth noting that not all individuals share the same level of enthusiasm regarding the transformation, with some expressing reservations about the'superstore' designation and the potential for a homogenized, big-box shopping experience that may compromise the distinctiveness and specialization of traditional retail establishments. Furthermore, certain patrons have taken issue with the temporary scarcity of select items and the perceived dearth of adept, ingenious solutions proffered by store personnel in response to inquiries regarding the impending reopening date."

The modified text is: "I placed an order for a set of noodles to be taken home, yet upon perusing the instructions, it became apparent that there was a discrepancy in the clarity of the directions regarding the intensity of the chili component within the dish. Despite the sweltering heat that had enveloped Phoenix throughout the day, I was eager to return home and indulge in the culinary delight. Upon arriving at my residence, I observed that the sauce accompanying the noodles appeared to possess a striking resemblance to molten lava in both color and consistency. Following the consumption of approximately one-third of the dish, I fervently wished that I had abstained from partaking in it altogether, as my lip began to exhibit signs of inflammation and my facial area was overcome with perspiration. In an attempt to mitigate the internal turmoil caused by the fiery ingredients, I rapidly consumed an entire bottle of Coca-Cola. It is imperative that measures are taken to assess the degree of pepper spice incorporated into take-home orders, lest similar unpleasant experiences recur. Notwithstanding, I am willing to accord them another opportunity, provided they demonstrate a concerted effort to rectify the situation and furnish a comprehensible explanation. A reevaluation of my rating shall ensue, contingent upon their ability to convincingly justify themselves."

I aspire to cherish this establishment, yet I simply cannot. My initial impression was that it was a middling hamburger joint with an exceptional assortment of beers. Upon entering, I was perplexed by the absence of any indication that I was expected to accommodate myself. The lack of menus on the tables further contributed to my bewilderment. It is imperative that eateries ensure their tables are equipped with menus, particularly when catering to novice clientele. 
  I opted for the bruschetta and pesto burger, which, while delectable, was regrettably diminutive in stature. For a paltry $7.59, the portion size was unacceptably minuscule. No aspect of this burger could possibly justify its cost. Patrons must additionally purchase sides, such as fresh cut fries, shoe string fries, or sweet potato fries, thereby elevating the price of a meal to approximately $10, which is somewhat exorbitant considering the quality and quantity of the food provided. 
  My dining companion selected the mac and cheese with bacon burger, the constituents of which were undoubtedly scrumptious. Nonetheless, the burger itself was disappointingly arid. Perhaps the implementation of a cheese sauce would have enhanced its overall flavor? 
  The beer selection is truly extensive and impressive, featuring an abundance of excellent brews worthy of sampling. Notwithstanding, my overall assessment of this venue remains merely average.

I am a habitual patron of this establishment, as I frequent this store on a regular basis. The employees are cordial and accommodating, however, the state of the restroom facilities is a persistent source of dissatisfaction for me. In light of this, I find myself deliberating over the wisdom of continuing to shop at this location, given the unpleasant nature of the bathrooms.

Pretty good sports bar located across from the sports book in the MGM. So cool place to go and grab a beer and some food after making your bet.  The place gets packed on Saturdays and Sundays during the football season so you might have trouble grabbing a table if you're with a big group.  There appeared to be a good amount of seating at the bar if you can get in there early.

Food is basic bar food, I wouldn't get anything other than wings or perhaps a burger, anything else would be a waste in my opinion. They have some decent deals during game day, I went with the shot and beer combos. Nice variety of beer on taps and most of your classic domestics in a bottle.

Nothing overly special but a nice place to chill and enjoy the games on the numerous TVs.

Green River soda pop, a culinary delight reminiscent of a bygone era, alongside delectable fried mushrooms, constitute merely a few of the myriad gastronomical indulgences available at this establishment, which prides itself on offering an array of quintessential Chicago specialties, including, but not limited to, Red Hots and an assortment of savory hot dogs, all of which are presented with aplomb; however, it is worth noting that the service, while not necessarily expeditious, is nevertheless adequate, and although the current menu may not be as extensive as that of its predecessor, a former pizza purveyor, the quality of the fare remains undiminished.

This Dunkin Donuts is one of the first to open around the Madison area.  It's located on the corner of Hwy Q and Hwy 19 in Waunakee, and is attached to the BP Gas Station that's on that same corner.  \n\nThe staff was super friendly and helpful, the donuts were decent.  If you're in the area and craving a donut, give these guys a shot.

fun spot, pretty good food-not crazy authentic but definitely still worthy of a meal or two here-and the service was good.  Very casual laid back but I loved the tortilla soup :) Don't come in looking to be wow'd by the service but they did fine in my book, it's so casual so I don't understand why everyone was so eerked about the service.

"This particular Motel 6 establishment proved to be satisfactory in my opinion, primarily due to its economical pricing during the peak summer season. The lodging was well-maintained and spotless, while the personnel were cordial and hospitable. Despite oversleeping and missing my designated wake-up time, I must acknowledge that the accommodations were adequate. In addition, the motel featured a modest pool adjacent to the building, which provided an opportunity for guests to relax and unwind. Ample parking space was also available. However, I would advise potential patrons to be aware of the proximity of this motel to an amusement park, which may generate considerable noise during the daytime hours. Although the facility itself is not directly visible from the motel, the sounds emanating from the park are audible and may pose a disturbance. Furthermore, the surrounding area lacks a variety of dining options, making it necessary to travel by car to obtain breakfast, thereby adding inconvenience to one's stay."

"Satisfactory, yet somewhat unremarkable in terms of overall quality. A diverse array of cake batters, including vanilla and chocolate variations, are available for selection. Additionally, a sufficient assortment of toppings is provided, though it would be wise to specifically request the inclusion of mochi, a traditional Japanese rice cake, to enhance the culinary experience. The interior ambiance is quite pleasant, boasting an eclectic mix of intriguing individuals. Notably, an inquiry regarding my hourly rate was posed by an Indian mother, which engendered a degree of discomfort, given that I was attired in a'rent by the hour' shirt at the time."

I'm glad that someone else mentioned that this was known as the Kabob House, because if they didn't, I'd never have found it.  I don't know that I've ever seen it called Khaneh Kabob (though perhaps that's what it says in their native tongue).

Anyway - the place is indeed clean, though in an odd twist, it's attached to a beverage store.  That's not bad, just a statement of fact.  If you order a kabob that contains steak or chicken, I can definitely see how you might be disappointed - you don't get a lot.

If you order a kabob that has ground meat, you'll probably have leftovers.  Unfortunately, I can't tell you which kind to order, because we always go with our friends who do the ordering for us, but I can definitely tell you that these are not your typical Americanized shish-kabobs.  These are Persian-style kabobs.  So don't be disappointed.

The ground-beef-style ones are wrapped around a long, flat skewer and cooked on the skewer, and you get a ton of meat.  I don't know if you have to order side dishes separately, but we always get them - rice, bread and other items - because the meat by itself is good, but you'll want to have other items as well, because it makes it so much better.

Service is friendly, but it isn't speedy, and they have not historically been able to communicate particularly well in English.

During the festive Christmas period, we visited this establishment and were met with an elevated pricing structure for the midday buffet, amounting to approximately $30-something per individual. The queue to gain entry was densely populated, thus, had it not been for the line pass we possessed, it would have been a futile endeavor to partake in the buffet experience.

On a previous visit last year, the quality of the cuisine appeared to have diminished slightly. While the food was satisfactory, it did not particularly stand out as exceptional. The offerings included standard fare such as shrimp, prime rib, and roasted poultry, et cetera. The king crab legs seemed to be the primary draw, as numerous patrons had heaping portions on their plates. Personally, I do not have a preference for king crab legs, and I found many of the dishes to be somewhat arid, necessitating liberal application of sauces to enhance their flavor.

The truly exceptional aspect of the meal was the assortment of sweets. A variety of delectable delights, ranging from creme brulee to creampuffs, diverse ice cream flavors, brownies, banana fosters, and cookies, were available. I sampled both the creme brulee and cookies, which were quite satisfying.

Included in the cost was pop and juice, so it was advisable to capitalize on these beverages. Ultimately, while the buffet was not worth the premium price of $30-something for lunch, it may be acceptable at the regular price of $20-something.

"Recently, in the company of numerous colleagues, I partook in an evening excursion to a local culinary establishment, whereupon I sampled their signature Kobe burger, complemented by a delectable assortment of white cheddar and sweet potato fries. Although the gastronomic experience was indeed pleasurable, with the burger being cooked to perfection and the fries displaying an unparalleled crispness, it did not quite ascend to the lofty heights of my most memorable burger experiences. Nonetheless, the convivial atmosphere and camaraderie shared among our group served to enhance the overall enjoyment of the meal."

Personally nothing to write home about here.... Every time I go in, it does satisfy my need for a good sandwich that is different then your usual sandwich shops. Below is what I like:

-Large selection of soups

-Decent sandwiches

-Ice Cream

Personally, I won't go out of my way for Jason's Deli but then again, I also won't avoid it if I am passing by or meeting friends here.

"Culinary excellence. My epicurean inclinations were satiated by the delectable Chicken Marsala, yet my fiscal sensibilities were dismayed by the somewhat prohibitive pricing structure. Notwithstanding, an adolescent employee bearing a striking resemblance to either Jonah Hill or Seth from the cinematic masterpiece 'Superbad,' complete with an unmistakable 'white boy' coiffure, served to enhance the overall dining experience, thereby rendering the merely adequate service marginally more palatable."

This establishment has the potential to attain a five-star rating if certain adjustments are made. While the menu offers an acceptable selection, the culinary offerings are palatable. The ambiance of the venue is quite impressive, boasting an indoor-outdoor layout that permits patrons to bring their canine companions onto the patio. However, the bartenders exude an air of pretentiousness, which may deter some patrons from fully enjoying their experience. It would be beneficial for the ownership to dispatch these bartenders to Ve Bene in Ahwatukee, where they can observe how skilled bartenders engage with their clientele. Unfortunately, the lack of evening drink specials and the elevated prices of beverages may contribute to the sluggish pace of business, potentially deterring prospective customers. Perhaps management assumes that maintaining a lofty atmosphere is essential to discouraging undesirable patronage.

The first time I went here, I got the shredded beef burrito ($6.29) and thought it was just ok (it was HUGE).  However, I LOVED their warm chips ($.99) and guacamole ($2.69)!  

Although I've revisited this location, I haven't tried anything else off their menu...I just run in for an order of chips and guacamole.  My mouth is watering just thinking about the lightly salted chips and tangy guac.

BTW, although I prefer Qdoba's chips, for burritos, I prefer Baja Fresh.  As others have mentioned, Qdoba is just like Chipotle.  It's even located across the street from Chipotle...go figure.

It was good. It wasn't outrageously great, but it wasn't horrendously bad. 

I ordered the Turkey & Rosemary Omelet and my boyfriend ordered the French Toast Strata. 

My meal came with an omelet, oven-roasted potatoes and fresh fruit. While everything was good, I have to say that I probably could have made the meal at home. If I go back, I wouldn't not eat this again, but I would definitely like to try something from their lunch selection first. My boyfriend was pretty much in agreement there. While he said his meal was good, he wants to try their burgers. 

They have a nice size menu filled with lots of veggie and lean meat dishes, which are perfect for me. However, they also cater to my boyfriend's style with such dishes like the Wisconsin Pride Burger (cheese curds and bacon on top of a 1/2 lb burger). 

We actually went their for breakfast for my boyfriends birthday. With that in mind, we left with a cupcake (I passed; too full to even think about cupcakes). My boyfriend chose the carrot cupcake with cream cheese frosting and walnut bits sprinkled on top. He wolfed it down and said it was good. 

I may update this review after we go for lunch sometime.

We decided to start our Winter Break with pizza!  We had a coupon to try Florencia's. 

We got there just before 3pm and had the place to ourselves, but for two other tables. 

Melissa greeted us at the door and grabbed our drinks super quick. We ordered the XL Cheese pizza, we were all craving cheese!  The pizza looked great and tasted as good as it looked!

Three stars due to the fact that we had to get our second round from the bar on our own. We won't let that stop us from trying Florencia's again. The pizza was cheesy and full of flavor, the crust...perfect!
Its just okay even with the low price. I stayed there during the Mining convention and it seemed understaffed. The room was clean and the water hot.  Its okay.

Sometimes it pays to be in larger groups when the bill will be larger and provide bigger tips.  

My wife and I seemed to be overlooked, especially towards the end of the meal.  Took 16 minutes to order dessert.  Way too long.

The ravioli was great and pork belly was tender.  Ther prawns were a little over done.  I would try going here again to see what happens.  I was not going to cause a scene, but by the end, I was just trying to get out of there.  The food was a 4, but the service seemed slow.

Surprisingly decent venue- larger than expected, back wall is a massive bar. Lines for drinks get long, and prices are predictably steep for generic draft beer, but the staff are friendly. In addition to bartenders, there are a lot of people cleaning and monitoring the crowd, which is a nice touch.\n\nBathrooms are huge with 20+ stalls, so getting in a trip between sets isn't a huge wait as it is at other venues. The acoustics are fairly good, but I found it odd that the general admission/floor area is divided up by odd iron rails- I understand they don't want a giant mosh pit going or anything, it's an unusual setup.

I have had the occasion to partake in the culinary offerings of this establishment on several occasions over the course of my residency in this city, totaling five years, and it is with a sense of relief that I can report that there has been a marked improvement in the quality of the fare provided, specifically in regards to the moisture level and overall taste, which previously left much to be desired, having been characterized by an unpleasant dryness and a strong suggestion of having been stored for an extended period of time in close proximity to the preparation area. It is my sincere hope that this upward trend in gastronomical excellence shall continue unabated.

Little pricey for the food.  The reason it pays to come to this place is the excellent drink menu, and souvenir cups, glasses, mugs, etc. that you can take with you.  The place is packed with movie trivia and buy stuff in the store next-door.\nNice stuff for lunch during the convention...and creates a good memory!

Having had memorable meals at Kai, we were thrilled to learn of its former chef joining partnership here at Mod.   Signature touches and flair were apparent in the presentation, the food was innovative and some of it was excellent, such as the \"shroom\" dish.  The venison lollipops were too rare for me, but my husband said they were tasty.  He also had the pescado loco tar tare, and found it to his liking. I ordered the duck large plate and was disappointed-duck was good, but dish featuring beans, rice, okra, etc. was no better than say one would get at Milagro Grill or The Mission. The okra was unusually salty.  A server came to our table with a covered dish and asked if it were ours.  We inquired as to to what it was. He didn't know. He had come from the kitchen; not a regular waiter, but totally clueless. I do understand it was Labor Day Weekend and staff may have been not the usual crew. Our waitress was very pleasant, the hostess welcoming, and the others we encountered were attentive. Loud music for a younger crowd was intrusive. I could see going again for appetizers and a cocktail, but would not go back for dinner, considering the myriad of choices available here in the Valley.

As a native Detroiter and previous resident, I was eager to indulge in a brief culinary excursion that would provide me with a nostalgic taste of my hometown. Unfortunately, my enthusiasm was quickly dampened by the discovery that the Valet service was exclusively accessible to hotel guests, which I found to be somewhat restrictive and inconvenient. Furthermore, the parking garage presented an additional challenge, as the first seven levels were designated solely for valet parking, leading to a rather perplexing and circuitous route that ultimately terminated without a clear exit strategy. Despite these setbacks, I remained determined to partake in the gastronomical experience that American Coney Island had to offer. While the fare was passable, I felt that the chili portion accompanying their signature dish was somewhat meager, which left me yearning for a more copious serving of this quintessential condiment. In my opinion, a bottle of Vernors, that refreshing and iconic Detroit soft drink, would have served as the perfect accompaniment to complete the authenticity of this quintessential Detroit culinary experience. Following my culinary exploits, I decided to take a stroll through the casino's premises, but my enjoyment was somewhat diminished by the presence of the exuberant and boisterous table dancers, whose antics struck me as somewhat tasteless and over-the-top. Additionally, the blaring music emanating from the speakers contributed to an atmosphere that I found to be excessively raucous and cacophonous. In conclusion, while my visit to this establishment had its moments, it ultimately fell short of my expectations due to a combination of logistical issues and aesthetic missteps.

We experienced a brief layover in Phoenix, which ultimately led us to dine at Jose Roux, whereupon I opted for steak tacos accompanied by an order of ice water. The menu explicitly stated that rice and beans would incur an additional fee of $4, collectively, thereby prompting me to relinquish my interest in consuming them.

The gastronomical delight that were the tortillas, were, unfortunately, diminutive in stature, yet their inherent quality remained uncompromised- authentic, handcrafted corn tortillas, both soft and pliable. The taco itself boasted an abundance of toppings: juicy steak, fresh lettuce, succulent tomatoes, and a flavorsome salsa. Notwithstanding, the steak, while undoubtedly marinated in pineapple, failed to disclose any palpable traces of its advertised ingredient. Moreover, the meat proved somewhat chewy in texture. Conversely, the mild salsa accompanying the dish exhibited a satisfying degree of flavor. Additionally, black beans and unremarkable white rice appeared on my plate, albeit unwarranted by my initial order; however, the attentive server did not include these items in the calculation of my bill.

The pace of service at the establishment proved leisurely, bordering on sluggishness, which, while understandable given the venue's proximity to an airport, remained a tad vexing. Nonetheless, this shortcoming seemed to be a recurring issue at such establishments.

"I would assign a rating of 3.5 to Bei, whereas those who draw comparisons between it and Shin Bay on Yelp have ostensibly never had the pleasure of dining at the latter establishment, and their assessments are thereby rendered dubious. In fact, it falls short of even approximating the gastronomic experience offered by Hiro, and can at best be likened to the culinary offerings of Ra or Kona Grill. Therefore, I implore my fellow Yelpers to refrain from such fanciful comparisons and instead, let us refer to a spade as a spade - it serves passable sushi in Scottsdale. Furthermore, for those who dissent, I suggest they broaden their gustatory horizons by sampling authentic sushi."

"It is somewhat better than it was two years ago. Primarily for me, the experience varies significantly with airline companies. Qatar Airways boasts the most expedient check-in process I have ever encountered in my life. Quite literally, I completed the baggage drop-off, customs, and immigration procedures within a mere 30 minutes. I felt like a VIP! In stark contrast, my experience with Air Canada two years ago was utterly mediocre. The check-in process took an excruciating 1 hour and 20 minutes, while the customs procedure lasted a paltry 10 minutes. \n\nThe primary drawback that everyone experienced was the interminable queue with the ostentatious 'Welcome to Canada' sign (and here's your hat, you have the impression that they are missing the word IDIOTS), because it was so slow. However, they have since revamped their pass verification system; now, a reader scans your declaration form and passport. A simple 'yes' or 'no' answer determines whether your passport has been verified successfully. If everything checks out, the process takes no time at all. If not, well, you'll just have to wait. It's a far cry from the abysmal experience I had two years ago, but it's still not perfect."
Food is great. Grilled salmon burrito is awesome! Customer service, very friendly and 'above and beyond.'  I was surprised how unhygienic and gross the men's bathroom was; like a smelly truck stop.

So I went back again after probably 3 years, due to a hankering for Greek food since I was in the area. This time, I ordered their Spanakopita to see if the recipe has changed. The presentation was exactly the same but this time, it tasted great! The pastry was flaky and it had the right amount of saltiness. It looked kind of like a spinach lasagna. It was over a bed of rice pilaf. I did not care for the rice, it was lacking flavor and moisture. I also ordered their pumpkin cheesecake. Way too sweet. Even sweeter than the ones I order at the Cheesecake Factory. I would say 3.5 stars this time around.

"Sichuan, a geographical locality situated within the People's Republic of China, boasts an illustrious reputation for its copious supply of comely maidens. For those cognizant of the factors that contribute to an individual's appeal, it is widely acknowledged that a combination of both physical attractiveness and intellectual prowess is necessary to constitute a truly captivating persona. Those who prioritize one aspect over the other are often perceived as either superficial or lacking in substance.
