A prevalent trend observable in online reviews pertaining to dining establishments within the Sichuan region is a tendency to disparage aspects such as interior design, customer service, or ambiance. Such criticisms are frequently voiced by individuals who harbor a preference for eateries akin to Imperial Garden. Notably, a considerable number of patrons express profuse admiration for the culinary offerings of Sichuan restaurants, with particular emphasis on dishes like oxtail and tripe or pickled soup. As for this writer's personal preferences, I must confess a strong affinity for Sichuan cuisine, and their spicy crispy chicken ranks among my favorite dishes. However, my experience with the Kung Pao chicken at this establishment was somewhat disappointing, as the dish lacked discernible spiciness and the sauce exhibited an excessive sweetness. It is my suspicion that the restaurant mistakenly assumed I had ordered from the Americanized portion of the menu. 

Now, the enigmatic Ichiban, whose moniker translates to 'number one' in Japanese, presents an intriguing case study. This intelligent and self-assured young woman remains unfazed by the opinions of others, a trait that, while admirable, also engenders a pang of wistfulness within this author, as he secretly wishes she were more concerned with his thoughts and feelings."

(Lyrics - Maroon 5 - Payphone)

I'm at the Attic trying a burger
All of my taste I spent on you
Where have the times gone? Bo Bites, it's all good
Let's go and make a reservation for two

Yeah, I, I know it's hard to remember
The reviews we used to make
It's even harder to take a pic
That you're here eating next to me

The Attic is located upstairs in ... well the attic - wink.  Actually its just plain upstairs if you want me true opinion.  Came in on a Wednesday happy hour and apparently it's $10 burger and beer night!  Super awesome in my books.  

They serve mostly craft brews so I went with the Avery Karma, a pale ale from Boulder, CO.  The ale had a crisp hoppy taste.  For the burger I went with their special, a mushroom and swiss cheese burger.  Overall, it was okay since I didn't really care for mushrooms in general.  The burger was not as juicy as I would like it to be even though I ordered it medium.  The bun was probably my favorite part.  Nice and toasty, but soft in the inside.  

Service was okay, except I would appreciate more smile I guess.  In the end, I think I would definitely return to the attic for it's atmosphere.  It had a sports bar lounge ambiance with a classic view. - Enjoy!

Grab decent sandwiches and gyros, and enjoy live music if it's scheduled.  I was addicted as a student and still enjoy stopping in when I visit C-U, but it's a simple joint.  Right on campus near the quad.

"We visited this establishment on two separate occasions during the same evening, and our rationale behind such a decision was primarily driven by the desire for an affordable and satisfying dining experience, as well as the craving for a substantial quantity of nachos that would satiate our collective hunger. The price point of $16 per plate was certainly a factor in our decision-making process, as it represented a relatively economical option compared to other dining establishments in the surrounding area. Furthermore, while the cheese could have been melted to a slightly greater extent, the quality of the nachos remained satisfactory, particularly when consumed in a state of intoxication. For those seeking additional alcoholic beverages, we suggest resorting to unconventional means, such as panhandling or offering dance performances in exchange for a $1 margarita, which, despite its low cost, proved to be potent and flavorful, thus ensuring the continuation of one's inebriated state."

We informed them that we were on the esteemed guest list, yet they appeared to be nonplussed by this revelation. Subsequently, we all contributed $20, inclusive of the fairer sex, despite the absence of any queue. It transpired that lodging at the Venetian Resort Hotel Casino rendered the entry fee redundant.

Upon gaining admittance to the nightclub, we discovered that the interior was quite congested. The female patrons who engaged in vigorous posterior movements captivated our attention, as did those who partook in reciprocal massages. The ubiquitous presence of Buddha statues throughout the venue struck me as somewhat unsettling, although I conjecture that others may have been less sensitive to their presence.

We were directed to ascend a flight of stairs, leading us to an area typically reserved for TAO Beach during daylight hours. While the surroundings were pleasant, the unsightly plastic sheeting obscuring ongoing construction efforts detracted from the ambiance. We opted to occupy the couches, only to be informed that they were reserved for bottle service clientele. Thus, we were compelled to relinquish our seats.

It appears that various chambers within the nightclub feature distinct musical styles. The primary chamber, where we witnessed a foam precipitation phenomenon, did not appeal to my personal preferences. As I meandered through the crowd with a beverage in hand, a female patron accidentally collided with me, causing my drinking straw to obtrude into my nasal passage. This resulted in a minor nasal hemorrhage, followed by a fit of coughing that expelled the blood. Happily, I can assure you that I am now in good health.

Product:  One of the best meat quality in the Vegas area, variety of selection that cannot be gotten in other restaurants.  It is also very clean unlike other places around. 

Service: It is only good if you speak Korean or sit in the same table with a person that speaks Korea, but i guess it is a common theme in all Korean restaurants around Vegas. 

Price: A little high compared to other, but i would pay it for the quality of the product. 

Overall: If you can live with the poor service of a typical Korean restaurant, i would strongly recommend go there for the quality of the meats.

This place is pretty silly but fun, I suppose - fake 'rustic' decor and staff dressed in what look like sack-cloth shirts. It's more of a cow byre look than a potting shed, though! \n\nIt's not somewhere I'd go all the time but it's in a good spot, and the food looks good.

"It is evident that San Felipe's fortuitously benefited from its proximity to the stage at Tempe Marketplace; we arrived at 7 pm on a Saturday and, regrettably, missed their happy hour. The establishment was not particularly crowded, and the line at the entrance for age verification was modest. After being instructed to "wait to be seated," we waited for an extended period before two young women, who appeared rather indifferent, began to clean menus. Eventually, they condescended to acknowledge our presence and placed our name on a list. We were eventually seated at the bar and ordered beverages. Subsequently, the table we had desired on the patio became available, much to our delight. However, our server took an inordinate amount of time to attend to us, which led to an excessive delay in receiving our orders. Notwithstanding, the quesadilla I ordered was satisfactory, albeit somewhat overpriced at $4.95 for a small portion, with additional charges of $2 for chicken or steak and $3 for shrimp. The heating lamps were activated prematurely, causing the temperature to rise, but later subsided, creating a comfortable ambiance. Unfortunately, the men's restroom attendant was absent during this visit, which was a welcome relief. In conclusion, San Felipe's merited three stars due to the complimentary chips and exceptional salsa, which was chunky, perfectly spicy, and augmented with black-eyed peas and corn."

"We have had the pleasure of partaking in culinary indulgences at this esteemed establishment on multiple occasions prior to this particular visit, and our experiences have been overwhelmingly positive, with the exception of this specific instance. It is unfortunate that the level of service we received during this visit fell short of our expectations, as we were forced to endure an extended period of time, approximately thirty minutes, before the arrival of our meals. Furthermore, the dimensions of the burgers we ordered were disappointingly diminutive, even in comparison to the lesser-sized option advertised by the restaurant, which led us to question the value of our dining experience in light of the price point. Despite our overall satisfaction with the ambiance and staff, it is uncertain whether we will choose to return in the future."

"Culinary excellence was abundant at this establishment, which we had the pleasure of experiencing during a recent visit on a Sunday, which happened to fall within the duration of an extended weekend. Unfortunately, the kitchen was temporarily shut down during our tenure, which slightly impeded our ability to fully indulge in the delectable offerings. Notwithstanding, the ambiance of the venue was aesthetically pleasing, albeit not particularly sophisticated or high-end; it leaned more towards a welcoming atmosphere suitable for families or casual outings for couples on weeknights."

Watched Secret Life of Walter Mitty, the theater was ok. It reminded me of home in Stockton. It's quite small, but does the trick I suppose. The seats were not comfy and you have to 'look' up at the screen. It's really old fashion including the restroom. \n\nI guess if you have NOTHING else to do and want to see a movie, this is the place.

"Our maiden voyage to the Church Brew Works yielded an experience that fell short of our expectations, with a meager offering of mediocre brews and a pedestrian schnitzel dish that failed to impress. Despite this underwhelming encounter, we must admit that the venue's environs did possess a certain je ne sais quoi that bordered on the extraordinary."

While I reserve the right to upgrade this my gut is 3.5 stars rounded down Thanks yelp. 

Service: 
5 stars, granted there were only us and 2 others for a short time. The staff was great and friendly. 

Food: 
2.5 Stars, I had a burger and knew that it was not going to be the best burger ever but decided to try it anyway. They Flat Grill (fry) a hand pattied 1/2lb burger and serve it with mayo, mustard, 1000 Island, let and tom. While it was not over cooked it was too thin to cook med rare. The flavor was ok but there was no seasoning at all on it. 
The fries needed salt desperately also. 
There was a small and I mean small cup of what appeared to be coleslaw.. wow it was bad. 

Building: 
3 Stars Clean open, plenty of light. Looked nice to me. 

I WILL be back for some breakfast.

"An diminutive yet exceptional venue for a morning repast. The culinary offerings are comprised entirely of regional and naturally cultivated produce, thereby aligning with the principles of sustainability and environmental stewardship. Although the ambiance may be somewhat deficient, the hospitality of the staff compensates for this shortcoming, ensuring a satisfying experience for patrons. I shall unquestionably return to partake in their delectable fare once again."

The build your own burger concept is nothing new, but they do have some interesting toppings to put on as well as a variety of buns.  I ended up going for a 1/3 lb. brie (yes, brie.  One of the most underrated cheeses for hamburgers) and ham burger.  It was incredibly juicy and tasty.  

The down side however is that the food is rather expensive.  My hamburger ended up just shy of $10.   Toppings like bacon, ham, fried onions and mushrooms cost an extra $1 on top of their base price ($8 for a 1/3 burger).  A second cheese is also an extra $1.  The standard lettuce, tomato, onions and pickles uses up your 4 free toppings, so anything more you'll have to pay an extra 50 cents.   

Then there's the $3 for a single serving of fries (although with the size of the burgers, you probably will want to split the fries.)   And there's the shakes, though delicious cost $5 which made me channel Vincent Vega from Pulp Fiction.

So, good food, but not worth the extra expense in my opinion.

"Underwhelming experience with too much repetition."
Nothing can be compared to the prolonged and arduous wait of ten minutes at the bar, only to be met with an elusive and unresponsive bartender who seems to prioritize the attendance of other patrons over one's own thirst-quenching needs. Furthermore, the presence of another bartender who appears to be preoccupied with frivolous flirtation rather than attending to customers further exacerbates the situation. In light of such circumstances, it may be wise to consider alternative options, such as securing a table and informing the hostess of the reasons behind doing so, in order to avoid prolonged dissatisfaction. Unfortunately, even management personnel seem to be impervious to the plight of patrons, as they may deliberately ignore or disregard concerns brought to their attention.
It is truly lamentable that establishments with considerable potential, such as this particular pub, fail to meet expectations and fall short of providing adequate service and knowledge. This is particularly evident in the case of beer, wherein the staff displays a glaring lack of familiarity with the various offerings available. In fact, the server's inability to effectively promote the pub's own beer, despite having an extensive selection of thirty plus options on tap, is a testament to this deficiency. While the quality of the beer itself may be satisfactory, the absence of enthusiasm and expertise among staff members undermines the overall experience. Moreover, delays in receiving food orders only serve to compound the issues already present. Ultimately, given the unsatisfactory nature of the visit, it is unlikely that a return trip will be made to this establishment.

For the bad, it's a 1 star. But also for the bad, it's a 5 star. So I'm splitting the difference and going with 3 stars.

The Sirens of TI is like the ugly Christmas sweater. It's ugly and awful. But it's also fun and the theme of hip holiday parties. The Sirens of TI is so bad, it's kinda awesome.

If you go into this free show expecting something amazing, you will be disappointed. But if you approach this show like an ugly Christmas sweater holiday party - if you relish in the badness of it - you will have a good time and understand its awesomeness. If you go with the right mindset, you just might laugh so hard that tears stream down your face.

For best viewing, catch an early show. Prior to the club officially opening for the night, the patio area of Christian Audigier is open - and there is no cover. Access it from the outside. It's a perfect view as you are sitting right alongside one of the pirate ships. And you can sit and have a drink, as opposed to stand in the crowd and get shoved by small children who should not be allowed to view this show.

"This location experiences a conspicuous lack of patronage, which I find utterly delightful. Moreover, it offers an extensive array of items catering to both my appliance and tool necessities, thereby precluding the need for me to frequent that other establishment specializing in tools. Additionally, I derive immense satisfaction from the fact that they stock the specific component required for me to replace the water filter in my refrigerator independently, thereby allowing me to feel both handy and domestically inclined. Furthermore, the customer service provided by the staff is both helpful and unobtrusive, striking the perfect balance between attentiveness and respect for personal space."

I have been a fan of this place for a while. I have stayed here a few times throughout the years. I like the rooms, the only problem is the location of the casino from the strip. Although it is still super close walking distance. I love the 25cent wings after midnight. I like playing here as well. The only reason why I'm rating it a 3 star instead of a 4-5 star is because of the horrible rude staff there. Every single person I ran into that worked there had a horrible presence and talked to me like I wasn't worth there time. Which really made me mad. I'm a huge gambler and that made me just walk out the door.

Surely it would be advisable for you to take a seat in the downstairs area, as it offers a vastly superior ambiance compared to the upstairs section, with a preference for a seat located on the far left side of the establishment, providing an unobstructed view of the picturesque Pittsburgh downtown skyline; additionally, the service was of high quality, and while the swordfish dish was quite satisfying, the shrimp appetizer, though not without its merits, was somewhat lacking in originality in terms of flavor profile, leading to a mildly disappointing culinary experience.

I called in a pasta order ahead.  I tried two dishes.  The chicken parm and one other dish.  The sauces were tasty but a bit on the salty side as the other reviews have mentioned.  AND I LOVE SALT!!

I don't know what it was but the staff (owner and cook) were both very nice but for some reason I felt awkward in that place like I was an unexpected guest.  Then again, I'm a younger, sharper dressed, fine watch, imported car kind of American boy and this strip mall isn't in the part of town that makes you all warm and fuzzy inside.. It wasn't enough to turn me off but I did feel weird being in there.

The food was good overall with the exception of being really salty.  At least it isn't bland and has flavor.  

I will surely give them another shot and try the pizza...

We indulged in a culinary excursion at this establishment during the previous weekend, and my gastronomical expectations were thoroughly satiated by the delectable victuals presented before me. However, upon perusing the menu, I noticed that the prices seemed to be slightly disproportionate to the quantity and quality of the dishes offered. Specifically, the hummus, which was undoubtedly scrumptious, appeared to be somewhat overpriced at $10, considering its volume could have been more substantial. Similarly, my spouse's lamb shanks, while flavorful and tender, seemed to carry a price tag of $23 that was marginally excessive relative to the portion size. Additionally, the cost of a Stella Artois and an Apple Martini, both priced at $10, struck me as somewhat steep. Notwithstanding these reservations, the ambiance was pleasantly enhanced by the attentive and courteous service proffered by the staff. Nonetheless, the cacophonous melodies that permeated the atmosphere had an unfortunate tendency to detract from the overall dining experience, imbuing it with an incongruous and rather jarring quality. For those seeking a distinctive epicurean adventure, this venue may still merit consideration, despite certain pecuniary misgivings.

"The quality of the breakfast was unprecedented, with a duration of 8-0 hours, which I have never experienced before! The cost was reasonable, with all items priced at 4.90 EUR, and a discount of one euro for each beverage. However, the most expensive coffee of my life was 3.90 EUR for a large cup, which was quite disappointing compared to the standard coffee. The breakfast itself was satisfactory, but any additional requests incurred additional charges (no exchange of butter and marmalade for Nutella was possible). The service was attentive, friendly, and prompt."

It is an antiquated cinema, to say the least; I utterly abhor the parking arrangements here, albeit, I am under the impression that they are in the process of renovating it...I believe the service can be somewhat sluggish, and they urgently require additional ticket kiosks!!!! The seating is not particularly comfortable, and the screens are merely adequate. I attend this theater solely for its proximity to my domicile and the convenience of not having to traverse a bustling casino to access it; however, I must admit that it is one of the few cinemas that showcases a few independent documentaries and films that I rarely find elsewhere. Although, I previously believed that Village Square was a declining plaza, the influx of novel eateries instills hope that it may still flourish.

HOT TIP: Avoid being misled by the sign at the box office indicating that a kiosk within the lobby is available for use when there is a considerable queue outside. There tends to be a brief line for that solitary kiosk, and trust me, people are generally unfamiliar with its operation and expend an excessive amount of time utilizing it; thus, it is rather amusing.

After two hours of suffering in the YMCA half-marathon this weekend, my wife and I were driving back home and noticed The Nile Cafe. Well, to be fair, we noticed that there was a sign for a new coffee shop called Rev right next to the Quizno's. We got out of our car and noticed that Rev is still a shell with nothing in it, and we walked to the other side of the buildings and happened across Nile.

This place is so new it was tough to tell it was open. Nothing in the way of decoration, but so what? I don't eat paintings!

We just grabbed a large container of their Cilantro-Jalapeno hummus ($5.75)  and some pita bread and took it home. Let me tell ya, it's got some kick! It's definitely my favorite hummus, and I will try putting this even on things hummus doesn't belong on! 

I had to knock a couple stars off for the store-bought pitas. The Nile Cafe is gonna have to do better on the pitas to compete. But I still plan on rounding up some work friends and trying these guys for lunch. Schwarma, falafel, howashi and tabouli all sound good to me! The chicken curry soup sounds tasty, too.

I'll update this after my first real meal there. But go get some hummus. Seriously.

"My culinary experiences with Jason's have been confined to catered luncheons, where I have savored their offerings with relish, but I have never had the pleasure of dining at the establishment itself until now. The salad bar, an unmitigated delight, boasts an impressive array of ingredients that cater to diverse tastes and dietary restrictions, earning it a well-deserved perfect score of five. Regrettably, my experience with the Mediterranean Wrap proved underwhelming, as the tortilla wrap's texture was unyielding and the filling lacked generosity in portion, rendering it an unworthy choice for future orders."

"In the event that you are seeking East Coast style Chinese cuisine, this establishment constitutes a suitable venue for said purpose. Upon perusing their menu, we elected to exercise the option of ordering individual dishes, as opposed to partaking in the all-you-can-eat buffet, primarily due to our personal preference for selecting specific items. The culinary offerings did indeed meet our expectations, boasting generous portions, an adequate temperature, and a palpable freshness. However, it is worth noting that the waiting staff's proficiency in the English language leaves much to be desired, thereby resulting in a subpar level of customer service. Additionally, the ambiance of the dining area is somewhat marred by the audible shouts emanating from both the kitchen staff and the servers, which detracts from the overall dining experience. Furthermore, the decor appears somewhat antiquated and could benefit from a thorough cleaning. In light of these factors, we shall limit our patronage to their takeout services in the future."

We came here on a Thursday evening. 2 AYCE dinners. 15.12 each with boarding pass

- NEW Sign ups get a 2 for 1 buffet! 
- Already used it? Ask your friend to sign up and use theirs! haha. Cashiers don't check. Make sure you bring cash! haha :D
- 30-35min wait time at 8pm. Err'body hungay bruh. 
- $3.75 ATM fee. dammit! :/
- Nigiri sushi fail. I guess you have to come earlier
- Love the chinese fried chicken! small wings! better than the american style.
- Get the tofu stir fry! 
- Soups are tasty, even though a bit salty. get the hot and sour soup and chicken noodle!
- Always have to get tacos! Not as wet as Sunset Station
- BBQ ribs bonus! summer special! 
- Chopped sweet potatoes! At Sunset, they give you the whole piece!

"A vast array of products and merchandise is available at this establishment, which boasts a diverse assortment of items that cater to various needs and preferences. While the selection may not be the most extensive or impressive, it is undeniable that the staff members associated with the pharmaceutical department possess a certain je ne sais quoi that renders them remarkably hospitable and accommodating. It is highly likely that I will return to this location in the future, primarily to avail myself of the pharmacists' expertise and proficiency."

"A diverse array of culinary options, predominantly comprising comfort foods, with an emphasis on accessibility and unpretentiousness, which may cater effectively to the preferences of those who do not appreciate sophisticated gastronomic experiences. Additionally, the restaurant's welcoming atmosphere and well-prepared prime rib dishes make it a suitable destination for families, while the subpar quality of their coffee may prove disappointing to aficionados of the beverage."

Decent southern food. Great Biscuits!!  I would come here again to try their breakfast, but stopped in for the lunch.  Soup was amazing, but the southern fried catfish was very thin. I am used to southern cooking where the catfish is very thick and real good.  The fried okra was good as well.  I will be back to look into this place some more!

"Upon entering the establishment, it became apparent that the staff members were taken aback by our presence, as if the notion of patrons partaking in culinary indulgences within their premises was an unforeseen occurrence. The dearth of atmospheric elements such as music or television, coupled with an eerie silence, engendered a sense of incongruity; it was almost as though we had inadvertently trespassed upon their domain. Furthermore, the seating arrangement was characterized by an unconventional configuration, with a large outdoor sign situated behind our booth in a manner that rendered it conspicuous and somewhat disruptive to our dining experience. Notwithstanding these drawbacks, the culinary offerings proved to be of considerable quality, and the option of having them delivered to one's domicile is certainly a viable alternative to physically dining at the restaurant. However, owing to the aforementioned idiosyncrasies, it is unlikely that we would opt to partake in a meal within the confines of the establishment again."

"The Saturday night Noches Caliente Latin Dance Party features a live band and an animated and fervent assemblage of local patrons and extramural visitors who are ardently devoted to engaging in rhythmic movement. The $10 entrance fee encompasses a beverage (with restrictions on the scope of available orders) and Live Entertainment Tax. There are seats with tables situated on three sides of the dance floor, offering unobstructed vistas of both the performance area and those partaking in the festivities. It is advisable to don footwear with adequate grip, as the wooden floor surface manifests a marked degree of slipperiness, exceeding expectations."

I have an affinity for establishments that are off the beaten path, where the ambiance may be less polished, but the service and culinary offerings often surprise and delight. However, my experience at this particular venue was somewhat mixed, as while the food was generally satisfying, the service was somewhat sluggish and appeared to be somewhat disorganized. Specifically, I opted for the garlic bread, which, while unremarkable in its presentation, was nevertheless quite delectable. The bolognese, too, was palatable, yet it struck me as somewhat unexceptional, as it is a dish that can be challenging to prepare poorly. Ultimately, my impression of this eatery was one of mediocrity, with few distinguishing features that might have elevated it above the realm of the mundane.
Love Amsterdam! Went there forever ago for fun $2 martinis and manicures on Tuesday nights. The show is awesome too, there's no way to go and not have a fun time!

"With regard to Kohl's, it is imperative that shoppers capitalize on sales and utilize coupons to attain optimal pricing. Failing to do so will result in paying a premium for merchandise. As an astute shopper, I habitually exploit such opportunities, thereby enabling me to acquire an array of items, including playthings, literary works, and ornamental pieces, at remarkably reasonable rates. 

The store's inventory of playthings appears to undergo frequent changes, suggesting a rapid turnover rate and ensuring customers have access to the most recent and advanced products. Additionally, Kohl's offers an extensive selection of kitchen utensils, bathroom accessories, and framing options; however, it is essential to shop during sales periods to secure the best deals.

While I have not purchased adult apparel from Kohl's recently, I have observed that children's clothing, albeit on sale, tends to be slightly more expensive than comparable items found elsewhere. Therefore, it is advisable to await clearance sales or utilize combinable coupons to maximize savings."

"My assessment of this dining establishment is somewhat ambivalent, as certain aspects of the experience were satisfactory, while others fell short of my expectations. Specifically, the quality of the food was generally consistent with my expectations, with the filets, ribeye, and seabass being cooked to my liking. However, the sides were a significant letdown, as the creamed spinach and mac and cheese were excessively soggy due to an overabundance of panko breadcrumbs, which rendered them unpalatable. In contrast, the mashed potatoes were adequate, albeit unremarkable. 

The service we received was also variable, as the initial wait staff seemed dismissive and disinterested in our needs, whereas the Asian server who replaced them was more attentive and responsive. Notably, the hostesses who greeted us upon arrival were quite condescending and appeared to be engaged in derogatory conversation about our group, which was disconcerting and unwelcoming. 

In terms of ambiance, the physical space of the restaurant was appealing, but our preference for seating upstairs was thwarted by a private party, which limited our options. Moreover, the practice of automatically including a generous gratuity in the bill, despite the inconsistent quality of service, struck me as inappropriate and potentially exploitative. 

In conclusion, while the culinary offerings of this establishment were largely satisfying, the deficiencies in customer service and the questionable practice of bundling tips with the bill leave me hesitant to wholeheartedly recommend it. Nonetheless, if I find myself in the vicinity again, I might consider giving it another chance, contingent upon the assurance of improved service standards."

Location makes this place the best choice for anyone that forgets to bring food to school (CSN). Was not really the best I have had at Chipotle, it fact, it may have been the worse, but I did waste time waiting to be NOT served at McDonald's next door (SEE review) after leaving with my fat burrito and then I had to walk all the way to Building Kilo so I can fire up my Smartpop in the microwave (just discovered that there is a micro-onda [actually two] in Bravo building as well). 

So yeah, it was a smudge cold. And the food as they were placing it onto the tortilla did not look as fresh as Doug E. Fresh (in the 80s) either. I went in the early evening, and there was only two other customers in the restaurant, so maybe a visit during the busy lunch hour would be a better barometer on the best they can do. 

Overall, the carnitas burrito with brown rice/pinto/pico/lechuga was alright. I consumed every morsel. - E

After having made this post, my husband received a telephone call from the manager at Pep Boys, which prompted me to express my gratitude for his apologies regarding the subpar service we had encountered; however, I still believe that both the corporation and its clientele should be cognizant of the predicament we had undergone, and thus, I have chosen to revise this review and augment the number of stars appended thereto in recognition of the laudable efforts exhibited by the manager in his endeavor to rectify an unfortunate situation, thereby extending my sincere appreciation to him.

"Undoubtedly delectable Thai cuisine, albeit with a price point that could be considered somewhat elevated, given the rather unremarkable surroundings. Multiple visits have consistently yielded savory and well-seasoned dishes, yet portion sizes tend to be somewhat diminutive. It is worth noting that the establishment exudes a strong odor of pine-sol or lysol, which has been known to cause headaches among patrons. Furthermore, the ambiance leaves much to be desired, as the restaurant is situated within a dilapidated shopping plaza, replete with unsavory establishments such as adult entertainment venues and massage parlors. The proximity to these questionable enterprises has led to unsightly incidents, including public displays of lewd behavior, which may render this eatery less than suitable for hosting out-of-town visitors. Notwithstanding, the male servers are generally quite affable and accommodating, while the female staff members at the front desk exhibit a markedly frosty demeanor."
Bring cash and small bills. There is a change machine that will give you back coins. They will change it out for bills in the gift shop, but avoid the hassle.

Booked two rooms for my mom and aunt. The rooms were fine, staff was bad and  good. We had one big problem with the reservation, which left a sour taste in my mouth. I had the call recorded and that saved my mom the extra sixty seven dollars.  Besides that I can't say too much positive, as the hotel needs some upgrades, and the buffet was not provided as promised. Finally the pool was filthy. I like the RIO pool way better. The Luxor needs work, as does the staff, and wait to check in.

This is one of the few places in Vegas that does not try to rip you off. I think the best time to come to this restaurant is lunch time. They have great lunch specials at $5.99. I ordered grilled chicken with mashed potatoes and vegetables while my friend ordered the mushroom penne pasta. I think my grilled chicken was better than her mushroom penne dish. The chicken was a little dry, but immerse it in the mashed potatoes and all of a sudden it becomes okay.

The most annoying part about the experience is that there is a lady who comes over to your table and asks you if you want your picture taken so you can have a souvenir card. However, as much as this sounds enticing, it is a nuisance because once they bring you the postcard, they also try to sell you your picture. Beware, just kindly decline when this lady approaches you. I do not know why they do this. 

Also, the seats on the outside of the restroom are uncomfortable (they are plastic chairs). The seats in the restaurant look much more comfortable and I'd recommend sitting inside.

The service was very very slow. The waitresses and hostesses were dressed very young and not very professional. (I get this is a chill restaurant with a chill vibe, but when the employees look like they just left the gym with tight spandex leggings, form-fitting tank tops, and messy buns, I couldn't tell who worked there and who was dining there). However, the sweet potato tots were TO DIE FOR (I found myself craving them weeks later) and the burger was really good. I will definitely be back to try the PBJ & Bacon Burger that everyone has raved about, but the slow service could absolutely use some improvement.

This establishment fails to meet expectations, perhaps due to our misguided menu selections; however, the ambiance does not live up to its reputation, despite its unassuming exterior, reminiscent of the hidden gems found in San Francisco. We sampled an array of dishes, including their renowned chicken wings, a papaya salad, a flavorful tom yum noodle soup, and an additional entrÃ©e that escapes my memory. While the cuisine was satisfactory, it did not surpass our expectations. They merit two stars for their culinary offerings and an additional star for accommodating us on a busy Friday evening, as the hostess, despite initially informing us of a prolonged wait time, efficiently seated us within a five-minute period. For those who have yet to indulge in Thai cuisine, this venue serves as a suitable introduction.

"Partake in the Thursday trivia extravaganza, and be prepared to become engrossed in the ensuing bar fights that are sure to ensue. Additionally, indulge in the reasonable prices of our rotating Great Lakes tap, a veritable cornucopia of delectable brews that will satiate even the most discerning palates."

I feel like a little bitch today, but please put down your drink so you can serve mine, especially after you are out of what you told me to order. Usually good beans, but shoddy service today...everywhere. Thanks millenials!
Coole Location. Leider was zu gro\u00df, daher wirkte alles leicht verloren. Schade auch, dass ab xx:xxuhr der Club (sowie Personal etc.) von gay zu straight wechselt. Aber sonst super

"Pure, while not necessarily catering to a youthful demographic, does possess an ambiance that certain patrons might find appealing, particularly those who appreciate a more mature and refined atmosphere; the interior design, replete with flowing white drapery, evokes a sense of classical Grecian elegance. It is worth noting that during my previous visit, the bartender was in an advanced state of gestation, which, while not necessarily unusual, did strike me as somewhat remarkable. The venue's crowning jewel, however, lies in its uppermost level, where a rooftop bar offers a panoramic view of the Las Vegas Strip, an attribute that unquestionably enhances the overall experience of patronizing this establishment."

I go more out of convenience than preference. Its an odd place, with lots of odd characters. I have never been there at night, but I am guessing that it gets even more \"interesting\" at night. I think Metro SB is having an identity crisis. I am not sure if it is a dive, a club, a restaurant, a pool hall... But that is okay. I will still continue to go there. \nNote: They are a cash only bar, but they do have an ATM machine, which I am sure charges a ridic service fee. So bring your cash!

I've gotta go with A-OK on this one. Not quite ready to commit to being "a fan," yet. 

To me, being "a fan" would mean I would be willing to drive from North Central Phoenix all the way downtown, devil-may-care style on a work day, to wait in line and put up with the slamming of the metal door every time a customer's lunch order was fulfilled. (That's not a complaint, mind you. It was cool. All part of the charm.)

You see, dinner is not an option. They're only open until 4. 

That said, I obeyed Robert M.'s instructions and ordered a green chile burrito, enchilada style with a side of beans. The beans were runny but good for dipping my bites of burrito. The sauce that made it  "enchilada style" had a good heat. 

I was pleased. It was "A-OK." I'd go back. Just probably not devil-may-care on a work day.

The biscotti procurement endeavor was merely confined to the designated biscotti sector, and while the flavors were indeed satisfactory, the texture left much to be desired in terms of cohesiveness, prompting a reevaluation of the overall quality of Italian cuisine at PIT, as the expectation had been that the culinary offerings would surpass the mediocrity that had been experienced thus far. Moreover, the biscotti displayed an unfortunate tendency to disintegrate easily, almost reducing to dust-like particles upon handling, suggesting that environmental factors such as humidity may have played a role in this anomaly.

A acquaintance of mine desired to convene at TT Roadhouse, thus I ended up at said establishment.  She informed me that it possessed an intriguing jukebox, however upon my arrival, I discovered that it did not live up to my expectations.  While it exuded a certain punk rock ambiance, I managed to locate a few tracks by Jawbreaker that somewhat alleviated my disappointment.  The beverages were priced reasonably, and the patrons did not consist of the stereotypical Old Scottsdale demographic.  Although unremarkable, it remains a viable option for those in the vicinity...

Pretty Good Airline overall, more of a Bus in the Sky if you will. I have actually grown to like the anything goes, sit-where-you-want thing they got going. Minus 1 star because they always take forever to unload the baggage here. But they don't lose it (like they do in Burbank and Sacramento).

A small family owned business that I frequent often,  they have excellent pastries and bread!  It would be nice if they expanded on spices and sauces and some other traditional items. 

Word of caution:  I don't know if it a supply and demand issue but the shelves are often very empty...so don't go at the last minute as you may not find what you ate looking for. 

Be sure to get a slice of apple strudel!

The food here was outstanding as one would expect of a Wynn facility.  Lobsters were roasted perfectly & filet was perfectly done and seasoned excellent.  Facility wonderful. 

What drove down the rating was the SERVICE - lack of..  

The Host staff were great, welcomed us and sent us to the bar to wait on our table.  Then when the table was ready came up to us and address us by name to leads us to our table.  That nice touch instead of calling out a name to a room of people.

The table service started out good.  They rolled our the lobster cart and we ordered immediately.  Great energy and sense of humor.  

Then we get turned over to our waiter and table staff.  All down hill from here.  Once the food arrived, there was no check back to see if everything was good.  To get drink refills we had to rudely call out at wait staff as they dashed by - at times more than once just for drink refills.  

Price point - Vegas reasonable.  With menus online, if you are surprised by a bill you just didn't plan ahead.  But the service concerns WILL prevent me from bringing guests back here in future trips.  Botero is safer option at Wynn.

I'm lucky that I'm able to come during a time when everyone is at work, so I can't really comment on the busy times. 

My biggest complaint? One of the check-in staff is the rudest person I've ever encountered. He never says hi, I have to ask for a towel each time, and he's just straight up impersonal, almost to the point of being hostile. Dude. If you don't like your job, get another one. Everyone else I've ever checked in with manages to make eye contact, say hello, and glance at the screen to know that I get a towel.

Other than that, I enjoy coming here because it's clean, fast, and people don't really bug you.

I am excited aobut the larger menu choices now.  I asked two employees when that happened and neither of them knew.  I am guessing very recent. My burger was very good.  Next time I will order it medium rare.  It was too well done for my taste.  I asked for hot fries and I got them.  My daughter was disappointed with the pretzels and beer cheese.  We told the waitperson that there was something wrong with the cheese.  Beer cheese is usually orange and very creamy.  It cost $7 too.  It was pretzel bites.  The cheese was whitish and watery and tasted like salad dressing.  Looked like ranch to me, without the garlic.  My daughter said it was awful.  When I tasted it, I knew something was wrong with it.  It was REALLY bad...tasteless and watery...no taste of cheese or beer whatsoever.  The waitress did not appear to believe me or offer to replace it...that was surprising.  She should have insisted on bringing another bowl or comping it.  I felt bad because my daughter ordered appetizers instead of a meal.  Happy to see appetizers and other sandwiches now on the menu.  Always associated Goldies with burgers, wings, and pizzas.  I will come back and try a sandwich.

Came here to get a full body massage.  It was okay.  The one thing I didn't like is that since it is just one big room, you get distracted by hearing other people chatting, walking about, and some even make noises when they get massaged.  I kinda wish they would separate the beds by a screen or something.  I wasn't totally relaxed but I guess that's what you get for the price you pay. 

The lady that did my massage was nice, at first she was gentle but she went pretty hard on my shoulders...and they're still sore the next day.  

The other weird thing is that when you go pay at the front, your masseurs go to the front and just wait for you to tip them.  It's like they won't leave or let you leave till they get tipped.

It was definitely an experience, but I probably won't be going there again.

I'll start with the reason why I gave 3 stars and not 5 stars.
Ambience was terrible. When I go to a winery I don't expect it to be like a night out at a club; however, when you go out you want the environment to be appealing. There was no music (non that I remember), few crowds, quiet, and the servers were in jeans. 
Bruschetta was not up to par. It was made on regular toast, small, thin, and flavorless.
Mushroom risotto, Twisted burger, and Mac and cheese were on point!! Like amazing. The risotto was vegetarian so if you have a larger appetite I recommend adding a protein.  
The service was excellent! 
Overall, my husband and I enjoyed the meal but the overall experience may be forgetful when deciding on a future date night.

After I found out that Sephora stocks Korres products I headed over to the new store in Fairview, Pointe Claire. Apparently Sephora Quebec doesn't stock Korres but Ontario stores do, due to packaging regulations (i.e language, as Korres products are in Greek and English)

Completely ridiculous and another reason consumers will always find a way to buy elsewhere if they don't get access to what they want. So I can shop online at SkinStore.com and only pay 5$ shipping from the USA for an entire order.

Apart from that, Sephora did have a great selection of brands, not all girly, if you know what you are looking for.   Staff were very helpful and  love to to direct you to the $150 creams (sorry couldn't resist). I would recommend researching the brands first though, many may just be in there because they have compliant packaging rather than really being the best brands you can buy. Many were missing in the store from the Sephora website. The prices seemed inline with elsewhere i.e. Dr. Hauschka prices were the same as Olgivy's, but again, I would compare as some products may have a premium attached to the price simply because you can't readily get access to that brand elsewhere in Montreal. 

Another thing that sucks is that on the Sephora website orders in the US over 50$ are free, however Canadian orders it's over $150 to get free shipping, Again, check out skinstore.com

"An open-air shopping plaza catering to the needs and preferences of an older demographic, offering a pleasant ambulatory experience on temperate days, replete with ubiquitous misting systems and an array of dining establishments serving diverse culinary options."

The further they move up Eastern, the less I tend to like them. For years, my family have gone their to buy birthday cakes, but Freed's quality has deteriorated. 

When I first came back from Korea, they were the first bakery I went to because I missed it so much. Strawberry Shortcake, Black Forest, and fruit tarts were my favorite. A few more visits and I find that the cakes are too sweet and a bit dry. It could be that my taste has changed, but then again, so did their prices. For something that is not as good as before, the cost has gone up on their items.

People mention that the service is nonexistent. It is more like spotty. Sometimes it is great with people walking around, handing out samples, and chatting with customers. Other times, it is neglectful.

Decided to take the family here after receiving a coupon and was intrigued by the all natural concept. We loved the decor and the place seemed clean. We were immediately disappointed when we discovered the lack of a kids menu. We were informed by the staff that we could order anything plain. So we get to pay $6 for a burger for our 6 year old. Same with the hot dogs. You pay for a Chicago dog and then tell them to hold all the good stuff.  Fries are separate although the large seemed to feed us all. We ordered waters and were presented with 5 shot glass sized plastic cups. I realize they make money on drinks but this is Arizona!  We need water. 

The only saving grace is that the food was pretty good. The burgers were small but had good flavor.  Just wondering how American cheese made into an all natural place.

We may come back, but I doubt we will make a special trip.

Our group stayed here for our Vegas trip. I would have much more liked to stay in a burlap sack. I understand that renovations take time and money. Seeing that this place robs people at the table, you would think ALL of thier rooms would reflect that. NOPE

They have 4 different buildings and unfortunatley my friend was in the "old building". His room was literally 2 beds and a TV. The service at the front desk is non existant and the bellhop looks like they are angry at you.  

I couldnt complain about my room but i wondered to myself...why aren't all the rooms like this? The Wold Fare Buffet was disgusing and there is a food court inside of the Casino with all terrible eateries. 

They just need to punch up this place alot more to be competing with other Hotel and Casinos on the Vegas Strip.

DH & I went to Upper Crust for Happy Hour. We had a pizza and wings, which were on happy hour specials. The pizza was good, similar to the grimaldi's style. The wings were a one star. The ambiance was a little dark, could use some color. Lots of TV's to watch any game were available.

I was genuinely conflicted about whether to confer three or four stars upon H&H, as my experience was characterized by both positive and negative aspects. 
  The quality of the cocktails was unremarkable, lacking any distinguishing features or exceptional elements, yet still maintaining a level of craftsmanship. 
  The ambiance and decor were unimpressive, with an underwhelming sense of emptiness attributed to both the sparse population and the absence of any extraordinary features. 
  Our visit took place on a Sunday evening, specifically at around 8 pm, which may have contributed to the dearth of patrons. 
  The service was adequate, with a single bartender attending to our needs, but their demeanor was somewhat indifferent, as they failed to demonstrate enthusiasm when discussing the cocktails and instead offered a cursory assurance that all options were equally excellent. 
  We opted for two particular cocktails: Agnatha & Anni and August 21st, 1959.  My Agnatha was quite enjoyable, with its crisp, tart, and robust flavors, although the presence of minute ice shards was slightly bothersome; however, this issue was quickly resolved as the ice dissolved.  The August 21st was relatively unremarkable, possessing a smoky essence that, while not aligning with my personal preferences, may appeal to those who appreciate such characteristics. 
  Despite some reservations, I would still consider revisiting H&H due to its convenience, abundant street parking, proximity, passable drinks, and lack of concerns regarding seating availability.

"Great Sushi has an obligatory responsibility to serve palatable dishes, and their spicy tuna sashimi undoubtedly lives up to expectations. However, my culinary expedition did not conclude without minor disappointments, as both the Fillet Mignon steak and grilled poultry exhibited inconsistencies in texture and flavor. Specifically, the chicken was slightly arid, but upon requesting a complementary teriyaki sauce, my gustatory satisfaction was promptly redeemed. In essence, while not every dish met my lofty standards, I was generally impressed with Great Sushi's offerings and shall unquestionably revisit the establishment in the future to sample alternative menu items."

"It is emphatically not an optimal destination for families with mature offspring, as this venue is tailored specifically for juveniles below the age of eight. However, it does feature a laser tag attraction that can potentially captivate elder children, albeit with the caveat that diminutive patrons may also be present."

The food here is okay, there is nothing in particular that has ever impressed me. Not even anything uniquely bad  but nothing ever sticks out. I have eaten here a couple of times and though the service is good, the food just comes across as bland and boring, almost like everything is pre-packaged or came to the restaurant as frozen.

"Indulging in gatherings at the prestigious Ritz Carlton has led us to indulge in the hotel's esteemed bar and restaurant, Bistro 24, which has proven to be a delightful and serendipitous experience, particularly on a Friday evening. The Grill Night buffet has surpassed our expectations, offering an array of delectable delights that would satiate even the most discerning palates.

The appetizer buffet boasts an impressive selection, featuring Blue Point oysters, lobster bites, seared tuna adorned with wasabi cream, bite-sized filet mignon, succulent shrimp, duck, and an assortment of artisanal cheeses. Moreover, a dedicated sushi stand showcases an array of expertly crafted sushi rolls, further elevating the dining experience.

The outdoor grill station offers a veritable feast for carnivores, with mouthwatering filet mignon, lamb chops, organic salmon, and grilled shrimp accompanied by creamy mashed potatoes and a medley of grilled vegetables. To cap off this gastronomic journey, a decadent dessert stand beckons with its tantalizing treats, while an extensive wine list provides the perfect accompaniment to this epicurean adventure."

some of the best dining experiences happen when you almost don't go inside the restaurant. this is the kind of eatery that makes you thankful for crappy strip malls.

sure, the exterior isn't great. and the neighborhood isn't perfect. but this place is small, friendly, clean. the food is excellent

my friend and i tried las glorias because we were in the area and we had a coupon. we were incredibly happy with ourselves after we found this place.

the chips were crisp and fresh. the bean and salsa dips were delectable. the rice was great. the portions were large. my friend said this place reminds her of her very favorite spot from home. she is something of a chile relleno connoisseur, and she said this one was among the best she had ever had. this batter and lots of cheese.

we will definitely be going back., coupon or not.

I read all the reviews before buying the Groupon, so I knew what to expect. Since I am a master procrastinator, I waited until it was almost expired to make my appointment. Luckily the girl was able to fit me in with a few days to spare! They had the girls team up with Jennifer doing my mani and Kelly did my pedi. Both girls did a good job, they were friendly and it took about and hour and a half. My two complaints would be 1) It was a little awkward because I sat in a chair facing sideways for the pedi and turned my torso for the mani, I saw they had a room with couches for the ladies just getting pedis and it looked more comfortable. 2) I didn't think they had a good enough color selection for me, as I prefer nude shades. They explained to me that after I used my Groupon, I had one more discounted visit and then I would be paying full price, which is not nearly as expensive as going to a salon. I don't have my nails done very often, but I hope to be back soon!

"The culinary offerings and hospitality we experienced during our recent visit were truly exceptional, representing a remarkable upgrade from the mediocre fare and lackluster service we have grown accustomed to in recent times; however, it is worth noting that our enjoyment of the establishment's ambiance was slightly marred by the presence of an unsettling individual accompanied by his canine companion, whose questionable adherence to basic sanitary standards left us feeling somewhat apprehensive regarding the overall cleanliness and safety of the premises, despite the otherwise excellent quality of the food and beverages served."

"During the culinary celebration known as Restaurant Week, a companion and I opted to partake in a dining experience at this establishment, securing reservations in advance to ensure our admittance. Upon entering the eatery, we were greeted by an ambiance that, while perhaps lacking a certain je ne sais quoi, still managed to exude a sense of warmth and hospitality. The libations offered on the beverage menu proved to be both delectable and potent, providing an auspicious start to our meal. My gastronomic journey commenced with the selection of a starter, specifically the Pickle Plate, which showcased an assortment of vegetables that had undergone the process of lacto-fermentation. For my principal course, I elected to sample the pan-seared trout, accompanied by a side of barley risotto. The fish was cooked to perfection and boasted an impressive flavor profile, while the grain dish complemented it admirably. Lastly, I indulged in the key lime pie for dessert, primarily due to my unwavering fondness for all things citrus. In conclusion, my visit to this restaurant was a thoroughly enjoyable experience, and I eagerly anticipate the opportunity to return and explore their regular offerings."

"My maiden visit to Vintage transpired on February fourteenth, whereupon I opted to partake in an alfresco dining experience adjacent to a crackling conflagration, thereby evoking an atmosphere of refined elegance. Moreover, their signature Sangria proved to be an unparalleled delight, capable of titillating even the most discerning palate. It is worth mentioning that on most Saturday evenings, Vintage plays host to a talented local songstress named Sarah, whose melodious performances are certain to captivate audiences and imbue them with an unwavering sense of euphoria. In essence, this esteemed establishment serves as an ideal venue for either a romantic escapade or a relaxed gathering among acquaintances."

This establishment has consistently served as our preferred destination for Chinese cuisine in a buffet setting, particularly given our prolonged residency in Las Vegas and exposure to numerous Chinese restaurants that have come and gone. The quality of their offerings has remained unwavering, with a sushi bar that boasts impeccable freshness and attention to detail, including timestamped labels indicating the time of preparation for optimal freshness assurance. Furthermore, their Mongolian barbecue station presents an extensive array of options for customizable Chinese dishes, which are promptly cooked to order, resulting in an unparalleled culinary experience. Spacious in size, this venue accommodates a large volume of patrons, leading to a high turnover rate of dishes and minimizing the likelihood of encountering cold or nearly empty plates. Instead, an abundance of fresh, steaming dishes awaits, showcasing a diverse selection ranging from crawfish to soups, fried rice, wanton soup, fried wontons, potstickers, mussels, hot wings, and even pizza for children. The value offered by this restaurant easily justifies the cost, ensuring a satisfying experience for diners. Enjoy!

It is imperative that we provide an update regarding Bricktop's, as the culinary experience offered therein is truly exceptional and worthy of elaboration. While the celestial bodies remain unchanged, my acquaintance's laudatory melody inspired me to expound upon the delectable nature of their brunch offerings. Hence, my companion and I ventured forthwith to sample the gastronomical delights proffered by this esteemed establishment in SouthPark.  

Bricktop's brunch menu boasts an array of innovative dishes, aligning with their contemporary American eclectic style, akin to their lunch and dinner selections. Patrons may create their own bloody mary cocktails at the bar, complemented by an assortment of specialty beverages such as blood orange mimosas and bellinis served by the carafe â?an absolute delight.  

During my successive brunch excursions, I have had the pleasure of savoring the same scrumptious entree â?French Toast. This sumptuous dish consists of generous slices of brioche bread, skillfully cooked to a golden brown perfection, accompanied by an assortment of sweet caramelized bananas, warm maple syrup, fluffy whipped cream, and crispy bacon strips. Although somewhat indulgent, this treat is undoubtedly worth the modest price of $11. For those seeking an additional decadent indulgence, the bite-sized homemade doughnut appetizer, comprising thirteen sugary doughnuts paired with three diverse dipping sauces â?raspberry, chocolate, and vanilla cream â?is an absolute must-try.  

While the cost of partaking in Bricktop's brunch extravaganza may escalate somewhat owing to the liberal consumption of mimosas, the culinary experience is indubitably worth the financial investment. Thus, I wholeheartedly recommend paying a visit to this esteemed eatery and relishing in the delectable fare they offer.

"Cantina undeniably excels in providing an exceptional dining experience, offering a wide array of delectable cuisine and potent potables that cater to the discerning palate. Despite its unassuming exterior, this establishment is often bustling with a vibrant clientele, particularly during peak hours, thereby necessitating advance reservations to avoid prolonged waiting periods. Rest assured, the delay will be inconsequential, as the culinary offerings and hospitable ambiance are well worth the brief interval.  

Cantina presents an extensive selection of premium Mexican libations, including their signature margaritas, which are undoubtedly among the finest in the city. For those who crave something divergent, the Kiwi/Strawberry Special is an exquisite alternative. Additionally, an assortment of quality Mexican brews is available on tap for your pleasure. Imbibe liberally, as everyone else is indulging in the same manner.  

Their menu boasts an impressive variety of dishes, leaving patrons spoiled for choice. For a lighter repast, the chopped tostada salad is an unparalleled option. Alternatively, heartier appetites will be satiated by the flavorful refried beans and tender pulled chicken. However, the true piÃ¨ce de rÃ©sistance lies in the Kobe beef fajitas, which are an absolute must-try. Suffice it to say, Cantina warrants repeated visits. Nonetheless, it's advisable to refrain from planning an energetic evening subsequent to dining, as the convivial atmosphere and satisfying fare will leave you suitably sated and exhausted."

"The gastronomical offerings at this establishment are truly exceptional, and it is highly recommended that patrons arrive either prior to or subsequent to the peak lunch hour in order to optimize their dining experience and ensure seating availability."
Cheap beer decent food. You get what you came for in this place. Can get loud but that's to be expected from a blue collar dive bar

During our sojourn in Montreal, we engaged in some retail therapy and happened upon a quaint watering hole that offered a respite from the exorbitant prices typically associated with such establishments. The al fresco seating afforded us an excellent vantage point for observing the local populace, and the hospitality of the staff was truly commendable. Unfortunately, the absence of culinary options - with the exception of the grilled cheese sandwiches that were prepared on a diminutive hot plate behind the bar - proved to be a minor letdown.

Borealis is probably my favourite restaurant in the Cambridge area. The very often used slogan think globally act locally is taken to heart by this lovely restaurant since all food and beverages at this reataurant are supposedly sourced locally to the Waterloo Region or within Ontario. The food is consistantly great with some variation in menu items based on local avilability and the chef. The drink menu has a pretty decent selection of Ontario beers and wines that wil keep your thrist quenched. Service has never been a problem but it has never been stellar either. The interior is a converted period building of some type, I believe it was a school house at one point and evokes a great atmosphere which also features a large concreate patio out front of the restaurant. Make sure you check out the specials as there are often great drink deals on.\n\nI'd like to give this place 5 stars due to its excellent combination of food, drink and atmosphere with local touch but the price point is a little too high to keep coming back regularly so 4 stars from me, check it out!

This is really a great shop. What you find is hit or miss- as is true with most consignment stores.  BUT I have been able to find a few things every time I enter.  babyGap jeans and plenty of other good labels (Janie and Jack, The Children's Place).   I love this store and now that I am prego again need to check out their maternity section also.
Don't be put off by the name if you are not a wine fan -- there is plenty to drink.  Went there for lunch and was very impressed by the efficient and friendly staff as well as good food.

Where the condiment serves as the dominant component, and the bread assumes an elevated status, Canes poultry dish does not possess any extraordinary attributes, and the potatoes prepared in a fried manner fail to elicit excitement; however, the aforementioned condiment exhibits remarkable quality, prompting me to procure an additional four servings each time, for the purpose of immersing both my avian entity and my potatoes within its delectable confines. Although I harbor an inclination toward coleslaw, the variety offered by Canes underwhelms my expectations, compelling me to opt for an increased quantity of toast instead.

"I have an immense fondness for this establishment, evidenced by my unbridled enthusiasm towards both its locations; however, I must confess that my predilection inclines me towards the western venue. Their extensive menu boasts an impressive array of more than 20 vegetarian options, which cater to my culinary inclinations as a self-proclaimed habituÃ©. The delectable offerings include an assortment of remarkable salads, such as the Bruschette Salad, which I highly recommend, and the Athens Fries, whose excellence transcends mere description. My ardent affection for this eatery is such that, were it feasible, I would partake in their gastronomic delights on a daily basis."

Oh, la la! I was aimlessly driving around Henderson, looking for a place to get some good lunch eats - each strip mall I passed featured some sort of random chain restaurant. I was about to settle on Taco Bell when I saw an oasis in the desert - Trader Joe's!

This just opened recently, so it had the "new car smell." It was clean, had wide aisles and all the fabulous products! And best of all, it wasn't crowded like the SF locations!

I went to their ready made sandwich section, there were a few veggie options - I settled on the PB&J sandwich lunch bag for $3.49. This is the first time I've ever seen this kind of offering, and it was good. You get a 1/2 PB&J sandwich, a little bag of cut green apples, a little bag of 100 calorie cookies, string cheese and small bottle of water. The sandwich was by no means the best - the bread was a little dry and the PB&J fillings were strangely stiff in texture, but the thought of having the other tasty treats in the bag kept me going.

For $3.49, I think this was a great deal. I'm hoping I can find it when I go back home to SF...

"In this geographic locale, there exists a limited array of culinary establishments offering Japanese cuisine, thereby rendering Squid Ink an acceptable venue for satisfying one's sushi yearning. Although I tend to opt for takeout over in-house dining, the efficiency of the service staff and the edibility of the fare have been, on most occasions, satisfactory. Their happy hour offerings, while perhaps lacking in imaginative rolls, do provide a reasonable value; however, the prices charged for the menu items, when juxtaposed against the quality of the food, may be deemed somewhat excessive by certain patrons."
People honestly review airports? As if you have options? As if you honestly decide whether or not to visit a city because of it's airport? The fact this this has 800+ reviews blew my mind!

"Although Tryst may no longer be considered the premier IT destination in Las Vegas, having been surpassed by the likes of Marquee and XS, it still boasts an undeniable charm and appeal. As the sister venue of XS, it shares a similar ambiance, complete with an outdoor waterfall and atmospheric lighting that envelops the surrounding area. The club's interior is equipped with poles that invite female patrons to showcase their dancing prowess, while the male counterparts enthusiastically capture their performances on their mobile devices. The musical offerings at Tryst were quite satisfactory, and despite the crowded state of the bars, our group of four, comprising two females and two males, opted to venture to Tryst at approximately 1 am, following a lackluster showing of the production, KA, and indulging in complimentary drinks at the casino tables. Prior to our arrival, I had taken the initiative to place my name on a host's guest list; however, upon arriving at the entrance at 1 am, which lies beyond the designated guest list time frame, the courteous door staff allowed us admittance without any issues or additional charges, thereby enhancing our overall clubbing experience and allowing us to maintain our elevated mood."

"Although the eatery's ambiance may not be particularly elaborate or sophisticated, the culinary offerings more than compensate for any perceived deficiencies in terms of aesthetic appeal. Indeed, the flavors and aromas emanating from the kitchen are reminiscent of those found in establishments featured on the popular food network show, Diners, Drive-Ins and Dives. In fact, the quality and presentation of the dishes served at Flavors of Louisiana are such that one might surmise that the proprietors have successfully implemented a formula for creating an unparalleled gastronomical experience. The essence of this formula seems to lie in the harmonious marriage of various ingredients, skillfully combined to produce a symphony of flavors that tantalize the palate and satisfy even the most discerning of diners. Furthermore, the absence of an excessive amount of grease in the dishes allows the natural flavors of the components to shine through, thereby enhancing the overall enjoyment of the meal. Additionally, the generous portions served at Flavors of Louisiana make it an excellent value for the price, especially considering the high quality of the cuisine. While a liquor license would undoubtedly enhance the dining experience by allowing patrons to enjoy a cold beverage alongside their meal, it is not necessary to appreciate the exceptional quality of the food. In conclusion, Flavors of Louisiana is an exemplary establishment that sets itself apart from other restaurants in the area due to its commitment to serving delectable and satisfying dishes that showcase the rich culinary heritage of Louisiana."

"Gourmet sandwiches, albeit delectable, tend to necessitate consumption in multiples of 1.5 to 2 units per individual, thereby rendering the overall experience somewhat costly. Nonetheless, for those seeking purely sensory gratification or possessing limited appetites, this venue remains an excellent choice for social gatherings. The sole drawback consists of the prolonged queues that often ensue."

"Upon finally indulging in the culinary offerings of Caffe Boa, I must admit that my expectations were surpassed by the gastronomical delights presented before me. Following the unfortunate spectacle of Payton's porcine butchery at Devoured, I felt compelled to sample the fare of this establishment, and I am pleased to report that my experience was largely satisfactory. \n\nThe colossal paper cone of french fries that I requested as an appetizer was indeed impressive, and the accompanying sauces elevated the dish to a level of unparalleled flavor. However, my selection of a calzone as the main course proved to be a questionable decision, as it failed to meet my expectations of a traditional calzone. Although the flatbread housing the ingredients was unique and enjoyable, the overall composition of the dish struck me as somewhat unconventional. While the quality of the ingredients within the calzone was undeniable, I cannot claim that it fully satisfied my cravings. Nonetheless, the service provided by the staff was commendable, and I appreciated the ambiance of the patio area. Unfortunately, the uninspired atmosphere of the strip mall in which Caffe Boa resides detracted from my overall satisfaction."

If you've read a few of my reviews you would know that I don't frequent or recommend many franchise restaurants. But Texas Roadhouse is one of the few. I've probably been to 8 different locations in 5 different states and the service has always been good, the steak cooked the way I ordered and the value excellent. And this location is no exception. Our server was great, food was tasty and well prepared and the call ahead seating made our wait, oh, about a minute!

"A remarkably satisfactory breakfast venue, located approximately 10-15 minutes away from the strip, rendering it a worthwhile excursion. We had the pleasure of partaking in their delectable offerings at an early hour, around 9 am on a Wednesday, and were impressed by the bustling atmosphere, which suggested that tardiness in arriving might result in a delay in being seated. Upon our prompt seating, we opted for Mama's French toast, accompanied by eggs and a choice of either bacon, sausage, or ham, with the latter being our preference. Additionally, Anthony selected the ham steak plate, which included toast (specifically Texas toast), potatoes, and eggs, all of which were expertly prepared and presented. The culinary experience was thoroughly enjoyable, satisfying our breakfast cravings, and we were also afforded the opportunity to encounter Mr. Mama, a gracious and dedicated proprietor who took great pride in ensuring the satisfaction of his patrons, even extending the offer of coffee refills personally."

Literally hadn't been here in years. Went today to see 'Takin over the Asylum' and it was a great production! The theatre itself is beautiful, very classical with a massive chandelier and everything! Students get \u00a35 tickets on Wednesday matinees too!

"It is utterly impossible to refrain from bursting into laughter, as I am compelled to quote Nicole W. for the second time, for she succinctly encapsulated the essence of Alexander Michael's by stating, 'Alexander Michael's is the quintessential go-to spot for solid food, good drinks, and superb company, all packaged into a quaint little spot in the 4th ward.' Particularly for those residing within walking distance, this establishment represents a veritable haven where one can repeatedly indulge in unpretentious culinary delights, complemented by an impressive array of artisanal beverages. My personal experience involved consuming their delectable chicken pita, which surpassed my expectations with its impeccably cooked, seasoned chicken nestled within a warm, sturdy pita bread. Furthermore, a side of beans satiated my additional craving for protein, obviating the need for the ubiquitous French fries. 

The ambiance of the restaurant is undeniably captivating, boasting a unique charm that is accentuated by the presence of a beam in the ladies' room, which has become the unsuspecting victim of numerous visitors who have inadvertently collided with the structural element. Moreover, the menu features a historical account of the house, providing patrons with engaging reading material while they await the arrival of their initial round of orders. 

My sole criticism pertains to the presence of a television in the dining area, which seems somewhat incongruous with the otherwise cozy atmosphere created by the low ceilings. However, this minor drawback does not detract significantly from the overall appeal of Alexander Michael's, which remains an ideal setting for savoring a satisfying meal amidst convivial surroundings."

"Upon entering this establishment, one cannot help but notice the unique feature that graces the entrance; a large fish tank that serves as the floor, providing an unconventional yet captivating welcome to the premises. The interior design boasts a contemporary flair, with sleek lines and a palette of muted hues that exude a relaxed ambiance. On a Wednesday evening, we opted to partake in a pre-dinner libation at the bar, where the atmosphere was tranquil and the clientele sparse, allowing us to savor the experience without the encumbrance of overwhelming crowds. The sushi that followed was a culinary delight, with each piece expertly prepared and presented, showcasing the freshness and quality of the ingredients. However, a minor drawback was encountered in the form of the bathroom's sink, whose unconventional faucet design, while aesthetically pleasing, proved problematic in terms of functionality, as the water flow was erratic and required a forceful slamming of the handle to activate, resulting in an inconsistent and somewhat messy experience. Nonetheless, the overall enjoyment of our visit remained undiminished."

What a great "Americana" restaurant! This place brings back so many memories of what used to be very popular restaurant's back in the day ~  the buffet/cafeteria's.  This Furr's is conveniently located just west of the 101 Hwy on Grand and Sun City.  You can tell this Furr's has been around since the fifties based on their sign and building but they have done a very nice job maintaining everything inside and out.  

I had a very enjoyable lunch last with some fellow Yelper's; Rand H., Mike C. and Scott W..  This Furr's is a cafeteria however once you go through the line once, you can go back as many times as you like to, all for the same price of $7.39.  I really liked this concept because your not picking through what other the prior people have handled ~ you know what I mean!  You choose what you want and they serve it to you.  

They have most of the traditional "Americana" food options to choose from.  I recommend when you first go through the line asking for smaller portions and trying more varieties of things.  This way you can refill on what you really like without over stuffing yourself.  Everything was very tasty and fresh.  I'm looking forward to going back to this Furr's so hopefully I will see you there.

I have had the pleasure of frequenting Culver's on multiple occasions, and my son has developed an unwavering fondness for their delectable cheese curds, which are truly exceptional and worthy of high praise. Prior to visiting Five Guys, I harbored reservations regarding the pricing of Culver's, categorizing it as somewhat expensive in relation to other fast food establishments.
